DOC.HEAD: House Committee Approves Tough Anti-Abortion Bill
DOC.TEXT: A Louisiana House committee Thursday voted to ban abortions except in cases where pregnancy endangers a mother's life, a bill supporters hope will provide a landmark court test. Sponsors hope the measure, if approved by the full Legislature, to be the vehicle for a challenge to the U.S. Supreme Court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision, which legalized abortion. House Criminal Justice Committee members approved the bill without comment or objection. The vote ended two days of hearings in which anti-abortion and abortion rights advocates were each given four hours to state their cases. Anti-abortion sentiment is strong in both the full House and the Senate. Abortionists would face up to 10 years in prison at hard labor for violating the law if it were approved. In hearings, the committee tried to build a record of testimony and evidence that will lead to a reversal of Roe vs. Wade. The committee heeded the plea of Rep. Woody Jenkins, D-Baton Rouge, to avoid amending the bill to make exceptions in cases of rape or incest. Gov. Buddy Roemer, calling himself ``a pro-lifer,'' said he would veto any bill that doesn't contain those exceptions. Similar bills now are on both the House and Senate floors. Abortion-rights forces predicted the hoped-for challenge to Roe vs. Wade would fail if the law were passed. ``The state will wind up spending $3 million and we will look ridiculous,'' said Robin Rothrock, president of the League of Women Voters. Jenkins, floor leader for the anti-abortion forces, noted that legal experts had testified that a law without exceptions and with criminal penalties would likely bring a legal challenge that could reach the Supreme Court and test Roe vs. Wade.

DOC.HEAD: Knoxville Newspapers to Dissolve Joint Operating Agreement
DOC.TEXT:
The city's morning and afternoon newspapers agreed Friday to dissolve their joint operating agreement, ending The Knoxville News-Sentinel's lawsuit against The Knoxville Journal. Owners of The News-Sentinel and Journal announced they had reached an agreement in principle to end their 4-year-old pact by the end of December 1991. After the agreement ends, ``The Journal intends to publish separately and in competition with The News-Sentinel,'' the statement said. Under the joint operating agreement, The News-Sentinel provides sales, production and distribution for The Journal. Editorial departments of the two newspapers are separate. Under the Newspaper Preservation Act of 1970, the attorney general can approve a limited antitrust exemption if he finds one paper is in danger of failing and a joint operating agreement would ensure survival of independent editorial voices.
The lawsuit alleged The Journal's owner, Persis Corp., violated terms of the agreement when the Hawaii company purchased The (Maryville) Daily Times in neighboring Blount County in December. Journal editor and publisher Gerald Garcia also was made president and publisher of The Daily Times. The News-Sentinel, which recently began a zoned edition in Maryville, considered The Daily Times a direct competitor. The lawsuit contended that with Garcia in the dual roles, The Daily Times would have access to The News-Sentinel's confidential business information and trade secrets. As part of the termination arrangement, The News-Sentinel will pay Persis $40 million in two $20 million installments. The money will be in lieu of payments The Journal would have received from Dec. 31, 1991, through the scheduled end of the agreement on Dec. 31, 2005. The News-Sentinel is owned by the E.W. Scripps Co. of Cincinnati. The morning paper has a daily circulation of 101,000 and a Sunday circulation of 169,000. The Journal is an afternoon paper that publishes Monday through Saturday with a circulation of 40,000. ``We are pleased with the agreement,'' said Thurston Twigg-Smith, president and chief executive of Persis, which publishes six daily newspapers, including The Honolulu Advertiser, and three weeklies. ``Once we concluded that it was unlikely that the JOA would be extended beyond 2005, we wanted to begin separate publication at a time when The Journal was a strong and vital part of the Knoxville community,'' he said. Scripps president and chief executive Lawrence A. Leser said he was also satisfied with the settlement. ``This one-time payment is less than the expected amount The News-Sentinel would have paid in distributions to The Journal had joint operations continued through 2005,'' said Leser, whose company owns 19 daily newspapers. ``We look forward to hardy economic competition in addition to the fierce editorial competition that has existed between the two newspapers for many years.'' Until the termination in 1991, The News-Sentinel will continue to act as agent on certain business matters for The Journal under a special interim agreement that provides for The Journal's ``reasonable prospects for ongoing economic viability.''

DOC.HEAD: University Seeks Gender-Free Name for Students
DOC.TEXT: The University of Michigan is searching for a term to replace ``freshman'' in describing the first year of a woman's college experience. Mary Jo Frank, editor of the faculty and staff newspaper University Record, asked readers for their ideas. Of the 30 suggestions submitted, ``freshmore'' was the most common, but ``neophyte'' was the most emphatic. ``Neo would be neat-o,'' since ``neophytos'' is Greek for newly planted, said David C. King, a political science doctoral candidate. King said neophyte would be an easy term for students to pick up, since it would be fun ``bastardizing Greek.'' If neophyte seems too esoteric, other suggestions included firsty, alphamore, freshper, rookie, probationer, collegian and tenderfoot. One respondent suggested changing ``freshman'' would lead to substitutions for other masculine terms such as bachelor's and master's. Walter Harrison, a spokesman for the Ann Arbor school, said the university would consider dropping the term ``freshman''' if an acceptable replacement were found. Some colleges and high schools have started using ``fresher'' and ``frosh,'' according to ``The Nonsexist Word Finder,'' a 1988 reference book.

DOC.HEAD: No Charges Filed Against Driver in Death of 3 Children
DOC.TEXT: The county prosecutor said Friday night that no charges would be filed against a man whose car plowed through a baseball diamond, killing three children during a Little League game. Cook County State's Attorney Cecil Partee said that filing criminal charges against James J. Harasek, 59, of Westchester was ``not appropriate.'' Partee said in a news release that neither drugs nor alcohol was involved in the May 5 tragedy. He also said there wasn't enough evidence to prove that Harasek illegally disregarded the safety of others, a finding necessary to press criminal charges. Harasek lost control of his Cadillac as the Little League T-ball game began at a baseball diamond in the Chicago suburb of Riverside. The car smashed through a bench full of players and and continued across the field. Three children were killed and nine people injured, six of them children. A $5 million lawsuit filed on behalf of one of the injured children alleges Harasek continued to drive although he knew he was prone to losing consciousness. Harasek's driver's license was revoked because of the accident.

DOC.HEAD: Neo-Royalists Jailed For Attacking Singer
DOC.TEXT: A court has given six-month jail terms to each of three neo-royalists who attacked an opera singer performing rebel songs during last year's bicentennial celebration of the French Revolution. Christophe de Peyrelongue, 24, and 29-year-old twins Philippe and Giovanni Castelluccio were among 20 people who stormed the Bouffes du Nord theater last January during the performance by mezzo-soprano Helene Delavault. The group hurled tear gas into the crowd and threw blue paint on Ms. Delavault's clothing and glue on her hair. They then fled, shouting: ``Long live the king!'' Ms. Delavault gave her remaining performances under police guard. President Francois Mitterrand expressed outrage over the incident. On Thursday, the Correctional Tribunal gave the three defendants a one-year sentence but suspended six months. The court also ordered each to pay one franc (about 17 cents) in symbolic damages.

DOC.HEAD: KAL's Middle East Flight Allowed To Fly Through Chinese Airspace
DOC.TEXT: Korean Air, the country's flagship carrier, has obtained Beijing's approval to fly its only weekly Middle East flight through Chinese airspace beginning today, company officials said. It was the first time that China, which has no diplomatic relations with South Korea, has authorized a regular flight of the airline, known as KAL, to use its airspace. The decision was seen by observers as a further indication of improving relations between Seoul and Beijing. Although China is a longtime ally of Communist North Korea, it has been expanding trade and other unofficial contacts with South Korea. The Chinese decision will enable KAL Flight 801 to fly through Chinese air space en route to Tripoli, Libya. KAL officials said they were negotiating to fly all of their 10 European weekly flights through Chinese air space.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: How Superpowers Resolved the Nicaragua Conflict
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Dec. 7 is a date normally identified with the death and destruction at Pearl Harbor, but for American and Soviet diplomats it has also come to signify a momentous but little-known development in East-West relations. It was on that day last year that the Soviet Union, under heavy U.S. pressure, ordered the freighter Vladimir Ilyich back to its home port rather than deliver its cargo of four MI-17 Hip military helicopters to Nicaragua. That move is perhaps the clearest single piece of evidence to date of the Soviets' willingness to sacrifice the interests of an ally in order to advance the cause of superpower cooperation. As Washington saw it, President Mikhail Gorbachev was long on words but short on deeds on many of his policies. The recall of the freighter was, by those standards, an extraordinary deed. It was one of the high points of what, until now, has been the largely untold story of the private exchanges that took place between Washington and Moscow on Central America during President Bush's first year in office. A lengthy account of what transpired appears in the June 4 issue of Time magazine. In ordering the Vladimir Ilyich home, the Soviets put back on track a process in which the superpowers cooperated in promoting a free and fair election process in Nicaragua, culminating in the Feb. 25 triumph of U.S.-backed President Violeta Chamorro. The result is that of all the regional conflicts in which the Soviets and the Americans became involved on opposite sides during the 1980s _ Nicaragua, Angola, Afghanistan and Cambodia _ only Nicaragua has been resolved peacefully. After a decade of bitter debate at home and with Moscow as well, Nicaragua now has become, in large measure, an issue of secondary priority for Washington. The impossible actually happened: following an honest election, the leftist Sandinista government of Daniel Ortega turned power over to the pro-U.S. opposition. On no issue had U.S. policy changed more in the transition from Presidents Reagan to Bush than Central America. To the distress of some old State Department hands, Secretary of State James A. Baker III seemed almost contemptuous of the Nicaraguan Contra rebels and less than enthralled by the overall issue of Central America. He appeared to spend all of his time dealing with Europeans. But as the Time account suggests, both Bush and Baker, along with Assistant Secretary of State Bernard Aronson, engaged in titanic _ albeit private _ struggles with the Soviets on Central America. Their strategy was to try to influence Soviet actions in Central America by threatening to deny them American goodwill in other areas. In diplomatic parlance, that connection is known as ``linkage.'' Not surprisingly, the path to Soviet-American cooperation was bumpy. The crucial period occurred in late November when, addition to U.S. concerns about Hip helicopter shipments to Nicaragua, the Sandinistas got caught trying to send 24 surface-to-air missiles to the leftist rebels in El Salvador. Washington's reaction was such that the Soviets were afraid Bush would call off the Dec. 2 summit with Gorbachev in Malta. Hoping to avoid a crisis in the summit's aftermath, the Soviets recalled the Vladimir Ilyich. Things went more smoothly thereafter. The Soviets promised to urge Cuba to limit weapons deliveries to Central America and also assured Washington that they would refrain from sending weapons to the Sandinistas if Mrs. Chamorro won. In February, Baker and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze pledged to respect the outcome of free and fair elections in Nicaragua. All along, Washington did its part by refusing to rearm the Contras and by encouraging them not only to refrain from undertaking military offensives but also to join the election process. A footnote: The Soviets eventually sent the Hip helicopters to Nicaragua at the end of January. As a Soviet analyst told Time, the Kremlin felt a goodwill gesture was needed to ensure Moscow's continued ability to convince the Sandinistas to stick by their pledge to hold honest elections. The Soviets did something else to placate Washington: they sent the helicopters equipped for civilian use only.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: George Gedda has covered foreign affairs for the Associated Press since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: British Soccer Fans Convicted of Property Damage
DOC.TEXT: Fourteen fans of the British soccer team received one-year suspended jail terms for property damage after they smashed car windows following a soccer match. The court in Grombalia, 25 miles south of Tunis, on Thursday also fined the Britons a symbolic 10 dinars ($12.50) for drunkenness. Police arrested the British fans after they smashed windows of parked cars Sunday night in the suburb of Hamamet and disturbed residents with shouting and other rowdy behavior. The fans stayed on in the North African country after Saturday's World Cup warmup match that ended in a 1-1 tie. A spokesman for the British Embassy said the fans would leave the country immediately. The fans pleaded not guilty to all charges against them.

DOC.HEAD: Clinton Not Bothered By Showing in Primary
DOC.TEXT: Arkansas Gov. Bill Clinton secured a solid majority to win his sixth straight Democratic nomination. But, like a boxing champion who slipped by on points, he is being asked to explain the lack of a knockout punch. Clinton, 43, was the nation's youngest governor when first elected in 1978 and he has had a stranglehold on the state's Democratic Party ever since. But in last week's primary, he garnered just 55 percent of the vote while Tom McRae, an unpolished campaigner who heads a public policy think tank, earned 39 percent. Four also-rans divided the rest. Clinton, who toyed with the idea of running for the presidency in 1988 and already is talking about 1996, said he saw no cause for concern in the margin of his primary victory. ``I didn't see how I could get 60 percent, knowing the number of people who were saying in the surveys that they thought I was a good governor but were concerned about the tenure issue,'' Clinton said recently. Tenure was summed up repeatedly by McRae as ``10 years is long enough.'' Arkansans grow bored with their politicians sooner than voters elsewhere, Clinton said, in part because politics in the state is so personal. Pumping hands at shopping malls and crawfish festivals is considered as important as running the right television ad. ``I'm just trying to tell people that in business they wouldn't fire a 43-year-old with 10 years of experience who's doing a good job,'' Clinton said days before the primary. Sheffield Nelson, who upset Rep. Tommy Robinson for the Republican gubernatorial nomination, already is jumping on the theme, saying ``Arkansas is ready for a change.'' Clinton, who has focused on improving the state's education system, counters by calling himself the candidate of change. ``Frankly, if you look at what I proposed, compared with the others, it represents more change,'' he said. ``Ten years is an asset, not a liability.'' Clinton lost his first re-election bid in 1980 to Republican Frank White, but won again in 1982, 1984 and 1986, when the gubernatorial term was changed to four years. He has all but promised not to run for the White House in 1992 if re-elected this year. His showing in this year's primary, largely in line with pre-election polls, was the first time since his political comeback in 1982 that Clinton got less than 60 percent of the primary vote. ``I'm sure the governor would like to have made a better showing, but when you're in office 10 years you have a lot of friends and a lot of enemies,'' said Bill Paschall, a Little Rock political consultant. ``I don't think it's a death blow that he made 55 (percent), but it shows him he has to work harder.'' While the biggest complaint against Clinton appears to be that he has been in office too long, the governor also has been accused of being more interested in his national ambitions than state concerns. Clinton's recent troubles with the legislature also have been a sticking point. Twice in 1989 he failed to win legislative approval for proposals to increase taxes. Nelson, who hopes to paint Clinton as a tax-and-spend Democrat, said the primary election results show the governor is on the ropes. ``I'd say against an unknown who never held an office, I think that was low. It probably did make some bells go off in his head,'' Nelson said. Clinton said he would have done better if a large number of traditional Democrats hadn't crossed over to the GOP primary to vote against Robinson. ``We did poorly in areas where I did not campaign; where my supporters, in spite of my best interest, believed the polls and didn't work; and where we did a poor job of telling the people what I had done that affected their lives; and where people knew there was an alternative but didn't know much about what the alternative was,'' Clinton said. Betsey Wright, Clinton's former chief of staff, said the governor's supporters were complacent. ``Bill Clinton is always perceived as being so strong that people find it difficult to believe in calls for such cohesion and tight energies,'' she said of the primary.

DOC.HEAD: NIOSH Links Computer Use to RSI Problems at Newsday
DOC.TEXT: A government study conducted for Newsday and its union shows there is ``significant association'' between computer keyboard work and repetitive strain injury, one of the researchers said Thursday. The study, the first comprehensive survey of repetitive strain injury in the newspaper industry in this country, also concluded that computer terminal use among workers at Newsday and New York Newsday presented ``a hazard to workers' health.'' It did not quantify or elaborate on the risks. The study by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health and the University of Michigan found no single cause for the injuries, Cincinnati-based NIOSH researcher Susan Burt said in a telephone interview. She said several factors contribute to the risk of getting repetitive strain injury, or RSI, including: _Repetitive motions like those made while typing on a computer keyboard. _Work positions, like extending the wrists up in an awkward position in order to type. _Static position, caused by holding arms up in order to type. The study also found that how long a person worked at a keyboard without a break and how fast they typed contributed to problems associated with RSI. ``We do not recommend working at a keyboard for extended periods without taking a break,'' she said. No specific time limit was given. The study group included 834 workers at Newsday and New York Newsday. They included reporters, editors, clerical and secretarial employees who worked in the editorial, financial, advertising and circulation departments. Burt said the employees were asked if they had experienced any pain, aching numbness, tingling or burning in their hands-wrists, elbow, shoulder and neck area within a 12-month period. By definition, she said the pain had to last at least a week or occur at least once a month. They also had to have no previous history of acute injury to the area and the pain had to have started on their current job. Survey results showed that 331 of the 834 employees, or 40 percent, reported one or more symptoms in at least one of the four regions some time within the past year. Burt cautioned that the results were based on self-reporting and said NIOSH estimated they were ``twice as high than if we had done physical examinations as well as questionnaires.'' Of all the employees questioned, she said ``reporters appeared to be at higher risk'' than the other workers. Some believed that the type of keyboard used may contribute to RSI, but Burt said ``we found no significant difference.'' Researchers did say, however, that work stations crowded with computers, desks, chairs and other equipment could contribute to the problem. Repetitive strain injury is listed as the leading cause of occupational illness by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. The bureau said 115,400 cases of RSI were reported nationwide in 1988, representing 48 percent of all workplace illnesses. The malady has been reported in a wide range of workers including office employees, assembly-line jobs and within the meatpacking industry. The study was requested by Newsday and the Graphics Communication International Union Local 406, which represents nearly half of the newspaper's 3,100 full-time employees. Burt said they began their research last August. The report is to be released in a few days. It was given to Newsday and its union leaders on Tuesday and the results were published Wednesday. Researchers recommended that Newsday establish a labor-management committee to handle RSI problems and train employees on how to use adjustable equipment and change their work habits. Assistant Managing Editor Robert Keane said the newspaper has already initiated those recommendations. John McDonald, vice president of the union's editorial unit, said further studies may be done to show how individual work habits and equipment contributes to RSI. Burt said the agency is beginning work on two more studies on RSI at the Los Angeles Times and U.S. West, a large telecommunications company.

DOC.HEAD: Accord Reached to Save Jobs With Weapons Money
DOC.TEXT: Congress and the Pentagon are ending months of haggling with an informal agreement to save tens of thousands of military jobs by shifting money from major weapons programs, including land-based missiles. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and House Speaker Thomas S. Foley late Thursday decided to give the Pentagon the authority to transfer about $1.5 billion from weapons programs to payroll accounts. The money will allow the Defense Department to avoid dismissing thousands of men and women by October. The funds also will make up for a financial shortfall in the health insurance plan for military dependents, the Civilian Health and Medical Program of the Uniformed Services. Among the reductions are $8 million from the MX rail-garrison missile program, $10 million from the Midgetman missile, $20 million from the Trident missile submarine and $20 million from the Seawolf attack submarine. The tentative accord puts an end to bitter squabbling between the Pentagon and Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee. However, Rep. William Dickinson of Alabama, ranking Republican on the Armed Services panel, accused Aspin of holding the process hostage to a package of weapons cuts that is significantly less than what the chairman sought. ``What the speaker and the secretary finally agreed on bears little resemblance to the chairman's demands. Consequently, one cannot help but wonder what was accomplished by all this in the end,'' Dickinson said in a statement. Aspin's press secretary, Lynn Reddy, said the chairman had no immediate comment. Such shifts of money _ known as ``reprogramming'' _ are customarily submitted to the House and Senate Armed Services committees and the two chambers' defense appropriations subcommittees. In this case, Cheney had authority to proceed on his own, and he had threatened to do so if no agreement were reached. The Pentagon said it needed the transfer authority to avoid massive layoffs that would have been required under the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law. It estimated that it would have to discharge up to 68,000 of its 2.1 million uniformed personnel and deny enlistment to as many as 115,900 potential recruits, among other steps, unless given relief. Earlier this year, Aspin, with the backing of Foley, declined to bring the Pentagon request before his committee. He argued that President Bush could have exempted military personnel from the Gramm-Rudman law but decided against it last year. Aspin charged that Bush favored weapons over people. As a solution, Aspin proposed some of Cheney's favored weapons programs, including the B-2 stealth bomber, the Strategic Defense Initiative, the MX missile and the Seawolf submarine, as a source of funds for the personnel accounts. All total, Aspin called for $230 million from the strategic programs. Cheney and Foley reached a tentative agreement on $58 million from those weapons systems as well as about $1.4 billion from other programs. Late last month, Cheney said he had the agreement of the chairmen and ranking members of the respective committees, with the exception of Aspin. Dickinson said he was pleased that ``men of common sense like Dick Cheney and Tom Foley were able to find a solution. Unfortunately, it's one that shouldn't have taken six months to arrive at.''

DOC.HEAD: Exhibit Recalls Horrors, Absurdities of Stalinist Period
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A new exhibit in Budapest recalls the shadow of Stalinism that covered half of Europe for more than 40 years. It is called ``Sta-lin! Ra-ko-si!'' and is the first in Eastern Europe to depict the day-to-day life of the 1950s. Hungary's Stalin was Matyas Rakosi, who was installed by the Soviet dictator and ruled unchallenged. Stalin died in 1953, byt Rakosi's reign lasted until the 1956 uprising against Stalinism, which was crushed by Soviet tanks. The exhibit, constructed like a labyrinth, is in a castle on a hill above the Danube River. It includes newspaper headlines, photographs, uniforms of feared men, soiled clothing of the beaten and belongings of the executed. Emil Horn, who conceived it, said he wanted to juxtapose the truth and the Rakosi regime's representation of itself. ``Those days were very sad,'' He said in an interview. ``Now, there is a great irony.'' A giant reprint of a cartoon from the period depicts mice marching behind a placard of a grinning cat. Next to it are equally large photos of Hungarians marching behind portraits of Rakosi and Stalin. The exhibit focuses on the Rakosi era, but repeatedly draws comparisons with the Soviet Union, showing nearly identical uniforms, medals and even constitutions. A cast-bronze head of Rakosi adorns a three-tier podium, recalling the cakes each village, factory and school sent him on his 60th birthday. The podium is piled high with presents: hand-stitched banners, painted vases and flasks depicting the glories of communism. There is sheet music of hymns to the leader. Up a few steps, in a mausoleum-like chamber, are even more elaborate gifts to Stalin. The exhibit also notes differences between Stalinism in the Soviet Union and Hungary. ``Here, it lasted only seven to eight years,'' Horn said. ``Due to the liberal trends in Hungary, Czechoslovakia and the whole region, it would have taken much longer to completely suppress the people than in Russia.'' Horn is a former Communist who believed firmly in Marxism when the Soviets liberated Hungary. About what came later, he said: ``We are ashamed of ourselves.'' His exhibit ``contains my personal self-criticism as well,'' Horn said. ``For me, it is a kind of absolution. I didn't hurt anyone, but still, it is absurd that I and so many people were so stupid. ... Why was I so ignorant?'' Millions of people in Eastern Europe are asking themselves that question. In his New Year's address, President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia said all Czechoslovaks shared responsibility for Communist rule and cautioned against simply blaming leaders for the excesses. An exhibit about Czechoslovakia's history since 1918 opened in Prague last month. It is part of a general effort in what once was the Soviet bloc to express the truth of history and strip away Stalinist falsehoods. Budapest's Rakosi exhibit shows how the Communists rigged the 1947 elections, then chronicles the dissolution of other parties, collectivization of land and experiments in economic self-sufficiency that even included a short-lived attempt to grow cotton. The second part of the exhibit has the atmosphere of an interrogation chamber, courtroom and prison camp. Documents listing charges against prominent victims of the Rakosi regime are displayed along with photographs and personal belongings. They include Cardinal Jozsef Mindszenty and former Interior Minister Laszlo Rajk, who was hanged as a ``Titoist.'' In a depiction of the notorious labor camp at Recsk, where many people died, are huge prints of photos taken secretly by an inmate who now lives in the West. A small cabinet displays such banned materials as Carlo Collodi's ``Pinocchio,'' Disney cartoons and ``The Jungle Book,'' by Rudyard Kipling Looming over the exit is a border guard tower bearing two figures: 18,000, the number of people allowed to travel outside the country in 1951, and 10 million, the number in 1989. Across from the tower are statues of Rakosi and Stalin, toppled, as they were after protesters pulled them down at beginning of the uprising Oct. 23, 1956. Stalin's fist is in the dirt. One visitor wrote in the guest book: ``Thank God we haven't seen this in our lives.'' Another wrote below: ``Unfortunately we have.'' Still another echoed Horn: ``I'm ashamed that the Hungarian people were willing to accept all this for decades.''

DOC.HEAD: Tucson Woman Dies After Sleeping in Sun for Six or More Hours
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd graf pvs, `The woman...,' to ADD that temperature in Tucson reached 107 Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: A Tucson woman died Thursday after lying out in the sun for at least six hours, hospital officials said. The 37-year-old woman was unconscious when she was admitted to Tucson Medical Center Wednesday afternoon. Her identity was withheld. The woman had a body temperature of 107 degrees and badly burned flesh, officials said. The temperature in Tucson reached 107 Wednesday. ``She was packed in ice immediately, but she was already into severe sunstroke and had lapsed into a coma,'' said TMC spokesman Tom Reavis. ``She never regained consciousness.'' Doctors speculated she fell asleep in while sunbathing.

DOC.HEAD: Guam Holds Contest To Get Rid Of Snakes
DOC.TEXT: St. Patrick may have chased the snakes from Ireland, but unlike the winner of an upcoming contest here, he didn't get a pickup truck for the accomplishment. That's what this Pacific island is offering to the person who can collect the most brown tree snakes in a one-month period starting June 23. The first annual ``Sweep Snakes'' contest is part of an effort to rid the U.S. territory of the more than 2 million brown tree snakes that have infested the 212-square-mile island. The snakes were accidentally imported to Guam during World War II, possibly in military cargo shipments from the Solomon Islands. Since then, they have decimated the native bird population and are known to bite humans occasionally. Although the venom is not lethal to adults, it can put small infants into shock and, if untreated, can cause death. Other prizes in the contest include awards for the longest tree snake captured and the most innovative trap.

DOC.HEAD: Journalist Detained Nearly Three Years Without Charge Tells His Story
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: Brian Sokutu, a 28-year-old black journalist, was detained by security police June 16, 1986 under the national state of emergency, which President F.W. de Klerk lifted in most of the country Thursday. Sokutu was imprisoned nearly three years without being charged with a crime. When he was freed March 9, 1989, he was issued with restrictions that effectively barred him from practicing his profession until last February. He wrote this personal account for The Associated Press.

``When are you bringing him back?'' my frightened sister asked a security policeman on June 16, 1986 _ the day the police detained me under national emergency regulations decreed four days earlier. ``Don't worry, we'll bring him back soon,'' he said. ``Soon'' turned out to be nearly three years. When the police came, no one tried to keep them out. The emergency empowered them to kick in the door anyway. After hearing of the detention of other journalists, I thought of going into hiding. But after moving from house to house, looking for asylum, I eventually came home. ``How does a journalist go into hiding?'' I asked myself. The next night, the security police left with me. I had a jacket, a pair of jeans and a woolen hat. Algoa Park police station's offices were as busy that night as a black hospital's casualty ward. We sat on the floor of the cold waiting rooms until we were fingerprinted and photographed. ``Ja Brian, you write a lot in the papers,'' said one of the cops to me, making me feel like a little boy in a cage. One of the horrible experiences you go through in detention is that of being divorced from your family, your colleagues, and the outside environment. Inside the police station, I was kept with about nine other people in a filthy, tiny cell with blankets full of lice. We slept on the floor. Each day, we got cold porridge in the morning, two thin slices of bread and black coffee, served in a big tin for us to share. No one knew where we were, as we were denied newspapers, visits, pens and even clothes to change. I had to use my T-shirt as a washrag on occasion. My jeans and lumber jacket made perfect pajamas. A major breakthrough came sometime in July when we developed various sorts of ailments _ colds, ulcers, backaches. Some of us were admitted to Livingstone Hospital and were able to smuggle letters to our parents and bribe guards with food and money to get visitors. During that period, a detainee would be called for hours of interrogation. One young detainee, about 16 years old, came back sobbing. ``They've beaten me up,'' he said. He also told of being subjected to electric shocks. It seems the police were trying to prove that I was a revolutionary journalist who, during the 1985 consumer boycott, took pictures of people who broke the boycott of white businesses. According to police allegations, I took the pictures to ``the people's militia.'' I went to the Grahamstown Supreme Court to try to prove the police wrong. The case was dismissed, but I still have to pay the costs. What they could not do was to charge me with a crime. Later, I was transferred to St. Albans prison. The difference between the police station and prison was that we were entitled to have money, clothes and visits. Prison breaks one physically and psychologically, and solitary confinement is a method of torture. I spent three days in a tiny underground cell, which was like being buried alive. You see no car, hear no noise. On occasion a policeman walking on a floor above looks at you through a window. When you are escorted inside by police, your shoelaces are taken away. When you try to sleep, you are constantly awakened by police who say they are guarding against you ``killing yourself.'' The strain is tremendous. I suffered from depression and had to be brought back to St. Albans. What kept us going for those years of hardship: collective decision-making, consultation, a political program. Ironically, the structures crushed by the state in the African townships were revived in prison. We had an education panel, a political panel and sport. We had to bribe wardens and hardened criminals with money to get us newspapers. We even smuggled a small radio to listen to the news. Numerous struggles for our release were waged inside and outside prison. In February of 1989, there was an 11-day hunger strike. It proved to be instrumental in bringing about our release.

DOC.HEAD: Hey, Master: Where's My Slippers and Milk Bone?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: New evidence that architecture is going to the dogs: Canine critics at an exhibit of designer doghouses turned up their wet noses at the modernist ``Bauwauhaus'' and licked their chops over a ``Dog Cabin'' made of water-proof dog biscuits. ``Dog biscuits. That's the secret to good doghouse design,'' said Russ Post, who held the leash of a tan Labrador retriever. ``Old Boris here really perked up when he saw them.'' Old Boris didn't seem to like much of anything else on display outside the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, which challenged architects and designers to build a better doghouse for an exhibition that opens Friday. But the dogs who attended a preview of the luxury doghouses Thursday were confronted with the same architectural woes that dog human clients: cost overruns, self-indulgent designs, ignorance of the client's needs. Their masters forced them into the doghouses for the benefit of photographers, but the dogs seemed unimpressed. _Cooper, a tan Lab puppy, had to be forced into the sleek, gleaming white Bauwauhous. After one look around the spare, cold, Corian plastic interior, he scampered out. _Dora, a black Lab pup, sniffed around but refused to enter the igloo-shaped ``Guardian Dog House,'' possibly because of the 250-pound sculpture of a winged dog perched on the roof. _Ernie, an adult Lab, bumped his head as he tried to walk into ``Lassie Come Home,'' a junked television console that was turned into a doghouse by Smart Design Inc. To get an idea of how someone could try to pass off an architectural joke as doghouse, listen to Smart Design's Tom Dair, a talented designer of products such as toasters and sunglasses. ``There was no client, we didn't have to sell it, so we thought we'd have some fun,'' he admitted. ``We basically decided dogs don't care where they sleep _ you see them under a tree, in the dirt _ so it didn't make sense to go into some labor-intensive process.'' Inspired by the sight of a discarded television cabinet on a Harlem street corner, Dair and his colleagues bought a similar one for $40, painted it blue and equipped it with corrugated fiberglass roof. ``What does it sound like when it rains?'' he was asked. ``I don't know,'' he shrugged. At this point Boris walked by. He glanced at the console with its rabbit ears antenna (that's a joke, Boris) and made a sound that sounded like a grunt. Fortunately he could not read the designers' explanation: ``Television has become man's best friend _ dependable, lovable and entertaining.'' The two most popular houses _ the Dog Cabin and ``Dog House in the Mayan Style,'' both built with dog biscuits _ are impractical, because the inhabitants would either eat them or be frustrated by their inability to do so. The cabin's biscuits are covered with eight gallons of polyester resin waterproofing. The temple contains 400 pounds of dog biscuits. Russ Post kept Boris on a tight leash and told him, ``We can't have you salivating every time you walk in front of the Mayan Temple.'' Each architect was given $1,000 with which to build, but almost everyone spent far more. Michael MacLeod said he spent his share just on the dog bones that he stuck in the walls of his Guardian Dog House. Other doghouses seemingly designed more to amuse humans than shelter animals included a pyramid, ``the Cheops Doghouse''; a classical temple for ``Fido''; ``Don't Fence Me In,'' which is entered through a door that looks like a hole in a fence; and the mythologically inspired ``Trojan Dog,'' built in the shape of a dog. At least none of the doghouses looked like a fire hydrant, which may explain why none of the canine critics resorted to their ultimate insult. The show runs through Oct. 14.

DOC.HEAD: Stalin's Henchmen Tested Poisons, Murder Methods, on Condemned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Josef Stalin's henchmen used people already condemned to death to test cloak-and-dagger methods of execution, including poisoned food or poison-tipped walking sticks, a newspaper revealed. This week's Moscow News also detailed the arrest of Stalin's secret police chief Lavrenti Beria in 1953, saying the late Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev strapped on a pistol and helped nab Beria in the Kremlin. The portrait of Brezhnev, who came to power 11 years later, is surprisingly positive given current criticism that he led the country to decay until his death in 1982. Beria was executed in December 1953, nine months after Stalin died, by a handful of Soviet officials who feared he would use his brutal methods to seize power. Moscow News produced excerpts from the indictment against Beria, which alleged he and two underlings were responsible for ``carrying out experiments on live people. ``Seeking methods to use various poisons to carry out secret murders,'' Beria organized a secret laboratory to carry out experiments on Soviets who were sentenced to death, the newspaper said. Scientists at the secret laboratory poisoned their victims ``through food, a prick from a walking stick, or injections,'' the indictment said. At least 150 people died that way, the indictment said. A few dozen more were poisoned in hideouts in Moscow, Ulyanovsk, Saratov, the Carpathian region and the Ukraine, the indictment said. It quoted a statement from the head of the laboratory, identified only as Maironovsky, as saying of those he poisoned: ``I don't know their names, I don't know what they were guilty of.'' Millions of people were condemned to death for alleged anti-Soviet activities during the years of Stalin. Soviets for years could only whisper among friends about the repressive era. But many details of the terror have become public for the first time in the Soviet Union under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policy of glasnost, or openness. As details emerge, many Soviets increasingly are seeing little difference between Stalin and Adolf Hitler, whose Nazi Germany has been characterized here for decades as the epitome of evil. Memoirs of Marshal Kirill Moskalenko, who arrested Beria, were preserved for decades and published by Moscow News. He recalled how he was summoned to the Kremlin in June 1953, by future Soviet leader Nikita S. Khrushchev and asked to lead a band of men who would arrest Beria at a government meeting. They were armed because the secret police chief had his own well-armed guard. Moskalenko said that when asked to choose several trustworthy officials who could take part in the arrest, he chose Brezhnev, whom he recalled as a ``brave general, a political worker, dedicated to the Communist Party and the people.'' Brezhnev was given a pistol by Defense Minister Nikolai A. Bulganin, which he carried when the group burst into the meeting room on a pre-arranged signal to arrest Beria. The secret police chief did not resist and was executed after lengthy questioning. Brezhnev ousted Khrushchev as Soviet leader in 1964 and now is criticized for permitting what Gorbachev calls a ``period of stagnation'' to settle over the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern DC-9 Makes Emergency Landing in Atlanta
DOC.TEXT: An Eastern Airlines DC-9 carrying 97 passengers made an emergency landing Thursday night after the plane blew a tire while taking off from Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport, an official said. No injuries were reported. The passengers and the five crew members were evacuated. Eastern Flight 129 headed from Atlanta to Tallahassee, Fla., blew a tire on the left main landing gear when it took off at about 10 p.m., said John Braden, airport spokesman. Braden said the pilot shut down the left engine as a precaution and landed the aircraft safely at 10:25 p.m. A second tire blew upon landing, causing metal to scrape the runway and send sparks into the wheel well, he said. Fire suppressant foam was sprayed in the landing gear as a precaution, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Hit Quayle with Papers Was Unemployed Vietnam Veteran
DOC.TEXT: A Virgin Islands man charged with striking Vice President Dan Quayle with a small batch of papers is an unemployed Vietnam veteran who had been in counseling, officials said. Mwenea Sikuzote, in Washington Wednesday, shouted, ``I have some documents'' before throwing a roll of papers that hit Quayle on the head. Quayle was not hurt. Sikuzote was charged with assaulting the vice president, a felony punishable on conviction by up to 10 years in prison or a $10,000 dollar fine or both. Mel Vanterpool, director of the Vietnam Veterans Readjustment Counseling Program, said Sikuzote changed his name from Gilbert Hendrickson while living in the San Francisco area after returning from Vietnam in the early 1970s. ``He is a very intelligent fellow,'' Vanterpool said Thursday. ``We will be trying our best ... to assist him.'' He indicated that might include providing a defense lawyer. He said Sikuzote, 42, had been unemployed and a regular client at the center for some time. Acquaintances said Sikuzote had been worried about his unemployment. Police spokesman Lt. Noel Martin said Sikuzote had no criminal record.

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Panel May Probe Senator's Motivations in Financial Dealings
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the Senate Ethics Committee preparing trial-like proceedings against Sen. Dave Durenberger say they may delve into the motivations behind the Minnesota Republican's financial dealings. Committee Chairman Howell T. Heflin, D-Ala., and Vice Chairman Warren B. Rudman, R-N.H. said Thursday Durenberger could agree in the case that many facts involving key financial transactions are not in dispute. The committee could then turn to the intent behind those moves, Rudman and Heflin said at a news conference on procedures for the hearings, which begin Tuesday and could last two weeks. Durenberger already has acknowledged errors in judgment in his personal finances, but he told constituents last December, ``It was never my intent to circumvent the Senate rules or circumvent them for my own benefit.'' The committee previously announced it found ``substantial credible evidence'' of financial wrongdoing by Durenberger. Some of the allegations cover transactions from 1983 to 1989, relating to a Minneapolis condominium that Durenberger partly owned and for which he received Senate reimbursements. Other charges are connected to money collected by Durenberger in promoting two books he wrote and his acceptance of free limousine rides. These alleged violations took place in 1985 and 1986. Heflin said Durenberger's intent is ``one of the elements we'd be considering. That's an element among many elements.'' Rudman added Durenberger's motivation also could be considered in determining whether punishment should be applied. Both senators said there has been no plea bargaining that could result in a settlement before the case runs its course. ``We're not in the nature of trading,'' Rudman said. Senate rules, however, don't preclude a settlement at any point in the ethics process that could lead to the full chamber debating Durenberger's fate. A conviction could bring punishment ranging from a mild rebuke to expulsion, although the Senate's ethics history indicates it would take a criminal conviction to get expelled. Durenberger was elected in 1978 to fill an unexpired term. He won re-election in 1982 and 1988. His current term expires after 1994. Durenberger has spoken little about the case publicly in the last several weeks, and in an interview Thursday with WCCO-TV in Minneapolis, he offered no predictions on the outcome of the case. ``This is new for me as it is for the committee and for a lot of you, and I think we'll all get our answers beginning next Tuesday,'' he said. When the hearings are completed, special counsel Robert Bennett will report to the panel, which then would make recommendations to the Senate.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Searching for Crime Bill Compromise
DOC.TEXT: Senate sponsors of an omnibus crime bill with curbs on semiautomatic assault weapons say odds are better than even they can save their measure despite their failure to limit debate. ``My gut tells me that something will break and we'll end up with a bill,'' Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., said Thursday after talking with Republicans about a possible compromise. The Senate voted 57-37 in favor of limiting debate on the bill to 30 hours, but the tally fell three votes short of the 60 required in this case. Biden, floor manager of the measure, then pronounced the bill dead, but within an hour he was scrambling to revive it. Republicans met to discuss a plan by Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., to drop provisions that would in some cases allow courts to consider evidence gathered with flawed warrants and create an organized crime and drug division within the Justice Department. Thurmond's plan would allow each party to offer 12 amendments but keeps the rest of the bill intact. Democrats later agreed to explore the Republican plan. The bill contains remnants of a crime package sent to Congress by President Bush a year ago but largely rewritten since then. The administration now has little good to say about the measure. Democratic leaders said they needed a limit on debate to push ahead with floor action on the bill. They pointed to 300 pending amendments and described them as filibuster fodder. They said attempting to debate each of the 300 amendments would create open-ended delays that would prevent the Senate from voting on the bill. Those favoring curbs on assault weapons blamed pressure from the National Rifle Association for the failure of efforts to limit debate. ``It certainly was the major reason,'' said Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill. But others scoffed at the notion that fear of NRA retaliation at election time was the reason. ``It wasn't in my case _ I'm leaving here,'' said Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., who is retiring at the end of this year. In the days before the vote, the NRA blanketed gun owners in eight states with mailings criticizing senators who in a vote two weeks ago supported the bill's gun provisions. It said, for example, that Sen. Tom Daschle, D-S.D., ``betrayed every honest gun owner in South Dakota by voting for it ... because Daschle bought the big anti-gun media lie that gun control equals crime control'' and ``has now joined Ted Kennedy and the national gun ban crowd ....'' The NRA mailing was identical in other states, with only the senator's name changed. It called on gun owners to contact the senators' state offices and provided telephone numbers. Daschle issued a statement telling South Dakotans that ``as a hunter and gun owner, I am against gun control, period.'' ``Let's be realistic,'' he said. ``Taking a couple of very small steps to try to deal with the drug killers who use these assault weapons is not going to hurt a single, law-abiding South Dakota sportsman.''

DOC.HEAD: Iliescu Must Decide: Communism or Democracy?
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: After a bloody revolution, a contentious election and a damaging earthquake, Romanians now face the next upheaval in their lives _the move to a market economy. Ion Iliescu, the only former Communist popularly elected to lead an East European nation, has promised to transform Romania's centralized economy to a free-market system. But just how Iliescu carries out this pledge _ slowly or quickly, superficially or extensively _ will provide the first solid evidence of whether Romania moves down the road to Western-style democracy or Soviet-style reform communism. Western diplomats, intellectuals and opposition politicians said the first clue will come later this month when Iliescu announces his new government. It will reveal whether the economy is still being run from the top in the old Communist style, they said. Muzzled by communism for 44 years, the Romanian people know their future is at stake. Unfamiliar with making points through Western-style political dialogue, they are still resorting to the shouting, violence and volatility of December's revolution and the recent election campaign. ``The frustrations are now exploding _ it's like a carnival after a period of fasting,'' said Culture Minister Andrei Plesu, a leading dissident before December's popular revolt which ended Nicolae Ceausescu's 24-year dictatorship. An anti-Communist protest which has blocked University Square since April 22 simmers on, despite a threat from the mayor of Bucharest to clear the thoroughfare. The demonstrators, backed by about a dozen hunger strikers, are demanding a free press, independent television, and a ban on ex-Communists like Iliescu holding public office for 10 years. While there are some new faces in high places, many of the old Communist Party members who ran Ceausescu's government are still in key posts. Ironically, Iliescu's staggering 85 percent landslide and his National Salvation Front's winning two-thirds of the seats in Parliament may turn out to be costly victories. Iliescu wanted a coalition government to tackle the modernization of Romania's faltering economy, where production has fallen 30 percent since the revolution. But the opposition parties refused. Stelian Tanase, editor of the weekly ``22,'' one of the most anti-Communist newspapers, said Iliescu now will have to take all the responsibility for highly unpopular reforms. Iliescu also faces competing demands from his own supporters. The workers and peasants, the old base of the Communist Party who provided the bulk of his landslide, voted for stability, a slow transition to a market economy, and no unemployment. But the broad-based Front is split between conservatives who back the go-slow approach and reformers who want a speedy transition to capitalism. There are other problems as well: unresolved allegations of electoral fraud and intimidation, ethnic tensions involving the 2.2 million-member Hungarian minority, the drafting of a new constitution, and preparing for new elections in about two years. As if Romanians didn't have enough to worry about, the country must spend more than $25 million for emergency repairs from an earthquake last week that killed 14 people and injured 1,000 across central and Eastern Europe, officials say. Predicting two years of terrible complications, Plesu said, ``The winners are those who are already losing. ... It is not a very glorious victory.'' During the election campaign, many Romanians said they didn't understand what democracy meant. A cartoon by Mihai Stanescu, Romania's best-known cartoonist, shows a man holding a newly painted sign saying ``Democracy'' and shouting into the telephone: ``Hello, Mr. Bush. Now what am I going to do with it?'' A joke currently making the rounds in Bucharest gives some indication of the lingering distrust of intellectuals for Iliescu, a onetime Politburo candidate member who fell out with Ceausescu and took the reins of power when the dictator was toppled. In the joke, President Bush, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Iliescu are sitting in the back seat of a car. Bush tells the driver to turn right. Gorbachev tells him to turn left. Iliescu tells him to head right but turn left. In the last days of the campaign, Iliescu said he didn't want to take undue risks in the transition to a market economy for fear of creating ``social problems.'' But Adrian Severin, secretary of state in the Ministry of National Economy who has emerged as a champion of radical reform, said the interim government had prepared for a speedy and ``very deep reform of the economy'' without mass unemployment or soaring inflation. He said he expected the legal and institutional framework for the transition to a free market to be completed in one year. Romania will promote the creation of small and medium-sized private business, especially in agriculture and tourism, he said in an interview. Within eight months, Severin said, the government expects to turn state enterprises into autonomous companies which will be subsidized for several years and then either become independent or be dismantled if they can't compete.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Edith M. Lederer is an AP correspondent based in London who covers Romanian affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Kennedy, Cuomo Clans To Be Joined by Marriage
LaserPhoto AB1
DOC.TEXT: In a union dubbed ``Cuomolot,'' two rising stars from prominent political families will wed this weekend. Kerry Kennedy, a daughter of the late Sen. Robert F. Kennedy, and Andrew Cuomo, oldest son of New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, will be the bride and groom Saturday in a major social event for the political world. ``Everybody in the world knows the Kennedy family,'' said William Cunningham, a veteran Cuomo political adviser. ``And the Cuomos _ in New York state, in the political world _ are at the top of the heap.'' But Cunningham cautioned against blowing the wedding's importance out of proportion. ``This isn't the Middle Ages where the Duke of Normandy and the Duke of Avignon get together and decide on a marriage,'' he said. ``This is not a dynastic accomplishment, this is two people who decided to get married.'' More than 250 guests have been invited to witness the ceremony Saturday afternoon in the Cathedral of St. Matthew in Washington, D.C. Rory Kennedy, Kerry's youngest sister, will be maid of honor. Christopher Cuomo, Andrew's 19-year-old brother, will be best man. John F. Kennedy Jr., Kerry's cousin and son of the late president, will be an usher. A reception will follow at Hickory Hill, the Kennedy family estate in suburban McLean, Va. The bride, a 30-year-old graduate of Boston College law school, is the founder and executive director of the Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Center for Human Rights. The groom, a 32-year-old lawyer and his father's chief political adviser, runs HELP, a non-profit corporation he founded to build temporary housing for the homeless. The couple have been dating for more than a year and became engaged on Valentine's Day this year. While both are Roman Catholic, the children of liberal Democrats and running non-profit social agencies, there are differences. Kerry Kennedy grew up in affluence and attended the exclusive Putney School before heading off for an Ivy League education at Brown University. Andrew Cuomo, grandson of Italian immigrants who ran a small grocery store in Queens, attended parochial schools and then Fordham University in the Bronx. Kerry Kennedy is the seventh of Robert and Ethel Kennedy's 11 children. She was a baby during her uncle's ``Camelot'' presidency, which the New York Post alluded to by dubbing her marriage ``Cuomolot.'' She was 8 years old when her father was assassinated in a Los Angeles hotel the night he won the 1968 California presidential primary. Another uncle, Massachusetts Sen. Edward Kennedy, ran unsuccessfully for the 1980 Democratic presidential nomination. Andrew Cuomo's father last week announced he'll seek a third term as governor but left the door open to becoming a potential 1992 Democratic presidential contender. In 1980, then-Lt. Gov. Cuomo ran President Carter's New York primary campaign against Edward Kennedy. Kennedy won in New York. Kerry Kennedy came to Albany last week to watch her future father-in-law announce for re-election. In New York City, meanwhile, a bachelor party last week for Andrew drew a number of Kennedy family members and a host of New York's political elite, including New York City Mayor David Dinkins. A highlight of the evening, according to the Post, was a 15-minute videotape that featured friends and acquaintances roasting Andrew. ``He loves to take control so much, he'll end up having the babies,'' said fellow lawyer Avery Seavey. Following a six-day honeymoon in the Caribbean, the couple plans to settle in Queens.

DOC.HEAD: New Gov't Fashions New Style
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Camouflage pants, T-shirts and combat boots are out. Straw sun hats, cocktail dresses and manicured nails are in. The new government of President Violetta Barrios de Chamorro is sending clear signals that gentility is back in style _ no more Sandinista revolutionary garb, please. The first clue came on the night of the inaugural ball at the former country club. The dressed-to-kill crowd of upper-crust Nicaraguans at their old haunt was something not seen in leftist Nicaragua for more than a decade. ``It's like `The Great Gatsby,''' a South American diplomat said the morning after the ball. He was referring not only to the fine gowns and designer shoes, but to the refined manners and glittering atmosphere that left some people gaping. ``These are people who either did not live in Nicaragua because they were in Miami, or they lived (here) during the revolution as if they were living in Miami,'' said Rosario Murillo, the wife of former Sandinista President Daniel Ortega. Even in diplomatic circles, a relaxed, down-home attitude had been encouraged by the Sandinistas, themselves generally more at ease in nicely pressed combat uniforms and in working-class barrios than in glitzy halls. Change is apparent all over Managua. The Plaza of the Revolution, where the bourgeoisie used to be publicly scorned at Sandinista rallies, is now called Plaza of the Republic _ its pre-Sandinista name. Telephone operators now call customers ``Sir'' and ``Madame,'' replacing the egalitarian ``Comrade'' or the laid-back ``Honey'' of Sandinista times. Some things from the old government remain. A boulevard from the old country club to a shopping plaza retains its name: Ho Chi Minh Avenue. Groups of young, affluent Nicaraguans, fresh from Miami in their stylish clothes, flock to Salvadoran restaurants where the walls bear pro-guerrilla posters. Men have started wearing coats and ties to important public functions. ``I must admit I am a bit worried about that,'' said a northern European diplomat. ``I had gotten quite used to these clothes,'' he said of his white cotton guayabera, the Latin American men's shirt of many pockets worn outside the pants. It satisfied the dressiest dress code in Sandinista Nicaragua. Clothing style under the Sandinistas was dictated by ideology and economic reality. Few had the money to dress up; those who did were careful not to offend with clothes that bespoke a fatter pocketbook. Ms. Murillo perhaps carried to the extreme the Sandinista rejection of middle-class conservatism in her usually flamboyant style of dress. Her husband, on the other hand, exemplified the politically correct dress with his signature camouflage uniforms. Ortega changed his image during the election campaign, when he switched to cotton bomber jackets over black T-shirts and tight jeans in an effort to woo younger voters to his cause. He arrived at Mrs. Chamorro's April 25 inauguration wearing a red-and-black print cotton shirt and black denim pants, with the presidential sash in the blue-and-white colors of the Nicaraguan flag draped over his chest. Next to him, Ms. Murillo wore skin-tight jeans, huge earrings and knee-high riding boots. A baseball cap with a Sandinista campaign slogan completed her outfit. Mrs. Chamorro, a 60-year-old grandmother, wore an elegant white two-piece suit. Ms. Murillo is dismayed by a recent ban on miniskirts at the government complex. ``The miniskirt, long hair'' were revolutionary symbols, Ms. Murillo said. She called the ban ``attempts against freedom.'' A young Sandinista woman who kept her job at the Presidential House despite the change in government said the new clothing restrictions came as a shock. ``We held a meeting and they told us that we couldn't come wearing sandals or culottes,'' she said, asking her name not be used for fear of being fired. ``They said it was the new image. We asked them if they were going to raise our salaries.''

DOC.HEAD: Outcry Follows Ban on G-String Swimsuits
DOC.TEXT: A city ban on thong-backed swimsuits has prompted a rear-guard action by devotees of the skimpy swimwear. A couple of hundred demonstrators rallied Thursday outside City Hall to protest the ban, including several young women sporting the swimsuits, which leave the buttocks exposed. No arrests were made. Last month, police arrested five people on indecent exposure charges for wearing the G-string swimsuits at the city's Lido Beach, touching off a debate at City Hall that led to the May 22 ban. The council voted Monday to uphold the ban. If convicted, the five face up to to 60 days in jail, but no court hearing has been set. ``They can't think of anything else to do,'' said Michele Larsen. ``They have to complain something about us young kids.'' Others took a different view. ``I'm a proud, healthy, virile, 68-year-old Navy veteran of World War II. Love women,'' said Jack Hoffman. ``I feel this is an onset to demeaning our whole community.'' Authorities have not so far attempted to ban the swimsuits in neighboring Manatee County. Lifeguards there say they have spotted a handful of the suits on weekdays and about a dozen on weekends. ``They don't bother me, as long as I don't have to get into one,'' said Eleanor Bahr, 69. But her companion, Mary Catney, also 69, said, ``It bothers me; I like to have a little imagination.'' Cody Elmendorf, 26, vacationing on Coquina Beach from Albany, N.Y., said that ``from a man's standpoint, I'm in favor of it.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Pop-rock supergroup Fleetwood Mac is back minus one of its creative cogs, singer-guitarist Lindsey Buckingham, and much of the tension. The band recently released ``Behind the Mask,'' its first album without Buckingham. He departed for a solo career in 1987, saying he didn't want to tour anymore. He did, however, contribute acoustic guitar on the title track to ``Behind the Mask.'' Buckingham was replaced by guitarists Billy Burnette and Rick Vito. Stevie Nicks, Christine McVie and co-founders John McVie and Mick Fleetwood are the other group members. Fleetwood Mac formed in 1967 as a blues-rock band but reconstituted in 1975 with the addition of Buckingham and then-girlfriend Stevie Nicks and churned out a succession of slick pop hits, such as ``Rhiannon,'' ``Say You Love Me'' and ``Go Your Own Way.'' Success fired up tensions in the group. Husband and wife John and Christine McVie separated and Buckingham and Nicks broke off their relationship. ``Before we knew it, it was really like a soap opera,'' Fleetwood said.

Arnold Schwarzenegger was the surprise guest speaker at the Seaside High School graduation and emphasized the importance of education and physical fitness. When the actor and former Mr. Universe appeared at the podium, ``I think everybody just about swallowed their teeth,'' senior Brandy Bierly said. Bierly then gave the senior speech to the class of 90 teen-agers. ``Mr. Schwarzenegger was a very tough act to follow,'' he said. Afterwards Schwarzenegger shook hands with students and kissed some of the girls. Schwarzenegger is filming his new movie, ``Kindergarten Cop,'' in Clatsop County. His appearance was the handiwork of Jamie Burns, a junior whose mother is an extra in ``Kindergarten Cop.'' Burns said she tracked down Schwarzenegger through the film's director, Ivan Reitman, and then persuaded her principal to approve the guest speech.

Entertainer Roger Miller says black blues guitarists and fiddlers were an important influence on white country musicians in the 1920s. ``I think we need to give black people more credit for their role in country music,'' said Miller, who gained fame with his hit ``King of the Road'' in the 1960s. Now a hint of rock 'n' roll can be found in today's country music, he said. ``Country people used to be people who played music on the farms,'' Miller said. ``Now you've got younger listeners. The first rock 'n' rollers later went into country music and now you're hearing a rock influence.'' Miller, who composed the music for the Broadway production ``Big River,'' is heading back to the New York stage. He's currently working on a musical version of ``Shane,'' based on the Jack Schaefer novel, which was also the basis for the 1953 movie starring Alan Ladd. ``We're gonna put some cowboys on stage and see how the New Yorkers react,'' said Miller, who starts a four-day engagement Wednesday at the Roy Clark Celebrity Theater in this Ozarks tourist community.

Former President Reagan's memoirs, due in bookstores this fall, will be titled ``An American Life.'' ``I have chosen `An American Life' because that is exactly what mine has been,'' Reagan said Thursday in a statement released from his Century City office. ``Only in America could one go from being a poor boy on the shores of the Rock River in Dixon, Ill., to being a sportscaster, a movie actor, governor of a major state and finally, to the White House,'' Reagan said. Reagan, 79, was completing work on the book at his office, spokesman Mark Weinberg said.

Gov. Michael S. Dukakis relished his heritage but took a few lessons on the fortunes of politics when he met with Greek Premier Constantine Mitsotakis. ``This is a visit we will treasure,'' Dukakis, a Greek-American, said Thursday. Mitsotakis, who called the governor a ``personal friend,'' tried to offer Dukakis some solace regarding his failed bid for the presidency. ``Yes, it is true politics have ups and downs,'' Mitsotakis said through an interpreter. ``The circle goes up and down and changes winds.'' Dukakis met privately with the Greek premier, who had met with President Bush at the White House earlier in the week, and then was host of a Statehouse reception for him.

DOC.HEAD: Increased Cancer Deaths Found in Wives, Children of Asbestos Workers
DOC.TEXT: The wives and children of asbestos workers are dying of cancer at 1{ times the rate of the general population, and their only exposure to asbestos was the dust on the clothes of their husbands and fathers, a study shows. ``This finding of elevations in cancers really concerns us,'' said the author of the study, Lou Joubert of the American Cancer Society. The study was described Thrusday at a conference on the hazards associated with asbestos in place in schools and other public buildings. In other studies, alarmingly high levels of lung damage were found in construction workers who don't work directly with asbestos. Many previous studies have found elevated disease and death rates among workers who produced asbestos or worked with it. The new studies find that asbestos is deadly even for construction workers who do not use it in their jobs. High levels of asbestos-related cancer were also found in school custodians in three separate studies, suggesting that the asbestos hazard in schools is greater than anticipated, said Dr. Philip J. Landrigan of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York. Landrigan was one of the conference's organizers. ``The hazard of asbestos in place is more than we anticipated,'' Landrigan said. Jacques Dunnigan of The Asbestos Institute, which represents the interests of Canadian asbestos mines, argued that Canadian asbestos, called chrysotile asbestos, is less dangerous than other forms. Asked about the reports at the conference, he said, ``It's very, very poor science that I'm listening to.'' Asbestos-related diseases _ lung cancer, a lung-scarring called asbestosis and a cancer of the lung lining called mesothelioma _ occur 20 to 30 years after exposure to asbestos. Asbestos was widely used as insulation in schools and other buildings during the construction boom of the 1950s and 1960s, and so asbestos-related diseases are just beginning to appear. These diseases now cause about 10,000 deaths per year, said Dr. Stephen M. Levin, also of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine. Joubert studied 878 children and wives of men who worked at a now-closed asbestos plant in Paterson, N.J. Of the 115 that have died, 38 percent died of cancer, compared with an expected death rate of 20 percent to 25 percent in the general population. Dr. Laura Welch of George Washington University in Washington found that 40 percent of sheet metal workers _ who do not use asbestos in their work _ had asbestos-related lung damage, a precursor of asbestosis or cancer. They were exposed to asbestos on construction sites, Welch said. Landrigan found the same asbestos-related lung damage in firefighters with at least 20 years of service. Their rate of lung damage was seven times that of the general population. The firefighters are typically exposed to asbestos when they enter buildings after fires have been put out, he said. Levin reported the results of a study in which he and his colleagues examined 660 New York City school custodians 20 years after any possible exposure to asbestos. The researchers found that 28 percent of the custodians had asbestos-related lung damage. ``It was somewhat surprising,'' he said. ``We knew exposure occurred, but while we expected to see some disease, the rates surprised us.'' Similar findings were reported from independent studies in Los Angeles and Boston, Levin said. An article in Science magazine in January argued that asbestos in schools and other buildings was not a significant hazard. Scientists at the New York conference were sharply critical of that article, which they said was already causing some building owners and regulatory agencies to be less diligent in containing or removing asbestos.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis Next Shuttle To Be Launched
DOC.TEXT: Columbia's astronomy mission with the $150 million Astro observatory is off until August because of a hydrogen leak, making Atlantis the next shuttle to fly, NASA says. Atlantis is scheduled to carry a secret military payload into orbit in mid-July. ``I do not have any problem at all moving Atlantis out and preparing it for its next flight,'' shuttle director Robert L. Crippen said Thursday. ``I think we've got a situation that is safe to go fly, and if we do not we will have evidence of that that will be very clear to us.'' Columbia's upcoming flights will be pushed back ``in an orderly fashion,'' Crippen said. A scientific research mission scheduled for August is now set for December, pushing Columbia's December mission with a microgravity laboratory into next year. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration will move Columbia from the launch pad back to the hangar next week so the hydrogen leak can be repaired. The leak was detected as more than a half-million gallons of supercold liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen were being pumped into the shuttle for last week's launch attempt. ``All of the checks and balances that we had in place worked just like they were supposed to work. We were never in an unsafe condition,'' Crippen said. A test Wednesday confirmed NASA's suspicion the leak is in or near a tight cavity between two metal plates that connect the orbiter and external tank. The orbiter and tank will have to be disconnected, a job that can be performed only at the hangar. Crippen said pipes and valves probably will have to be replaced in that area and another external tank used. He declined to estimate how much the repairs will cost and how much the delay already has cost. ``The problem we're dealing with is unique. We've never seen it before,'' he said. ``Until we pull it apart and do some detailed trouble-shooting on it we'll be unable to say specifically what the problem is.'' Crippen said the delay poses no risk to the Astro observatory, which consists of three ultraviolet telescopes and one X-ray telescope capable of examining some of the hottest objects in the universe. ``It just has to sit on the ground for longer than we had desired,'' he said. The Astro mission, the first in five years dedicated entirely to scientific research, already was two weeks late because of cooling system repairs. The mission originally was scheduled for 1986, but was delayed by the Challenger explosion. Discovery's flight in April with the Hubble Space Telescope was two weeks late because of a malfunctioning power unit that had to be replaced at the launch pad. Crippen said mechanical problems are to be expected now and then. ``Flying the space shuttle is not like operating an airline and it never will be,'' he said. ``It is a very complex vehicle ... that is going to have problems show up periodically and yet it does offer us a way to get large payloads into space on a fairly frequent basis.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Courts Have Jurisdiction Over PLO, Judge Rules
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has ruled that U.S. courts have jurisdiction over the Palestine Liberation Organization. U.S. District Judge Louis L. Stanton made the finding Thursday in deciding to let stand lawsuits against the PLO stemming from the October 1985 hijacking of the Achille Lauro cruise ship. The litigation included two lawsuits by passengers as well as claims by travel agencies that were sued by the estate of Leon Klinghoffer, the 69-year-old American who was shot to death in his wheelchair aboard the ship and thrown into the Mediterranean Sea. The complaints allege the PLO was responsible for the highjacking and seek to hold the organization liable for damages. The PLO sought dismissals on the grounds of diplomatic immunity and lack of jurisdiction. It denied any involvement and said its chairman, Yasser Arafat, mediated a peaceful resolution to the hijacking. The PLO's attorney, Ramsey Clark, said he would appeal the decision. ``I do not believe the United States courts have jurisdiction over the PLO,'' Clark, a former U.S. attorney general, said. The hijackers released the ship in Egypt in exchange for safe passage to Tunisia, but their plane was forced down in Sicily by the United States. A man directing the hijackers from shore was released but four others were held by Italy and subsequently sentenced to prison on weapons charges. Stanton rejected several of the PLO's arguments, including that the issue of its liability for a terrorist attack was a foreign policy question not appropriately decided in the courts. ``The seizure of a ship on the high seas poses no value judgments or debatable issues of the law of nations,'' Stanton wrote. ``Acts of piracy are clear violations of international law.'' Stanton ruled the PLO had no immunity from this litigation because of its status as an observer at the United Nations. ``Any acts for which the PLO could be held responsible in these cases did not occur in connection with its observer function,'' he said. The judge also settled jurisdictional questions by ruling that the PLO did business in Manhattan at its United Nations mission and therefore could be sued in New York. ``The PLO has purposefully established a permanent and extensive presence in New York,'' Stanton said. ``While the United States strictly limits PLO's activities, it still has constant and substantial contacts here.'' Stanton also ruled that the PLO was properly served with the complaints. The Klinghoffer lawsuit in federal court claims the owner and charterer of the Achille Lauro and travel agencies did not take sufficient steps to prevent a hijacking or warn passengers of the possibility. Jay D.
