Fischer, the Klinghoffer attorney, said the estate also has a lawsuit pending in state court alleging that the PLO was responsible for Klinghoffer's death. ``This decision vindicates the view of the Klinghoffer family that the U.S. courts constitute the appropriate forum for the determination of legal liability for the murder of Leon Klinghoffer aboard the Achille Lauro,'' Fischer said.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk's Move Criticized By Both Sides At Home
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk's lifting of the 4-year-old state of emergency met with some criticism on both sides here, with blacks calling it a ``half measure'' and right-wing whites warning the president he had gone too far. De Klerk's action Thursday, an effort to pave the way for black-white negotiations on dismantling apartheid, ended some of the harshest political restrictions ever imposed by the country's white rulers. ``The net result of the lifting of the state of emergency is that one of the main stumbling blocks (to constitutional negotiations) has been removed,'' de Klerk told Parliament in Cape Town. In Paris, African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela called the development ``a victory for the people,'' but he said he would continue to urge Western governments to maintain economic sanctions against Pretoria. He also criticized the retention of the state of emergency in Natal Province. De Klerk said that province will remain under emergency rule because violence there ``cannot be countered with the ordinary laws of the land.'' ANC leader Walter Sisulu said the state of emergency had done nothing to stop the fighting in Natal, where about 4,000 blacks have died in the past four years. The main combatants are supporters of the ANC and members of Inkatha, a relatively conservative Zulu organization. ``We are not asking for half measures,'' Sisulu told a news conference. ``What we have asked for is to clear the atmosphere to negotiations. That was not done.'' The ANC has said the lifting of the emergency, the release of political prisoners and the return of exiles are the main obstacles to full negotiations. The pro-apartheid Conservative Party, meanwhile, said the end of the state of emergency would lead to chaos and further alienate right-wing whites disgruntled with de Klerk's reforms. ``He no longer speaks for the (white) people he claims to represent,'' said Clive Derby-Lewis, a Conservative spokesman. But business groups and world leaders heaped praise on de Klerk. The White House called the lifting of the emergency a sign of ``the remarkable progress'' in recent months in South Africa, and U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said it was a ``positive development.'' During the state of emergency, more than 30,000 activists, most of them black, were detained without charge for varying lengths of time. Thousands more went into hiding after former President P.W. Botha imposed the restrictions on June 12, 1986. About 300 activists were being held under the emergency regulations as of Thursday, most of them in Natal. In announcing the end of the state of emergency, de Klerk also held out the prospect for other reforms. He said the government was considering changes to security laws that ``could possibly inhibit the free conduct of peaceful politics'' and said he was taking unspecified actions that would allow thousands of exiles to return home. The ANC says it has more than 15,000 exiled members. De Klerk also said that as a ``good will gesture'' he would release 48 prisoners convicted of politically motivated crimes. The ANC has said there are some 3,500 inmates it considers political prisoners. De Klerk wants to work out a new constitution with opposition groups that will lead to power-sharing between the 5 million whites and 28 million blacks, who under apartheid have no voice in national affairs. Mid-level officials from the ANC and the government worked out a joint program on the obstacles to negotiations last month and submitted the plan to the leaders on both sides. De Klerk said the government has accepted the plan and is ready to implement it, but the ANC has asked to delay its response until July 10. Details of the plan have not been released. The president challenged Mandela to stop advocating guerrilla violence. He criticized Mandela's recent statement that the ANC approves of ``organized, disciplined violence'' against chosen targets. The end of the emergency is likely to make it more difficult for Mandela to persuade foreign governments to maintain economic sanctions against Pretoria. French President Francois Mitterrand, who met Mandela in Paris Thursday, met de Klerk last month and indicated he would be willing to call for a reassessment of European Community sanctions if the emergency were lifted, political prisoners were released and exiles were allowed to return. More than 20 opposition groups were banned and several anti-apartheid newspapers were shut down temporarily during the emergency. Police repeatedly raided black trade union offices and broke up political meetings and demonstrations in black townships and university campuses. De Klerk in February nullified some of the restrictions as part of his reforms. Many of the emergency regulations are duplicated in existing security laws. But the emergency decree allowed the government and police to bypass the courts. Existing laws allow for detention without trial, provide authority to ban political meetings and permit the government to place restrictions on activists such as house arrest.

DOC.HEAD: National Rifle Association Meets As Group Suffers Declining Influence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Convention scheduled to open at 1 p.m. EDT. Lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: The National Rifle Association opens its annual convention today with some of its supporters puzzled why a group known for its clout is suffering legislative defeats and a sharp loss in membership. ``I think there's a great deal of frustration among the membership based on a very tough year,'' said James J. Baker, lobbyist for the 2.8 million-member gun lobby based in Washington, D.C. Once renowned for its political influence throughout the nation, the NRA has recently suffered legislative defeats in New Jersey, Maryland and Florida. An estimated 20,000 members will attend the convention in California, which last year passed legislation banning more than 50 types of military-style assault rifles. On Thursday, the gun lobby scored a tenuous victory when U.S. Senate supporters of a wide-ranging crime bill with curbs on semiautomatic assault weapons failed to stop a filibuster. Democratic leaders, blaming pressure from the NRA for the failure of efforts to limit debate, initially decided the bill was dead, then sought a compromise to revive the measure. The convention comes at a crucial time in the history of the NRA. Along with legislative defeats, the group has lost support among law enforcement and dropped an estimated 250,000 members in four years. Baker blames the falloff in membership on a $10 dues increase and unknown factors, but gun control advocates see a badly damaged organization. ``Over the last 12 months you're looking at the worst period in the NRA's existence,'' said Luis Tolley, western director of Handgun Control Inc. Among the events on the convention agenda is a membership meeting Saturday when the rank and file can question NRA leaders on legislative losses. California's clampdown on assault weapons came after five children were slain and 29 others were wounded in a schoolyard by a man with an assault rifle. The man, Patrick Purdy, killed himself at the end of the Jan. 17, 1989, attack in Stockton. California also now requires a 15-day waiting period for the purchase of rifles and shotguns. Elsewhere, Maryland voters approved a referendum in 1988 that bans the sale and manufacture of cheap handguns known as Saturday Night Specials. In New Jersey earlier this year, Gov. James Florio signed what he called the nation's strongest ban on the sale and possession of assault weapons. But Baker asserts that despite those setbacks, the NRA retains influence, using as an example the extension of the crime bill filibuster. The NRA had sent messages from Executive Director Wayne LaPierre to gun owners in eight states urging them to pressure their senators. ``We've lost some battles,'' Baker said Thursday. ``The war is far from over. You look at the votes in the United States Senate this morning and I think that gives you the proof that you need.'' Robert Ellison, helping to set up a convention booth for Sierra Bullets, blamed the NRA's troubles on widespread misunderstanding of gun issues, rather than on the organization's internal shortcomings. ``They do a good job and work in the best interest of members,'' he said. ``But the general public, quite frankly, isn't getting the right message.''

DOC.HEAD: Panel Votes to Slash Request to Rebuild Bugged Embassy
DOC.TEXT: A unanimous Senate Foreign Relations Committee wants to slash by 80 percent President Bush's request for money to tear down and rebuild a new U.S. Embassy building in Moscow riddled with electronic bugs. A 15-0 vote by the panel on Thursday demonstrated anew that there is no consensus among policy makers about what to do with the eight-story white elephant. In a drafting session called to deal with Bush's request for additional money for the embassy and to pay past-due U.S. fees to the United Nations, Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan called it ``humiliating and wasteful'' to tear down a nearly completed building that already has cost $60 million. Moynihan, D-N.Y., proposed instead to cut the State Department embassy request for $270 million in the fiscal year starting Oct. 1 to $50 million. He said that would be enough to finish the current office building, which could be used for non-classified activities, and to construct a secure ``bubble'' elsewhere in the embassy compound for sensitive intelligence and diplomatic activities. During a brief discussion of Moynihan's amendment there was no dissent except from a State Department representative, who said the administration would strenuously oppose the move because it would compromise security at the site. The administration wants to dismantle the building down to its foundation, which would be left in place. A new structure then would be built after a ``buffer'' layer is installed to insulate the new building from the foundation. The structure would then be put to its originally planned use as the primary office building for the complex. Intelligence experts, including the Senate Intelligence Committee, have endorsed that approach as the only secure one. A similar bill awaiting House action includes the full $270 million asked by the administration but defers the question of whether to raze and rebuild the office building until after negotiations are completed on purchase of additional land adjacent to the embassy compound. A House Foreign Affairs Committee staff report concluded that it is ``unnecessary and unwise'' to tear down the building because it could be put to use as staff housing, which is in short supply in Moscow. It is unclear whether the legislation approved Thursday by the Senate panel will ever be enacted. Few major foreign affairs bills have survived the full legislative process in recent years. Work on the embassy building was halted in August 1985 after it was discovered that the structure had been permeated with Soviet listening devices. Sources have said the United States still does not fully understand the technology used by Soviet spies to turn the building into a giant microphone. At least three outside consultants have done lengthy studies of what to do with the building, and numerous internal State Department and congressional studies have been performed. More than a dozen different solutions to the problem have been considered.

DOC.HEAD: America's Mightiest Rocket Carries Military Cargo
DOC.TEXT: America's mightiest unmanned space rocket, a Titan 4, blasted off today with a secret military payload. It was the second launch of a Titan 4. The giant rocket boosted a missile-warning satellite into orbit in June 1989. The rocket was launched at 1:22 a.m. EDT from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station, lighting up the sky as it thundered toward orbit. The Air Force refused to discuss or even acknowledge the flight until about 20 minutes later, when a statement was issued. The payload was not disclosed. ``This was an important launch for America's space program,'' said Martin C. Faga, the Air Force's assistant secretary for space. ``The Titan 4 is the largest booster ever launched by the Air Force. ... The Titan 4 provides our nation a vital path to space for critical national security payloads.'' John Pike, director of the Federation of American Scientists' space policy project, said the rocket's cargo probably is a $500 million electronic eavesdropping satellite capable of intercepting missile telemetry and radio communications. A less likely possibility, Pike said, is that it is a missile-warning satellite. Martin Marietta Space Launch Systems has a $7.1 billion contract with the Air Force to supply 41 Titan 4 rockets, with an option for eight more. The Air Force ordered the rocket in 1985 to lessen its dependency on NASA's manned space shuttle. The shuttle is the most powerful cargo carrier used by the United States, capable of putting a 52,000-pound payload into orbit. The Titan 4, an expendable launch vehicle, can lift a 39,000-pound payload into low Earth orbit or carry 10,000 pounds to stationary orbit 22,300 miles high. The Titan 4 stands 20 stories tall and is powered by two liquid fuel main engines and two solid rocket boosters. One of the engine's nozzles malfunctioned in last year's launch, but the other nozzle compensated and the rocket remained on target. The Air Force plans to launch future Titan 4 rockets from Cape Canaveral and Vandenberg Air Force Base in California. Ten Titan 4 rockets originally were to have been launched by October. The U.S. General Accounting Office criticized the program in a report last month, citing schedule delays and $209 million in cost overruns as of July 1989. Martin Marietta said it is working to improve production and cut costs. The Denver company encountered problems with a commercial Titan 3 launch in March. An engineering design error caused the rocket's cargo, an Intelsat communications satellite, to be placed in a uselessly low orbit. Intelsat's board of governors will decide at a meeting in Barbados this week and next whether to pay the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for a shuttle rescue mission, which could exceed $130 million. The Washington-based consortium of 119 countries operates a global communications system. A commercial Titan 3 is scheduled to carry another Intelsat communications satellite into orbit on June 21.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak Elections in Brief
With PM-Czechoslovakia-Election, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A brief glance at the main issues in the Czechoslovak elections today:

WHAT'S AT STAKE: 300 seats in the two-chamber federal parliament, 200 seats in the regional parliament of the Czech republic and 150 seats in the regional parliament of the smaller Slovak republic. The two republics have control over significant areas of public life, including education, culture and health care. The federal parliament controls foreign affairs, defense, finance and the environment. It also has to elect a new president, virtually certain to be the incumbent, Vaclav Havel, after he appoints a new federal government based on the results of the election. The chief task of the new federal parliament, which like the regional parliaments will sit only for two years, is to draft a new Czechoslovak constitution. This should remove the vestiges of four decades of Communist rule and will have to deal with rising separatist sentiment in the Slovak republic, where many people seek the eventual creation of a separate Slovak state that could enter a new united Europe.

MAIN POLITICAL PARTIES: There are 22 parties competing in the elections, although some are standing only in the Czech or Slovak republics. The heavy favorites to emerge as strongest forces are the Civic Forum and its Slovak partner organization, Public Against Violence, who led last winter's peaceful revolution against Communist rule. Latest opinion polls give them 39 to 42 percent of the vote nationwide. The second strongest force is the Christian Democratic alliance of three parties: the People's Party and Christian Democrats in the Czech republic, and the Christian Democrat movement in Slovakia. The third strongest is the Communist party, which is given around 10 percent in the latest pre-election polls. Other parties likely to get the 5 percent minimum vote required for seats in federal or regional bodies are the environmentalist Greens and the Social Democrats.

HOW VOTING WORKS: About 11.2 million people 18 and over are entitled to vote. They will cast ballots for lists of candidates in 12 electoral regions nationwide. Seats will be allotted on a proportional basis.

MAIN ISSUES: All parties support the transition to a market economy. A key issue will be the future status of Slovakia. Under the current federation created by the Communists in 1968, Slovakia is allotted half the federal funds, although it has only about one-third of Czechoslovakia's 15.5 million citizens.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Average Closes Lower
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,993.29, down 199.21 or 0.60 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says White House Has Good Food, But How Many Rooms?
With PM-Bush
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says he really likes the White House because ``they've got good food there'' even if the job entails reading ``tons of paper.'' The president reflected on his life as the nation's chief executive Thursday in a discussion with kindergarten through third-grade students at Chicago's Farnsworth Elementary School. He first discussed education and the war on drugs with a group of area principals and then read to a group of young students in observance of National Literacy Week. ``You really like it or are you just saying that?'' Bush asked his young audience, who clapped after he read from a children's book _ something that his wife Barbara does frequently in her efforts to promote literacy. He told the kids to go home and tell their parents and grandparents to read to them more. ``If you want to be president, learn to read and try to keep going in the right direction,'' Bush said. But, he said, ``there's tons of papers, just endless numbers of papers to read ... . I read so many I sometimes start reading backwards, which is very bad to do, because you don't understand it very well.'' Bush asked the students if they saw news accounts of ``the man from Russia,'' referring to Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's recent visit to the United States. ``You do things like that,'' he said. ``And you work with Congress.'' ``I like it a lot. They've got good food there,'' Bush said of life in the White House. ``It's fulltime work. It's very interesting. It's very important. You work with important people in the White House,'' Bush said. But ``it's not all hard work,'' he added, noting that he and Mrs. Bush like to walk their pet spaniel, Millie, around the grounds after he finishes work in the Oval Office each evening. One child asked how many rooms were in the White House. ``That's a good question,'' Bush said, clearly stumped. He said he guessed there were about 10 bedrooms, ``maybe even more.'' He said his favorite room in the White House was the Oval Office, because it is ``so special and so beautiful.'' He also said he liked the Lincoln bedroom, because it is where Lincoln signed the Emancipation Proclamation and ``freed all the slaves.''

DOC.HEAD: Euthanasia Advocates Say Death Machine Raises Few New Issue
DOC.TEXT: The suicide machine used by an Oregon woman to end her life has raised no new ethical questions in the Netherlands, where euthanasia is widely accepted, advocates of mercy killing say. ``There is no ethical or legal difference in the Netherlands between direct (euthanasia) action by a doctor or a doctor simply providing the means'' to commit suicide, Theo van Berkesteijn, chairman of the Royal Netherlands Physicians' Association, said in a telephone interview. Janet Adkins of Portland, Ore. died Monday after using the suicide machine designed by Dr. Jack Kevorkian of Michigan. She had been told she was suffering from Alzheimer's disease. The subject was discussed informally Thursday as a 21-nation euthanasia conference opened in the Netherlands. Formal discussion is expected today. Kevorkian's device has sparked a debate among American legal and medical authorities on whether it is legal and ethical for doctors to assist their patients in committing suicide. Medical regulators have joined prosecutors in investigating Kevorkian. But in the Netherlands, it has become widely accepted for physicians to go even further and personally administer lethal injections to terminally ill or suffering patients who have asked to die. The physicians' association has spearheaded a 15-year campaign for full legalization of euthanasia on the grounds that mercy killing can be a humane medical practice and should not have to take place surreptitiously. Kevorkian's machine is ``a technical innovation which brings no new ethical elements,'' said Pit Bakker, chairwoman of the Dutch Voluntary Euthanasia Society. The eighth World Conference of Right-to-Die Societies opened in the southern Dutch city of Maastricht on Thursday to discuss legal and ethical issues surrounding euthanasia. Derek Humphry, the British executive director of the Hemlock Society, a U.S. right-to-die advocacy group, described Kevorkian as ``a very brave pioneer who is trying to shock the medical profession into accepting voluntary euthanasia.'' But he said that ``We don't think that dying in the back of a van, 2,000 miles from home, is a dignified death.'' Mrs. Adkins, 54, traveled from Oregon to Michigan because the state has no clear laws on doctor-assisted suicide, according to Humphry. Kevorkian drove with Mrs. Adkins to a park outside Detroit and attached her to the electric-powered suicide device in the back of his van. She pressed a button that delivered chemicals that stopped her heart, and Kevorkian said she was dead within minutes. ``We accept this is what Mrs. Adkins wanted, because of the terrible (euthanasia) law in America,'' Humphry said. Although euthanasia is still technically a crime punishable by a 12-year prison term here, physicians are rarely prosecuted as long as they follow a set of semi-official guidelines that have received the tacit support of the government. Under the guidelines established by the physicians' association, doctors must make sure the patient has explictly asked to die and that relatives and other physicians are consulted before euthanasia is carried out. Berkesteijn noted that the Adkins case raised the issue of whether informed consent could be obtained from a patient suffering from Alzheimer's disease, an incurable disease that leads to deterioration of the brain. ``Euthanasia in the Netherlands is and should remain a case where patients are fully lucid'' when they seek death, he said. Last year, a government euthanasia proposal was shelved indefinitely after the center-right coalition government of Premier Ruud Lubbers collapsed over an unrelated issue. The proposal was a compromise between the pro-euthanasia Liberal Party, right-wingers on most other issues, and Lubbers' Christian Democrats. The Dutch Christian Democrats, an amalgam of religious-based political parties, take pains to avoid antagonizing the conservative Roman Catholic and Protestant communities. Lubbers wanted to avoid legalization but give government recognition to the status quo by codifying the existing guidelines. His current center-left coalition has ordered an investigation to determine the volume of euthanasia cases and their circumstances, a move criticized by advocates as yet more political waffling on what has already become widespread practice. Estimates of the number of right-to-die cases vary from a few hundred to 20,000 a year in this nation of 14.6 million, although experts stress thee are no reliable figures. Attending the conference are experts from Australia, Belgium, Great Britain, Canada, Colombia, Denmark, France, the Netherlands, Greece, India, Israel, Japan, Monaco, New Zealand, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, South Africa, West Germany and the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Forest Destroyed At Faster Pace
DOC.TEXT: The world's rain forests are being destroyed faster than previously thought, an environmental research group says. ``Every year the world loses an area of tropical forests almost as big as the state of Washington,'' said James Gustave Speth, president of World Resources Institute. The report, released Thursday by the institute, said data from satellites and ground sensors, along with reports from individual governments, indicate tropical forests are vanishing 50 percent faster than previously estimated. The report, citing 1987 data, concluded that 40 million to 50 million acres of tropical forests are stripped each year, compared to the official estimate of about 28 million acres _ based on 1980 data _ that still is used by the United Nations and many governments. Deforestation is a major concern to scientists and environmentalists because tropical forests absorb carbon dioxide and, therefore, serve as a carbon ``sink'' for the manmade gas, which contributes to global warming. As forests disappear, more carbon dioxide is allowed free to drift into the atmosphere, where it and other manmade pollutants act much like a greenhouse and cause the earth to warm. Some scientists believe such warming, if not checked, will cause severe changes in weather patterns, coastal flooding and economic disruptions by the middle of the next century. Allen Hammond, who headed the institute's research effort, said the satellite findings and data from studies in several countries with vast tropical forests provide the first exhaustive look at the current extent of deforestation worldwide. But other recent indications show that the official estimate of rain-forest destruction, based on data a decade old, was far too conservative. A study by a British scientists last year came to a conclusion similar to the institute's findings. Ken Andrasko, senior forestry analyst for the climate change office of the Environmental Protection Agency, said the ``definitive answer to how much forest we're losing'' won't be available until next year when the U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization revises its rain forest destruction estimates. Andrasko said indications are that the updated estimates will reflect findings similar to the Institute's report. Meanwhile, official estimates on the extent of the deforestation problem continue to be based on the 1980 data. For example, the EPA used the official data in drafting a policy options paper on global warming last year. ``We're talking about sparse (official) data that is credible,'' Hammond said. He said he considers the institute's findings conservative. According to the World Resources Institute report, about one-third of carbon dioxide pollution each year comes from the destruction of tropical rain forests. An additional 2.8 billion tons of carbon were released into the atmosphere in 1987 because of tropical deforestation, the study said. The report is based on data gathered in 1987 when deforestation in Brazil, which has the world's largest rain forest, was at its peak. As much as 20 million acres of forest may have been destroyed in Brazil that year, the study said. The Brazilian government has since begun to curb deforestation, but Hammond said the destruction of the Brazilian rain forest continues at a significant rate and deforestation elsewhere is increasing. According to the 1987 data gathered in the institute's study, 11 countries were responsible for 82 percent of the world's tropical deforestation: Brazil, Indonesia, Burma, India, Colombia, Ivory Coast, Thailand, Laos, Philippines, Nigeria and Vietnam. Satellite sensing studies showed deforestation in India at 3.7 million acres in 1987, 10 times the earlier estimate, the study said. Large areas of India legally still designated as forest land ``already are virtually treeless according to the satellite imagery,'' said the researchers. Burma, which was not among the top 10 countries in deforestation a decade ago, now ranks near the top with 1.7 million acres of forests lost annually, a 500 percent increase over 1980. As a result of deforestation, Brazil in 1987 caused 1.2 million tons of carbon to be released, about the same amount of carbon released by the United States from the burning of fossil fuels that year, the study said.

DOC.HEAD: Economists Say Johnson Resignation Won't Affect Interest Rates
DOC.TEXT: The departure of Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Manuel Johnson will have little immediate effect on interest rates, economists say, but it will give President Bush another chance to put his stamp on the central bank. Johnson, 41, unexpectedly announced Thursday he will resign from the No. 2 job at the central bank on Aug. 3 to return to an academic career. Bush, who has been pressing the Fed to relent and let interest rates fall to keep the country out of a recession, will get his third chance to appoint someone to the seven-member Fed board. Earlier this year, Bush appointed David Mullins, a top aide to Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, and reappointed Edward W. Kelley Jr., originally appointed by President Reagan. Early speculation pointed to Wendy Gramm, chairman of the Commodities Futures Trading Commission, as a likely nominee to succeed Johnson. But economists said the changes on the board would not chance the Fed's current tight-money policies. Despite administration complaints, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan and his colleagues have been keeping interest rates high to dampen economic demand and reduce inflationary pressures. This ``soft-landing'' approach appears to be working. Economic growth has slowed but the economy has not dipped into a recession. Lyle Gramley, a former Fed board member and now chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association, said Fed policy-makers, including Johnson, had been supporting Greenspan's approach. ``The bulk of policy-making officials are committed to bringing down inflation through a process that involves slow growth,'' he said. ``The Fed isn't closely divided now where one vote in either direction would make much of a difference.'' A published report in March quoted an anonymous Bush adviser as saying the president was ``mad as hell'' at Greenspan and predicting he would not reappoint the chairman when his term expires next year. Bush later denied the report, but left no doubt he would prefer to see lower interest rates. Johnson had been considered one of the leading candidates for the chairman's job should Bush decide to fire Greenspan. But Thursday, Johnson said he fully supported Greenspan's reappointment in 1991 and would decline any offer to succeed him at that time. Gramm, the wife of Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, has opposed an administration effort on Capitol Hill to transfer the CFTC's control over stock index futures to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Her appointment to the Fed would remove her from that debate. Others mentioned as possible candidates for a Fed appointment were John Taylor, a member of the president's Council of Economic Advisers, and Treasury Undersecretary Robert Glauber. ``The administration is likely to choose some one out of the same mold as Mullins, a pro-administration Republican with an academic background,'' said David Jones, author of a book on the Federal Reserve and chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Co. Johnson said he was leaving because he wished to return to the private sector. ``The main reason I decided to step down is that I have spent 10 consecutive years in public service,'' he said. ``Ten years is long enough to serve in positions in government.'' Johnson was appointed to the Fed by President Reagan on Feb. 7, 1986, and was elevated to vice chairman six months later. Johnson said he planned to return to George Mason University in Washington's Virginia suburbs and assume the Koch Chair in international economics and become director of the Center for Global Market Studies. He was a professor at the school in 1981 when he was selected to join the economics team in Reagan's first term.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Seeks No Prison Term for Poindexter
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for John M. Poindexter are asking the judge to reject a prosecution request to send the former national security adviser to prison. Defense attorney Richard W. Beckler argued in court papers filed Thursday that imprisoning Poindexter for lying about the Iran-Contra affair would only unjustly extend ``the suffering he has endured'' for 3{ years. Poindexter, convicted of five felony counts stemming from efforts to conceal details of the Iran-Contra affair from Congress, is scheduled to be sentenced Monday. The retired Navy rear admiral, who served as President Reagan's national security adviser from 1985 until his resignation when the affair became public in late 1986, could be sentenced up to 25 years in prison and fined $1.25 million. But the defense urged U.S. District Judge Harold H. Greene to reject a request by independent counsel Lawrence E. Walsh that he order Poindexter to serve a prison sentence for lying to Congress. ``This recommendation was made without the slightest reference to John Poindexter's lifelong career of service to his country and to his community,'' Beckler said of the retired Navy rear admiral. ``It is made without consideration of the heavy punishment that the more than three-year `Iran-Contra' investigation has already visited upon John Poindexter and his family,'' the lawyer wrote. ``To take him away from his family and the community he has served and can continue to serve, would be fundamentally unjust.'' The defense noted that all other Iran-Contra defendants convicted of crimes, including former White House aide Oliver L. North, were given terms of probation. ``If there is a distinction between these men and John Poindexter which the court should consider at sentencing, it is this: whatever John Poindexter has done, his actions were always motivated by what he truly believed to be the best interests of the presidency of the United States,'' Beckler said. Poindexter, 53, was convicted April 7 of making false statements to Congress by denying that the White House staff was secretly helping to arm the Contra rebels in Nicaragua after Congress had banned U.S. aid. He was also convicted of lying, destroying and altering documents to conceal the U.S. role in a 1985 shipment of Israeli Hawk missiles to Iran. Reagan, who gave a videotaped deposition that was played to jurors, testified that he never authorized Poindexter to break the law or lie. Prosecutors said the sentence ``must include a period of incarceration'' because the ``diet of lies'' Poindexter fed Congress ``did violence to this nation's fundamental principles of government.'' Beckler said Poindexter has suffered enough since the Iran-Contra affair became public. ``He has lost a bright and promising career in the United States Navy, he has endured the public ridicule of the Congress and the media, and he has suffered financial hardship,'' the lawyer said. ``Most painful of all, he has been convicted.''

DOC.HEAD: They're Off To See the Birthplace of the Star of the `Wizard of Oz'
DOC.TEXT: Thirteen surviving Munchkins will follow a real yellow brick road this weekend to pay tribute to the star of ``The Wizard of Oz.'' They're off to see the birthplace of the late Frances Ethel Gumm _ better known as Judy Garland _ who would have celebrated her 68th birthday Sunday. The diminutive actors and actresses will trek to Grand Rapids and walk down a yellow brick road built last year to honor Garland, who left the northern Minnesota city as a youngster and was 15 when she starred as Dorothy in the 1939 movie. She died of a drug overdose in 1969. A parade and an exhibit of private photographs of Garland are among the planned festivities as part of the weeklong Judy Garland Festival. It's touted as the largest gathering of Munchkins since Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer released the movie. About two dozen of the 124 Munchkins are still alive. ``I'm especially glad to be here with all my old pals,'' said Jerry Maren, 69, the only surviving member of the Lollipop Guild. In the movie, the three-member guild welcomed Dorothy to Munchkinland by giving her an enormous striped lollipop. The Munchkinland scene lasted only 10 minutes. But it took nearly seven weeks to shoot and helped make the movie a classic. Most of the Munchkins earned just $50 a week for their services. ``They paid Toto more than they paid me,'' quipped former Munchkin Fern Formica. Meinhardt Raabe, who played the coroner who pronounced the Wicked Witch of the East dead, said the Munchkins didn't know much about the rest of the movie while they worked. ``We didn't have the script. All we had was the script for Munchkinland. After we left, they shot the rest of the picture.'' In his book ``The Munchkins Remembered,'' Stephen Cox says gathering more than 100 midgets under one roof would be nearly impossible to repeat today. Unlike dwarfs, midgets have bodies that are proportionately correct, and advances in hormonal treatment now enable them to grow to near-normal stature. ``There just aren't enough little people any more,'' Maren said wistfully. Formica said he doesn't think ``The Wizard of Oz'' is dated. ``I think it'll be around for another 50 years,'' he said. ``I feel like someone much larger than us has had his hand on it from the very beginning.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Inches Up, Share Prices Drop
DOC.TEXT: The dollar inched up against the Japanese yen Friday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell moderately. The dollar closed the week at 152.65 yen, up 0.10 yen from Thursday's close of 152.55 yen. After opening at 152.58 yen, the currency ranged between 152.55 yen and 152.63 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 199.21 points, or 0.60 percent, closing at 32,993.29 points. The Nikkei index gained 239 points on Thursday. In the bond market, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds edged lower at 87.75 points as of 3 p.m. (0600 GMT), compared with Thursday's close of 87.94. The yield rose to 7.020 percent from the previous day's 6.980 percent. Currency dealers said the dollar-yen rate showed little change because of an absence of major market-affecting news and the approach of the weekend. ``Nothing is going on here,'' said another dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. On the stock market, the Nikkei index started moderately higher in a follow-through to Thursday's gains, but later moved lower in the absence of fresh incentives, securities dealers said. ``The market as a whole is taking a wait-and-see mood,'' said Kazuyuki Suzuki, a dealer with Daiwa Securities Co.

DOC.HEAD: Helmut Kohl Addresses Harvard University Commencement
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany urged the United States to participate actively in rebuilding Eastern Europe, and envisioned an open-border Europe in which nations had overcome ``mutual prejudice.'' In an address Thursday at Harvard University's commencement ceremonies, Kohl reaffirmed that the border between Germany and Poland should remain intact, but open. ``We Germans do not want to couple the unity of our fatherland with the displacement of existing borders,'' he said. Kohl had drawn protests when he last visited the United States early this year over his refusal to categorically rule out a shift in borders. Kohl, who received an honorary Doctor of Laws degree, said Europe and the United States needed to develop more intense political connections, possibly through new institutions, in ensuring the success of Europe's drive toward unification. ``My message today is this: German-American friendship is a decisive prerequisite for Europe and America managing to cope in unison with the tasks of the future,'' said Kohl, who meets today with President Bush at the end of a four-day visit. ``The Europeans and Americans must together elucidate their vision of a better world in which coming generations can thrive,'' he said. Kohl painted an optimistic portrait of an economically and politically prosperous Europe that could dispense with borders. ``The United States of Europe will ... form the core of a peaceful order in which the nations of the old continent finally overcome former rivalry, chauvinist thinking, and mutual prejudice,'' he said. ``Europe of the future will be a continent of diversity that affords the regions and nations new opportunities for self-development. This naturally includes above all, the protection of ethnic, cultural, and religious minorities.'' Kohl drew appreciative applause in stressing the importance of German unification for the human, political and economic gains of Europe. ``Unification of Germany will ... impart a strong impetus to the process of European integration, which will result not least in an economic upswing from which many will benefit,'' he said. Events in Europe, he said, must not distract attention from the problems of the Third World, of the need to preserve the environment and to continue to work for human rights and self-determination around the world. Harvard, the oldest university in the country, founded in 1636 and with a student body of 17,700, conferred 5,600 undergraduate and graduate degrees before an audience of more than 20,000 people. The university also conferred honorary doctorates on physicist Stephen W. Hawking, singer Ella Fitzgerald, social scientist David Riesman, poet and essayist Adrienne Rich, Nobel Memorial Prize-winning economist Herbert Simon, and Boston school principal Michael Kimbrough Marshall. Kohl's son, Walter, graduated from Harvard College in 1989. A second son, Peter, is a junior at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

DOC.HEAD: Reading, Writing Achievements Low
DOC.TEXT: Few American students are hooked on books and even fewer possess essential writing skills, according to a congressionally required study. The National Assessment of Educational Progress, popularly known as the Nation's Report Card, said few school students in grades four, eight and 12 have actually mastered reading and writing, mainly because most parents don't work with them at home and few teachers require much reading or writing in class or for homework. Even more troubling are the wide gaps in achievement between whites and minorities, said Roy Truby, executive director of the National Assessment Governing Board. The average assessment on the writing test for 12th-grade blacks is only slightly better than the average for fourth-grade whites; Hispanics are nearly as low. On the reading exam, on the other hand, which was primarily multiple-choice, the average black or Hispanic 12th grader performed at about the same level as the average for eighth-grade whites. This has been the pattern in many previous exams. ``No student should be allowed to go through the education system without mastering the essential skills of reading and writing,'' said Christopher Cross of the Education Department, which released the study. ``The data underscore the urgent need for parents and teachers to foster essential literacy skills through daily practice,'' Cross said. Key results were: _The average reading proficiency of schoolchildren increased substantially from grade four to grade eight, and somewhat less dramatically between grades eight and 12. In general, students appeared to have great difficulty with explaining what they had read, but less difficulty with questions asking about overall meaning and specific details. _Students reported doing very little reading in school and for homework. At all three grade levels assessed, 47 percent to 61 percent reported reading 10 or fewer pages each day for schoolwork across the curriculum. _Sixty-nine percent of the fourth graders reported watching three hours or more of television each day, while less than half, 46 percent, reported reading for pleasure on a daily basis. _About one-third of the eighth and 12th graders reported that they never discuss reading at home. These students had significantly lower reading proficiency. _Eighth-grade English teachers reported that 45 percent of their students wrote papers of a paragraph or two weekly, and only 14 percent wrote a one- or two-page paper each week. Only 6 percent wrote papers of three or more pages each week. Truby said the 1988 assessment data released Thursday was based on different tests than those reported earlier for measuring trends. The writing assessment gave students more time to write out some of their responses _ up to 30 minutes in some cases, instead of the previous 15-minute limit. Truby said the longer format in the writing test raised the average performance result for white students, but had little effect on the scores of blacks and Hispanics. ``As a result, the racial gap appears wider on the writing exam than on other NAEP assessments.'' The study also found that children who had preschool classes in reading scored higher than those who did not but the racial gap is slightly greater for those with preschool experience than for those without. NAEP released the first reading and writing reports in January. The two studies present additional findings from a national sample of 13,000 students in reading and 20,000 students in writing, as well as information from fourth-grade reading teachers and eighth-grade writing teachers.

DOC.HEAD: Belushi's Boxers on Charity Auction Block
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Maron cq in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: A 1965 Volvo, boxer shorts and Blues Brothers suits, hats and eyeglasses are among a wide assortment of the late comedian John Belushi's possessions going on the auction block Saturday. ``We have all kinds of personal memorabilia: clothing, photographs, autographs, artwork, guitars, movie scripts, you name it,'' said Maron Matz, spokeswoman for Leslie Hindman Auctioneers, an auction house normally reserved for more staid sales of fine art and antiques. All proceeds from the auction will benefit the John Belushi Memorial Foundation, which funds the John Belushi Scholarship for aspiring actors at Second City, a Chicago comedy troupe, and the Second Chance Foundation, founded by Belushi's widow and her fiance on Martha's Vineyard, Mass. ``I've been planning to do an auction for some time,'' Judy Jacklin Belushi said in a telephone interview Thursday from Martha's Vineyard. ``It came to me slowly when people would ask me for something for various charities. When I moved one time, I realized how much stuff I had,'' Mrs. Belushi said. She mentioned her idea to fiance Victor Pisano, who liked it. Together they founded Second Chance, which they hope will fund various charities on the island, and prepared for the auction. Mrs. Belushi said she hopes to raise at least $50,000. They will keep some things, like Belushi's Jeep and souvenirs from a trip he and Mrs. Belushi took to the Orient. But the best of the memorabilia will be auctioned, Pisano said. Among the items: a 1965 Volvo given to Belushi by his wife, scripts from four movies he appeared in, and boxer shorts with the inscription ``Continental Divide,'' one of the movies. There are six suits, three worn by Belushi and three worn by Dan Aykroyd in ``The Blues Brothers'' movie. There are Blues Brothers eyeglasses and hats. There's a toy soldier painted by Belishi, hand-knitted John and Judy Christmas stockings, Hawaiian shirts, a set of golf clubs, posters, a Chicago Cubs wastebasket and a 1944 Cubs baseball. Also: unemployment insurance claim cards, a citizens' band radio, bound volumes of early National Lampoon magazines, much of his album collection, slippers, monogrammed suitcases and briefcases and a laminated column Mike Royko wrote about Belushi and signed for him. Belushi died of a drug overdose on March 5, 1982, at the age of 33. He was a favorite on NBC-TV's ``Saturday Night Live,'' where he played memorable roles as an outrageous Samurai warrior, one of the ``Killer Bees'' and a violent television commentator. Besides ``The Blues Brothers'' and ``Continental Divide,'' the Chicago native appeared in such movies as ``1941,'' ``Neighbors,'' ``Goin' South'' with Jack Nicholson, and the acclaimed ``Animal House.''

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Says Barry Open to Plea Bargain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Jury selection process to resume about 9:30 a.m. EDT; will be led.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry is ``open to talks'' on a possible plea bargain agreement in his cocaine and perjury case, Jesse Jackson says. Jackson's comment Thursday followed a lunch meeting with Barry, who later denied a report that he would announce in the next day or two that he won't seek re-election. Barry refused to discuss the meeting with Jackson as he left the federal courthouse where jury selection for his trial continued. But Barry did address the suggestion of an imminent announcement that he won't seek re-election. ``If you hold your breath, you'll die,'' the mayor said through spokeswoman Lurma Rackley. He added there was no truth to the report broadcast on a local television station. The mayor has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession, three felony counts of lying to a grand jury and one count of conspiracy. Negotiations leading to a guilty plea on one or more of the 14 charges have stalled, sources close to Barry's legal team say. But Barry ``is open to talks as opposed to a drawing-the-line situation,'' Jackson said in a televised interview after he met with the mayor. ``I am rather convinced the mayor is inclined to ... do something to break the cycle and break the tension,'' Jackson said. ''I hope it happens sooner than later.'' Barry's lawyers and the prosecutors are ``nowhere right now'' in terms of plea bargaining, one source familiar with the situation said. ``It's increasingly unlikely that we will have any agreement soon,'' said the source, speaking on condition of anonymity. Jackson associates say he has been urging Barry for six weeks not to seek re-election and to strike a plea bargain with the government. The jury selection process continued in Barry's trial, with 13 prospective jurors sent into a pool from which a panel of 12 jurors and six alternates will be chosen. The total number of prospective jurors in the pool now stands at 37. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson said he would continue the selection process through the end of next week. It likely will take that long to question over 200 prospective jurors who have filled out questionnaires for the case.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Health Officials Brand Animal Rights Activists `Terrorists'
DOC.TEXT: As animal rights activists prepared for a weekend march in the nation's capital, federal health officials turned up the verbal heat, branding as ``terrorists'' the protesters who storm research labs. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan said he refused to be intimidated by the violent tactics of some animal advocates and predicted ``they will not succeed because they are on the wrong side of morality.'' Sullivan said animal research has saved millions of lives and holds promise for new therapies to treat devastating illnesses like Alzheimer's disease. ``It would be evil to forsake animal research when lives hang in the balance,'' he said at a news conference Thursday. He said he was ``saddened and a bit angry that we have to put up with major disruptions to science by so-called animal activists who are, in fact, nothing more than animal rights terrorists.'' Medical schools are spending about $6 million annually for damage from break-ins at research labs and other disruptive activities and for tighter security, the Association of American Medical Colleges said. Sullivan said ``virtually everyone agrees that unnecessary animal research or the cruel use of animals is wrong.'' But he said such incidents are rare because of regulations that require humane treatment of animals. Activists responded that supporters of animal research were perpetuating the myth that animals must be sacrificed to improve human health. ``Responsible medical professionals should be promoting quality research and effective disease prevention, not aligning themselves with pork farmers and other industry groups whose policies erode human health,'' the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine said. The animal advocates said Sullivan was ignoring the continuing exploitation of laboratory animals that suffer while alternative, non-animal testing methods are available. Animal rights activists plan to gather in the nation's capital on Sunday to ``March for the Animals,'' which is being coordinated by the National Alliance for Animals' Educational Fund. The march will focus on all kinds of animal exploitation _ from their use in medical experiments to zoos and circuses _ and embrace varying ideologies _ from those who would protect all animals all the time to those with more moderate views. ``We try to encourage legislation to put an end to abuse of animals,'' said Rebecca McGinley, events coordinator for the march. ``There are some people who want larger cages and some who want no cages ... we want to embrace all the people who are concerned. It's not an event to force issues on people.'' Ingrid Newkirk, national director of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, said she is ``morally opposed to exploitation of any individual or group of individuals who cannot fight for themselves. ``So I believe there is always a way if you look to get information without using animals,'' she said. She said Sullivan was wrong in claiming that inhumane treatment of research animals was rare. ``We can't even get them to stop cutting off the toes of rabbits to identify them,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Teens Threatened by Pregnancies, Drugs, Violence, Study Says
DOC.NOTE: For Release 10 a.m. EDT; time set by source
DOC.TEXT: A landscape of teen pregnancies, illegal drug use and violence threatens the health and well-being of the nation's adolescents, a commission of health, medical and business leaders said today. The commission, in a report assessing the health of American adolescents, concluded that ``young people are less healthy and less prepared to take their places in society than were their parents.'' Among the troubling signs cited by the panel were: _1 million teen-age girls _ nearly 1 in 10 _ get pregnant each year. _39 percent of high school seniors reported they had gotten drunk within the two previous weeks. _The suicide rate for teens has doubled since 1968. _Teen-age arrests are up 30-fold since 1950. _Homicide is the leading cause of death among 15-19 year old minority youths. ``Unhealthy teen-agers ... are unlikely to attain the high levels of education achievement required for success in the 21st century,'' the commission's report said. ``Thousands of these young people will experience school failure, which for many will be a precursor to an adult life of crime, unemployment or welfare dependency,'' the report said. The commission was formed by the National Association of State Boards of Education and the American Medical Association to make recommendations on the role of the school and community in improving adolescent health. The 37 panel members included former Surgeon General C. Everett Koop, Pollster George Gallup Jr., former Education Commissioner Ernest Boyer, Illinois Gov. James Thompson and California school chief Bill Honig. The commission recommended that all teen-agers be guaranteed access to health services, regardless of their ability to pay. This health care should include psycho-social as well as medical services, the report said. Also, communities should set up adolescent health centers in schools or other convenient locations, financed by local, state and federal funds as well as by private money. The report did not estimate the cost for these services. It also called on schools to play a larger role in improving adolescents' health. It suggested ``a new kind of health education _ a sophisticated multi-faceted program that goes light years beyond present lectures about personal hygiene.'' Such a program should include sex education, the panel said. ``The commission calls upon this nation to recognize that adolescents will not achieve their potential if they have social, emotional and physical health problems that interfere with their learning, and that they will cost society millions of dollars in medical and social costs if they continue to engage in health-risking behaviors,'' the report said. ``The future is bleak if we do not invest more in our nation's greatest resource _ our young people.''

DOC.HEAD: Vietnamese Student Can't Graduate After Failing English Test by One Point.
DOC.TEXT: A college-bound Vietnamese high school student who failed an English test by a single point won't be allowed to graduate with her peers. No exceptions are made on the district's competency tests, which all students must pass to graduate, said Superintendent Pat Sandro. ``I'm sure people would say, `Just give her the test again,''' Sandro said. ``But if you don't have standards, where do you draw the line?'' Ngoc-Nu Lam spoke virtually no English when she arrived from her native Vietnam six years ago. She has a B average at Union High School, and has been accepted at Ferris State University, where she hoped to study computer science. The 21 year old said she canceled her order for a cap and gown for Thursday night's commencement after hearing she would not be allowed to participate. ``I would like to march with the others,'' said Lam, who also skipped an honors ceremony earlier this week in which she was to receive the Presidential Academic Fitness Award. Sandro said Lam can retake the test in August, but Lam and supporters are urging Sandro to have the test regraded or allow her to retake it immediately. They say the wait might jeopardize college financial aid, even if she passes. Peggy Chance-Hicks, a Grand Valley State University tutor who works with Lam in a bilingual student program, said Lam failed the conversational English part of the test in which students read a paragraph and rewrite it conversationally. Conversational English is one of Lam's weaknesses since her family speaks Chinese or Vietnamese at home, Chance-Hicks said. She said the way the section is graded may have an inherent cultural bias. ``When the test becomes a barrier to a student _ who through their own tenacity and self-perseverance will become a success _ then it is a problem,'' Chance-Hicks said.

DOC.HEAD: Moynihan Presents Social Security Plan at Budget Talks
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., got a mixed reception when he tried to sell his plan to cut Social Security taxes to high-level budget negotiators, participants said. Moynihan visited Thursday's sixth session of private budget talks between Bush administration officials and congressional leaders. Most of the day was spent discussing the possibility of cutting federal benefit programs in order to reduce the budget deficit, with talks focusing on technical issues. No offers were exchanged. Moynihan has proposed rolling back the 7.65 percent levy workers pay to the retirement system. He argues that Social Security builds a surplus of tens of billions of dollars every year, money that is used to shrink the apparent size of the deficit. Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, the ranking Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, said there was ``not as much positive support'' for Moynihan's plan among negotiators as he had thought there might be. He predicted the plan ``has little chance of passing'' Congress.
DOC.HEAD: New Type of Vaccine Elicits Desired Response
DOC.TEXT: A candidate vaccine produced by genetic engineering fights the virus that produces AIDS, researchers at Johns Hopkins University have reported. The vaccine uses gene-splicing techniques to produce a chain of proteins mimicking a portion of the surface of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), the cause of AIDS. Vaccines against viruses usually are made of the whole virus, crippled so that it cannot cause the disease in question, or killed virus. The Johns Hopkins team reported its work Thursday in Science, the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. The candidate vaccine was injected into eight volunteers four times over 18 months _ an initial injection followed by three boosters. At the end of 18 months, three of the eight had developed a response in which the cells of their immune systems attacked the HIV virus and the cells it infected. They did so without attacking the so-called ``innocent bystander'' uninfected cells of the immune system, a major problem in AIDS research. The test vaccine is a long way from being shown to be a possible weapon against AIDS. Further clinical tests, which could take years to complete, must be conducted before the vaccine could be used.
DOC.HEAD: Labor Secretary Meets Separately With Both Sides in Greyhound Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole has no plans to intervene in the three-month-old Greyhound strike, but has met with both sides in the dispute, now tied up in bankruptcy courts. Mrs. Dole met Thursday with Edward M. Strait, president of the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions. Last week, the labor secretary met with Fred Currey, chairman of Greyhound Lines Inc., at Currey's request, said Dale Tate, a spokeswoman for Mrs. Dole. Union leaders representing the 6,300 striking drivers were invited following the Currey visit, Ms. Tate said. It was an informational session like the Currey meeting, she said. Mrs. Dole does not plan to intervene but is keeping on top of any progress being made by the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, Ms. Tate said. Bargaining talks have not been held since early May. Greyhound, which lost $56 million in the first three months of 1990, filed for court protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy laws on Monday so that buses can continue operating through the peak summer season. On Thursday in Brownsville, Texas, a bankruptcy judge gave the bus line permission to keep paying operating expenses so buses could keep rolling. He also ordered the establishment of a creditors' committee in time for a second hearing June 28.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Lodge Protest Over Quayle Meeting with Student Leader
DOC.TEXT: China said it was indignant and lodged a protest with the United States for allowing a Chinese student leader who recently escaped after 10 months in hiding to meet Vice President Dan Quayle and testify before a Senate committee. The Chinese Embassy on Thursday called the student, Chai Ling, ``a criminal wanted by the Chinese Public Security Department.'' In a statement read by press officer Zhu Taoying, the embassy said, ``Yet Vice President Quayle chose to meet her and the Senate of the U.S. Congress brazenly allowed ... (a) forum to attack the Chinese government. The Chinese government and the people express their utmost indignation at this.'' The Chinese ambassador, Zhu Qizhen, went to the State Department Thursday to see Lawrence Eagleburger, the deputy secretary of state. The embassy charged that the United States had ``gravely violated the norms of international relations, and wantonly interfered in the internal affairs of China.'' ``We have lodged a strong protest with the U.S. government through the diplomatic channels,'' the embassy said. The Bush administration was clearly intent on according the Chinese pro-democracy protest leader a high-level welcome. Her meeting with the vice president Thursday ran almost three times its allotted 20 minutes. Ms. Ling told reporters afterwards that she had stressed the importance of Voice of America broadcasts in getting the truth to the Chinese people, and urged that the radio service's broadcast signal be strengthened if possible. She also asked that the United States link any trade concessions to improvements in China's human rights record. Ms. Ling went into hiding after Chinese troops opened fire on pro-democracy demonstrators last year near Tiananmen Square in Beijing. The Bush administration has decided to renew for another year most favored nation trade status for China, despite Beijing's continuing crackdown on pro-democracy forces. The designation means that Chinese goods exported to the United States would be subject to the lowest possible tariffs. Quayle told Ms. Ling that the United States remains ``disappointed by the lack of progress on human rights'' in China, his spokesman David Beckwith said. Ms. Ling, 24, is a former graduate student in child psychology at Peking Normal University. She has been granted asylum by France.

DOC.HEAD: Sources Say FBI Agent To Plead Guilty in Slaying of Woman
DOC.TEXT: An FBI agent faces 16 years in prison after agreeing to plead guilty to manslaughter in the strangulation death of a pregnant woman who vanished a year ago, law enforcement sources say. The sources and the victim's sister, Shelby Ward, said the agent would enter his plea next Tuesday in Pike Circuit Court. They said no charges had been filed against him. Kentucky State Police and the FBI have been investigating the disappearance of Mrs. Ward's sister, Susan Daniels Smith, who was last seen on June 8, 1989. Outraged at the plea agreement, Mrs. Ward defied prosecutors' wishes and discussed the case in detail with The Associated Press. ``I think he should have been tried for murder, because it's cold-blooded murder to me,'' she said. ``I shook my head. I couldn't believe it. ... My family's all upset about this.'' Mrs. Ward said she was told the agent ``confessed to killing my sister'' during an argument in Pikeville over support of her expected child. Mrs. Ward said her sister had told her the agent was the father. She said prosecutor John Paul Runyon, state police Capt. Gary Rose and an FBI agent told her Tuesday that the agent described in a statement how he strangled Ms. Smith and dumped her nude body off a rural coal mine road at Harmond Branch, about five miles north of Pikeville. Officials at all those agencies refused to comment publicly on reports of the plea agreement. But law enforcement sources speaking on the condition they not be identified confirmed details of Mrs. Ward's story for The Associated Press. On Tuesday, state police and FBI officials said they had found human skeletal remains at Harmond Branch. David Wolf of the state medical examiner's office said Thursday the skeleton was that of a white woman. The Williamson, W.Va., Daily News on Thursday identified the agent as Mark Putnam, who was transferred from Pikeville to Miami last year. Ms. Smith was an FBI informant for him on at least two cases, the newspaper said. Attempts to reach Putnam for comment were not immediately successful. Directory assistance in Miami had no telephone listing for Putnam. In Miami, an FBI spokesman referred a reporter to the agency's Washington headquarters when asked if Putnam was based in Miami. Greg Jones, an FBI spokesman in Washington, refused to comment on the case. When asked whether to his knowledge there had ever been a case of an FBI agent charged in a murder, he said: ``I don't believe there ever has been.'' Mrs. Ward said in an interview at her home in Freeburn on Wedneday that her sister, an eighth-grade dropout and divorced mother of two, had repeatedly requested several thousand dollars in support. ``She wanted him to leave his wife. She was threatening to tell his wife about the baby and (the agent) was scared to death,'' Mrs. Ward said. Mrs. Ward said she was told by the officials that the agent placed her sister's body in the trunk of his car and disposed of it a day later _ after he made a business trip to Lexington. ``What was so bad is when he took the body and dumped it over the hill like it was nothing,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Pop Singer Goes Home from Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Michael Jackson was released from a hospital after chest pains he suffered were traced to bruised ribs. Jackson was sent home Thursday night, said a nursing supervisor at St. Johns Hospital and Health Center. The 31-year-old entertainer, who checked into the hospital Sunday, suffered from costochondritis, or cartilage inflammation of the front part of the ribs, Dr. Mark Zatzkis said in a statement released by Jackson spokesman Bob Jones. He apparently suffered the injury during his regular Sunday two-hour solo dance session in a bedroom of his Los Angeles home. The spokesman said Jackson would return to the hospital for additional treatment.

DOC.HEAD: Patton Letter Sold for Record $17,600
DOC.TEXT: A letter from Gen. George S. Patton Jr. describing how he ordered soldiers to attack after they had chosen to retreat sold for $17,600, the highest price ever paid for a typewritten letter sold at auction. ``The interesting thing was that the simple statement on my part that they would attack removed the nervous tension,'' Patton said in the letter sold Thursday. ``It is really amazing what the determination on the part of one man can do to many thousands.'' The hand-signed letter was written from Europe in 1944 to Gen. Charles Summerall, a former Army Chief of Staff in the 1920s and one of Patton's teachers at West Point. It was sold at Herman Darvick Autograph Auctions. The letter was purchased by a private New Jersey collector who wished to remain anonymous, a catalogue said. Among letters from U.S. military leaders, only letters from George Washington have sold for more, Herman Darvick said. Seven Patton letters sold for $50,325. One item that went unsold was a handwritten 1967 letter in which Ronald Reagan admonished his then 14-year-old daughter Patti for using ``deception'' to hide her smoking. The seller, a Connecticut collector of presidential memorabilia, had set a minimum sale price of $20,000 but the bidding only reached $19,000, Darvick said. Ms. Davis, 37, sold the letter for about $5,000 to an unknown buyer who later sold it to the Connecticut collector, he said. Other items at the auction included: _Greta Garbo's last movie contract, signed in 1941 for ``Two Faced Woman,'' sold for $5,500. _A 1955 document signed by then-Emperor Hirohito awarding Japan's highest honor, the Order of the Rising Sun, to Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, sold for $8,800. _An 8-by-10-inch sketch of Mickey Mouse signed by his creator, Walt Disney, sold for $16,000. Earlier Thursday, an 1847 letter from Charlotte Bronte to the publisher of her novel ``Jane Eyre,'' sold at Christie's auction house for $52,800. Signed with the Victorian author's pen name, Currer Bell, the letter tells how she was unable to pay for the mailing of the novel's manuscript. ``If when you acknowledge the receipt of the M.S. you will have the goodness to mention the amount charged on delivery, I will immediately transmit it in postage stamps,'' she wrote. The book was published by Smith, Elder & Co. within six weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Searches for Missing Plane Near Virgin Islands
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard has begun searching the waters near the Virgin Islands for a small plane missing since Tuesday with one woman aboard. The Piper 28 aircraft was en route from the Dutch-French island of St. Martin to St. Croix in the U.S. Virgin Islands when it disappeared, Fred Farrar, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration, said Thursday night. A Piper 28 is a single-engine plane, and the distance from St. Martin to St. Croix is about 100 miles. Farrar identified the pilot as Mary Pomeroy. He said that details were sketchy but that it was believed that Ms. Pomeroy was a British noblewoman, possibly known as the countess of Malta or duchess of Malta. Reference books on the British nobility list one Rosamond Mary Pomeroy _ the sister of Thomas de Vautort Pomeroy, 10th viscount of Harberton. Reached at home on the Isle of Wight, Miss Pomeroy was surprised to learn she was feared to be missing at sea. She said a woman who once lived with a cousin of hers on another Caribbean island legally took the name Pomeroy decades ago, but she had no idea if this was the missing pilot. ``It's absolutely nothing to do with our family, the Harberton family, because we would know,'' Miss Pomeroy said. ``Unless it's this woman who took the name by deed poll when she was living with as cousin of mine in St. Kitts and Nevis, at least 30 years ago.'' The missing airplane left St. Martin about 3:05 p.m. Tuesday, flying under visual flight rules, Farrar said. The pilot radioed about seven minutes later that she was in level flight at about 4,500 feet, and that was the last transmission from the plane. A squall line had been reported between St. Martin and St. Croix about that time, Farrar said. The search did not begin until Wednesday because it was initially reported that the plane had turned back to St. Martin, Farrar said. Coast Guard helicopters, a C-130 airplane and a cutter searched an area about 40 miles from St. Martin but found nothing, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dog Returns from Retirement To Find Missing Girl
DOC.TEXT: A retired police dog that had helped save six people and arrest more that 100 people returned his nose to service long enough to help find a missing blind and deaf 3-year-old. ``It brought tears to my eyes to get that kid last night,'' deputy sheriff Michael Bushman of Manitowoc County said Thursday. ``I truly believe that, had that child been out overnight, she would have succumbed to exposure.'' Angela Bolle, who has Down's syndrome, wandered away from her family's yard while playing with friends Wednesday evening. About 100 deputies and volunteers were unsuccessful searching nearby woods with two other dogs. As daylight faded, searchers summoned Duke, an 8-year-old German shepherd that retired two years ago because of waning stamina. After sniffing for 40 minutes, he caught the girl's scent and found her lying face down and crying in a hay field 600 feet from the house, Bushman said. ``The dog caught wind of her about 100 feet away. I didn't see her until I was standing over the top of her,'' he said. ``He went right in and started licking her face. His tail was wagging about a mile a minute. ``He likes kids a lot.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Suffers Fatal Heart Attack Trying To Aid Stricken Friend
DOC.TEXT: Two 77-year-old men died of heart attacks within minutes of each other as one was trying to help his stricken friend, authorities said. William Detrick died Wednesday after collapsing in the driveway of his neighbor, Jack Shearer. Detrick and his wife, Betty, had been summoned by Sarah Shearer after her husband suffered a heart attack while sitting on his front porch, said Detrick's son, William, of Cincinnati. Mrs. Detrick called an ambulance after her husband collapsed. ``When we got there, we found two people with cardiac arrests, instead of one like we thought,'' an unidentified paramedic told the Beaver County Times. The couples had been close friends for many years, said William Detrick.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rejects Challenge to Census Adjustment
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge rebuffed a group of states and cities led by New York City that challenged Commerce Department guidelines for deciding whether the 1990 census should be adjusted to compensate for any undercount. Judge Joseph McLaughlin upheld the guidelines, which the group, including New York state, Los Angeles, California and other governments, had argued were biased against the very idea of a statistical adjustment. The census is intended to reach and count every person. But critics argue that distrust and fear of government among some minority groups, particularly immigrants and the poor, ensure they will be undercounted. McLaughlin said the guidelines were not biased, but said some of the criteria ``lend themselves easily to abuse.'' He warned he would not tolerate any ``backdoor attempts'' by the Commerce Department, which runs the Census Bureau, to make an unfair decision about whether to adjust the count. The census is used to decide the amount of federal aid each city and state gets. It also determines representation in Congress and state legislatures. The general counsel of the Commerce Department, Wendell Willkie II, said his agency was ``extremely pleased'' with the judge's decision. Under the guidelines upheld by the judge, it is up to the secretary of commerce, Robert Mosbacher, to decide whether to make the statistical adjustment. The guidelines do not set technical standards but state, among other things, that an adjustment must not violate the U.S. Constitution. The Commerce Department must decide for or against adjustment by July 15, 1991. State Attorney General Robert Abrams said his department had wanted the guidelines struck down, but said ``we are nevertheless heartened by his stern warnings to the department that a decision not to adjust will be closely scrutinized.'' Mayor David Dinkins, who has said the guidelines all but precluded an adjustment, said he hoped the Commerce Department would fulfill its obligations for a complete count. ``It is an especially heavy burden because it is impossible for the department to explain why a census intended to count every American fails to count so many,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Working To Meet Sundown Deadline
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Shamir aide's comments, radio pulling back, details. No pickup. Changes byline.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir was ironing out last-minute obstacles to forming a narrow right-wing government today and hoped to meet a sundown deadline, an aide said. If Shamir manages to pull together a right-wing Cabinet, it would replace the coalition between his Likud bloc and the center-left Labor Party that collapsed more than 2{ months ago. Israel radio reported early today that Shamir had apparently pulled together a coalition. Later, however, its reports became less certain as meetings dragged on between the prime minister and potential coalition partners. Likud officials said Shamir had support from 62 members of the 120-seat Parliament, but news reports said last-minute differences with ultra-Orthodox religious parties could upset the coalition. Shamir spokesman Yossi Ahimeir said Shamir, who is caretaker prime minister, expected to sign a coalition agreement with at least eight small far-right and religious factions in his office later today. With firm agreements, Shamir would be able to fulfill the legal requirement of informing President Chaim Herzog that he has a government. Then a vote could be scheduled in the Knesset, or parliament, to install the new Cabinet. If Shamir succeeds, the Knesset would likely be convened on Monday. The 42 days given Shamir to form a government technically end at midnight, but the Jewish Sabbath begins at sundown. The coalition agreement was being held up by a disagreement between two religious parties _ the National Religious Party and the ultra-Orthodox Degel Hatorah _ over control of the Religious Affairs Ministry. Another ultra-Orthodox party, Shas, or the Torah Guardians, was given the Interior Ministry but asked for one more important Cabinet post. It reportedly rejected the Economy Ministry as not prestigious enough.
