National Religious Party leader Zevulun Hammer came to Shamir's office today and said he would discuss his differences with Degel Hatorah. The state-run radio reported that key posts in the new Cabinet have already been assigned. It said the Foreign Ministry would be headed by David Levy, now housing minister and a chief rival to Shamir for leadership of Likud. The defense portfolio would go to Shamir's closest ally, current Foreign Minister Moshe Arens, it said. Former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon will get the Housing Ministry and head a group of ministers dealing with immigration, the radio said. Sharon, as defense minister in 1982, engineered the invasion of Lebanon. In the last election in November 1988, Likud won 40 seats and Labor 39, forcing them into a so-called National Unity Government despite their deep philosophical differences. The coalition collapsed in a parliament vote of no-confidence on March 15 after Likud rejected Labor's demand to accept a U.S. proposal for peace talks with Palestinians. News reports have said the 74-year-old Shamir would prefer another coalition with Labor. In a right-wing government, he would be squeezed between U.S. pressure to move forward with the peace process and the far-right's refusal to do so. After the government's collapse, Labor leader Shimon Peres failed in a 35-day effort to form a left-leaning government. Shamir was given the mandate on April 27. The delicate coalition bargaining has involved a number of small parties, each with different views. The National Religious Party and Shas each have five seats in the Knesset, and Degel Hatorah has two. The lengthy bickering has raised demands for political reform to end the system under which tiny parties hold the balance of power. Late Thursday, police clashed outside the prime minister's office with protesters shouting they wanted an end to ``political extortion.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher, Gold Steady
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was higher against key currencies in European trading this morning. Gold was steady in moderate trading. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 152.65 yen, up 0.10 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted a 153.27 yen. Yuichi Tsuchiko, a dealer with Fuji Bank in Tokyo, said the dollar moved little throughout the day's trading. He said even inter-bank trading was scarce. Tsuchiko said the market is watching for a series of economic data to be released next week by both Japan and the United States. Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday: _1.6922 West German marks, up from 1.6913 _1.4433 Swiss francs, up from 1.4385 _5.7010 French francs, up from 5.6993 _1.9075 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9028 _1,244.00 Italian lire, unchanged -$1.1745 Canadian, up from $1.1678 The British pound was quoted in London at $1.6880, unchanged from late Thursday. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommend price of 353.60 dollars a troy ounce this morning, down from $354.15 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, gold traded at $353.50, up from $353.00 bid late Thursday. Gold in Hong Kong rose 39 cents an ounce today, closing at $356.06 per troy ounce. Silver bullion was quoted in London at $5.02 a troy ounce, up from $5.01 bid late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstoms Over Midwest, Central Plains and South
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms moved into the South early today, and for the third straight day were over parts of the Ohio Valley, the central Plains and Mississippi Valley. Rain fell in the southern tip of Florida and the coastal Pacific Northwest. Showers also dampened the Great Lakes region, as a warm front moved up from the Gulf of Mexico. The front was expected to be pushed east by the jet stream and bring evening thunderstorms to much of New England. There were mostly clear skies and fair weather in the West. Early today, thunderstorms were over central Georgia and the coast of South Carolina. Thunderstorms also were over Iowa, Nebraska, Indiana and Michigan. Thunderstorms developing along a warm front produced severe weather in the central Plains and the mid-Mississippi Valley on Thursday. The storms over eastern Kansas spawned at least three tornadoes, two in Missouri, two in South Dakota Almost 1{ inches of rain deluged Max, S.D., in 30 minutes. Golf-ball size hail was reported in eastern Nebraska, eastern Kansas and southern Illinois. Winds gusted to 80 mph over central-western Iowa. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation, with sunny skies prevalent from California to the western edge of the Plains. The nation's high for Thursday was 110 degrees at Presidio, Texas. Other reports at 5 a.m.: _East: Albany, N.Y., 50 partly cloudy; Atlanta 74 fair; Boston 61 fair; Buffalo 56 cloudy; Charleston, S.C., 76 cloudy; Chattanooga 72 foggy; Cincinnati 73 partly cloudy; Cleveland 66 showers; Detroit 59 thunderstorm; Hatteras 75 foggy; Jacksonville 68 foggy; Key West 81 showers; Knoxville 69 foggy; Macon 75 foggy; Miami 81 cloudy; New York 62 fair; Philadelphia 60 partly cloudy; Pittsburgh 61 foggy; Portland, Maine 59 cloudy; Richmond 68 hazy; Tampa 72 foggy; Washington, D.C., 68 hazy. _Central: Birmingham 75 fair; Bismarck 55 fair; Denver 62 fair; Des Moines 63 foggy; Fort Worth 78 windy; Indianapolis 67 cloudy; Kansas City 72 cloudy; Little Rock 75 fair; Louisville 74 fair; Memphis 78 fair; Nashville 75 fair; New Orleans 74 fair; North Platte 63 partly cloudy; Oklahoma City 76 fair; Omaha 69 drizzle; Rapid City 55 partly cloudy; St. Louis 74 cloudy; Minneapolis-St. Paul 62 cloudy; Sault Ste. Marie 50 partly cloudy; San Antonio 78 partly cloudy. _West: Albuquerque 64 partly cloudy; Anchorage 58 fair; Boise 53 fair; Casper 44 fair; Fairbanks 54 fair; Great Falls 44 fair; Honolulu 77 partly cloudy; Las Vegas 83 fair; Los Angeles 65 partly cloudy; Medford 56 fair; Pendleton 53 cloudy; Phoenix 84 partly cloudy; Portland, Ore., 58 cloudy; Reno 63 fair; Salt Lake City 59 fair; San Diego 64 foggy; San Francisco 57 fair; Seattle 53 rain; Spokane 47 partly cloudy. _International: Calgary 54 windy; Montreal 48 partly cloudy; Ottawa 54 partly cloudy; Regina 52 showers; Toronto 55 partly cloudy; Winnipeg 54 rain; San Juan 75 fair.

DOC.HEAD: Jungle Battle Leaves at Least 48 Dead
DOC.TEXT: A battle between two jungle tribes armed with arrows, spears, machetes and poison darts in central Peru has left at least 48 people dead, authorities said. The battle, involving at least 1,000 members of the Ashaminka tribe and 200 members of the Campos tribe, took place Monday near the Andean jungle town of Satipo, about 160 miles east of Lima, Gov. Andres Galarza Flores of the Junin Department said Thursday. Witnesses said as many as 200 people died in the battle, with most of the bodies thrown into the Perene River, Galarza said. Police investigating the battle found only three bodies but confirmed that 48 people had died, Galarza said. Reports of the battle were delayed because there are no phones in the area and transportation is slow, Galarza said. The two tribes are longtime rivals and have had earlier confrontations over rights to grow coffee and coca in the area, he said. Politics also may have played a part in the battle, Galarza said. The Ashaminka are solidly behind presidential candidate Mario Vargas Llosa, while the Campos support his rival, Alberto Fujimori. Vargas Llosa faces Fujimori in a runoff Sunday. Witnesses said the battle started when a large truck entered the Ashaminka town of Yarividoni during an important tribal festival. An Ashaminka watchman found up to 200 heavily armed Campos hidden under a tarp on the truck's flatbed. Witnesses said the chief of the Ashaminka then ordered his men to attack, Galarza said. There were unconfirmed reports that both sides also used grenades, dynamite and rifles as well as their traditional weapons in the battle, which lasted more than four hours. The Ashaminkas captured 10 of the Campos, who were later turned over to police. There also were reports that militia groups from neighboring towns joined with the Ashaminka in battling the Campos. Many tribes in the region have well-organized militias. Peruvian soldiers have set them up to help tribespeople protect themselves against Maoist Shining Path rebels.

DOC.HEAD: Kansas, Missouri Hit By Tornadoes
DOC.TEXT: A tornado touched down twice, wrecking businesses and homes and blowing tractor-trailers and cars off a highway in this east-central Kansas city. At least 21 people were injured, two seriously, authorities said today. Another tornado Thursday night destroyed two homes in central Missouri. Severe thunderstorms with high winds demolished 10 small planes, damaged roofs and buildings, uprooted trees and downed power lines in central and northern Missouri. No injuries were reported in the state. The Emporia tornado tore a half-mile swath of destruction through businesses on the city's west side and another about a quarter-mile long to the northwest, police said. ``The damage is pretty severe to businesses and to the residential area on the northwest side of town,'' said Emporia police officer Laramy Bargo. Charles Brooks, a deacon at the West Side Baptist Church, said about 15 members of the church sought shelter in the church basement. When some people went upstairs to pray at the altar, Brooks said, he took a look outside. ``There was a large tornado with a large tail and we watched it go by. It looked like you could reach out and touch it,'' he said by telephone from the church basement. ``Then we came inside and gave a good thanks to God for our safety.'' A 4-month-old girl and her father were critically injured in their home, said Emporia Police Capt. Bob Rodriguez. He said the man was trying to bring his daughter to safety when they were hit by flying debris. Nineteen other people were injured and treated at Emporia hospitals, said Kristy Kelley, a Lyon County Sheriff's dispatcher. She said about 25 homes and two businesses were damaged in the county. A gas station was destroyed, but three employees who hid in a bathroom were not injured. Only two walls of the bathroom were left standing. A nearby rental business, a car dealership and a restaurant were among buildings heavily damaged. Authorities said the roof of a Coca-Cola bottling plant caved in, damaging trucks and trailers. Three employees who took cover in an inner room escaped injury. Police said one semi-trailer traveling south on the Kansas Turnpike was knocked over. The tractor was found 100 yards from its trailer. Injuries to the driver were unknown. Two people in another semi were hurt when their vehicle was knocked off an Interstate 35 bypass, authorities said. About 2,500 Emporia customers were without electricity, said Tom Taylor, spokesman for KPL Gas Service. The National Guard was activated, and 25 troops guarded damaged areas. Shelters were opened. In central Missouri, a tornado destroyed two homes in Moniteau County, deputy sheriff Russell Borts said. Other homes and outbuildings in the area also were damaged. The deputy said a second tornado touched down south of High Point, but there was no damage. A storm earlier Thursday demolished 10 planes and damaged six others at the Spirit of St. Louis Airport in Chesterfield. The wind also tore the roof off a hangar, causing an estimated $250,000 damage, said the building's owner, Barry Stone. Single-engine aircraft outside were strewn about. Some were tossed upside down and others were severely damaged. Dick Hrabko, director of aviation for St. Louis County, said the storm moved in about 4 p.m. with winds clocked up to 100 mph. Storm winds also tore the roof off school offices in Wright City in Warren County, uprooted trees and damaged roofs and buildings in St. Charles and damaged some buildings in the Earth City area.

DOC.HEAD: `Elliot Loves,' A New Play by Jules Feiffer, Opens Off-Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS last 8 grafs with other New York critics' reviews. Will stand for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: Boy, that Elliot sure has problems with women. And he's not shy about revealing them _ at least not to a theater audience. They are chronicled in exhaustive detail in ``Elliot Loves,'' Jules Feiffer's self-absorbed comedy-drama about the never-ending struggles between male and female. The play, starring Anthony Heald and Christine Baranski and directed by Mike Nichols, opened Thursday at off-Broadway's Promenade Theater. It's a disappointment, considering the stature of the playwright, the cast and the director. What starts out as a promising look at how the sexes survive each other, turns into a narrowly focused and theatrically static evening about some not very nice or even interesting people and their not very nice or interesting problems. Feiffer's dialogue is flip and occasionally very funny. His characters make wry, witty observations, almost too witty to be real. The one-liners would be more at home in the playwright's brilliant weekly comic strip than in a full-length play. Feiffer's hero is a fortyish, Chicago polltaker, divorced and trying to establish a relationship with Joanna, a slightly ditsy but accommodating woman. ``I'll never do better. She's good for me,'' he tries to tell himself and us in the play's opening monologue. If only he'd listen to himself. But Elliot has hangups about love, not to say guilt about establishing a commitment to someone new. ``The distance between what I need and what I'm getting is love,'' he theorizes. It's that distance or gap that Elliot focuses on, the one thing in his less-than-satisfactory life that has quality, shape and substance. To validate his relationship with Joanna, Elliot takes her to meet his three best friends. She charms them but not before old wounds are opened up and the men reveal their bitterness about women and each other. The unlikely buddies include a recovering alcoholic, a black editor at Playboy and a misogynistic accountant who has had the pleasure of driving his spouse's car over a cliff. How he survived is a question the play doesn't address. The party ends disastrously with Elliot verbally attacking the alcoholic, the nicest and weakest of his three friends. It seems inconsistent with his personality which, until then, has been morose but not malevolent. The boyish Heald is miscast as the guilt-ridden Elliot. There's no sense of worry in his performance. He seems foolish rather than frantic. The sexy, personable Baranski exudes a flaky likability as she prepares for the dinner party and nervously tries to memorize details about the men she is about to meet. Bruce A. Young, Oliver Platt and particularly David Pierce as the sad sack alcoholic offer some strong support. Latanya Richardson is wasted in an unnecessary role as one of the men's wives. Nichols' direction is determined, not letting the play's momentum falter until the very end. Part of that motion is due to designer Tony Walton's stylish set of a high-rise apartment that spins with great ease. The play's final scene is a tedious telephone conversation between a drunken Elliot and Joanna as they try to patch up their tattered relationship. It nearly stops the play dead, as Elliot keeps reiterating his love for the protesting Joanna. After a while, you want to shake the self-centered man and tell him to get on with his life. That's because there's a lingering suspicion the only person Elliot really loves is himself. The reviews by New York newspaper critics were generally poor. Most scribes were put off by the characters and the letdown after an excellent opening monologue. Frank Rich in the New York Times, Howard Kissel in the Daily News and Linda Winer in New York Newsday all disliked ``Elliot Loves.'' Clive Barnes of the New York Post enjoyed it. ``Feiffer asks theatergoers to spend an evening with empty characters without offering the payoff of insight,'' said Rich, adding that he found the play ``bleak and unsatisfying.'' If ``Elliot Loves'' were as compelling, as entertaining, as thoughtful as its opening monologue, it would be altogether remarkable,'' wrote Kissel. ``There's enough material in the monologue to make a harrowing and wonderful play. The heartbreak is that somehow, that play never got written,'' Winer opined. Rich, Kissel and Winer all thought the acting was superb. In the Post, Barnes raved: ``Elliot Loves''..., in its comparatively modest sketch-like way seems totally successful, not to mention hilarious. I promise you, you will laugh and laugh.''

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Gives Los Angeles County 20 Days to Plan Redistricting
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge gave Los Angeles County 20 days to submit a plan for remapping districts to give Hispanics more representation, but did not rule whether Tuesday's election results will stand. U.S. District Judge David Kenyon on Thursday warned he will ``do whatever is necessary'' to devise a redistricting plan if the Board of Supervisors fails to meet his June 27 deadline. ``I do believe time is important here,'' he declared. Supervisor Mike Antonovich, who attended the federal court hearing, told reporters 20 days was insufficient time to hold public hearings on the issue. Antonovich is one of the board's conservative majority which voted to appeal Kenyon's decision mandating new districts. Hispanics make up an estimated 35 percent of the county's 8.7 million people, but no Hispanic has been elected to the board since 1875. Liberal supervisors have called for a settlement that would increase the number of districts and supervisors to offer more representation. Kenyon did not rule whether Tuesday's election results in two supervisor races should be voided. But he remarked, ``The court would note that none of the candidates ran without full knowledge that this lawsuit was pending.'' On Monday, the day before the election, Kenyon found the five board members had conspired to ``protect their incumbencies and that of their allies'' when they redrew the county's five voting districts in 1981. The lawsuit, filed in August 1988, charged that the supervisors deliberately spread the county's Hispanic population across several districts when they changed voting boundaries following the 1980 federal census. Attorneys for the American Civil Liberties Union and the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, which joined the U.S. Justice Department lawsuit on the matter, said Kenyon's order put those results in doubt. ``Obviously the implication is that Tuesday's election doesn't really mean anything,'' said Richard Fajardo, a MALDEF attorney. ``Remember, that election took place under an unconstitutional plan.''

DOC.HEAD: NASA Cancels $700 Million ``Space Tug'' Program
DOC.TEXT: NASA has scrubbed a $700 million program to build an orbital ``space tug'' designed to service satellites, including the Hubble Space Telescope. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said ``budgetary pressures'' and the lack of a ``firm near-term requirement'' for the spacecraft influenced its decision. William B. Lenoir, NASA's associate administrator for space flight, said the space tug ``eventually will be needed in our space infrastructure, but we will have at least two or three years to develop firm requirements before it will be necessary to begin development.'' The agency did not cite what budget constraints compelled it to cancel the program. The tug, or ``orbital maneuvering vehicle,'' was to have been a remote-controlled, reusable spacecraft performing satellite service and retrieval missions. In addition, NASA planned to have the vehicle periodically boost the Hubble Space Telescope into a higher orbit around Earth. Begun in the 1980s, the project employed 280 people at TRW Inc.'s Space & Defense Sector facility in Redondo Beach, said company spokeswoman Julie Meier Wright. The company's portion of the program totaled $400 million. Workers will be reassigned at the facility, which employs 17,900 people, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Warsaw Pact, Declaring `Enemy Image' Over, Begins Transformation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with NATO comment, INSERT 2 grafs after 2nd pvs, `After meeting...' Pickup 3rd pvs, `Members of...'
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the Warsaw Pact say they want to change the Soviet-led alliance from a military to a political body by this fall, reflecting the reduced East-West tensions in Europe. After meeting Thursday in Moscow, the pact leaders declared their ``readiness for constructive cooperation'' with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. NATO foreign ministers, concluding two days of talks in Scotland, today welcomed the statement by their longtime rival. ``We are ready to contribute actively to building confidence and closer relations between all European countries, including the members of the two alliances,'' a NATO statement said. Members of the Kremlin-led Warsaw Pact alliance also discussed various roles for a united Germany in Europe, said Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Yuli Kvitsinsky, but he indicated there was no agreement. The members said they favor the formation of a new, ``all-European security system and the creation of a single Europe of peace and cooperation,'' without artificial barriers and ``ideological hostility.'' ``Participants in the meeting are unanimous in their opinion that the ideological enemy image has been overcome by mutual efforts of the East and the West,'' the declaration said. The Warsaw Pact meeting came as the old structure of the 35-year-old alliance is crumbling in the wake of last year's democratic upheaval and the ouster of hard-line Communist regimes in Eastern Europe. In light of the changes, it has become necessary ``to reconsider the character and functions of the Warsaw Treaty,'' the members said in their declaration. New proposals on such a transformation will be drawn up before the end of October. Soviet and East European sources familiar with the thinking of government leaders have said that the envisioned new structure of the pact would be patterned roughly after the NATO secretariat and council in Brussels, although no firm plans have been disclosed. Warsaw Pact members include Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary, Poland, Romania and the Soviet Union. The declaration said a commission will work out proposals on transforming the alliance before the end of October, and the Political Consultative Committee _ the group that met in Moscow Thursday _ will examine them before the end of November. Despite statements before the meeting by Hungarian Prime Minister Jozsef Antall that he wants to remove his country from the alliance, Kvitsinsky said ``there wasn't a single statement made relating to a wish to quit'' the pact. Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel, too, said upon returning to Prague that he stressed that his country should remain in the pact in order to oversee its transformation. Pact members also heard a detailed report by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on his Washington summit last week with President Bush. Havel and his foreign minister, Jiri Dienstbier, also indicated there was no agreement on future security arrangements for a united Germany. The Soviets oppose NATO membership for a united Germany, and Gorbachev and Bush failed to resolve their differences over the issue last week.

DOC.HEAD: Museum Warns of Federal, State Aid Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Black was the color of national Arts Awareness Day at the Fuller Museum of Art. Staff members wore black Thursday, and they used a black band to cordon off an exhibit of pieces loaned by Boston's Museum of Fine Arts. The idea, they said, was to warn that the museum may not be able to afford some exhibits if federal and state funds are cut back or eliminated. The cordoned-off gallery, now showing classical furniture borrowed from the Boston museum with money from the National Endowment for the Arts, will be closed if grants stop, the museum said. Fuller officials said the museum will have to cut its staff or operating hours if its allocation from the Massachusetts Cultural Council is cut from the $30,000 this year to $15,000 next year as the Massachusetts House has recommended. ``We feel a sense of loss,'' said James Keneklis, director of the Fuller. ``Our demonstration is in support of the NEA and a request to Congress to renew its five-year term without limiting funding.'' Bills have been introduced in Congress and the state Legislature that would prevent the National Endowment for the Arts and the Massachusetts Cultural Council from making grants to institutions exhibiting art considered obscene or offensive.

DOC.HEAD: Building Will Be Lit Lavender To Honor Gays
DOC.TEXT: The top 30 floors of the Empire State Building will be lit with lavender lights in honor of Gay Pride Weekend later this month. The Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation said it has lobbied the management of the 102-story-tall building for the past six years to have the landmark building illuminated in honor of their cause. ``Everybody is going to look up that weekend (June 22-24), gay and straight, and they will see that New York City is recognizing the existence of the gay and lesbian community,'' said Tom Lynch, a member of GLAAD. Owners and managers of the building issued a statement on the decision: ``We are in total agreement with ... leaders who seek to end the bigotry and discrimination directed against gay and lesbian New Yorkers. We hope our participating will help end the type of ignorance that breeds this mindless prejudice.'' Gay Pride Weekend includes the city's second largest parade, which draws about 150,000 marchers. The 102-story building is illuminated in various colors associated with specific holidays, such as red, white and blue for the Fourth of July, Labor Day, Presidents' Day and Veterans Day, and green on St. Patrick's Day. Lavender was chosen for Gay Pride Weekend because it is the traditional color of the gay and lesbian movement.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Ambassador Calls on Aoun to Step Down
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Ambassador John McCarthy urged rebel Gen. Michel Aoun to step down and recognize the government set up last year under an Arab League peace plan, a newspaper reported today. The forces of Aoun and militia chieftain Samir Geagea skirmished today with mortars and machine guns in East Beirut. Police said one erson was wounded by sniper fire in the Ashrafiyeh district before the exchange ended. The fighting violated a shaky cease-fire that was called May 17 to halt more than four months of intra-Christian clashes for dominance of a tiny enclave northeast of Beirut. The power struggle between the rival Christian forces began Jan. 30 and has killed 1,036 people, wounded 2,772 and forced about 40 percent of the Christian enclave's 1 million population to flee their homes. Th newspaper Ad-Diyar reported that McCarthy said he told President Elias Hrawi in Cairo early this week of the U.S. administration's ``support for the legal Lebanese authority to enable it to carry out its responsibilities.'' Hrawi was elected president Nov. 24 in line with an Arab League-brokered peace accord to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. The peace plan was worked out by Lebanese legislators in the Saudi resort of Taif in October. Aoun has rejected the Taif accord because it does not contain a specific timetable for the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon, and he has refused to recognize Hrawi as head of state. Geagea, who heads the Lebanese forces militia, has recognized Hrawi's authority and voiced cautious support of the peace plan. ``The United States still supports the Taif accord and sees it as a pressing need that Aoun should step down,'' McCarthy told Ad-Diyar. Aoun has refused to withdraw from the presidential palace in Baabda, east of Beirut. Hrawi has been forced to set up headquarters in Moslem west Beirut. ``I don't mean by stepping down that Aoun should leave Baabda only. He also should recognize the legal authority and join the national reconciliation march provided by the Taif accord,'' McCarthy said. McCarthy and his American staff evacuated the U.S. Embassy in Beirut's northern suburb of Aoukar Sept. 6 after pro-Aoun youths besieged the compound protesting alleged American opposition to their leader. McCarthy met Hrawi in Cairo during an Arab tour by the Lebanese president that also took him to Libya and Tunisia. Aoun's control of about 40 percent of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave has prevented Hrawi's Syrian-backed government from spreading its authority to the disputed sector. McCarthy said continuation of the present situation in Lebanon would lead to ``further fragmentation (of the nation), inter-communal clashes and more refugees.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Horse Hits Car Door; Driver Saddled With Ticket
DOC.TEXT: A man whose car door was flattened by a police horse says it was the last straw when he got a ticket for obstructing traffic. Kirk Hudson, 27, was parked at a meter in downtown Detroit on Feb. 8 when he opened the driver's side door of his Honda Civic and, ``there was this blur of brown hair and a black boot going by and I heard `crunch, pop,' and the hinge popped out of my door and the door was flattened against the car.'' Magistrate Thomas Shannon of 36th District Court dismissed Hudson's $70 ticket Thursday after a police witness failed to appear. Hudson said his insurance company paid the $1,700 in damages, calling it ``an act of God.'' Hudson said Officer Paul Priemer, a member of the Detroit Police Mounted Section, shouldn't have tried to ``skinny his horse,'' Ollie, between the cars. Priemer, who said Hudson should have looked more carefully, said his boot and Ollie's chest got caught on the door. ``It scared me,'' Priemer said Thursday. ``It scared the horse. Either this horse is powerful, or that door is real cheap.''

DOC.HEAD: Pope Calls Ukrainian Summit Inviting Clandestine Bishops
DOC.TEXT: For the first time since the Ukrainian Catholic Church was banned more than four decades ago, its clandestine bishops will meet with the pope later this month, it was announced Friday. Pope John Paul II set the meeting for June 25-26 to discuss efforts to legalize the church and recover its lost property, the Vatican said in a statement. The 10 Ukrainian Catholic bishops living in the Soviet republic will be joined by the 18 Ukrainian prelates living in the West, said Rome-based Ukrainian Cardinal Myroslav Lubachivsky in a separate statement. ``This will be the first meeting between the pope of the universal church and the Ukrainian Catholic hierarchy from the Ukraine since the Ukrainian church was liquidated ...in 1946,'' Lubachivsky said. The suppression was carried out by dictator Josef Stalin, who forced the Ukrainian Catholics to merge with the Russian Orthodox Church. Bishops and priests who resisted were shot or imprisoned. According to Western estimates, there are 4 million to 6 million Catholics in the Ukraine. Until recently, they practiced their faith clandestinely but in the past few years many have emerged to worship openly and demand official recognition. The Ukrainian issue was one of the topics discussed when Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met with John Paul in December in the first visit of a Kremlim chief to the Vatican. Gorbachev pledged enactment of a law guaranteeing freedom of conscience in the officially atheist country, which would pave the way for legalization of the Ukrainian church. The bill is slowly working its way through the Soviet legislature. Since Gorbachev's visit, the Ukrainians have regained many churches and the faithful have been registering with authorities parish by parish in anticipation of full legality. Lubachivsky said the 10 Ukrainian bishops were all consecrated clandestinely. Only in the past two years have some of their names been made public. Talks bringing together officials of the Vatican, the Ukrainian and the Orthodox churches broke down in March when Ukrainian leaders complained that Moscow was dragging its feet on the freedom of religion law. But the Ukrainians have said they are prepared to go back to the negotiating table. The return of church property is a major stumbling block because the Orthodox stand to lose hundreds of churches they took over after 1946. The Vatican statement, issued by papal spokesman Joaquin Navarro, said the Vatican hopes the meeting will ``contribute to the solution of still existing difficulties in the Ukraine.'' It referred to the Ukrainian Church as a ``meritorious'' church that has given ``heroic testimony of its Catholic faith in particularly difficult circumstances.''

DOC.HEAD: AP Names Two New Special Correspondents
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press today named two new special correspondents, the wire service's top designation for its writers and reporters. They are Tad Bartimus and Nancy Shulins. In the history of the AP, only 14 other AP staffers have been designated special correspondent. ``Tad and Nancy join a special group of AP people whose talent represents the best of the AP _ fine writing supported by intense reporting, a combination that produces memorable news copy,'' said Louis D. Boccardi, president and general manager of the news cooperative. Bartimus, 42, won the Associated Press Managing Editors Top Performance Award in 1988 for her story about three young Missouri brothers who drowned. The story also was a finalist in the Pulitzer Prize feature category. She was one of a team of AP reporters who covered the Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska, a state where she earlier worked as AP's bureau chief. Shulins, 35, has written stories about such diverse topics as women of the Ku Klux Klan, excessively aggressive children and the Hmong people of Cambodia who resettled in the United States after the Vietnam War. She earned a 1983 Clarion Award from Women in Communications, Inc., for her KKK story. Bartimus, a native of Belton, Mo., joined the AP in Topeka, Kan., in 1969 following graduation from the University of Missouri. She transferred to Miami later that year, and in 1973 went to Saigon to cover the war in Southeast Asia. She was named correspondent in Anchorage, Alaska, in 1974, and the following year became AP's first Alaska bureau chief. In 1977 Bartimus returned to the foreign service in London, where she reported for two years. She then became a roving reporter covering Central and South America during 1978-79. For that work, she received a special Tom Wallace Award from the Inter American Press Association, an award named for that organization's first U.S. president. Later in 1979 she returned to Topeka and from there covered stories in the Midwest and West. Her base of operations shifted to Denver in 1981, and she was named Mountain States regional reporter when the AP established a six-person team of regional writers in 1985. Shulins, a native of Hanover, N.H., began her AP career in Montpelier, Vt., in 1976, after working as a reporter for the Lebanon, N.H., Valley News. She was named correspondent in Montpelier in 1978 and correspondent in Evansville, Ind., the following year. Shulins became a member of the AP's national reporting team, based in New York, in 1981, and the following year moved to AP Newsfeatures, where she has written enterprise stories aimed at Sunday newspapers. Bartimus and Shulins join six active AP special correspondents: Vice President Walter R. Mears, who writes a poltical column from Washington; Jules Loh, Hugh Mulligan and Saul Pett, all AP Newsfeatures writers; Mort Rosenblum, based in Paris, and George Esper, the AP's New England regional reporter based in Boston. The other special correspondents were: photographer Eddie Adams, now a free lancer; Peter Arnett, now with CNN; Will Grimsley and John Roderick, both retired, and the late John Hightower, Relman Morin, William L. Ryan and Don Whitehead.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Militants Assassinate Relative of Indian Minister
DOC.TEXT: Three Moslem militants shot and killed the uncle of India's home minister at his home in the disputed Kashmir Valley, authorities said today. Ghulam Hassan Shah, an uncle of Home Minister Mufti Mohammad Sayeed, was killed Thursday night in Bijbiara, 25 miles southeast of Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir state and a stronghold of Moslem secessionists. Shah was one of several relatives whom Sayeed had evacuated to New Delhi last winter, fearing they would be targeted by Moslem militants seeking independence for Jammu-Kashmir. Shah, 62, returned to Bijbiara a week ago because of his concern for the well-being of a son who had stayed behind, according to the neighbors who spoke on condition of anonymity. Sayeed's daughter, Rubaiya, was kidnapped by Moslem separatists in Srinagar in December and held hostage for six days until the government freed five members of the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for Shah's slaying. Neighbors said he was killed by militants who came to his house about 9 p.m. Thursday. A similar account was given by a state police spokesman in Jammu, the state's winter capital. A retired state tax officer, Shah was especially close to Sayeed, one of the most prominent Moslems in Prime Minister V.P. Singh's government. The kidnapping of Sayeed's daughter shortly after Singh took office spurred new government tactics in Kashmir, culminating in a harsh military crackdown on the escalating Moslem separatist movement. At least 504 people have been killed in Kashmir since the crackdown started Jan. 20. The majority have been Moslem militants and their supporters slain by Indian security forces. The crackdown has sparked tensions between India and Pakistan, which has supported its fellow Moslems in Jammu-Kashmir. Jammu-Kashmir is the only state in predominantly Hindu India with a Moslem majority. About 64 percent of the 6 million inhabitants are Moslem. Nationwide, Moslems make up only 12 percent of India's 880 million people, while Hindus account for 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush `Couldn't Care Less' About 65th Birthday
With PM-Bush Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf pvs, bgng: ``Mrs. Bush... '' with 4 grafs to add details on Bush call; picks up 5th graf pvs, bgng: ``Reading to...''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush marked her 65th birthday today doing what she loves best: pushing literacy and reading aloud to children. Seated amid about a dozen children on ABC-TV's ``Good Morning America'' show, the white-haired first lady read the story ``Leo, the Late Bloomer,'' about a lion who was slow to learn to read and write, and was rewarded with a chorus of ``Happy Birthday, Mrs. Bush.'' ``Oh, how'd you know?'' she asked. ``Who told you that secret? Thank you very, very much.'' President Bush telephoned birthday wishes to his wife today from Iowa, wrapping up a four-state political trip. ``I did talk to Barbara this morning. She seemed unexcited about her 65th birthday,'' he said. Later, the National Pork Producers' Council gave Bush a a box of pork chops and several bags of pork rinds, a favorite snack. ``Maybe that's what I'll give to Barbara for her birthday present,'' he quipped. Mrs. Bush said Thursday she ``couldn't care less'' about the milestone. Reading to children, Mrs. Bush said, is ``about the most important thing parents can do.'' She cited studies finding that children who were read to at home do better in school, and said she and her husband read regularly to their children when they were young. ``It was a chance for us to put an arm around a child and have a special time,'' she said. ``It does a lot for bonding with your children and it pays off later.'' Mrs. Bush, a longtime crusader for literacy, planned to read again later to second graders at a library in nearby District Heights, Md. President Bush, in a political fund-raising speech in Chicago on Thursday, said he had just been on the phone with ``tomorrow's birthday girl, the one who did so well at Wellesley'' College in her commencement speech there last week. As she left an event honoring children who read hundreds of books to raise money for the March of Dimes, Mrs. Bush groaned when asked about her birthday. ``Ohhhhhh!'' she said, as if hammered by a verbal blow. But she quickly added with a laugh: ``I couldn't care less. No, I have no feelings about it.'' She is coming off perhaps the most celebrated event in her 15 months in the White House: last week's televised commencement address at Wellesley with her Soviet counterpart, Raisa Gorbachev, at her side. The first lady's speech was made more dramatic by a student protest beforehand questioning whether George Bush's homemaker wife was a suitable role model for the graduates of the elite, career-driven college. But Mrs. Bush, with liberal doses of wit and candid advice about putting family ahead of job advancements, won cheers for her speech. Crowds in Wellesley gave a tumultuous welcome to both first ladies. ``I had a very good week, and I plan to have a great week next week, too,'' Mrs. Bush told reporters. ``I felt all of America had a great week last week,'' she said, reflecting on the recent superpower summit. ``I was really proud of the Wellesley girls and Boston,'' she said. ``I was really proud that we could show Raisa that kind of (welcome). The only problem was she wanted to thank each one personally.'' Mrs. Bush draped ribbons around the necks of local March of Dimes' ``reading champions.'' The top reader was Nicholas Daly, 9, of Beltsville, Md., who read 435 books in a single month. The drive raised more than $14,000 to warn women about the dangers of drugs, alcohol and cigarettes during pregnancy. Mrs. Bush, saluting the youngsters at a ceremony at The Washington Post, said, ``You've shown us once again that everyone, no matter how old or young, or how small their allowance, everyone has something very precious to share with others. ``Because you've been willing to share your precious ability to read, our babies will be born into a brighter world,'' she said. President Bush, who turns 66 next Tuesday, was in Des Moines, Iowa, today bound for Omaha, Neb., before returning to the White House this evening for dinner with Mrs. Bush and visiting West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Mrs. Bush has two more commencement speeches to give: one at Kennebunk High School in Maine on Sunday and the other at Dunbar High School in Washington next week. She was born June 8, 1925, in New York City.

DOC.HEAD: Thomas R. Sheridan, Former Aide to Robert Kennedy
DOC.TEXT: Thomas R. Sheridan, a prominent trial lawyer who served as a special assistant to U.S. Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy, has died of a heart attack at age 60. Born in Boston, Sheridan graduated from Catholic University in Washington, and earned a law degree at the University of California, Los Angeles. He began his career as a trial attorney in the Justice Department's antitrust division and later headed the criminal division of the U.S. attorney's office in Los Angeles. Kennedy, then attorney general, appointed Sheridan his special assistant in 1962. In 1965, Sheridan was named general counsel and executive director of the McCone Commission, created to investigate what set off rioting in the Watts area of Los Angeles and to make recommendations to avoid future violence. Sheridan entered private practice in 1965. Among his clients was C. Arnhold Smith, a San Diego millionaire who was convicted in 1975 of making illegal campaign contributions. Survivors include four sons, two brothers, two sisters and two grandsons.

DOC.HEAD: Court: Feds Can't Seize Drug Property From Unwitting Owner
DOC.TEXT: The seizure of a 4,600-acre ranch used as a landing field by drug traffickers has been reversed by a federal appeals court, which ordered the property returned to the innocent owner. When marshals moved against the Tucker Ranch east of Lake Okeechobee in September 1988, U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen hailed it as part of the largest drug-related propety seizure in the nation. But the Tucker family vigorously fought the action, saying they had no way of knowing their tenant, Frank Brady, was using the land for illegal purposes. On Wednesday the seizure was dismissed by the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. Robert T. Godley, a senior vice president for the First Union National Bank of Florida, the current trustee for the property, applauded the decision. ``It's been very tough,'' Godley said. ``In our quest to end the drug problem in this country, laws are being passed and citizens are being denied their civil rights. We were guilty until proven innocent. It's a bit of anarchy.'' No one disputed the ranch was used as an airstrip by Brady, a Medellin drug cartel smuggler who was sentenced to 10 years in prison in 1986. Brady flew marijuana into the country from the Bahamas; at one point, he was listed as one of the FBI's 10 Most Wanted. But Brady only rented part of the ranch, and the Tucker family, which was never implicated in the case, said it was unfairly penalized. Their attorney, Edward A. Marod, argued the owners had done everything possible to prevent illegal activity on their land short of sealing it from the air with barbed wire. In August 1989, Miami U.S. District Judge Edward Davis sided with the Tuckers. The judge ruled he was unwilling to require majority shareholders to walk thousands of acres ``to assure themselves that no illegal activity is taking place.'' The U.S. attorney's office appealed Davis' decision. Last week, however, it reversed its stand and asked for the dismissal. Lehtinen's office had no immediate comment on the case. The dismissal clears the way for a sale arranged more than a year ago. Martin County property records show the land is worth about $7.3 million. Federal law enforcement officials defend their practice of seizing property used for drug smuggling and called it ``one of the most effective tools in the war on drugs.'' ``If a landowner allows drug smuggling on his property, people have to just face that the consequences can be devastating,'' said Paul Miller, spokesman for the FBI in Miami.

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll Climbs in Kirghiz Unrest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs with state of emergency in Uzbekistan and appeal by president of the republic. EDITS thereafter to conform. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A state of emergency was declared in eastern Uzbekistan today because of ethnic warfare over the distribution of plots of land, and the president of the republic asked the Kremlin to help settle the conflict. The Soviet news agency Tass said five days of clashes between ethnic Uzbeks and Kirghiz in Kirghizia have left at least 78 people dead and 330 wounded. On Thursday, dozens of people in Uzbekistan crossed into neighboring Kirghizia, and one person was killed and 33 injured in fights, a Soviet Interior Ministry spokesman said on condition of anonymity. Uzbek President Islam Karimov declared the state of emergency for the region near the Kirghiz border and sent an urgent telegram to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warning that the violence could cause open conflict between the two republics, Tass said. Karimov called on the Kremlin to dispatch a government commission, headed by a member of the Politburo and including deputies of the Supreme Soviet legislature, to assist in ending the strife. A state of emergency already is in effect in the Kirghiz border city of Osh, where the fighting broke out on Monday, and in Kirghizia's capital, Frunze. Residents of the two densely populated Soviet republics have been fighting each other in a dispute over the allocation of plots of land. The Interior Ministry spokesman said more than 3,000 Kirghiz youths in Frunze demanded today to be allowed to go to Osh, 195 miles south. Tass quoted Col. Felix Kulov as saying the situation remained tense near Osh. The area is closed to Western correspondents, and official accounts of the unrest and the death toll have been sketchy. Tass said thousands of police and soldiers have been sent into the region. On Thursday, Interior Minister Vadim Bakatin told lawmakers in Moscow that 1,500 soldiers, 900 police and Interior Ministry troops and 450 border guards were in Kirghizia in an attempt to quell the fighting. Authorities declared the emergency in Frunze after cars were destroyed and thousands of people surrounded Communist Party and government buildings. The protesters demanded the resignation of the republic's leaders within three days and urged Kirghiz to unite and strike back at Uzbeks, Tass reported. Tass said 249 houses and 40 cars had been burned in the fighting and that police had confiscated 79 guns. The sequence of events in Kirghizia has been similar to other outbreaks in past months in the heavily populated, poverty-stricken region of Central Asia: a local dispute _ in this case, conflicting claims by Kirghiz and Uzbeks to private plots _ unleashing pent-up fury between the ethnic groups. The Uzbeks and the Kirghiz are predominantly Sunni Moslem ethnic groups that speak different Turkic dialects. Abdurakhim Pulatov, one of the leaders of the Uzbek popular movement, Berlik, said Thursday that refugees were ``telling horrible stories about how Kirghiz are destroying the Uzbek population.'' He said Berlik and the Uzbek government were trying to appeal to Uzbeks in Kirghizia to defuse the crisis, but added, ``It's hard because the people are already in the streets. This should have been done a week ago.''

DOC.HEAD: Committee Hears Super Collider Suggestions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `billion billion' is correct in next-to-last graf
DOC.TEXT: Some of the world's top physicists savored the possibility today of making the ``Siberian snake concept'' and shooting subatomic particles underground to Arkansas with the planned superconducting super collider. Somewhat like selecting options for a new family car, members of an advisory committee are soliciting project suggestions for the atom smasher, scheduled to be built south of Dallas. Fourteen groups representing more than 1,500 scientists began their presentations Thursday and continued today. ``Some of the best physicists in the world are obviously eager to go,'' said Roy F. Schwitters, director of the SCC laboratory. When completed, the 53-mile particle accelerator is expected to confirm many theories about matter and energy while disproving others. Murdock Gilchriese, of the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, in Berkeley, Calif., said the competition that opened Thursday is exciting for those involved because it brings them so much closer to the work they believe will reap great discoveries. ``It's essentially the same reason people climb mountains _ to see what's over the hills,'' Gilchriese said. Schwitters said that completion is at least eight years away, adding that it's ``too soon to say'' how much the total cost will be. Current estimates are about $8 billion. The project passed a critical test Thursday when a House subcommittee in Washington unanimously accepted the White House's spending recommendation of $318 million for the super collider. The experimental programs being touted in Dallas by representatives of the 14 groups not only included recommendations for possible experiments, but concepts for detectors that can record results of experiments. More than 100 people, including many of the world's leading physicists, listened as the presentations unfolded Thursday. The proposals will be evaluated by the advisory committee during the summer and the fall. The committee will make its recommendations Nov. 1-3. Alan Krisch of the University of Michigan led off Thursday with a pitch to include spin-correcting devices in the collider. He stressed the importance of considering the rotation of the protons as they are shot at around the giant ring. Under the proposal from Krisch's group, a series of eight half-meter-long magnets would be placed every 3 kilometers. At each point, the magnets would force protons to flip over 180 degrees. ``Whatever imperfections there are in the facility would cancel each other out,'' explained Krisch. The technique is called the ``Siberian snake concept,'' and one of its creators, Y. Derbenev of the Soviet Union, will soon be conducting research at Ann Arbor, Mich., alongside Krisch. Another group wants $150 million to search for the Higgs particle, which has eluded scientists so far. Group spokesman Dick Lander said the particle's attributes have been predicted by many, including namesake Peter Higgs, and the super conductor has been designed to be large enough to find one. ``If it exists, it should show up as a particle that decays into four other particles. It's almost guaranteed the way the theory is written that we'll find it,'' he said. ``If we can't find it, the theory can't survive.'' Lander said a planned accelerator in Europe also was designed to be large enough to look for the Higgs particle. ``It's a race for the Higgs,'' he said. Michael Lieber of the University of Arkansas said his group wants the committee to consider equipping the super collider with the capability of shooting a stream of neutrinos to Arkansas. ``They would shoot 20 billion billion neutrinos per pulse, and we would stop about a million of those,'' Lieber said of a planned neutrino detector 200 meters in diameter. It would be placed in a lake near Hot Springs, Ark. The experiment would try to determine if and how neutrinos change as they travel. Lieber said scientists ultimately would like to know why only about a third of the neutrinos shot earthward from the sun actually make it here.

DOC.HEAD: Gang Members Shoot From Limousine While Returning from Funeral
DOC.TEXT: Gang members returning from a friend's funeral allegedly used two rented limousines in a drive-by shooting that wounded one man, police said. The unidentified man was treated for a gunshot wound to the foot at Brotman Medical Center in Culver City after the 2:30 p.m. Thursday shooting, Sgt. Bob James said. James said no arrests were made immediately, but the limousines were impounded and the drivers questioned and released. ``These drivers don't know what these people are doing,'' James said. ``These people are in the back partying. The drivers don't know what's going on.'' On Tuesday, gang members opened fire from a limousine and killed 19-year-old Robert Lewis Riley Jr., police said. Both shootings were under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Clears Police Officers in Shooting of Bank Robber
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury rejected a convicted bank robber's lawsuit for $10 million in damages from injuries she suffered in a shootout with police after she and her boyfriend pulled off the heist. The U.S. District Court jury deliberated less than three hours Thursday before exonerating four members of an elite police unit in the Sept. 15, 1982 shooting of Jane Berry. Assistant City Attorney Victoria Chaney called the verdict ``a signal to other people that they should think carefully about filing lawsuits against police officers who place their lives on the line every day dealing with very dangerous situations.'' Berry, 43, had sought $10 million in damages in her civil rights suit against members of the Special Investigations Section. She is serving a 15-year sentence in state prison. Berry testified she never heard police order her to freeze after she and her boyfriend, John Crumpton III, robbed a Security Pacific Bank branch in Burbank. She also disputed officers' claims that she reached for her gun moments before she was shot. Crumpton, 33, died of 38 bullet and shotgun pellet wounds. Berry received 14 shotgun and pellet wounds.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to restore paragraph marker in 2nd graf
New Government Would Crack Down on Uprising, Step Up Settlements
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with reaction from pro-PLO activist, Peres, quotes from new coalition's policy guidelines, other details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today announced the formation of a new right-wing government that pledged to ``uproot'' the Palestinian uprising and expand Jewish settlements in the occupied territories. A leading Palestinian activist immediately criticized the new coalition's policies, calling them ``obstacles in the way of peace.'' Shimon Peres, leader of the rival left-center Labor Party, predicted the coalition would be beset by infighting. Today's coalition agreement would give Shamir 62 votes in the 120-member Knesset, where a vote approving the government could come as early as Monday. Shamir's announcement came after he signed an agreement with a string of far-right and religious factions, plus a defector from the Labor Party. The formation of the new government, the first to be fully controlled by Shamir's Likud bloc since 1984, breaks a 3-month-old political deadlock. Close election results since 1984 had forced Likud and Labor into power-sharing arrangements, but ideological differences often paralyzed political action. A Likud-Labor ``unity'' government fell apart March 15 in disagreements between the two parties over whether to take part in U.S.-proposed peace talks with Palestinians. After the government's collapse, Peres failed in a 35-day effort to form a left-leaning government. As legally required, Shamir telephoned President Chaim Herzog to report the formation of the new coaltion. The announcement came only hours before his 42-day mandate for forming a government ran out at sundown with the beginning of the Jewish Sabbath. The new government's expected hard line on the 30-month-old Palestinian uprising and its plans to push for more settlements of Jews in the occupied lands were likely to exacerbate tensions with the United States. Washington has been urging Israel to make concessions to Palestinians to revive the stalled peace process. On the uprising, the coalition pledged to ``to uproot the phenomenon of violence and disturbances and create tranquility in all parts of Israel.'' Faisal Husseini, a leading pro-PLO activist in the occupied lands, said after the announcement: ``We believe the next few months will be hard ones.'' ``There will be more obstacles in the way of peace,'' he said. The new coalition's policy guidelines oppose the formation of a Palestinian state and renew Israel's refusal to talk with the Palestine Liberation Organization. They insist on the right of Jews to settle in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, saying the government will ``act to strengthen, expand and develop the settlements.'' Arab countries have claimed that Israel will settle many of the thousands of Soviet Jewish immigrants in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Ariel Sharon, a leading right-wing figure, was reported to be in line to become housing minister and thus would be in charge of the settling of Soviet immigrants. After the announcement, Sharon was asked about settling Soviets in the territories. ``Israel is a democratic country. Everyone can settle where he wants,'' he replied. Peres said on Israel radio that opposing views of the many coalition partners were likely to split the new government. ``Most of the time and energy will be spent in holding it together instead of advancing the state,'' he said. The delicate coalition bargaining involved a number of small parties, each with different views. The lengthy bickering raised demands for political reform to end the system under which tiny parties hold the balance of power. Shamir, asked if Cabinet posts had been assigned, replied: ``Not yet.'' But reports said Likud hard-liners would be in charge at the key ministries. Israel army radio said Housing Minister David Levy would become foreign minister and the present foreign minister, Moshe Arens, would be defense minister. Besides Likud, the coalition partners include three right-wing parties, three religious ones, two one-man factions and lawmaker Ephraim Gur, who quit the Labor Party on Thursday. News reports had suggested Shamir would have preferred a coalition with Labor, but he said on army radio he did not expect the rival party to join the new government now. ``At this stage it is not realistic,'' he said. In the last election in November 1988, Likud won 40 seats and Labor 39, forcing them into a so-called National Unity Government. Shamir alluded to that failed government as he announced the formation of the new coalition. ``I pray that national unity will exist in this government that we are forming today and that all of us will act together ... for the Israeli people and the land of Israel,'' he said. Radio reports said the government's guidelines include various promises to meet demands of the small partners. One promise, intended to satisfy ultra-Orthodox parties, says the government will press to outlaw the sale of pork in Israel in line with Jewish dietary strictures.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says More Info Sought On Palestinian Attack
With PM-US-PLO
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III today said Washington is seeking more information on a foiled Palestinian raid along the Israeli coast before deciding whether to cut off talks with the PLO. Last week's attempted raid ``has to be taken very seriously,'' Baker said, but he added that ``some perspective and responsibility is required in dealing with the issue.'' Baker, responding to reports that a cutoff in talks was imminent, told reporters the talks are continuing while the administration seeks to find out ``all we need to know'' about the circumstances. He declined to say what information was still lacking. Baker made his comments during a news conference at the conclusion of a two-day NATO foreign ministers meeting in Turnberry. Israel and some U.S. lawmakers have demanded that the Bush administration break off the 16-month-old direct contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization because its chairman, Yasser Arafat, has refused to condemn the attempted raid by a PLO faction on May 30. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, in a separate news conference, said ``a break in the dialogue would be a real setback'' to peace efforts in the Middle East. ``I am very keen that he (Baker) and the U.S. administration should remain directly engaged. That is crucially important.'' But Hurd also urged Arafat to be ``more precise and specific'' in condemning the attempted raid. Israeli forces foiled the raid on the beaches of Tel Aviv and the Palestine Liberation Front, a wing of the PLO, claimed responsibility. The attack followed the slaying 10 days earlier of seven Palestinian laborers by an Israeli the government described as deranged. Since then, the Bush administration has weighed whether to suspend the talks with the PLO that in December 1988 after Arafat renounced terrorism.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Ambassador To Fiji Killed in Car Crash
DOC.TEXT: Japanese Ambassador Toshio Isogai was killed when his car hit a utility pole while apparently trying to avoid a cow that had strayed onto a road, embassy officials said today. He was 62. The accident occurred late Thursday night near the town of Sigatoka, in the west of the main island, Viti Levu, the officials said. The embassy said the ambassador's wife, Toshiko, was not injured. The couple's personal chef, Takashi Tabata, suffered a broken leg. Isogai was born Aug. 24, 1927, in Okayama in western Japan. He graduated from the Agriculture-Fisheries College of Tokyo University in 1953 and entered the Foreign Ministry in 1956. He served as consul general at the Japanese Consulate in Seattle from December 1982 to December 1986, when he was named ambassador to Fiji. In addition to his wife, Isogai is survived by a son.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Leader Calls for Continued Sanctions, Also For Future Aid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to CORRECT that Mandela turns 72 next month, sted 72 now. Pickup 4th graf ``Given the...''
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela said today that South Africa will one day need massive Western financial aid to help its people but that economic sanctions should be maintained until the white government scraps apartheid. The black nationalist leader, who underwent surgery last week to have a benign cyst removed, canceled a morning meeting with Red Cross officials due to fatigue, a Red Cross spokeswoman said. However, Mandela, who turns 72 next month, spoke later to the International Labor Organization. ``Given the fact that apartheid has not ended, it is only logical that we should continue this weapon of struggle,'' Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, told the annual meeting of the 150-nation U.N. body. In the future, he said, the South Africa economy will need ``massive international intervention if we are to move forward at a pace that recognized the urgency of the needs of our people.'' Mandela, freed in February after 27 years in prison, concluded his speech by talking of a ``glorious vision of South Africa free of racism ... no longer the skunk of the world.'' Mandela says other countries should not lift their restrictions on trade and investment to South Africa despite an announcement Thursday by South African President F.W. de Klerk to drop repressive state of emergency measures in three of the nation's four provinces. The apartheid system still deprives the nation's 28 million blacks of a say in the government, while the 5 million whites control the economy and maintain separate services. Mandela received a thunderous ovation from more than 2,000 delegates crowding the assembly hall of the United Nations headquarters in Geneva. The International Labor Organization expelled South Africa 25 years ago because of its racial policies. The organization sets international standards for working conditions, but the standards are non-binding and must be ratified by individual governments. Mandela canceled a morning visit to the International Committee of the Red Cross because of ``fatigue,'' a Red Cross spokeswoman said. Catherine Pelissier said Mandela had been due to hold private talks with Red Cross chief Cornelio Sommaruga. However, Mandela kept a lunch appointment at the International Labor Organization and was expected to address the World Council of Churches later. Mandela is on a six-week trip to Europe and North America. He will stay in Switzerland throughout the weekend before continuing to West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher, Gorbachev Meet on European Security
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Gorbachev comments. Pickup 6th graf pvs, `Yesterday, I...'
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that NATO and the Warsaw Pact alliances should be cooperating with each other in the same way that European leaders from both blocs have been in close contact. ``If the leaders of the governments cooperate on the political level, these organizations can't stand aside from their governments,'' he said at a joint news conference with visiting British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Mrs. Thatcher said she did not think the time was right for a system of all-European security _ a plan that would end the division of Europe into competing military alliances. Gorbachev said he differed with Mrs. Thatcher on this poit. ``One can have the policy that will resemble an elephant in a china store: One move to the left smashes half of the store. A move to the right smashes the other half,'' he said. ``If this is the policy we choose, I don't envy us.'' Both alliances were created to provide security, he said. ``In the period of the Cold War, they reached this using one method,'' the Soviet leader said. ``In the period of the construction of the common European home, they should use other methods.'' Earlier, aides to Mrs. Thatcher said that after her consultations with Gorbachev, she felt increasingly confident that the East-West standoff over Germany would be resolved ``without ultimatums or deadlines.'' The leaders discussed a nine-point U.S. proposal aimed at easing Soviet concerns about a united Germany belonging to the NATO alliance, said British officials, speaking on condition of anonymity. The plan would allow Soviet troops to remain temporarily in what is now East Germany and keep Western forces out. ``The prime minister felt encouraged,'' the British official said. ``The whole issue of East-West relations is evolving. ... People have not adopted fixed positions.'' As he greeted Mrs. Thatcher in his office at the Kremlin, Gorbachev said he still felt jet-lagged from his U.S. visit. ``Yesterday, I almost fell asleep during the Warsaw Treaty meeting,'' he joked, referring to a summit meeting in Moscow of the now dying Warsaw Pact, the military alliance of the Soviet Union and its former Communist allies. But Thatcher aides said that during the 2{-hour private talks before lunch, Gorbachev showed no sign of weariness or despondency over his mounting domestic problems. ``He was cheerful, ebullient and confident throughout,'' said a British official, speaking on condition of anonymity. Mrs. Thatcher arrived Thursday at the start of a four-day visit. She was to hold separate talks later today with Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov and Defense Minister Dmitry T. Yazov. She and Gorbachev met as both the Warsaw Pact and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization wrestled with the need to find new roles. At a meeting in Moscow Thursday, the seven-nation Warsaw Pact said it needed to transform itself into a political body and sought ``constructive cooperation'' with the 16-member Western alliance. NATO foreign miisters met Thursday and today in Scotland, also trying to work out new stances before a special summit meeting in London in July. Both the East and West blocs are seeking to increase the role of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe as a new pan-European forum. It comprises all the countries of Europe, except Albania, as well as the United States and Canada. Mrs. Thatcher leaves Moscow Saturday to visit a British trade and cultural exhibition in the Ukraine capital, Kiev. On Sunday she goes to a part of Armenia that was devastated by an earthquake 18 months ago.

DOC.HEAD: Cleanup Resumes, First Mate of Grounded Tanker Arrested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with cleanup efforts today. Picks up 6th graf, `Football-sized blobs ...'; INSERTS 1 graf after 9th, `The first ...' to ADD captain's name and urine tests conducted for him. Edits next-to-last graf to conform.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NR1
DOC.TEXT: Cleanup crews labored to corral blobs of oil floating on the waters of the Kill Van Kull today after officials arrested the first mate of the British-operated tanker that spewed 260,000 gallons of heavy oil. Authorities charged the first mate of the 811-foot tanker BT Nautilus with operating a vessel under the influence of alcohol or drugs. The Kill Van Kull and the Arthur Kill, a second shipping channel between New Jersey and New York, have had four major oil spills this year. The Coast Guard said the quick deployment of absorbent boom shortly after the accident at 5:15 a.m. Thursday contained nearly all of the No. 6 heating oil in the normally busy channel, which remained closed indefinitely. About 300 workers, including 50 sailors, and six vessels from the Coast Guard, resumed cleanup operations this morning. Five skimmer boats cruised the channel collecting oil, and a special Coast Guard strike team brought in 10 small boats for maneuvering in small coves. Football-sized blobs were found as far away as the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, about three nautical miles from the spot where the tanker struck bottom as it was docking, said Coast Guard Lt. Cmdr. Paul A. Milligan. Oil leaked for about five hours from one of the tanker's 10 1.2-million-gallon holds, the Coast Guard said. Divers found a gash about 30 feet long and 12 to 16 inches wide in the ship's No. 4 tank, but the Coast Guard had not determined the cause of the rupture late Thursday night. New Jersey Gov. Jim Florio called the spill ``inexcusable,'' saying it indicates that ``something is dramatically wrong with the way the petrochemical industry does business.'' The first mate, Gregory Frederick Geoffrey, 52, of Merkse, England, was released on $50,000 bail from police custody in Bayonne Thursday night. He pleaded innocent to state charges of operating a vessel under the influence of alcohol or drugs, and negligent discharge of a pollutant without a permit. Urine tests were conducted for the ship's captain, identified by the Coast Guard today as Albert Ainscough, and the harbor pilot brought aboard for docking. Coast Guard officials had no further information about the crew. Christopher Florentz, a spokesman for Attorney General Robert J. Del Tufo, could not say if Gregory used drugs or alcohol, or what led to his arrest about 4 p.m. Thursday. ``I believe he was the spotter, so he was up front,'' Florentz said. But Geoffrey's lawyer, Richard F.X. Regan, said the first mate's responsibility during docking was to remain on the forecastle, not to act as spotter. ``It appears that my client is really a scapegoat ... for what appears to be an accident,'' Regan said. The Coast Guard said the cleanup team included guardsmen from Mobile, Ala., who were deployed on skimmer boats and vacuum truckers to shovel, rake and sop up the oil. About 27,000 feet of floating booms were already on the water. Coast Guard Rear Adm. Richard Rybacki said the tanker owner, Nautilus Motor Tanker of Gibraltar, has assumed responsibility for the cleanup. The tanker is operated by Bulk Tanker Management of London and registered in Hong Kong.

DOC.SECOND: PM-2 Live Crew, 2nd Ld - Writethru, a0535,0819
DOC.HEAD: Civil Libertarians See National Effect from Obscenity Ruling
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with record store owner being arrested, quotes from him and sheriff's spokesman. Picks up 8th graf pvs: `The recording ...'
DOC.TEXT: A judge's obscenity ruling against a 2 Live Crew rap album has no legal effect outside south Florida, where a record store owner was arrested today, but civil libertarians see a practical effect spreading nationally. ``This does pose a real threat that the amount of obscenity actions may increase around the country,'' New York attorney Floyd Abrams, a First Amendment expert, said Thursday. ``It is a direct threat to freedom of expression in the arts, as well as in music in particular.'' U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez ruled Wednesday that the lyrics of the Miami group's sexually explicit album ``As Nasty As They Want To Be'' are obscene, leaving area retailers liable for arrest for sales of the platinum-selling record. Today, a Fort Lauderdale area record store owner was arrested on an obscenity charge after selling the album. Broward County sheriff's deputies arrested E-C Records owner Charles Freeman at his store less than three hours after he received a shipment of 25 copies. ``America is free, free for everybody,'' Freeman said. ``And as long as this is America and I'm not living in Cuba, I feel my rights are violated.'' An undercover officer went in to buy copies of the record and tape, then uniformed officers entered the store to make the arrest. ``I would have to say that the research and the consultation that we were doing has apparently been concluded and we're prepared to enforce it,'' sheriff's spokesman Jim Leljedal said minutes after the arrest. Before authorities arrived, Freeman said he had sold all but six copies of the recording. He said a line had formed outside the shop in anticipation of the shipment's arrival. ``I'll go to jail, and I'll come back and sell it again,'' he said before deputies arrived. ``I opened up a record store three years ago expecting to sell records and this was the furthest thing from my mind.'' Asked why he would challenge the ban, Freeman explained: ``I'm a small independent. All my money is going to be made on R&B and rap, so it'll hurt me in the long run.'' The recording industry generally favors warning stickers on album covers to bring attention to lyrics that some might consider objectionable. But Michael Greene, president of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, said he hoped the specter of censorship raised by the Fort Lauderdale ruling would act as a unifying force. ``This ruling, alongside the chilling lyrics legislation which is making the rounds through the statehouses nationwide, must serve as a call to mobilize all who value basic artistic freedom and who are willing to tenaciously fight for the protection of First Amendment rights,'' Greene said. Bruce Jesse, vice president of advertising and sales promotion for the 265-store Wherehouse record store chain based in Los Angeles, concluded, ``You're putting the retailer at a significant risk.'' But Bruce Fein, former counsel general of the Federal Communications Commission, saw a limited impact, saying, ``I don't think this sets a nationwide precedent that will cause all off-color rock music to be banned.'' Supplies of 2 Live Crew's disputed record dried up in South Florida as the obscenity case was argued, but the decision is widely expected to boost sales elsewhere. ``The lesson of history has always been, if you tell people you can't have anything, they want it all the more,'' said Nova University law professor Bruce Rogow. He represented 2 Live Crew in its lawsuit against Broward County Sheriff Nick Navarro over his threat to prosecute retailers. The decision had no effect on the group's plans for two shows Saturday night at Club Futura in nearby Hollywood. Club owner Kenneth Gerringer told City Council members Thursday that the opening show would be a tame performance for all age groups, and he would ask the rappers to shun explicit lyrics in the later adults-only show. Ten uniformed police officers will be working inside and outside the club, primarily for crowd control, said Paul Dungan, administrative assistant to the police chief, who was out of town. ``We're handling this as if Michael Jackson were coming to town, or Dean Martin or any of the top stars,'' he said. ``I would not advise officers to go up on the stage and arrest four people in front of 1,000 people.'' But Mayor Sal Oliveri gave Gerringer a stern warning to pass along to 2 Live Crew, saying, ``Artist or no artist, I don't want Hollywood to have the reputation, in my opinion, that we have obscene entertainment.''

DOC.BYLINE: Former Church Treasurer Denies Wrongdoing ^By DEBORAH BAKER
DOC.TEXT: Clyde Womer says he wasn't trying to hide _ not from the police, not from the wife and five children he abandoned, not from his past. If he had been trying to hide, the fugitive New York church treasurer says he would never have lived in Taos. This village in the mountains of northern New Mexico _ 3,700 people in the town limits and another 6,000 on the outskirts _ is a major tourist mecca. Its streets are clogged already with swarms of summer visitors marveling at the azure sky, bright sunshine, some 80 art galleries, historic Indian Pueblo and shops, all sculpted in adobe. It was tourism that did Clyde Womer in. A visitor from New York wandered into the J.C. Penney store on Taos' main street and recognized Womer as the man who police say fled Suffern, N.Y., eight years ago with $267,000 from Christ Church of Ramapo, N.Y. He was to be returned to New York today to face charges of grand larceny brought in 1982 by a Rockland County grand jury. He's to be arraigned Monday. Womer was known here as Lawrence ``Howie'' Krantz. He often visited the J.C. Penney store managed by his second wife, Betty Sutton. He strolled the town plaza, where ``He'd always strike up conversations with the police,'' police Officer Gabriel Medina said. ``We've had a wonderful time here,'' Womer said Thursday in an interview at the Taos County Jail. ``I had nothing to fear. I went everywhere, did everything.'' The bearded, gray-haired Womer acknowledged transferring money from church accounts to his own accounts. He said he did so for reasons he cannot disclose, but he denied stealing the funds.
