He said he felt all right about leaving his wife and children because after years of commuting into New York City, he had become estranged from them. ``I was the outsider. I was ready to leave,'' he said. He said he committed only two crimes: applying for a New Mexico driver's license under a name that wasn't his own and committing bigamy. ``I'm sorry for the hurt that I've caused other people,'' he said. Ms. Sutton refused to be interviewed, saying only, ``I've had a bomb dropped this week.'' Taos police say she apparently knew nothing of his past and faces no charges. She said Wednesday she was aware the man she knew as Krantz had been married before and had five children but that she had been told his first wife died of cancer. The two married in 1984. Suffern police detective Sgt. Leo Costa, who was in Taos, said Womer's first wife now lives in Colorado Springs, about 200 miles to the north, and her children are grown. He said she was upset when she learned he was married in New Mexico. Costa said she had been in the process of filing papers to declare her husband dead so she could receive Social Security. The Rev. John Andrews, rector of the Episcopalian church in Suffern, flew to New Mexico to identify Womer. He said the day Womer disappeared he discovered Womer wrote two checks totaling $165,000 on church accounts. He said he had personality conflicts with Womer and had wanted him relieved as treasurer but had no idea money was missing.

DOC.HEAD: Police Suspect Animal Rights Activists in Bomb Attack
DOC.TEXT: A veterinarian employed by the Ministry of Defense escaped injury when a bomb exploded underneath her vehicle, and police said Friday that their investigation centered on animal rights groups. The explosion occurred Wednesday as Margaret Baskerville, who works for the Chemical Defense Establishment, was backing her car away from her home at Winterslow, a suburb of Salisbury. ``It has now been established the explosion was caused by a device fitted underneath the vehicle,'' Inspector Graham Chivers of the Wiltshire police said Friday. No group claimed responsibility. The Chemical Defense Establishment uses animals _ primarily mice and guinea pigs _ in tests of protective measures against chemical and biological agents.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Sees Beginning of End of Cold War
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 1 graf after 9th graf pvs, bgng: ``But despite...'' to add quote on PLO; picks up 10th graf pvs, bgng: ``Later, Bush...''
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today that despite improving relations between the United States and Soviet Union, ``we cannot lose sight of the differences that remain between our two countries.'' He heralded ``the beginning of the end of the Cold War'' in the wake of his summit meeting last week with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. But one problem that will not be ``solved quickly or easily'' is the future of a unified Germany, Bush said before heading home from a Midwest swing to consult in Washington with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. ``The question of a unified Germany is not one that will be solved by the United states alone,'' Bush told a fund-raising breakfast for Republican Gov. Terry Branstad. ``In the final analysis, it's a question for the people of Germany to decide. But the United States remains committed to German membership in NATO,'' Bush said. The Soviet Union is opposed to having a unified Germany in NATO. Bush also renewed his call for the Soviets to establish peaceful dialog with Lithuanian leaders to resolve the tumult in that Baltic republic. Bush touted the five-yearcognized people whose homes he had stayed in during early campaign trips. On Friday the president returned as a major drawing card for GOP candidates. Mary Matalin, Republican National Committee chief of staff, said Bush's current political speaking trip is raising millions for GOP candidates. His visits are following a usual formula: He speaks at a breakfast, lunch or dinner that usually costs up to $1,000 per ticket. Then, for amounts ranging from $2,000 to $5,000 apiece, depending on the locale and the race, supporters can meet the president at a private reception and have a picture taken. Matalin said Bush will take time out from campaigning in July because of the NATO summit in London and the economic summit in Houston, and will vacation in Kennebunkport, Maine, for much of August. But he will be campaigning nearly nonstop in September and October. Bush, himself a former RNC chairman, has even suggested trips himself that party officials haven't recommended, Matalin said. For instance, she told reporters, Bush wanted to do a fundraising stop on Thursday in Milwaukee for Gov. Tommy Thompson even though Thompson is far ahead in the polls and RNC officials felt he didn't need the help. On most political stops, Bush also appears at a ``presidential'' event _ so that part of the cost of the visit can be defrayed by tax dollars. Thus, in addition to his stop here to speak for Branstad, Bush spoke with Iowa pork producers on ongoing trade talks in Geneva. He was combining a stop in Omaha, Neb., later Friday for GOP Senate candidate Hal Daub, with a discussion with a community anti-drug group. Bush spoke on Thursday at fundraisers for Thompson's re-election effort in Milwaukee and for Illinois GOP gubernatorial candidate Jim Edgar in Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Eleven Miners Drown in West Siberian
DOC.TEXT: Eleven coal miners trapped by flooding in a western Siberian mine have drowned, the labor newpaper Trud reported Friday. The newspaper said six bodies had been recovered so far and rescue workers were searching for the remains of the other miners. ``A government commission is investigating the causes of the accident, but it is already clear that safety violations were responsible,'' Trud said. The accident occurred Sunday in the Dimitrov mine near Novokuznetsk in the Kuznetsk Coal Basin, 2,100 miles east of Moscow. Scuba divers on Monday attempted to reach the trapped miners but were unable to reach the disaster site, a mine official said.

DOC.HEAD: That's No Defendant, That's My Son!
DOC.TEXT: A woman was excused from jury duty because she knew the defendant. From birth, in fact. Fannie DiMarco filed into a Delaware County courtroom Thursday with 43 other potential jurors only to find that her 34-year-old son, Ronald Bull, was the defendant. ``When she came into the courtroom she immediately panicked and reported to a court officer that she was his mother,'' Assistant District Attorney James Mattera said. ``We had a conference with the judge and, of course, she was excused. It's a strange occurence. I never heard of it happening before,'' he said. The jury that was selected convicted Bull of possession with intent to distribute 29 grams of phencyclidine, or PCP.

DOC.HEAD: Alderman: Council Should Stop Reciting Pledge Regularly
DOC.TEXT: A city alderman is creating a stir with his proposal that the city council stop reciting the Pledge of Allegiance regularly. ``Routine recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance in a situation having no direct relationship to the entity to which the allegiance is being pledged tends to trivialize the flag,'' Alderman Les Nelson's resolution says. Nelson said council meetings have only a ``mimimal'' relationship to the federal government. He added that the pledge would be more meaningful if it was recited only on special occasions, such as Veterans Day or Flag Day. The council is scheduled to consider the resolution Tuesday night. Alan Colvin, another member of the council, called it a ``a wacky idea.'' ``The Pledge of Allegiance to the flag is symbolic to patriotism. I think it's important for us to do these kind of things, especially as elected officials. Patriotism and Americanism are hot issues these days. This will attract a lot of attention,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Student Searches for Silver Lining in Economic Problems
DOC.TEXT: She studies for a job that may not exist, lives on an allowance that seems to buy less, and comes from a city where the main industry is expected to die. Beatrice Uhlig sat in front of East Germany's Parliament at midnight Thursday, one of a few hundred college students sprawled on the steps of the big building, their banners crumpled beside them. Earlier in the day, thousands staged a sit-in at the Parliament's main entrance to demand increases in their living allowances, which they say are not keeping pace with rising prices. At 8 a.m., Beatrice Uhlig was calling for a higher stipend to stay in college. At midnight, as the students' protest wore on, she was contemplating life after school. ``Do I have hope? Not much,'' said the 23-year-old dairy science student at East Berlin's Humboldt University. ``But I am young. There is always a future.'' East Germany is to officially become a free market July 2, when it merges its economy with West Germany's in a major step to German unification. The day that Germans call ``Day X'' is still five weeks away, but the effects have already begun. Joblessness has started to rise. Farmers are sitting on stocks of unsold meat and vegetables, which are being shunned by East German consumers who prefer better-quality Western goods. Several industries are facing canceled orders from distributors, who are keeping their warehouses open for the influx of Western-made products they would rather sell. East German lawmakers held a heated debate Thursday over whether to force retailers and distributors to sell goods grown or made by East German industries. They finally decided not to tamper with the embryonic free market, voting instead to allow farms and industries to bypass wholesalers completely and try to sell their goods directly to retail stores. This was a mere stopgap measure to Miss Uhlig, who has little hope for the future of her field. She is an agriculture student specializing in dairy production, a highly specialized area that is geared to work on a Communist farm collective. The huge collectives are run as overstaffed factories, with workers trained for specific jobs. The system is inefficient compared to market-oriented Western farms, where cows are milked by regular workers, not college-trained dairy engineers. ``I am not sure if there is much hope for my type of job,'' she said. Miss Uhlig's hometown is the southern industrial town of Zwickau, which produces the East German Trabant auto, a tiny, low-tech, two-cylinder car that is disappearing fast from East German streets. ``My sister's husband works there, but I don't know for how long,'' she said. Economics Minister Gerhard Pohl told Parliament on Thursday that the government will discuss the possibility of closing large sections of industries to conduct massive retraining programs. He said this discussion would take place against the backdrop of the ``hopeless situation'' in many industries, including the auto industry. The stipend Miss Uhlig receives while attending school is 200 marks a month, right now the equivalent of 100 West German marks, or $60. The students who protested Thursday demanded 500 marks. ``We need it,'' she said. ``Prices are high. Prices are high because East Germans are buying West German products.'' Miss Uhlig said she feels pessimistic because so much of East Germany's transition to a new society is a mystery. Both German governments believe an initial stage of economic hardship will dissipate as Western investment moves in, creating new jobs and raising living standards. ``I hope it happens,'' said Miss Uhlig.

DOC.HEAD: Car-Crossed Lovers Seek Damages for `Accidental' Pregnancy
DOC.TEXT: A couple of car-crossed lovers is suing an insurer for damages, claiming an unplanned pregnancy resulted from an automobile accident in Naples' ``love park.'' Italian newspapers reported Friday that the claim involves an accident in March involving a medium-sized Regata and a tiny Panda car. The accident occurred in a park that nightly attracts scores of couples who make love in their cars. The young man claimed he and his girlfriend were engaged in amorous activity in their small car when the large car hit it from behind. The impact momentarily made them lose control, resulting in the pregnancy, La Stampa and La Repubblica newspapers reported. The case came to light when an agent of the insurance company decided to publicize the claim to illustrate the absurdity of some bids to win compensation, La Stampa reported. The suit demands compensation for the cost of repairing the Panda and the cost of the wedding the couple decided to have after discovering the woman was pregnant.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Welcomes Warsaw Pact Plans To Transform Itself
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Gorbachev comments on need for greater cooperation between military alliances. EDITS to trim. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: NATO foreign ministers today welcomed plans by the rival Warsaw Pact to study ways of transforming itself from a military alliance into a political organization. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said in Moscow that NATO and the Warsaw Pact should be cooperating in the same way as European leaders from both blocs and that he might support one security system for all of Europe. The ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization said they were ``encouraged by the positive spirit'' shown by a summit of Warsaw Pact leaders in Moscow on Thursday. In a final statement concluding their own two-day meeting, the NATO ministers said they were ``ready to contribute actively to building confidence and closer relations between all European countries, including the members of the two alliances.'' NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner went out of his way to extend ``the hand of friendship and cooperation'' to the Soviet Union and others in the Warsaw Pact. He said NATO wanted to end Soviet isolation from the rest of Europe. ``The Soviet Union would gain stability,'' he said. ``It would gain partners, even friends _ what a gain for the Soviet Union, what a gain for the whole of Europe.'' U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the Western allies were themselves forming ``a new alliance, renewed and reinvigorated to develop and ensure a Europe whole and freed.'' NATO officials have been taking a hard look at their own alliance and its strategy in an era of reduced East-West tensions. On Thursday, leaders of the seven Warsaw Pact nations ended their summit by declaring that their military alliance, long dominated by the Soviet Union, must be ``transformed'' to reflect the changes in Europe. The summit said it would study ways to bring that transformation about. A senior U.S. official said today he saw the Warsaw Pact summit as a triumph for Gorbachev in that he managed to keep Hungary and Czechoslovakia in the alliance for now. ``The fact that the Warsaw Pact was able to do this may make the Soviet Union a little calmer'' about the impending unification of Germany, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Warsaw Pact has nearly collapsed since the Soviet Union's allies began ousting their long-ruling Communist regimes last year. Gorbachev said today it was time for greater closeness between the alliances because of the changing politics in Europe. ``If the leaders of the governments cooperate on the political level, these organizations can't stand aside from their governments,'' he said at a joint news conference with visiting British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Mrs. Thatcher said she did not think the time was right for a system of all-European security, which would end the division of Europe into competing military alliances. But Gorbachev said he disagreed. ``One can have the policy that will resemble an elephant in a china store: One move to the left smashes half of the store. A move to the right smashes the other half,'' he said. ``If this is the policy we choose, I don't envy us.'' If NATO shows the same willingness as the Warsaw Pact to transform itself ``this will open the possibilities for ... some agreement in favor of an all-European system of security,'' Gorbachev said. The NATO communique also stressed that the ministers ``attach the highest priority to the conclusion this year'' of a treaty to cut U.S. and Soviet troops and non-nuclear weapons in Europe. The allies said they were prepared to make ``reasonable compromises'' to finish the treaty. They said they told their negotiators in Vienna to pursue new approaches, particularly on aircraft, armor and verification measures. The Soviets have been objecting to the inclusion of hundreds of planes that the Western allies categorize as combat weapons. Moscow argues that their mission is purely defensive. The ministers reiterated their demand that a united Germany be a member of NATO. ``We believe that European stability, as well as the wishes of the German people, requires that a unified Germany be a full member of this alliance,'' they said. They also said the West sought ``no unilateral advantage from German unity'' and was prepared ``to demonstrate this, taking into account legitimate Soviet security interests.'' President Bush said today he did not believe the future of a unified Germany would be ``solved quickly or easily.'' ``In the final analysis, it's a question for the people of Germany to decide,'' Bush said at a Republican fund-raising breakfast in Des Moines, Iowa. Mrs. Margaret Thatcher felt more confident after meeting today with Gorbachev that the standoff would be resolved, a spokesman said. Gorbachev has opposed NATO membership for a united Germany. The Soviets have suggested that the new German state either be neutral or belong to the Warsaw Pact. The NATO ministers also endorsed a nine-point list of assurances drawn up by the United States to gain Moscow's support of NATO membership for the new Germany. The list includes promises to allow Soviet troops to remain temporarily in what is now East Germany and to keep Western forces off that territory.

DOC.HEAD: Former Costa Rican President Dies at 83
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf pvs, `The U.S...' with 1 graf to CORRECT date military abolished to 1949. Pickup 4th, `Affectionately...'
DOC.TEXT: Former President Jose Figueres, who led Costa Rica through a revolution and into 41 years of continuous peace, died today, officials said. He was 83. Figueres died at home in San Jose, presidential spokesman Ana Lorena Vargas said. The cause of his of death was not known. The U.S.-educated Figueres was elected president three times. He abolished the army in 1949. A civil guard remains the nation's sole line of defense in this island of tranquility surrounded by neighbors in turmoil. Affectionately known as ``Don Pepe,'' Figueres was a contradictory figure. He boasted of having worked closely with the CIA in his earlier days. But he raged against U.S. policy against Nicaragua's leftist Sandinista government, which ruled until it was ousted earlier this year in free elections. Born in 1906 of Catalonian immigrants in Costa Rica, Figueres entered politics and by the 1940s had developed a strong following. In 1948, after allegedly fraudulent elections, Figueres took to the hills with a band of rebels and led a brief but bloody revolution that overthrew President Fernando Calderon Guardia, who had allied himself with the Communist Party. After taking over as president of a provisional junta for a year, Figueres banned the Communists, oversaw the writing of a new constitution that provided increased social services and, most importantly, banned the army, the only Latin American leader in history to do so. ``This small country made a contribution to mankind by outlawing the army,'' he said. ``But we had to pay dearly. We killed 2,000 Communists.'' Figueres had a second term from 1953 to 1958 and a third from 1970 to 1974. He was an accessible president, often seen on the streets of San Jose. His short, graying figure remained for years a familiar sight at gatherings of almost any class in Costa Rica, always traveling alone without bodyguards. He lived his last years in a simple A-frame house on a farm in the hills 10 miles east of San Jose. While anti-communism had been a trademark of his earlier years, Figueres grew to tolerate and even embrace the left. He was an adviser to the Sandinistas before and after they ousted dictator Anastasio Somoza in 1979. He saw U.S. backing for anti-Sandinista rebels as flawed. However, he said U.S. policy was succeeding in El Salvador, where he visited as an observer during elections in 1984. Figueres studied electrical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, Mass. from 1934 to 1938, but never pursued engineering. He married Henrietta Boggs of Alabama in 1942, and they had two children before the marriage ended in 1952. He then married Karen Olsen, a naturalized American citizen of Danish birth. They had three children and were divorced in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Allies Hope For Arms Cuts Accord With Warsaw Pact This Year
DOC.TEXT: NATO officials ended a two-day meeting Friday saying they want an East-West accord this year on arms and troop cuts in Europe and are willing to compromise further to get one. The negotiations in Vienna have slowed down over proposed cuts in warplanes and over Soviet reservations about a unified Germany belonging to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. But Secretary of State James A. Baker III and allied foreign ministers who met in this Scottish seacoast town concluded the Soviets were lowering their objections. The Soviets have opposed NATO's efforts in the Vienna negotiations to restrict aircraft that Moscow considers defensive. As a result, the Warsaw Pact has not responded to the latest NATO proposal, which sets a ceiling of 195,000 on U.S. and Soviet troops in Central Europe and imposes limits on tanks, aircraft, artillery, armored personnel carriers, helicopters and other non-nuclear arms. ``We strongly emphasize that we attach the highest priority to the conclusion this year of a CFE (Conventional Forces in Europe) treaty,'' the NATO communique said. The allies pledged ``to explore all open issues on the basis of a willingness on all sides to make reasonable compromises. ``We have, therefore, instructed our negotiators in Vienna to pursue new approaches to mutually acceptable solutions, in particular, on aircraft, armor and verification,'' the NATO ministers said. Baker, at a news conference, said Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze indicated to him Tuesday in Copenhagen, Denmark, that ``they would have new proposals.'' Other U.S. officials said they might be put on the table in Vienna in the next few days. Baker has offered Shevardnadze a nine-point Western package of guarantees, including that NATO troops would not move into what is now East Germany after the German states are united. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher insisted the final communique reiterate past West German statements pledging the territory would be off-limits to NATO troops. That apparent rift aside, Baker, NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner and foreign ministers of the Western alliance emphasized they wanted to allay Soviet concerns about having a more powerful neighbor. ``We extend to the Soviet Union and all other European countries the hand of friendship and cooperation,'' Woerner said. The NATO statement also welcomed plans by the longtime rival Warsaw Pact to undertake a drastic political overhaul. The allies said they were ``encouraged by the positive spirit'' shown by at the summit meeting held by the Soviet Union with leaders of Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary, Poland and Romania in Moscow on Thursday and especially pleased ``by the readiness on the part of the countries ... for constructive cooperation.'' Woerner said ``we want to build bridges'' to the Warsaw Pact and end what he described as Soviet isolation from the rest of Europe. At the same time, Woerner did not try to woo the members into the Western alliance. ``It is not our task to invite such moves nor it is our intention to do so,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Stalls Efforts To Slap Bush With First Veto Override
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd graf pvs, bgng: ``Senate Minority...'' to add Bush comment; picks up 3rd graf pvs, bgng: ``Bush has...''
DOC.TEXT: Senate Republicans are stalling Democratic efforts to slap President Bush with his first veto override after the House voted to set aside presidential rejection of an Amtrak funding bill. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole of Kansas said the vote was too important to the president for a vote Thursday or today with several Republicans absent. None of Bush's 10 vetoes last year was overturned, and the Amtrak bill prompted his first veto of 1990. Bush told reporters today, ``I think it's going to be very close'' in the Senate. He said he hoped Congress would sustain his veto. Bush has said he supports the bill's authorization of $2 billion for Amtrak over the next three years but vetoed the measure because of a provision that increases government control over freight railroad buy outs. Democrats accused the administration of trying to scuttle support for the successful national passenger rail service _ a course followed unsuccessfully by the Reagan administration. ``The administration has again showed its opposition to the funding for Amtrak,'' said Sen. James Exon, D-Neb. As Republican senators tried to round up votes to protect presidential prestige, House GOP leaders introduced an alternative measure that supports Amtrak but leaves out increased Interstate Commerce Commission authority over rail takeover attempts. The ICC already has the power to scrutinize takeovers involving multiple railroads or a portion of a railroad. The bill would give it authority over the buy out of a whole railroad by non-rail interests. Bush, in his veto message, called the provision ``a step backward for the entire rail industry.'' He said it would interfere with the ability of railroads to obtain financing and be a step towards re-regulation of the industry. Democrats argued that government scrutiny is needed to prevent corporate raiders from ruining the nation's railroads with leverage buy outs. ``The president is committed to an adequate passenger rail service,'' said House GOP leader Bob Michel of Illinois. He said Bush would not veto the measure if it is passed again without the ICC provision. The vetoed bill also contained provisions needed to start a commuter rail service into Virginia suburbs near Washington, to save Amtrak $16 million over two years in unemployment insurance for rail workers and to allow truck, bus and rail workers to file state income tax in only one state even though they may work in several. Exon opened debate on the override in the Senate and tried to push for a quick vote, but Republicans first failed to field any response, and then Dole announced he'd prevent a vote. ``The trains are going to run whether we do this today, next Wednesday or a week from Wednesday,'' Dole said. The veto has not affected Amtrak operations because the railroad is working with money that Congress already has appropriated. The bill envisions more than $2 billion going to the line through Sept. 30, 1992. Actual amounts will be determined when Congress appropriates the money. Democrats are expected to push for a vote on the override again next week. The Amtrak authorization passed the House 322-93 and got unanimous support in the Senate, but the ICC provision was added during negotiations between the two houses that produced the final bill. Several Republicans indicated opposition to the Amtrak aid as well as the leverage buy-out provision.

DOC.HEAD: Mehta, Pavarotti in `Il Trovatore'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No other version planned.
DOC.TEXT: Although he has been music director of the New York Philharmonic since 1978, Zubin Mehta has not conducted an entire opera in New York in 19 years. But that hasn't stopped him from conducting opera elsewhere, and on Thursday he led Luciano Pavarotti in the opening night of a new production of Verdi's ``Il Trovatore'' at the Maggio Musicale Fiorentina, Florence's spring music festival. Mehta, the longest-tenured music director in New York Philharmonic history, often has been accused of uninspired performances in New York. Part of the problem is the four-concert-a-week routine and the notoriously bad acoustics in Avery Fisher Hall. On Thursday night at the Teatro Comunale, his conducting was propulsive and exciting. At times he revved up the orchestra in a manner similar to that of Sir Georg Solti, the Chicago Symphony music director who long has been the champion of boisterous conducting. Mehta actually began his opera career in this art-filled city on the Arno River, debuting with Verdi's ``La Traviata'' in 1964. He has not conducted opera anywhere in the United States since leading Wagner's ``Tristan und Isolde'' at Los Angeles 2{ years ago. His last New York opera performance was a ``Trovatore'' at the Metropolitan Opera on March 20, 1971. Since Mehta also is muic director of the Maggio Musicale, he was able to put together a steller cast for Thursday's performance. Pavarotti also sang Manrico in the 4,000-seat Metropolitan Opera House two years ago; in an auditorium half that size he was much more convincing, his tenor filling the hall without strain. Dolora Zajick, a Slavic soprano, sang Azucena, a role she also performed with Pavarotti at the Met. While Dame Joan Sutherland and Eva Marton sang Leonora at the Met, the young soprano Antonella Banaudi sang it on Thursday night, a replacement for Susan Dunn. Giorgio Zancanero was the Count di Luna, Manrico's rival for Leonora's affections. The production, the first new ``Trovatore'' in Florence since 1977, was done by Giuliano Montaldo, a film director. Nana Cecchi designed outstanding period costumes and the sets by Luciano Ricceri were handsome and unusually realistic _ the opposite of the ugly black marble steps that dominate Fabrizio Melano's Met production. In sharp contrast to the way things are in New York, Mehta was the star of the show, getting the loudest ovation of the night from the glamorous Florentine audience.

DOC.HEAD: NEA Chairman Gets Free Voice Lessons From Employee
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts acknowledged Friday that he receives free singing lessons from an employee. A spokesman said he intends to continue doing so. ``There would be no reason not to,'' said Jack Lichtenstein, the endowment's public affairs director. NEA Chairman John Frohnmayer, an amateur lyric baritone, said Alvin Knutsen, a special assistant with the agency, has provided between 12 and 15 lessons since Frohnmayer came to Washington in October. Frohnmayer said he does not pay for the sessions. Frohnmayer said neither Knutsen nor Ann Colgrove, NEA's director of policy, who provides piano accompaniment for the sessions, was coerced. ``We all have done it as friends,'' he said. Asked if he saw any impropriety in it, he replied, ``None whatsoever.'' The chairman said Knutsen, a former professional bass-baritone, volunteered to provide the lessons, which are given ``at the end of the day or around the lunch hour.'' He said the sessions are normally in preparation for some event such as an in-house program at the endowment or his recent appearance as a guest soloist with the Capitol Hill Choral Society. Frohnmayer is an attorney from Portland, Ore. His official NEA biography says he has appeared in recital, oratorio, musical comedy and other musical productions in New York, Chicago, Palo Alto, Calif., and Oregon. Knutsen declined to comment on the instruction he provides his boss. ``All the inquiries are being handled by the press office upstairs,'' he said. ``I am sorry I can't help you.'' The first account of the lessons appeared in The Washington Times on Thursday. Knutsen, who has a doctorate in vocal music and opera, has been with NEA for about two years.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor Tells Judge He Wants to Form Committee To Study His Device
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with eight grafs to UPDATE with today's hearing, CORRECTS prosecutor's name to Thompson, sted Thomas; Picks up in 4th graf pvs, ``Meanwhile, a ...''
DOC.TEXT: The inventor of a device a 54-year-old woman used this week to commit asked a circuit judge today allow him to form a committee to establish an international ``planned death policy.'' Dr. Jack Kevorkian told Judge Alice Gilbert he wanted to form a committee with members from all sectors of society that would study his device, which involves injection of coma- and death-inducing drugs, and the circumstances under which it could be used. The panel would establish a policy ``for the world'' for use of his invention, Kevorkian said, promising he would refrain from using it again until the committee completed its work. Gilbert recessed the hearing in Pontiac until this afternoon without ruling. Oakland County Prosecutor Richard Thompson took Kevorkian to court, seeking an injunction barring further use of the device that killed Janet Adkins of Portland, Ore. Although Michigan has no law against assisting suicide, Thompson has said authorities are investigating the possibility of charges against the doctor, and they don't want the device used again. Adkins killed herself Monday after Kevorkian hooked her to the machine and she pressed a button to release the lethal chemicals. Fewer than half of the states have outlawed helping someone commit suicide, but law professors say the legality of such assistance is open to interpretation. Meanwhile, a survey in USA Today found that two-thirds of people say the terminally ill should be allowed to end their lives, and medical facilities should be available to help them do it. The phone poll of 724 adults, with a sampling error of 3.5 percent, also found 28 percent feel Kevorkian should be prosecuted and 43 percent said he shouldn't be punished. Although authorities failed to subpoena Kevorkian at his Royal Oak home Thursday, they did serve papers to his sisters, Margo Janus of Troy and Flora Holzheimer of Frankfurt, West Germany. They allegedly were present in the Oakland County park where Adkins died in the back of Kevorkian's 1968 Volkswagen van. Assisting a suicide is a crime in 23 states and three U.S. territories, said Robert Brown, professor and director of the Health Law Center at the University of Detroit Law School. In those jurisdictions, assisting suicide is classified as a unique offense, manslaughter or murder, Brown said. States and territories with laws against aiding suicide include: Arizona, California, Connecticut, Delaware, Florida, Guam, Hawaii, Kansas, Maine, Minnesota, Mississippi, Montana, Nebraska, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, Oregon, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Puerto Rico, South Dakota, Texas, Washington, Wisconsin and the Virgin Islands. ``I think it's unlikely that Michigan is going to become the suicide haven of North America,'' Brown said. ``There may be an aiding and abetting statute in which a prosecutor may squeeze these facts in.'' Suicide is legal in Michigan, but Professor Yale Kamisar of the University of Michigan Law School said the legality of assisting a suicide is open to debate. In 1920, the Michigan Supreme Court ruled that a man who had put poison within the reach of his deathly ill wife was guilty of first-degree murder when she committed suicide, Kamisar said. But in 1983, the state Court of Appeals said a man shouldn't be charged with murder because he had given a friend a gun that the friend later used to commit suicide. ``The high court didn't review the 1983 appeal, so we have this intermediate court causing all this confusion,'' Kamisar said.

DOC.HEAD: In This Wagon Train, Whining Has Its Place
DOC.DATELINE: ALONG THE JIM BRIDGER TRAIL, Wyo. (AP)
DOC.TEXT: When the going gets tough, even the toughest pardners on the Wyoming Centennial Wagon Train can get going _ straight to the whining tent. All in all, folks have been pretty happy on the month-long, 260-mile trek, wagon train spokesman B.J. Wertz said. But this being the enlightened '90s _ 1990s, that is _ certain precautions must be taken. ``If someone starts complaining, we send them to the whining tent,'' Wertz said. ``That pretty much lightens people up.'' So far, the only things people have had to whine about have been some fairly stiff winds on Thursday, some bad hay and a couple of minor accidents. More than 70 wagons and nearly 1,000 people from across the United States are participating in the trip from Casper to Cody, which is being made to celebrate Wyoming's centennial. On Thursday, they campd at Arminto, about 50 miles west of Casper. In one of the most frightening mishaps so far, a 13-year-old girl was thrown from her horse Thursday and flown by helicopter to the Wyoming Medical Center, where she was treated and released. The girl, whose identity was not made public, will be rejoining the wagon train, Wertz said. Other minor incidents, like a sheep wagon coming loose from its hitch and sliding into a barrow pit, or broken wagon wheels and hitch tongues, have pulled the train together, Wertz said. ``It's just like if you're driving along the highway and you break down, only someone will stop and help you,'' she said. Pulling together on the trail has also made for fun evenings in camp. ``Every night there's been guitar playing and storytelling,'' she said. There's a squeeze box (accordion) in camp and there's lots of music and dancing. It's real spontaneous fun. There's even cowboy poetry.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says U.S. Considering Breaking Off Talks With PLO
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 grafs after 9th graf pvs, The Palestine... to UPDATE with further White House comment
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he is considering breaking off talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization in the wake of a terrorist attack on an Israeli beach but ``no decision has been made.'' Bush, speaking with reporters on a Midwestern political trip, was asked about a report in The Washington Times that the administration has decided to break off its 16-month dialogue with the PLO. ``I'm not prepared to make an announcement on policy at this point,'' Bush said. However, he said, ``our dialogue is predicated on a renunciation of terror. In my view, this is sheer terror.'' Speaking separately at a NATO conference, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the administration is seeking more information on the raid. He said a decision on the U.S.-PLO talks would be made ``when we are satisfied we know all we need to know.'' Bush said he'd like to see PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat ``speak out ... I've expressed my outrage about the attack,'' Bush said. ``Maybe I can take this opportunity to express my outrage about all the violence in the Middle East.'' Asked if he was planned to cut off the U.S.-PLO dialogue, Bush said, ``We are discussing all of that. No decision has been made.'' Arafat has denied any PLO involvement in last month's raid but has not condemned the act outright. The Palestine Liberation Front, a PLO faction, claimed responsibility for the raid, in which six speedboats attempted to attack a crowded beach but were intercepted by Israeli security forces. The PLF is headed by Mohammed Abbas, who uses the name Abul Abbas and who masterminded the Achille Lauro cruise ship hijacking. In Washington, White House deputy press secretary Roman Popadiuk said the administration has received some information about the attack from the Israelis. Separately, an administration official said a decision was not expected for a number of days. The official, who declined to be identified, said the United States has held at least four meetings with PLO representatives since the raid to discuss the organization's views on it. On the subject of the possible formation of a new right-wing government in Israel, Bush said that was ``an internal matter for Israel.'' ``Israel can do what it wants with this government and I'll work with whoever that country puts forward as their government,'' Bush said. ``But they know the policy of the United States on peace talks. U.S. policy is firm. We want the peace talks to begin.'' Diplomatic sources in Washington said earlier in the day that the United States had decided to suspend the talks and would make the announcement next week. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the administration would cite the attack and the PLO's decision not to condemn the action. Baker, in Turnberry, Scotland, for a NATO foreign ministers meeting, said terrorism is not the sole issue in deciding whether the United States will suspend its 16-month dialogue with the PLO. ``It is important that we pursue peace in the Middle East in a serious manner,'' Baker told a news conference. Asked if he meant to suggest the impact a cutoff might have on Middle East peace talks would outweigh the U.S. anti-terrorism policy, Baker said: ``I don't want to seem to be suggesting in any way that we would countenance terrorism in order to advance the noble cause of peace.'' Baker told reporters the talks were continuing while the administration sought to find out ``all we need to know'' about the circumstances. He declined to say what information was still lacking.'' The dialogue with the PLO, carried out by Robert Pelletreau, the U.S. ambassador in Tunisia, where the organization has its headquarters, was begun after PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat renounced terrorism and recognized Israel's right to exist in December 1988. The U.S. government said it would end all contact at any time if the PLO failed to live up to its renunciation of terrorism. The May 30 assault by Palestine Liberation Front guerrillas was thwarted by Israeli forces. PLF leaders said the attack was aimed at a military target, but Israeli officials say they have proof the aim was to murder civilians. Arafat said the PLO had nothing to do with the operation, but he has been unwilling to condemn it, and said he had no authority to throw the PLF's representative of the PLO Executive Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Republican Says Democrats May Have Sabotaged Their Convention
DOC.TEXT: A Republican official says Democrats may have deliberately sabotaged their own state convention with a police demonstration and then falsely blamed the GOP. Democrats have accused the Springfield police union and White House aide Ronald Kaufman with trying to embarrass the party and disrupt the convention with a police picket line outside the hall last Saturday. The protest disrupted the Democratic convention at the Springfield Civic Center, nearly forcing its cancellation. ``It will be very interesting when all is said and done who really caused the problems in Springfield,'' state GOP Executive Director Alexander Tennant said Thursday. Tennant offered no proof for his accusations, and Democrats have offered little proof for their accusations against Kaufman, saying he met briefly with the police union president the night before the picketing. Robert Jacobson, president of the Springfield police union, which backed George Bush over Gov. Michael S. Dukakis in the 1988 presidential campaign, denied Democrats or Republicans had anything to do with the picketing. He said the union picketed to call attention to its problems with Springfield Mayor Mary Hurley over getting a contract. Republicans suggested Thursday that Democratic gubernatorial candidate John Silber and Senate President William Bulger, also a Democrat, may have been behind the police demonstration. The state Democratic Party has sued the police union and has vowed to sue Kaufman over the demonstration. Tennant said Republicans intend to seek depositions from Silber, Bulger and others. ``It will become clearer and clearer that the Republican Party had nothing to do with this, and that there was a conspiracy,'' Tennant said. Robert Donahue, Silber's campaign manager, called the Republican suggestion ``ludicrous ... beyond belief.'' Bulger spokesman, Paul Mahoney, said, ``We had absolutely nothing to do with any strike or disruption.''

DOC.HEAD: Last FEMA Field Office Closes Nine Months After Storm
DOC.TEXT: Nearly nine months after Hurricane Hugo pounded South Carolina, the Federal Emergency Management Agency on Friday shuttered its last disaster field office. The North Charleston office was opened two days after Hugo smashed ashore Sept. 21, causing an estimated $5.9 billion damage and claiming 29 lives in the most destructive hurricane to ever hit the United States mainland. The North Charleston field office served as the nerve center for FEMA recovery operations in the hurricane-ravaged area. The work involved 1,300 state and federal employees, more than 3,400 military and Army Corps of Engineers workers, plus nearly 500 workers hired locally. That office remained open longer than any other field office to respond to disasters in FEMA's Southeast region which includes the Carolinas, Georgia, Florida, Mississippi, Alabama, Tennessee and Kentucky, FEMA spokesman Frank Mosco said. More than 89,000 people applied for aid to cover uninsured storm losses. In all, FEMA and the Small Business Administration have spent $675 million helping South Carolina recover from the storm.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Died Gets Job Back
DOC.TEXT: A man who died while going to a hearing to fight his job dismissal has been reinstated to the job. The State Industrial Commission made its decision so the family of the unidentified 62-year-old man can collect a $6,160 pension payout. The commission ruled Thursday that Norman Ross Discounts fired the 10-year employee unfairly for failing to check a truckload of stock, some of which later turned out to be missing. But Norman Ross was short-staffed at the time, and the commission ruled that the worker could not reasonably have been expected to check the load. Joe de Bruyn, secretary of the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Union, which pursued the case, said the man suffered a heart attack while on his way to a hearing to fight for his job. The company is appealing the decision.

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush Spends Part of 65th Birthday Promoting Reading
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush devoted part of her 65th birthday Friday to a favorite task, reading to children, and recalled that she and President Bush did that often when their kids were young. ``It was a chance for us to put an arm around a child and have a special time,'' said the first lady. ``It does a lot for bonding with your children and it pays off later.'' Mrs. Bush appeared on ABC-TV's ``Good Morning America'' and read to a dozen children seated around her. The story was ``Leo, the Late Bloomer,'' about a lion who was slow to learn to read and write. The children responded with a chorus of ``Happy Birthday, Mrs. Bush.'' ``Oh, how'd you know?'' she asked. ``Who told you that secret? Thank you very, very much.'' A day earlier she had said she could not care less about her birthday. She was born June 8, 1925 in New York City. Bush telephoned wishes from Iowa, where he was finishing a four-state political trip. He told reporters that ``she seemed unexcited about her 65th birthday.'' The National Pork Producers' Council gave the president a box of pork chops and several bags of pork rinds, a favorite snack, and he quipped: ``Maybe that's what I'll give to Barbara for her birthday present.'' The first lady, who made literacy a personal crusade, said on the television program that ``about the most important thing that parents can do for their children is to get them excited about and start them reading.'' That, she said, is because parents are the first teachers. ``My first memories of my mother and father are my mother curled up on a couch reading and my dad reading,'' she said. It's a proven fact now that children who are read to do better in school.'' Mrs. Bush recommended letting children pick the books they are interested in, then reading to them. ``We're not talking about hours,'' she said. ``We're talking a little bit about a way of life. Have books out. Have books available. You don't have to buy them ... have them there so the child can pick up a book, not just story books but books about science or whatever you think your child might be interested in. ``It is quality time; maybe it's 15 minutes a night, maybe it's allowing your child to pick a book they want to read themselves to sleep to. It's just a way of life and it's a very easy to establish.'' Mrs. Bush spoke also about the time she spent last week with Soviet first lady Raisa Gorbachev, who was in this country with President Mikhail Gorbachev. ``She told me that she herself, as a working woman, had turned down promotions so she could be home with her family,'' Mrs. Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: A Philadelphia Landmark Goes Dark
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Saving, 13th graf, cq.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Empire State Building
DOC.TEXT: To some Philadelphians, it was an electrical jolt as shocking as Ben Franklin's kite-flying experiment. The PSFS sign was turned off. The 27-foot-high red neon letters, which have glowed atop the 39-story PSFS Building for 58 years, were turned off May 21 because the bank inside the building no longer owns the rights to the letters. The reasons are complicated, but to some architectural historians, the result is simply a mistake. ``Because of mergers and acquisitions in corporate America, the sign's turned off,'' William Blades, executive director of the Philadelphia Historic Preservation Corp., said Thursday. ``It's silly.'' The untrained eye may consider the 491-foot building at 12th and Market streets just another modern skyscraper, not too big, not too dazzling. Building buffs, however, positively gush when they talk about it. In 1932, architects George Howe and William Lescaze, they say, designed the first truly modern American skyscraper, lovingly detailed and way ahead of its time. And the sign, says Susan Shearer, past president of the Society for Commercial Archaeology, is ``an integral part of the building, and an important element in the landscape of Philadelphia.'' ``To turn off the sign,'' she said, ``is to eliminate a major part of the archictectural statement.'' Until the mid-1980s, Philadelphia custom dictated that no building be higher than the statue of William Penn that crowns City Hall. And the PSFS building, then the city's second tallest structure, was a dominant feature of the skyline. ``If this was a billboard that's been up there two years, that's another issue,'' Blades said. ``But this is a National Historic Landmark.'' Sign supporters point out that it is the country's first large-scale illuminated graphic on the country's first modernist skyscraper, housing the country's first savings bank. The bank in question was the Philadelphia Saving Fund Society, founded in 1816 as the nation's first savings bank for regular folk, not just businesses. It became known as simply PSFS. This year, PSFS's parent, Meritor Savings Bank, sold 54 PSFS branches and the PSFS name to Mellon Bank Corp. Meritor is staying in the building and keeping 29 branches, using the new name Philadelphia Savings Fund Society. But since it no longer has the legal rights to the name PSFS, Meritor decided to turn off the sign. The sign itself must stay, protected by the landmark designation. ``Legally, we have no right to the PSFS name, and that's why the sign is off,'' said Leslie Voth, vice president of corporate communications for Meritor. ``Mellon bought the rights to the PSFS name. If they wanted it illuminated, they would have to pay for it.'' Mellon spokeswoman Becky Brinks offered nostalgic Philadelphians a hint of hope. ``We're certainly willing to discuss the possibility,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Astronaut Named Associate Director of NASA's Ames Research Center
DOC.TEXT: An astronaut who has flown on three space shuttle missions will give up space duties to become associate director of NASA's Ames Research Center. Del Harding, spokesman for the Mountain View center, announced Thursday that Steven Hawley, 38, will start the job in late July. Hawley has been deputy chief of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Astronaut Office at Johnson Space Center in Houston since 1987. Harding said the full-time associate director's position hasn't been filled on a permanent basis since 1988. The salary is still under negotiation, but will be about $70,000 a year plus ``performance incentives,'' he added. Hawley has been an astronaut since 1978, making his first space voyage in August 1984 and his last shuttle trip this in April on Discovery. Born in Salina, Kan., he graduated from the University of Kansas and received his doctorate in astronomy and astrophysics from the University of California, Santa Cruz in 1977.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Kills Husband, Mother-in-Law, Then Self
DOC.TEXT: A woman telephoned police to say she had just killed her husband and mother-in-law. Then, after asking the police to take care of her dog, she shot and killed herself, authorities said. The three dead were identified as Lorraine Napieralski, 42; her husband, Anthony, 43, and his mother, Theresa, 63. ``I've just killed my husband,'' a detective quoted Lorraine Napieralski as saying in her phone call to police shortly after 5 a.m. ``I've just killed my mother-in-law. I'm about to kill myself. Please take care of my dog.'' Police said they made it to the Napieralski home in this Buffalo suburb in one minute, but not in time to prevent Mrs. Napieralski from killing herself. Detective Lt. Thomas Rowan said police are aware of a motive in the killings ``but we're not going to talk about it at this point. It's a tragic family matter, and not much else is going to be served at this point by talking about it.'' The first officers to arrive found Mrs. Napieralski on a living room couch and the two others in their bedrooms. All three were pronounced dead at the scene of gunshot wounds. ``We believe the husband was shot first,'' said Rowan. ``We believe the mother _ mother-in-law was shot next. The woman then called the police and took her own life.'' Investigators found the dog, Taffy, unharmed. Later in the morning, the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals picked up the animal. Napieralski was a former worker for the Internal Revenue Service, Rowan said.

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Governor Defends Wife's `Earthy' Comments
DOC.TEXT: Ohio Gov. Richard Celeste defended his wife's ``fairly earthy'' advocacy of gay and lesbian rights and shrugged off suggestions of political damage. ``What's the embarrassment?'' Celeste said when asked about remarks by his wife, Dagmar. ``I'll bet you there are a lot of people around here who say fairly earthy things.'' Celeste, who heads the Democratic Governors Association, was in Iowa for private meetings with Democratic activists and candidates and to tape a television debate on peace issues. But he found himself questioned Thursday about a newspaper account of a speech his wife delivered to a group of homosexual advocates in Cincinnati. The Cleveland Plain Dealer reported earlier this week that Mrs. Celeste quoted sexually explicit language from a lesbian author in asserting her support of gay rights during the April speech. The Plain Dealer based its account on a report in the Cincinnati-based Gaybeat newspaper. Mrs. Celeste said her remarks were taken out of context. She was attending the Cincinnati dinner to accept an award on behalf of the governor, who was honored for opposing discrimination against homosexuals. ``It was a surprise to me that a newspaper would write a story about an event that occurred in April, based solely on a report in an advocacy journal that they would normally never use as a basis for a story and treat it as an objective description of the events,'' the governor said. Celeste, occasionally mentioned as a Democratic presidential candidate, made a similar tentative foray into Iowa in 1987 to talk with party activists but decided against running for president.

DOC.HEAD: Slimy Sewer Scene of Hour-Long Police Chase
DOC.TEXT: It was slimy. It was spider-infested. And it was all in a night's work for a few police officers. Police followed a group of burglary suspects into a storm sewer Thursday night and spent an hour chasing them in the cramped and dirty drain. ``It was slimy and skinny down there,'' said Sgt. G. Morimoto. Five or six men were seen carrying items out of a house on Albuquerque's west side, police said. Morimoto said witnesses told police the men fled down the street. When police showed up, they saw the suspects duck into the sewer. Six officers climbed into the tunnel entrance to the sewer. The three who were arrested, ages 28, 22 and 16, were caught before they could squeeze into a narrow section of the sewer, Morimoto said. The others escaped through a sewer grate. The three were arrested on charges of breaking and entering and conspiracy.

DOC.HEAD: Sutherland Marks Fifth Year As Hostage
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Students and colleagues of American educator Thomas Sutherland gathered at the American University of Beirut on Friday to mark a grim milestone _ the passing of Sutherland's fifth year as a hostage in Lebanon. Sutherland begins his sixth year in captivity Saturday. In the time since he was captured June 9, 1985, the only word on his welfare has come from former hostages who were held with him. The pro-Iranian group that holds him, Islamic Jihad, has never issued a photograph of Sutherland as it has its other captives. ``The four things that mean the most to Tom ... are his home, his family, his work and his friends, and he found all four of those here in Beirut and at AUB,'' Sutherland's wife, Jean, told the gathering at the lecture hall in the university's agriculture facility. One of those attending was Elham Cicippio, the wife of American hostage Joseph Cicippio, who was the acting comptroller at the American University of Beirut. He was kidnapped Sept. 12, 1986. ``People who have come out from where he is and who have been with him say that Tom speaks and thinks of AUB and wants to come back,'' Mrs. Sutherland said. The Scottish-born Sutherland, 59, of Fort Collins, Colo., was dean of agriculture and food sciences at the American University of Beirut when he was kidnapped June 8, 1985. In addition to Sutherland and Cicippio, 14 other Westerners are missing in Lebanon. The hostage held longest is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Next to Anderson, Sutherland has been held the longest. Most of the hostages are held by pro-Iranian Shiite factions. Mrs. Sutherland still lives at the American University in Moslem west Beirut, continuing the work she and her husband were doing when he was abducted. ``Tom and I are ordinary people,'' she said Friday. ``We came here to do a job. The job is still to be done and we're still doing it. ``All that we know is that he has life and health and work to do and we will continue with that work,'' she added. She said what her husband is going through is ``only a reflection, a shadow of what the people in Lebanon'' have gone through in 15 years of civil war. She and the students pinned photographs of Sutherland in happier times to a board in the hall. ``What Tom would say to the faculty of agriculture and food sciences is we have our memories on the board out there, but we don't go to the past,'' Mrs. Sutherland said. ``Let's not let this time be a time of sadness, but rather a time of gladness,'' she added. ``We hope that ... when he comes out it means reconciliation, it means that people are not divided, that people are on their way to work together in peace and harmony,'' she said. The Sutherlands have three daughters, Ann, 32; Kit, 30; and Joan, 26. They all live and work in the United States. Former hostages have told Mrs. Sutherland that her husband's captors had given him a picture she had placed in a newspaper of his only granddaughter, Simone, 3, who was born after his abduction. Sutherland was seized as he drove from the airport after arriving from the United States to attend the graduation of his students. Mrs. Sutherland said in an interview with The Associated Press that her husband had been hesitant about returning to Beirut because of the civil war and kidnappings. ``But somehow there weren't any further indications that things were any worse than they had been, and he made that decision to go,'' she said. She recalled that in the last week before he returned to Beirut, an interviewer asked her husband whether he was afraid. ``He said, `If I'm going to be afraid I'd better not be there.''' She added: ``We made the choice to come. We made the choice to stay and I know that Tom always felt that it was worth it. ``We always had the sense that if somebody can make it, Tom will because he's a very strong person. But he's also a very sensitive person and I know that for him this has been an ordeal because his work is his life,'' Mrs. Sutherland said. ``So, I try to to carry on the sense of that work and I feel everything I do is Tom and I doing it together,'' she added.

DOC.HEAD: Empire State Building to be Illuminated Lavender for Gay Pride Event
With AM-Dark Sign
DOC.TEXT: The Empire State Building, which is illuminated with green lights every St. Patrick's Day and red, white and blue for the Fourth of July, will be awash in lavender this month to honor Gay Pride Weekend. The building's managers agreed to the special display after six years of lobbying by homosexual rights groups. The lavender lights will be on June 22-24. Lavender is the traditional color of the gay rights movement. ``We are in total agreement with ... leaders who seek to end the bigotry and discrimination directed against gay and lesbian New Yorkers,'' the manager, Helmsley-Spear Inc., said in a statement. ``We hope our participating will help end the type of ignorance that breeds this mindless prejudice.'' The decision was made at the request of the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation. It was one of hundreds of requests for special lightings the 102-story building receives annually. Helmsley-Spear's statement did not say why the decision took six years. A spokesman, Robert Udowitz, declined to elaborate. On June 21, the top 30 stories of the Empire State will be illuminated with black, gold and green lights _ the colors of the African National Congress _ to mark the June 20-23 visit of ANC Deputy President Nelson Mandela, Udowitz said. On Monday it was blue for ``Unity Day,'' promoting racial harmony. In other annual displays, the tower is illuminated with yellow and white lights during Easter week and red, black and green lights for Martin Luther King Day. Gay Pride Weekend includes a march of as many as 150,000 people.

DOC.HEAD: Interns Wander in Wienermobiles
DOC.TEXT: Oh, Jamie Willard wished he was an Oscar Mayer wiener. That is what he truly wanted to be. And if he drove around in a 23-foot-long hot dog, people on the street certainly would be agog. Willard is one of 13 college graduates to complete a Oscar Mayer Food Corp. training program this week to drive the motorized promotional hot dog around the country for the Madison-based food provider. Willard says he plans to relish his new job. ``I loved the commercials but I never thought I'd be doing this,'' he said. ``This is going to be the best job in the world.'' Willard, who graduated last month from Aquinas College in Grand Rapids, Mich., and his ``hotdogger'' colleagues will be divided into groups of two and will cruise around the country in the 23-foot-long hot dog vehicle. While cruising the United States, the vehicle will make promotional stops. The hotdogger training includes classes on the history of Oscar Mayer and how to deal with the public, although the real test is when the driver gets behind the wheel of the giant dog for the first time. After Russell Coy, a graduate of New Mexico State University in Las Cruces, mustered up the courage to get into the cockpit-like driver's seat, he said it felt good to be honking and waving at surprised people on the street and in cars. ``I feel like I'm the top dog!'' Coy declared. Hot dog jokes have been passed down through the three classes of hotdoggers, who warn newcomers against such job hazards as getting grilled by reporters. Laughing and having fun are prerequisites for being a hotdogger, said Rick Wood, who is in charge of keeping the Wienermobiles running and teaching students to drive them. The paid, year-long internship program began in 1988 as a way to beef up advertising and give graduates the chance to learn about Oscar Mayer, he said. About 500 people applied for the program this year. ``Some of our best salesman have come from the Hotdogger program,'' he said. The first Wienermobile, built in Chicago in 1936, was a 13-foot metal hot dog built to transport Little Oscar, the world's smallest chef. Although their new jobs will be demanding _ they'll be on the road 25 days a month _ the interns beamed when they talked about the coming year and how the job will help them in the future. ``At first, my parents said, `Four years of college _ why this?''' said Isabelle Ferrera, a graduate of the University of Wisconsin-Madison. ``But it's a great career move and it will be a nice transition.'' Wood offered the graduates a final wiener warning: ``Watch your buns.''

DOC.HEAD: Plant on Fire South of Houston
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with quotes, further details. ADDS byline. No Pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A series of explosions rocked a solvent packaging company south of Houston late this morning, injuring at least one person and spewing black smoke that could be seen from downtown Houston 12 miles away. There was no immediate report of any deaths from the inferno at the Solvents and Chemicals Inc. plant, located in an industrial area south of Houston. Emergency officials said they did not know what was burning. The plant, with about two dozen employees, handles kerosene and gun cleaning agents, televised reports said. More than an hour after the first blast at 11 a.m., fires were still setting off storage tanks and hurling smaller storage drums in the air. A four-block area near the plant, about three-quarters of a mile north of a residential area, was evacuated. One person at the locally owned plant was taken by helicopter to Hermann Hospital in Houston, the hospital said. There was no immediate word on the extent of the person's injuries. John Loessin, whose family owns Pearland Lumber Co. Inc. about three blocks from the plant, said, ``We didn't hear any boom at all. We keep looking out the window and we keep seeing a big puff of black smoke go out.'' Loessin and employees at the store said they found out about the explosion when a spouse of an employee called to see if they were OK. Pearland, a community of about 15,000, is located 12 miles south of Houston. Last October, a Phillips Petroleum Co. plastics plant exploded at Pasadena, about a dozen miles away from today's blast, killing 23 people and injuring more than 100. There is a heavy concentration of plastics and chemical plants and oil refineries in the metropolitan Houston area.

DOC.HEAD: Former Soldier Charged With Selling Military Secrets To East Bloc
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with nine grafs to UPDATE with comment by Justice Department spokesman, further background; brings higher material from affidavit inserted in previous writethru; picks up in 5th graf, ``Ramsay was ...''
DOC.TEXT: A former Army sergeant responsible for safeguarding sensitive documents was arrested on charges he conspired to sell information on the nuclear defense of Europe to Hungary and Czechoslovakia, the FBI said. ``This represents a hemorrhage of extremely sensitive information which caused grave danger to the United States and its NATO allies,'' FBI agent Allen McCreight said. ``We think it has major implications.'' Roderick James Ramsay, 28, was arrested without incident Thursday night on a downtown street; he being held at an undisclosed location. He was scheduled to appear today before a federal magistrate. The FBI has been investigating Ramsay for about two years and has conducted a covert surveillance of him for some time, said a law enforcement official who spoke on condition of anonymity. In Washington, a Justice Department spokesman said that the information that Ramsay is accused of helping provide the Hungarian and Czech spy agencies eventually fell into the hands of the Soviet KGB. ``This is a significant case from the point of view of U.S. security interests,'' said spokesman Doug Tillett. ``It involves an extensive amount of information provided to the Soviet intelligence service (KBG) through Eastern European surrogates'' Ramsay worked in West Germany from 1983 to 1985 directly under Clyde Lee Conrad, 43, a retired U.S. Army sergeant convicted of treason by a West German court and given a life sentence earlier this week, the FBI said. It said Ramsay's arrest stemmed from the investigation of Conrad. An affidavit filed in court noted that in January 1986 Conrad visited Ramsay in Boston, gave him a cow bell and told him that anyone displaying a similar cow bell was involved in the spy ring. Ramsay said he kept the bell and had it at his mother's Tampa home until April, when he turned it over to federal authorities, said an affidavit signed by FBI agent Joe Navarro. Ramsay acknowledged to Navarro that he was recruited by Conrad and participated in spying activities while in the Army, the affidavit said. He also told the agent that he had top-secret documents at his mother's house that he had planned to sell in the future, Navarro said, but destroyed them in August 1988. Ramsay was charged with conspiracy to gather or deliver defense information to aid a foreign government, the FBI said. That information included sensitive documents on the use of tactical nuclear weapons by U.S. forces and NATO allies, and plans for the defense of Central Europe, the Justice Department said in a news release. ``It's fair to say the information would have been very useful to the Soviet Union,'' U.S. Attorney Robert Genzman said. He refused to confirm whether the East bloc countries passed it on to the Soviets. FBI agents said the seven-year nationwide investigation into the alleged spy ring was continuing. They refused to say how many people were involved. FBI Director William S. Sessions said the investigation was one of the most complicated of its kind ever undertaken by the bureau, and the information passed on was ``extremely sensitive.'' Court papers filed in the case charge that for $20,000 Ramsay gave Conrad the documents as well as technical manuals about military communications technology and material about the coordination of NATO forces. The material was passed to Hungarian and Czechoslovakian intelligence agents, according to the court papers. Ramsay worked directly under Conrad in the 8th Infantry Division G-3 plans section in Bad Kreuznach as the assistant document custodian. The G-3 section of a division is in charge of the unit's military operations. Ramsay's duties included safeguarding all classified and military documents. He held a top-secret clearance. The affidavit charged that in December 1985, Ramsay videotaped hundreds of documents and gave them to Conrad for their eventual sale to the Czechs and Hungarians. Conrad was arrested in August 1988. The trial judge in his case said his offense _ passing secrets to Hungary and Czechoslovakia from 1975 through 1985 in return for $1.2 million _ ``endangered the entire defense capability of the West.'' It could have led to ``a breakdown in the defenses of the Western alliance,'' and to ``capitulation and the use of nuclear weapons on German territory,'' said Ferdinand Schuth, chief judge of the court in the West German state of Rhineland-Palatinate, where the spying occurred. According to court records, Conrad was introduced to the Hungarian secret service in late fall 1975 by his supervisor in the 8th Infantry Division, former U.S. Army Sgt. 1st Class Zoltan Szabo. Szabo was convicted of espionage in Austria in 1989 and received a 10-month suspended sentence. He identified for investigators some of the documents the court said Conrad sold to the Hungarians. Ramsay faces a maximum penalty of life imprisonment if convicted of espionage conspiracy.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Calls Rocket Launch Successful
LaserPhoto MLB1
DOC.TEXT: A giant Titan 4 rocket thundered into orbit Friday with what's believed to be a military surveillance satellite. Air Force officials said the early morning launch went smoothly. It was the second launch of the nation's most powerful unmanned space rocket and one of three planned for this year. ``Everything went very well. It was a beautiful sight to behold,'' said Air Force Col. Frank Stirling, director of the Titan program. ``It was a great step for us in the Air Force to get the second Titan 4 launched on time as planned.'' The $173 million rocket blasted off at 1:22 a.m. from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station. It resembled a large ball of fire as it cut through clouds on its way toward an undisclosed orbit. The Air Force refused to discuss or even acknowledge the flight until it issued a statement about 20 minutes after liftoff. The payload was not revealed, but civilian experts believe it is an electronic eavesdropping satellite or a missile-warning spacecraft. A Titan 4 successfully boosted a missile-warning satellite into orbit in June 1989, even though an engine nozzle malfunctioned. Stirling said the problem was corrected and did not occur in Friday's launch. Martin Marietta Space Launch Systems has a $7.1 billion contract with the Air Force to supply 41 Titan 4 rockets, with an option for eight more. The goal is to have 75 by the end of 1997, which would put the cost of the program at $17 billion, Stirling said. The Air Force ordered the rocket in 1985 to serve as a complimentary launch vehicle to NASA's manned space shuttle, the most powerful cargo carrier used by the United States. The shuttle is capable of putting a 52,000-pound payload into orbit. The Titan 4, which stands 20 stories tall, can lift a 39,000-pound cargo into low Earth orbit or carry 10,000 pounds to stationary orbit 22,300 miles high. After the 1986 Challenger explosion, the Air Force revamped the program and targeted the Titan 4 as its primary booster for heavy Pentagon payloads. Stirling said the switch from ``an off-the-shelf'' rocket to one of shuttle caliber led to schedule delays and a $209 million in cost overruns as of July 1989. The U.S. General Accounting Office cited program delays and cost overruns in a report last month, noting that 10 rockets originally were to have been launched by October. The rocket launched Friday could have gone up several months ago, but its payload was not ready, Stirling said. The Air Force plans to launch two more Titan 4 rockets this year from either Cape Canaveral or Vandenberg, Stirling said. Several rockets are at each site, ready to go, he said. Smaller rockets such as the Delta and Atlas will be used to carry lighter payloads, Stirling said. The space shuttle will be used only if astronauts' assistance or the shuttle's unique capabilities are required, he said. Atlantis is scheduled to carry a secret military payload into orbit next month. It will be the seventh shuttle mission dedicated to the Defense Department; only a few remain on the shuttle flight manifest. ``Right now, the idea is to have a robust and capable launch vehicle program that stands alone, based on a mixed fleet, so we never get into a posture again of having to rely on a single means of access to space which is in many regards technically fragile,'' Stirling said.

DOC.HEAD: Explorers Enter First of Eight Icebound Aircraft
DOC.TEXT: Explorers shimmied through a 42-inch hole to poke around one of eight icebound World War II aircraft in southeastern Greenland for the first time and found it in good condition, expedition officials said Friday. Richard Taylor, who is supervising the the Greenland Expedition Society's effort to recover the planes, radioed the society's suburban Atlanta headquarters: ``We have been down to the plane and gotten inside it. Its condition is good and just as we all hoped it would be.'' Taylor and Gordon Scott entered the B-17 bomber Wednesday, Pat Epps, the society's founder, said Friday. On Wednesday, Epps said the group succeeded in reaching the plane for the first time and would try to get inside by descending 250 feet through a 42-inch shaft in the ice. The B-17 bomber is one of eight U.S. planes _ two B-17s and six twin-engine, P-138 Lightning fighters _ that crash-landed on the Greenland icecap on July 15, 1942. They ran out of fuel en route to Europe after being given false radio transmissions from German submarines. The crews survived. Epps, owner of an air service in suburban Atlanta, said the salvage team, which has been in Greenland since May, reached the buried bomber by digging through 250 feet of ice with a thermal borer. ``We plan to get the fighters out this year,'' he said. ``We will work until September 1.'' The Greenland Expedition Society has worked to find the aircraft for almost a decade. In 1988, its members found the planes by using low-frequency subsurface radar. Last year, they drilled down to the B-17 and brought back poker chip-size pieces of its skin.

DOC.HEAD: Research Team Produces Genetically Engineered Calves
DOC.TEXT: Scientists have produced a calf with a human hormone gene and three others with extra cattle genes, in research that could lead to leaner beef and cows that give more milk. The three bulls and one heifer were given the extra genes while still embryos as part of a continuing project at the Diamond G Ranch in southeast Texas. In addition, 60 to 70 cows at the ranch are pregnant with genetically altered embryos. ``I'm not willing to say any of the animals we have produced or those we're about to produce will have commercial value,'' said Ken Bondioli, a senior scientist at Granada BioSciences of Houston. ``This is research in its infancy. There's a lot of potential there. We don't think we have all the answers.'' The human gene is carried by the eldest of Granada's experimental cattle, a 15-month-old bull, researchers said Thursday. The animal has not grown as large as researchers anticipated, but they still hope the gene altering could lead to strong, healthy cattle without the use of steroids. Steroids have been linked to heart disease and impotence. ``The purpose of these kinds of things is to prevent disease, make animals more immune to particular kinds of diseases,'' said David Eller, Granada's chairman. ``In the broad analysis, it's to make food-producing animals more economical for producers to grow and more healthy for the diet-conscious, health-conscious consumers of today.'' Researchers have experimented successfully with gene altering in chickens, pigs, sheep and laboratory animals. Human genes have also been previously inserted into farm animals. But the Granada experiments are believed to be the first performed on cattle in the United States. Gene-altered cows have been produced in Europe and Canada. The testing is being done by Biondoli, Bert O'Malley, a cell biologist at Houston's Bayor College of Medicine; and Robert Hammer, a physiologist at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute in Dallas. To produce their first genetically engineered bull, the scientists used a human estrogen gene, reproduced in the lab, to promote growth. The hope was that an animal with the extra gene would enjoy the same benefits steroids provide without the health risks. The first bull, however, did not show any abnormally fast or healthy growth.
