A second bull was born last September; a heifer was born three months later. The fourth, a bull, was born last March. These three calves received additional bovine genes. The two bulls received an insulin-growth factor gene, designed to promote growth. The cow received a growth hormone gene, which the scientists hope will promote milk production.

DOC.HEAD: Radio's `One Man's Family' Star Dies
DOC.TEXT: Radio actor Michael Raffetto, who played the original Paul Barbour on ``One Man's Family'' during the 1930s and '40s, has died. He was 91. Raffetto died May 31, his family said Thursday. No cause of death was given. Raffetto played the eldest son of Henry and Frances Barbour on ``One Man's Family,'' among radio's longest running and most popular programs. From its initial broadcast on April 29, 1932, until May 8, 1959, ``One Man's Family'' was heard regularly on NBC. Raffetto left the show in 1956. Raffetto played a fighter pilot who was wounded in World War I and whose bride had died in a flu epidemic. Beginning in 1939, Raffetto also played globe trotter and soft-spoken hero Jack Packard on ``I Love a Mystery,'' a radio program popular during the Depression and World War II. Raffetto was born in Placerville. He graduated from the University of California, Berkeley, in 1925 and practiced law briefly in San Francisco. He returned to Berkeley as a drama teacher and directed at Los Angeles' Greek Theatre in the late 1920s. In 1930, he starred in and produced NBC's ``Arm of the Law.'' He went on to become the network's West Coast program director and join the ``Family'' cast. His other radio credits included ``Death Valley Days'' and ``Attorney for the Defense.'' Raffetto made a few silent films in his youth, including ``Tillie's Punctured Romance.'' He also had a small part in ``A Foreign Affair'' with Marlene Dietrich in 1948 and ``Storm Center'' with Bette Davis in 1956. In his later years, Raffetto lived in Europe, where he wrote novels and short stories. He returned to Berkeley in 1960. He is survived by his wife, Constance, four daughters and five grandchildren.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS first item to CORRECT that Makarova is artistic adviser, sted artistic director
DOC.TEXT: Natalia Makarova will be the American Ballet Theatre's artistic adviser. In a statement Thursday, Miss Makarova said: ``I have considered American Ballet Theatre my home since I left Russia in 1970. ... I am happy to now be re-associated with ABT and look forward to passing on my knowledge and artistic experience.'' The dancer, who made her ABT debut in 1970 in ``Giselle,'' spent 15 years as a ballerina in the company. In her new position, she will consult on repertory and planning and advise on casting, coaching and stagings. She is married to businessman Edward Karkar. They have a son, Andre Michael, and live in San Francisco. No one has been named as ABT's artistic director since Mikhail Baryshnikov's resignation in September.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Hears Testimony on Possible Changes in Child Labor Laws
DOC.TEXT: A Texas businessman stung in a federal crackdown on child labor law violations cautioned Congress Friday against letting ``governmental paternalism'' ruin worthwhile work opportunities for youngsters. Donald Farrell said jobs like those he provides give youngsters, especially those from unstable homes, a chance to earn money, experience and self-respect. The Dallas business Farrell owns is under investigation for allegedly letting nearly 300 children illegally sell newspaper subscriptions at night. ``Please do not allow misguided idealism and governmental paternalism to close that door. They desperately need an alternative to the street corner and the dangers associated with that irresponsible lifestyle,'' Farrell told the House Government Operations employment and housing subcommittee. Farrell faces $150,000 in fines for alleged violations uncovered in a nationwide Labor Department sweep in March. He was one of several business officials who testified as the panel continued hearings on protecting children in the workplace. Executives from McDonald's, Burger King and Domino's pizza said they had implemented programs to ensure that young employees do not work in violation of federal law. Youngsters may only work restricted hours and are prohibited from working at dangerous machines such as paper balers, dough machines and meat slicers. Two high school students also testified, saying their grades had slipped because they were devoting too much time to their jobs. Christopher Randolph, a senior from Clifton Park, N.Y., said teen-agers were ``easy marks for exploitation.'' ``Our natural naivete and intuitive trust of adults makes us easy prey,'' said Randolph, adding that his former restaurant job frequently kept him at work until 11 p.m., two hours beyond the legal time. Congress is considering legislation to increase civil fines for child labor law violations from $1,000 a violation to $10,000. The legislation also would require jail terms for repeat and willful offenders. Along with congressional attention, the Labor Department has stepped up its enforcement. The nationwide sweep conducted in March uncovered 15,000 alleged violations. Federal agents followed with a one-day effort this week by visiting another 2,000 establishments.

DOC.HEAD: Funnywoman of Old Hasn't Seen the New
DOC.TEXT: Imogene Coca, a queen of comedy in television's early days, says she doesn't know the work of a current crown contender, Roseanne Barr. ``I've never seen the Roseanne Barr show,'' she said in Sunday's issue of Parade magazine. ``That must be on a night where they have a terribly good movie.'' Coca, 81, and Sid Caesar, stars of the 1950s ``Your Show of Shows'' variety program, have revived their act in a New York nightclub. Otherwise, Coca said, she is ``practicing to be a recluse.'' She said she often hunts for old movies on television to beat insomnia and watches soap operas from 11:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. ``I could have killed Dan Rather one day during a crisis when he came on and I couldn't see the soaps,'' Coca said. ``And it wasn't even that great a crisis, either.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Holds Hearing on Key Evidence Behind Closed Doors
DOC.TEXT: A judge ordered the press and public out of his courtroom Friday while hearing arguments on key evidence in the case against two brothers charged with the shotgun slayings of their parents. Superior Court Judge James Albracht closed a hearing on the question of whether the records of a psychiatrist who treated Erik and Lyle Menendez are admissable evidence. Gerald Chaleff, attorney for Lyle Menendez, asked that the hearing be held in secret, saying that it concerned matters of the psychiatrist's privilege and could not be held in public without violating that privilege. ``I apologize for these in camera (closed) proceedings'' Albracht told reporters and spectators in the crowded courtroom. ``I hope you can understand the reason for closing some of these proceedings. Privilege would not matter much if we had to discuss those privileged matters in public.'' Albracht said, however, that the material discussed in tape recordings seized from the doctor have never been disclosed to him because of their sensitivity. ``I think freedom of the press is very important,'' he said after several reporters raised their hands and asked to be heard on the issue. ``But I've given this a lot of thought and we simply cannot proceed in public when we discuss matters of privilege.'' The brothers are accused of murdering Jose Menendez, 45, and his wife, Kitty, 44, in the family's Beverly Hills mansion on Aug. 20. The couple was hit numerous times with shotgun blasts. Menendez was a wealthy executive of Live Entertainment Inc., a video distribution firm. The brothers said they found the bodies of their parents when they returned home from a night out. Prosecutors allege the brothers were motivated to kill their parents to claim their father's fortune.

DOC.HEAD: Nearly Empty Chamber is Last Straw for Senate Majority Leader
DOC.TEXT: The sight of a nearly empty Senate chamber Friday proved the last straw for Majority Leader George J. Mitchell. The Maine Democrat announced to a half dozen of his $98,000-a-year colleagues and about four times as many tourists that he was going to force some elected noses to the grindstone. Other senators were milling about elsewhere in the Capitol. ``We're just reaching the point where it is very, very difficult to move forward on any piece of legislation,'' said Mitchell. The man who is supposed to make things happen in the Senate couldn't force completion of action on any of four bills on his menu this week. The frustration over absences, delays, filibusters and endless amendments had been building. ``It is intolerable that the Senate cannot function if one of a few Senators have something else to do on one of the three days of the week of the three weeks of the month that the Senate is supposed to be in session and working,'' he said Thursday after trying to juggle next week's voting schedule. Senators have quit holding votes on Mondays and Fridays, presumably so they can visit with the people who elected them. Friday was an exception that Mitchell is suggesting he might make permanent. The majority leader is threatening to make Mondays and Fridays voting days, hold votes in the morning, make lawmakers burn the midnight oil other than on Thursdays, and cut into the four-week August recess. He didn't mention having the sergeant-at-arms make midnight arrests and physically carry reluctant lawmakers to the Senate floor. Democrats under former Majority Leader Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia resorted to that tactic in February 1988. Mitchell said he understood that two senators were in Czechoslovakia to monitor elections and others were attending graduations. And he said he understood the need for senators to sound out their constituents for advice. ``But those actions are not a substitute for, but in connection with and in preparation for activity which occurs on the Senate floor. ... All other considerations must give way to that overriding public consideration.'' Sen. Robert Dole, the minority leader, told Mitchell that he could lead senators to the floor but couldn't make them pass bills. ``I think I tried them all but none of them worked,'' said Dole, who was once majority leader. Being on the floor ``doesn't mean we're going to do anything in that time.'' Dole argued that the minority Republicans have their own view of what legislation is important and must use the available tactics _ such as filibusters and offering irrelevant amendments _ to affect the flow of bills. The Senate this past week was unable to complete action on a crime-fighting measure, a bill to change timber management at the Tongass national forest in Alaska, an override of the presidential veto of the Amtrak authorizing bill, and a bill to let blind airline passengers sit in exit-row seats. The Senate still has to deal with major pieces of legislation like the budget, defense, civil rights, and farm programs.

DOC.HEAD: Greek Prime Minister Renews Call for Turkish Army to Quit Cyprus
DOC.TEXT: Greek Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis said Friday that Turkish military forces on the island of Cyprus are ``a blot on the reputation'' of NATO and urged President George Bush to press Turkey to get out. Mitsotakis also said he had promised Bush, in their Wednesday meeting, that his newly elected New Democracy Party would rid Greece of the anti-American and Palestinian terrorism that plagued the Socialist government of his predecessor, Andreas Papandreou. ``My government intends to end the friction in relations with Washington that was evident during the eight years of Socialist rule in Greece,'' said Mitsotakis, whose meeting with Bush was the first visit by a Greek leader to the White House in 26 years. U.S. officials say relations with Greece have already improved since the conservative prime minister came to power in April. Mitsotakis, a newspaper publisher and veteran politician, said he had told Bush and other U.S. leaders that at a time when the Soviet Union has pulled out of Afghanistan and South Africa had withdrawn from Namibia, Turkey's continued occupation of Cyprus ``is a terrible blot on the reputation of the entire Western alliance. ...'' Mitsotakis addressed reporters and members of the Greek community at a National Press Club luncheon before departing for New York. Turkey invaded the Mediterranean island in 1974 in what it described as a move to protect the Cypriot Turkish community from the Greek majority. Cyprus has been divided into two regions with a U.N. force keeping the peace. ``The members of NATO, and especially the United States, can do much to end the Cyprus crisis and the time is now,'' he said. U.N. efforts begun last year to start peace talks between the sides have failed to progress. The United States has refused to become involved in the feud between Greece and Turkey, both members of the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization, preferring to let the United Nations mediate. Bush discussed the issue this week at a White House luncheon with U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar. Mitsotakis said he had made clear to the United States his government's desire to resolve the Cyprus problem in order to improve ties with Turkey. But, he added, the United States has it in its power to press Turkey into changing its policies. The Greek premier said he had told Bush his government would decide before the end of September whether to extradite Mohammed Rashid, a Palestinian wanted here in connection with a 1982 Pan Am bombing. The case has been stalled by Papandreou's government. ``In any case, we will never let Rashid free,'' he promised. Mitsotakis said that Rashid would either be handed over to the United States or put on trial in Greece.

DOC.HEAD: Maryland Anthill May Be One of the Nation's Largest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Some termites ...' to CORRECT that the Allegheny ants make largest mounds sted are largest ants
DOC.TEXT: William Merica doesn't want to make a mountain out of a molehill, but he did discover what a Harvard researcher says is one of the nation's largest anthills. Merica was walking down a road last month in this small town south of Baltimore when he saw what appeared to a moving mound of dirt. ``I thought the sun was playing tricks on me when I looked at it,'' said Merica. ``At first I thought the whole hill was moving, but then I looked up close and, my God, it was just solid ants! It was unbelievable!'' About 500,000 Allegheny ants constructed the 3-foot high, 8-by-15-foot oval mound, which is the largest in a six-mound area connected by a 115-yard ``ant highway.'' ``I've spent a lot of time in the woods camping and hunting and whatever, and I have never seen anything like it,'' Merica said. Merica reported his find to state and county officials. Harvard University researcher Stefan Cover said it probably took the ants at least four years to build the mound. Some termites are known to build larger nests in the tropics, but the Allegheny ants build the largest mounds in the United States and among the largest in the world, said Cover, an assistant curator of the world's largest ant collection, at Harvard. He said the largest Allegheny mound he has even seen was 8 feet across. State entomologist Gaye Williams identified the Arnold ants as Formica exsectoides, a harmless species native to Maryland. ``It's a very nice ant, very handsome and very strong. But it is of no importance other than as a curiosity,'' said Williams, who studies, plays with and even eats insects, as well as occasionally wearing jewelry made of them. The individual ants look like common red ants, about a quarter-inch long with red heads and bodies and black bottoms. Cover explained that the ants are able to build such enormous colonies because, unlike most ants, they do not harbor tribal prejudices. ``In most ant species, queens are intolerant of other queens, and the separate nests compete with one another for food. But with exsectoides the mounds can contain 30 or 40 queens working together,'' Cover said. The separate mounds even cooperate and seem to communicate with each other, forming a sort of United Nations of the ant world, he said.

DOC.HEAD: NRC Concludes Plant Vogtle Accident Could Have Been Prevented
DOC.TEXT: A Nuclear Regulatory Commission investigation concluded Friday that an accident that cut electrical power to safety systems at a Georgia nuclear power plant last March could have been prevented. But investigators praised operators at Plant Vogtle near Waynesboro, Ga., for restoring power to a reactor's cooling system within 36 minutes after a truck accident knocked out one power system and a backup generator failed twice to kick in automatically. ``My personal opinion is we ought to congratulate those operators,'' NRC Chairman Kenneth Carr said after the special investigative team briefed the commission on its findings. ``They were operating without a full deck of cards ... and they did a heroic job to get it back in 36 minutes,'' he said. The accident occurred March 20 while the plant's Unit 1 reactor was shut down for refueling. Two of the four electric power sources for Unit 1 safety systems were out of service at the time, and the reactor's cooling system was open for maintenance. A fuel delivery truck knocked out one of the two remaining power sources when it backed into a support column in an electrical switchyard at the plant. During the 36 minutes it took to get the backup diesel generator started, the temperature in the reactor cooling system increased from 90 to 136 degrees Fahrenheit. The accident also triggered an automatic shutdown of the Unit 2 reactor, which was operating at full power, because of a wiring error that had gone undetected since the plant was constructed. Carr said there never was ``any real serious danger'' that the loss of the Unit 1 reactor cooling system would have damaged the reactor core and resulted in a release of radioactivity. But he said the incident can provide lessons to improve the safety of nuclear plants. Ken McCoy, Georgia Power Co. vice president in charge of Plant Vogtle, agreed with Carr's assessment and with the investigative team's conclusion that the accident could have been prevented. ``I never felt uncomfortable that there was ever any real threat of a release of radioactive material,'' McCoy said. ``The operators were well trained and they did an outstanding job of getting the unit back on line.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Reiterates Warning To Curb Jewish Emigration
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday reiterated warnings that he will curb the emigration of Soviet Jews unless they stop settling in the Israeli-occupied territories. ``This is a very serious matter,'' Gorbachev said. He urged Israel to heed his warnings against West Bank and Gaza Strip settlements made during last week's summit in Washington. ``I hope that Israel will listen and then ... this process (of Jewish emigration) can go on normally and we won't be forced to introduce any corrections,'' Gorbachev told a news conference. ``If the situation became such that we have to react, we probably will have to apply our sovereign rights, our competence, and act,'' he said. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, who was visiting Moscow, joined Gorbachev at the news conference. Answering an Arab journalist, said settlement of Soviet Jewish emigres on the West Bank was wrong. She said Israel, not Gorbachev, was to blame. ``It is wrong that people who leave the Soviet Union should be placed in the occupied territories which we really regard as belonging to someone else and not the state of Israel,'' said Mrs. Thatcher. ``I think it is almost letting down those of us who have campaigned vigorously'' for Jewish emigration rights. A record number of Jews are leaving the Soviet Union following Gorbachev's lifting of emigration curbs. Israel says some 35,000 Soviet Jews have arrived this year and as many as 150,000 are expected, but that only ``a few hundred'' have so far settled in the West Bank. Israel says it has no policy of directing Soviet Jews to the occupied territories, where there are some 1.7 million Palestinians and about 70,000 Jewish settlers. The Palestinian uprising against the 23-year-old occupation is now 2{ years old.

DOC.HEAD: Inter-American Press Association Awards Announced
DOC.TEXT: The Inter-American Press Association, in its annual awards competition, has honored The Miami Herald for overall coverage of inter-American affairs and The Patriot Ledger of Quincy, Mass., for a supplement on the drug problem. The Miami-based group also honored three human-rights activists _ Elizardo Sanchez Santa Cruz, Hubert Jerez and Hiram Abi Cobas _ who have been imprisoned in Cuba for talking to U.S. journalists. The three were winners of the Pedro Joaquin Chamorro Freedom of the Press Award, named after the slain Nicaraguan publisher. The Miami Herald will receive the IAPA-Tom Wallace plaque for its year-round attention to inter-American affairs, exemplified by the series ``A Desperate Journey,'' documenting the flight of Nicaraguan refugees to the U.S. The award is named after the first president of the IAPA. The Patriot Ledger will receive the IAPA-La Nacion of Buenos Aires award for its supplement ``Crossroads _ Finding Our Way out of a World of Drugs.'' Kevin Sullivan of The Journal-Bulletin of Providence, R.I., was honored for his spot news coverage on Colombia and drug traffickers. Honorable mention in that category went to Diane Lindquist of The San Diego Union for a series about Mexico's ``maquiladora'' industry, in which U.S. parts are assembled using Mexican labor. The award for interpretive reporting went to Joel Millman for an article about the Salvadoran army in The New York Times Magazine. An honorable mention went to the Latin American staff of The Associated Press for a series of articles on ``A Continent in Crisis.'' The IAPA award for editorial writing went to Harry A. Fuller Jr. of The Salt Lake Tribune for a series on Latin American affairs. In the illustrations category, awards were given to editorial cartoonist Don Wright of The Palm Beach Post and photographer Ben Deboto of The Houston Chronicle, with an honorable mention to photographer David Walters of The Miami Herald. El Norte of Monterrey, Mexico, received the top award for Latin American newspapers. The awards will be presented at the IAPA's 45th annual General Assembly, to be held in Kansas City, Mo., Oct. 15-18.

DOC.HEAD: State of Emergency Lifted Except in Natal
DOC.TEXT: The 4-year-old state of emergency was lifted everywhere in the country Friday but in a region torn by black factional fighting, and a black union demanded the emergency be ended there too. President F.W. de Klerk announced Thursday the emergency would end at midnight Friday in three of the country's four provinces. The action removes some of the harshest political restrictions ever imposed by the country's white rulers and should help clear the way for black-white negotiations on ending apartheid. The end of the emergency ``is an important step in the normalization of our society and is an illustration of the government's declared policy to affirm the rule of law in a democratic South Africa,'' said Justice Minister Kobie Coetsee. But in the eastern province of Natal and the adjoining KwaZulu homeland, police still have sweeping powers to detain people without charge and break up demonstrations. The government had indicated it would keep the measures in effect in Natal, and it formally announced the decision Friday in the official Government Gazette. Black factional fighting has claimed more than 4,000 lives in Natal since 1986. About 500 people were killed in clashes during first three months of this year. The country's largest black labor federation criticized the government for extending the emergency decree in Natal, saying it was a pretext for police to continue abusing blacks. ``Our experience of the state of emergency in Natal is that it has provided a cover for the security forces ... to terrorize the people,'' said the Congress of South African Trade Unions, which is allied with the African National Congress. ``Retaining the state of emergency in Natal can only worsen the conflict, not resolve it,'' the federation said. The ANC, the country's most powerful black organization, has also condemned the retention of the state of emergency in Natal. The main combatants in Natal are supporters of the ANC and members of Inkatha, a relatively conservative Zulu organization. The ANC has said that in order for there to be black-white negotiations on a new constitution, the government must lift the state of emergency, release political prisoners and allow exiles to return. De Klerk wants to work out a constitution with opposition groups that will lead to sharing of power between the 5 million whites and 28 million blacks, who under apartheid have no voice in national affairs. Meanwhile, the pro-apartheid Conservative Party said the end of the state of emergency in Cape, Transvaal and Orange Free State provinces would lead to chaos and further alienate right-wing whites disgruntled with de Klerk's reforms. Conservative leader Andries Treunicht said the government should have required the ANC to renounce its armed struggle against apartheid before the state of emergency was lifted. But leading newspapers praised de Klerk's decision. The Cape Times said the action will have ``a steadying effect at home, while once more demonstrating to the world (de Klerk's) firm commitment to a negotiated settlement.'' ``Even for the cynics, the lifting of the state of emergency will mean more space, however small, has been cleared for political activity,'' said the Sowetan, a black-oriented newspaper. During the national emergency, more than 30,000 activists, most of them black, were detained without charge for varying lengths of time. Thousands more went into hiding after former President P.W. Botha imposed the restrictions on June 12, 1986. About 300 activists were being held under the emergency regulations as of Friday, most of them in Natal.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovakia Holds Its First Free Elections in Four Decades
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead, minor editing thereafter to trim and conform. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FRA3
DOC.TEXT: Voters cast ballots Friday in Czechoslovakia's first free elections following four decades of Communist rule, bringing democracy to their country only months after the overthrow of their hard-line rulers. President Vaclav Havel, the former dissident playwright elected by Parliament in December after a peaceful revolution, was loudly cheered as he walked with his wife Olga from his central Prague home to vote. Jostled by the crowd of about 200 people as the couple emerged from the polling station minutes later, Olga was asked how it felt to vote freely. ``Beautiful,'' she said. Voters dressed in their Sunday best turned out in moderate numbers across Prague for the two-day election to choose the 300 deputies that will sit in a new federal Parliament. Also at stake were seats for the regional Parliaments in the Czech and Slovak republics. The new Parliament will choose a president, and it is expected to elect Havel. Parliament's chief task during its two-year term is to rewrite the constitution. That will mean dealing with rising separatist sentiment in Slovakia, where many would like to see a looser alliance replace the federation of Czech and Slovak republics set up by the Communists in 1968. The first of the 11.2 million registered voters to cast their ballots were the coal miners of Ostrava, a mining and industrial center on the Polish border long known as a bastion of Stalinism. Their polling stations opened two hours ahead of the 2 p.m. (8 a.m. EDT) start of voting so their mining shifts would not be disrupted. Polls close at 2 p.m. Saturday, with initial returns expected later in the afternoon. Final results are not expected until Sunday. Civic Forum, the movement founded by Havel to lead last winter's revolution, and its Slovak partner, Public Against Violence, were heavily favored to emerge strongest from the voting. ``Civic Forum will do well, I'm sure,'' said Havel's spokesman, Michael Zantovsky, after voting in a Prague suburb. Echoing the latest pre-election opinon polls, Zantovsky predicted that Civic Forum would get about 40 percent of the vote, with the alliance of Christian Democrats polling about 20 percent nationwide but doing better in rural Slovakia. Asked about the Communists, Zantovsky made a thumbs-down gesture. ``Less than 10 percent,'' he said. All the 21 parties contesting the election alongside the Communists campaigned on a heavily anti-Communist platform. The fairly subdued campaign turned acrimonious and even violent in its final week. A bomb planted by unknown terrorists injured 19 people in Prague on Saturday. On Wednesday, a fierce row broke out between the Civic Forum and the Christian Democrats over the alleged links of a top Christian Democrat, Josef Bartoncik, with the hated Communist secret police. Both the Civic Forum and the Christian Democrats have said a coalition with the Communists is unlikely after the election. But former or reformed Communists who have worked in the interim ``government of national understanding'' forged by the revolution may keep their posts. Havel, 53, who before last winter's revolution was a reluctant candidate for office, has clearly grown into his post and enjoyed both guiding his country toward democracy and helping to reshape the order of a changing Europe. ``I liked him as a dissident, and I like him even more as a president,'' said Havel's neighbor, Zdenek Zadnik, 64, one of the crowd waiting to see Havel vote. During the voting, authorities banned the sale of alcohol except beer and posted police at public places, from polling stations to post offices. For young people who had never voted, and older citizens who thought democracy had vanished in the 1930s with the Nazis and again in 1948 with the Communist takeover, the balloting was a dream come true. ``I didn't hope to see free elections again,'' said Milena Jirotova, 68. ``It's a new feeling,'' said Katrina Hauffova, 20. The old Communist order ``seemed unchanging,'' she added. ``I couldn't imagine anything like this. Elections always seemed so controlled.'' Asked what outcome she'd like to see, she smiled and said, ``Five percent for the Communists.''

DOC.HEAD: Educators Strongly Differ on Free-Market Reform Idea
DOC.TEXT: Educators on Friday praised as ``perestroika'' or criticized as detrimental a proposal to deregulate public education and allow students to use tax-funded ``scholarships'' to attend the school of their choice. ``American education is about as effective as Russian agriculture and it operates in much the same way. What they are doing is redefining public education,'' said Michael Guerra of the National Catholic Educational Association. Guerra was referring to a Brookings Institution study that has heightened an already intense debate over how much control parents should have in selecting schools for their children. Authors John Chubb, a senior fellow at Brookings, and Stanford University political scientist Terry Moe studied various education reform programs, declared them unsuccessful and called for an end to government operation of schools in favor of an entirely new system based on free enterprise. Schools would compete for students in the open-market by providing genuine educational choices for parents and children. Chubb and Moe said their recommendations result from a 10-year nationwide study of American high schools, considered the largest of its kind ever conducted. They studied academic achievement using surveys of more than 20,000 principals, teachers and students at some 500 high schools nationwide. Under the Chubb-Moe plan, each school would determine its own governing structure and the state could not dictate a school's internal organization. A community ``Office of Choice'' would dispense funds, while a ``Center for Parental Information'' would counsel parents. ``What they are proposing involves radical change. They are talking about `perestroika' for American education,'' said Guerra, using the term referring to reforms in the Soviet Union. While the idea is being billed as radical, even revolutionary, Myron Lieberman noted that a similar idea was espoused in 1962 by economist Milton Friedman and in his own book published last year. ``The major weakness ... is in singling out the marketplace as the answer,'' said Lieberman. ``There is more than one feasible way of applying a market system to education,'' he added, pointing to the idea of allowing schools to contract out various areas of instruction. Walter Cooper, a regent of the University of the State of New York, said the authors may be ``overrating the potential for the entrepreneurial spirit.'' Gary Watts of the National Education Association called the proposal impractical. Thomas Shannon, executive director of the National School Boards Association, predicted government would expand ``given the huge amounts of public money involved and the natural proclivity of legislators to regulate _ all within an emotionally charged environment when dealing with citizens' children, their rights and their tax money.'' Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, agreed with the authors that ``the present governance structure of public education forces schools to respond to or protect the myriad interests of diverse pressure groups. ``It's no surprise that the result is excessive bureaucratization and educational gridlock,'' he said. ``Required to do just about everything, schools often find themselves unable to do anything very well.'' But Shanker said the authors ``never consider the possibility of changing the legal functions or roles of school boards so they do not produce bureaucratic paralysis. And they don't look at the possibility of moving school control to some other level of government where schools might not be subject to the same pressures they now face.'' ``There's a lot to commend,'' said Shanker. ``But to think that if we only changed the governance structure of education to a market model _ or anything else for that matter _ we'd solve the problems in our schools is a fantasy.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Doctor to Stop Using Suicide Machine
LaserPhoto DT1
DOC.TEXT: A judge Friday ordered Dr. Jack Kevorkian to stop using his suicide machine until prosecutors decide whether to try him for letting an Alzheimer's patient use the device. Oakland County Circuit Judge Alice Gilbert also enjoined the 62-year-old retired pathologist from helping people use any other means to kill themselves. The temporary orders are effective statewide, assistant prosecutor Michael Modelski said. Kevorkian, who acted as his own attorney, had asked the judge to allow him to set up a team of ``Untouchables'' to help terminally ill people end their lives. On Monday, Kevorkian assisted in the suicide of Janet Adkins, a 54-year-old Portland, Ore., woman who had been diagnosed as being in the early stages of Alzheimer's disease. Modelski said there were no immediate plans to prosecute Kevorkian, but an investigation was continuing. Kevorkian had asked the judge for a partial injunction, instead of the full stop order sought by prosecutors, to allow use of his machine in ``a specific set of circumstances.'' He said he wanted time to set up a committee of specialists to establish a permanent ``planned death policy'' for when to use the machine. He said he also wanted to set up an ``obitorium,'' a clinic for the terminally ill who want medical help with suicide. ``Let me put together a small team, called the Untouchables,'' Kevorkian told a media-packed courtroom. ``I guarantee, under my supervision, it would be incorruptible.'' Modelski questioned the judgment of Kevorkian's suggested clinic involving a person who is physically well but mentally ill. ``It's got to be a medical decision. I've had many healthy people call me, begging to get them out of their misery,'' Kevorkian said, adding the clinic would focus on people with incurable diseases. Kevorkian created an intravenous device that he hooked up to Mrs. Adkins at her request. It allowed her to press a button that fed coma- and death-inducing drugs into her bloodstream. The county prosecutor, state police and state medical association are investigating, although Michigan has no specific law against suicide or assisting in it. ``If my medical license is revoked, I will build another one and still help patients, but not as a physician,'' Kevorkian said in court. Kevorkian said his colleagues have been in the Dark Ages in opposing doctor-assisted suicide. ``I'm sure if they could they would burn me at the stake,'' Kevorkian testified, often glancing around the courtroom at reporters. Kevorkian's sister, Flora Holzheimer of Frankfurt, West Germany, testified that she drove Mrs. Adkins to the Oakland County park where she committed suicide. Holzheimer spent Saturday evening before the suicide with her brother, Mrs. Adkins and Mrs. Adkins' husband, Ronald. Each time her health faltered, ``she died a thousand deaths,'' Holzheimer said of Mrs. Adkins. ``Someone said to her, `Janet, you're just getting there before us.' She said, `I know' and smiled.'' Also subpoenaed for Friday's hearing was another sister of Kevorkian's, Margo Janus of Troy, who reportedly was present during the suicide in the back of the doctor's Volkswagen van. A survey published Friday found wide support for medically assisted suicide for the terminally ill. Two-thirds of 724 adults surveyed this week by telephone believed medical facilities should be available to help the terminally ill end their lives. The USA Today poll, with a sampling error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points, also found 28 percent feel Kevorkian should be prosecuted and 43 percent said he shouldn't be punished for helping Mrs. Adkins.

DOC.HEAD: One Found Guilty, Another Acquitted, in IRA Bomb Factory Trial
DOC.TEXT: A court on Friday convicted a London man of conspiracy in an IRA bombing campaign in Britain and sentenced him to 30 years in prison. Nicholas Mullen was charged in connection with one of the biggest caches of terrorist equipment ever found in Britain. The stockpile of arms and explosives was discovered in London in 1988. Justice Anthony Hidden, said Mullen, 42, was ``a very dangerous man.'' ``You combine a high degree of criminal cunning with a commitment to a particular cause. That cause deals not with arguments but with atrocities,'' Hidden said. The Old Bailey Central Criminal Court jury deliberated 12 hours before finding Mullen guilty of conspiracy to cause bombings for his part in the Irish Republican Army's 1988 bombing campaign. Eamon Wadley, 36, also on trial for terrorist offenses, was cleared of all charges. Police accidentally discovered the arms and explosives stockpile in south London in December 1988 after a man was shot in the stomach in a disturbance on the street in front of an apartment complex. The gunman ran into the complex, and a search of the area found an apartment filled with terrorist equipment, including nearly 200 pounds of Czechoslovak-made Semtex explosive, an unspecified number of machine guns and other firearms, rifles, handguns, and bomb-making equipment. During the six-week trial the jury heard how Mullen helped the IRA by renting apartments, buying used cars and obtaining false identities for the guerillas. However, the Old Bailey jury found Wadley innocent of aiding terrorists, and he was acquitted of four charges of making property available for use in connection with terrorism. Prosecutor John Nutting called the south London apartment ``one of biggest caches of terrorist equipment ever found in this country.'' The prosecutor said that if the plot had not been unexpectedly foiled, the IRA's campaign would ``certainly have led to the death or injury of many people.'' The IRA is waging a bloody fight to drive the British out of the predominantly Protestant province of Northern Ireland and unite it with the Roman Catholic Irish Republic.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Weighs Breaking Off PLO Talks After Foiled Israel Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 2nd graf raising reference to possible 30-day suspension
DOC.TEXT: By TOM RAUM=

President Bush said Friday he is considering breaking off talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization after the ``sheer terror'' of a thwarted Palestinian attack on an Israeli beach. In Washington, a senior administration official said he expected a 30-day suspension of the talks, though he said no final decision had been made and outright termination of contacts also was possible. Bush called on PLO leader Yasser Arafat to publicly renounce the attack and suggested the continuation of U.S.-PLO contacts depended on Arafat's response. ``Our dialogue is predicated on a renunciation of terror. In my view, this was sheer terror,'' Bush said. Asked if, as several news reports have suggested, he were considering breaking off the talks begun in December 1988, Bush said ``We are discussing all of that. No decision has been made. ... I'm not prepared to make an announcement on policy at this point.''
In his first public comments on the matter, Bush criticized Arafat for refusing to condemn last week's attack on the Israeli coastline by the Palestine Liberation Front, one the PLO's constituent groups. Arafat has said the PLO was not involved in the attack but has not condemned it outright. Israeli forces intercepted two speedboats filled with Palestinian fighters near Tel Aviv. Four of the Palestinians were killed and 12 captured. The attack followed the slaying 10 days earlier of seven Palestinian laborers by an Israeli the government described as deranged. Bush commented aboard Air Force One as he neared the end of a political fund-raising trip to Midwestern states. Shortly before he spoke, Secretary of State James A. Baker III, in Scotland for a NATO meeting, said the attempted raid ``has to be taken very seriously.'' But he also said that ``some perspective and responsibility is required in dealing with the issue'' and that the Bush administration was seeking more information before deciding on possible action. In Washington, an administration official said the United States has held at least four meetings with PLO representatives since the raid to discuss the organization's views on it. The official, speaking only on condition of anonymity, said no decision on breaking off talks was likely for a number of days. Another senior official said he expects the administration to suspend the dialogue with the PLO for about 30 days. But he did not rule out outright termination if the administration concludes that such a message to the PLO is necessary. He, too, said no decision had been made. Earlier, diplomatic sources in Washington said the United States would announce suspension of the talks next week. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the administration would cite the attack and the PLO's decision not to condemn the action. Bush said the attempted attack ``was horrendous.'' ``There was no rationale for it other than, in my view, terror,'' he said. Bush said that he had discussed the Middle East peace process earlier in the day in a telephone conversation with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. ``Both of us are still committed to getting the peace talks going forward,'' he sid. ``I've expressed my outrage about the attack'' last week, he said. ``Maybe I can take this opportunity to express my outrage about all the violence in the Middle East.'' He expressed some pessimism about the progress of peace efforts. ``Every time you get something started, there seems to be some outbreak,'' Bush said. ``I'm still outraged by the holding of U.S. hostages. I have this on my mind all the time. All of those things have a way of coming together.'' On efforts by Yitzhak Shamir, the caretaker prime minister of Israel, to form a right-wing government, Bush said it was ``an internal matter for Israel.'' ``I'll work with whomever that country puts forth as its government,'' he said. Asked if such a government would hamper peace efforts, Bush said that Israel ``knows the policy of the United States'' in wanting to get peace talks going between Israel and the Palestinians. ``The world is crying out for negotiations on this question,'' he said. U.S. talks with the PLO have been going on intermittently in Tunis since December 1988 when Arafat renounced terrorism.

DOC.HEAD: Ames Plans to Close 221 Stores, Lay Off About 17,500
DOC.TEXT: The Ames Department Stores Inc., trying to jettison unprofitable operations, announced plans Friday to close 221 stores and lay off about 17,500 employees as it struggles to emerge from bankruptcy protection. The closings, which represent nearly a third of Ames' 679 stores nationwide, must be approved by the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in New York, where the nation's fourth largest retailer filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankrutpcy laws on April 25. ``This is a critical first step towards our primary goal of leading Ames out of Chapter 11,'' said Stephen L. Pistner, the new chief executive officer brought in by Ames to steer it through its current troubles. The 221 stores being closed include 33 stores Ames previously said it would close and 184 former Zayre stores. Analysts have said Ames' acquisition two years ago of the Zayre chain led to Ames' downfall. Most of the stores being closed are in Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, North Carolina and Florida. ``This downsizing will cut our expenses, reduce operating losses and allow us to focus our efforts on serving our customers,'' Pistner said. The 458 stores staying open are mostly in the northeast. The company employed about 55,000 people at the time of the bankruptcy filing. Ames also plans to close distribution centers in Plant City, Fla., and Worcester, Mass. The retailer plans to complete construction of a distribution center in Leesport, Pa., in early 1991, subject to court approval. Ames hopes to realize $180 million in cash from liquidation sales this summer. The stores being closed lost about $48 million last year, Pistner said. Ames, which reported losses of $228 million last year, has attributed its troubles to the sluggish retail market in the Northeast and to problems with its 1988 acquisition of the 392-store Zayre chain. The $788 million acquisition doubled Ames' size and transformed the company from a little-known New England-based chain into the nation's fourth-largest discounter. It has since closed 90 of those stores and converted others to the Ames name.

DOC.HEAD: Suicide Machine Cricitized by Some Euthanasia Practitioners
With AM-Suicide Machine
DOC.TEXT: Some practitioners of euthanasia on Friday defended mercy killing but criticized the inventor of a suicide machine that an Oregon woman used this week to kill herself. The case was discussed here Friday on the second day of the World Conference of the International Federation of Right-to-Die Societies. The 21-nation gathering of physicians, lawyers and right-to-die activists, was called to consider legal, ethical and psychological aspects of the right to die. Janet Adkins of Portland, Ore. died Monday after using the suicide machine designed by Dr. Jack Kevorkian of Michigan. She had been told she was suffering from Alzheimer's disease. A judge in Michigan on Friday ordered Kevorkian to stop using the machine until prosecutors decide whether to file chargers in connection with the Adkins case. Herbert Cohen, a Dutch general practitioner also known for his willingness to perform mercy killing, said Kevorkian had used the device ``just so he could run away'' from the moral repercussions of the woman's death. Kevorkian's machine makes use of a button-operated intravenous drip. ``Such a machine is no expression of compassion, tenderness or care,'' Cohen said. Dr. Piet Admiraal, one of two Dutch physicians who have spearheaded a 15-year campaign for the full legalization of euthanasia here, said he had been approached by Kevorkian about use of the machine, but rebuffed him. ``I tried to explain to him time and again we don't need such a machine here,'' Admiraal said. ``I prefer to simply inject (the lethal drugs) myself ... and if the patient prefers to do it we give him a (euthanasia) drink.'' In an address to the conference on Friday, Cohen made no direct reference to the Adkins case. But he urged his colleagues to take the time to ``sit down, hold hands'' with patients who ask to die. ``You cannot ... discuss euthanasia, standing at the foot of the bed, in a white coat, mumbling Latin incantations,'' Cohen told his audience. Dutch legal and medical authorities widely approve of the principle that patients be allowed to opt for death when they face pointless suffering or terminal illness. However, mercy killing is still technically on Dutch law books as a crime carrying a 12-year maximum prison term.

DOC.HEAD: Salesman Sentenced for Spying for East Germany
DOC.TEXT: A West German salesman who provided two East German agents with commercially available items including dictionaries and brochures was convicted Friday of spying for a foreign power. A special court sentenced Klaus Tscheu, who has lived in France since 1966, to four years in prison with 18 months suspended. The seven-judge panel acquitted a co-defendant, Francoise Drouillaut. During the two-day trial, Tscheu, 51, said all he furnished to two East German agents during contacts from May 1982 to May 1983 were items available commercially, such as a Franco-German dictionary of computer terms he bought in a book store and leaflets on office equipment. He said he was paid about $2,550 for his services. Tscheu told the court he ended his contacts after a fourth meeting in East Berlin. He was arrested by French secret agents a few weeks later. Tscheu became involved with the German agents after placing an ad in a West German newspaper offering to act as a commercial representative in France. He said his own commercial ventures, such as selling Greek carpets, had been unsuccessful and he was in need of a job. When he first met the agents, identified as Michael Neubus and Peter, they said he could represent them in France, selling porcelain and shirts. However, Tscheu admitted in court that the men appeared ``a little strange.'' In three meetings in East Berlin, they asked him to supply seemingly banal information such as details on modern office equipment, a civil aviation map and a Franco-German technical dictionary. Tscheu told the court the material he provided was all available commercially. ``I was arrested,'' Tscheu said in testimony Thursday. ``But I'm not a spy and I never was. I was afraid.'' French agents were alerted by the husband of Ms. Drouillaut, who was Tscheu's mistress. They began investigating Tscheu and arrested him within weeks of his last trip to East Berlin. Ms. Drouillaut's husband, a navigating engineer at a flight test center, became suspicious after she began asking him a series of questions. The questions came after Tscheu's contacts requested technical information on the aviation industry. The husband allegedly wrote an anonymous letter to the local gendarmerie denouncing Tscheu as a spy.

DOC.HEAD: Elvis Impersonators Compare Pompadours, Pelvis Grinds
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: By STANLEY D. MILLER=

You say your sneer's a little crooked, your pompadour's a little flat and _ gasp, what would the King think _ you've forgotten the words to ``Don't Be Cruel''? No problem. A weekend convention featuring an international lineup of Elvis Presley impersonators _ about 80 altogether _ includes a seminar on how to be a better Elvis. ``Sure, you have to look like Elvis, sound like Elvis and capture all the little idiosyncracies,'' said Dave Carlson, who conducted a seminar Friday. ``But I can't grab a person's leg and say, `Here, move your leg like this.''' Carlson demonstrates, grabbing his own knee and moving it in a circle that threatens to tear the joint from its socket. ``Something's got to be there,'' said Carlson, who's been doing Elvis for 20 years. ``Most of it has to come from the individual.'' And there's plenty of them to go around. This weekend in Rosemont, a west Chicago suburb, the EP Impersonators International Association is holding its first annual convention. Here, Elvis comes in all shapes and sizes. They come from the suburbs, England, Australia. In fact, 15 states and six countries are represented. There's even a woman. ``As far as I know, I'm the only one,'' said 26-year-old Janice Waite of London. ``But when I'm on stage, I really don't think about it.'' Ms. Waite, a horse jockey off the stage, said her English accent doesn't bother her, either. ``I sing in an American accent,'' she said. ``I can't talk in it very well, but I can't sing any other way.'' Jerome Marion of Manteno, south of Chicago, wears a white jumpsuit _ opened to the bottom of his ribcage _ blanketed with sequins and eagle designs. ``The girls are the most exciting part,'' he said, while his wife, Brenda, smiled. ``I never introduce her as my wife. It would intimidate the fans,'' Marion said. ``That was my idea,'' said Mrs. Marion, who helps Marion during his act. ``I know how important this is to him. He gets the mirror first in the bathroom, too.'' Jumpsuits like Marions' replica of Presley's ``Aloha Hawaii'' outfit are for sale in the hotel lobby for $800 to $2,250. Custom outfits start at $1,000. Carlson, meanwhile, an Illinois native, said he makes his living impersonating the King of Rock 'n' Roll, playing two to three shows a week at nightclubs, festivals and outdoor concerts. But, he insisted, ``I don't take it to bed with me. ``The biggest mistake a lot of impersonators make is they take it off-stage with them. You have to know when to turn it off.''

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Union President Calls for Removal of Company Management
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound union president Edward M. Strait called Friday for a bankruptcy judge to oust the company's management and approve an employee take-over plan to save the nation's only nationwide bus line. ``I think the only salvation right now is an employee stock ownership plan and that's what we're pursuing,'' said Strait, who represents Greyhound's 6,300 union drivers, who walked out March 2 in a wage and job security dispute. Strait, in his first detailed response to Greyhound's filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection earlier this week, said in an interview that the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions wants to work with the bus line's creditors toward implementing an employee stock ownership plan. Any such plan would first require a bankruptcy judge's removal of current Greyhound chairman Fred Currey and the appointment of a trustee, Strait said. Union drivers could then resume work under their old contract and help the company become profitable again _ possibly with third-party investors _ and pay off debts, Strait said. The union would gradually gain an increased amount of control of the company's operations, he said. The only other way to save the company, Strait said, is for Greyhound to return to the bargaining table and seek a contract with union drivers for an end to the three-month-old strike. ``Those are not the only two ways,'' countered Greyhound spokesman George Gravley, noting the company filed Chapter 11 so it could reorganize its finances and continue operating. The company was forced into bankruptcy, Gravley said, because of strike violence that cost the company close to $50 million. There were dozens of shootings and bomb threats early in the strike, as well as violence on the picket line. A striking driver was crushed to death in Redding, Calif., by a bus driven by a replacement driver. ``What we are faced with is this one-time charge that is directly attributable to the violence of the strike that overwhelmed our financial system when it occurred all at once,'' Gravley said. ``If this had been a lawful, peaceful strike, we would not be in Chapter 11 right now,'' he claimed. Strait noted there have not been any acts of violence in more than a month. ``The violence seemed to end when the company got rid of all their Ninja security guards. They traveled in these black vans, they had these uniforms tucked into boots. If that isn't planned to initiate something, I don't know what is,'' Strait said. Instead, Strait claimed, the ``turning point'' that brought Greyhound to bankruptcy was a National Labor Relations Board complaint alleging that Greyhound's unfair labor practices caused the walkout. The complaint, formally filed last week, was crucial because it prompted concern among creditors since it opens Greyhound up to possibly $10 million a month in back pay, Strait said. Gravley said Greyhound could easily continue operating once it reorganizes its finances. ``There is a strong demand for our service,'' he said. ``This is not a sunset business that is disappearing because no one wants to buy from us.''

DOC.HEAD: Nevada Judge Clears Way for Quadriplegic to End His Life
DOC.TEXT: A judge Friday cleared the way for a 31-year-old quadriplegic to end his life after hearing the disabled man's ailing father testify his son wants to die before him. State District Judge Donald Mosley granted a petition sought by Kenneth A. Bergstedt that would allow a doctor to give Bergstedt a sedative and disconnect him from the respirator that he needs to help him breathe. ``He wants to go before I do,'' Bergstedt's 65-year-old father, Robert, testified. ``There's no future for him. He knows he'll never walk again. He knows he has to depend on someone else the rest of his life.'' But Mosley ordered the state attorney general's office to appeal to the Nevada Supreme Court and cautioned the elder Bergstedt against acting too hastily. ``This merely allows you the option,'' Mosley said. Mosley ordered an expedited appeal so the Supreme Court could set a precedent. Nevada has no laws governing such cases. ``One district court judge's opinion does not put this to rest,'' Mosley said. ``For the residents of the state of Nevada, and for Kenneth Bergstedt, a definitive resolution needs to be had.'' The request for the order was not opposed by Deputy Attorney General Donald Haight, who said he based his opinion on Bergstedt having a constitutional right to privacy. Bergstedt, who did not attend the hearing, has been paralyzed from age 10 since his neck was broken when a girl jumped into a pool on him while he was swimming. The elder Bergstedt said his son has wanted to end his life for 17 years, ever since he came to the realization he had no hope of recovering from injuries that shattered any chances of leading a normal life. ``He sees all these things are denied him that a normal man would do,'' he said. ``When he had it for three or four years he started realizing there was no cure. He expressed then his desire to die.'' Bergstedt said his son decided to seek a court order allowing him to die after hearing of a similar case about 18 months ago in California. He said his son, who spends most of his time on a gurney and cannot feed himself or handle any of his bodily functions, sees no reason to continue living. ``I'm not overjoyed with it,'' he said of his son's desire to die. ``But I do consent with what he's doing. I can see why he's doing it.'' He has cared for his son on a 24-hour basis since his wife died in November 1978, and he said his son fears being put in an institution when he dies. The elder Bergstedt has one leg, suffers from high blood pressure and said he recently had a spot discovered on a lung. ``It would probably be very difficult for him to adjust to a bunch of different people caring for him,'' Bergstedt said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Glasnost Comes to America in Harmonic Tunes
DOC.TEXT: Perestroika has brought the Soviet Union baseball, Big Macs and now a barbershop quartet; and that country's first such troupe harmonized here Friday to American classics like ``Chattanooga Choo-Choo.'' The Quiet Don Quartet, wearing Western European-styled suits, pleased a small crowd at the Faneuil Hall Marketplace with familiar melodies and lighthearted showmanship. ``It's not very known in Russia, but wherever we go people love it,'' said Yuri Ivanovich Vasilief, the smiling tenor in the group, through a translator. ``The people (in the Soviet Union) are usually very surprised, and people from the audience like barbershop style,'' said the group's bass, Oleg Nikolaevich Kovalenko. Evgeni Garreivich Feldman is the group's lead vocalist and Sergei Alexandrovich Tarakanov sings baritone. Vasilief, 55, said the quartet first heard barbershop singing _ a popular American tradition of simple, easy-to-sing melodies in four-part harmony _ at a music conference in East Germany in 1987. The group was visiting with their chamber choir from the Soviet Institute of Music in Rostov. Friday, the singers smiled and gestured with their hands as they performed several songs including ``Toot, Toot, Tootsie, Goodbye'' and ``Side By Side.'' The quartet members spoke little or no English, but sang the songs in English. ``It is not difficult to learn the songs, because they are very interesting,'' Vasilief said. The quartet arrived from the Soviet Union a week ago to perform with a barbershop group called the Big Apple Chorus in New York City, said George O'Brien, a representative of the Southshore, Mass., Men of Harmony, which brought the troupe to Boston. This was the first stop in a ten-city tour for Quiet Don Quartet, whose name is taken from the ``lazy flowing Don River'' in the Soviet Union, Vasilief said. ``I think this trip is one of many new bridges of communication between the two countries,'' Vasilief said, noting Soviet Union President Mikhail Gorbachev's restructuring plans and open-door policy with the United States. Kovalenko said the group received several letters and finally an invitation from a Los Angeles troupe, The 139th Street Quartet, to visit the United States. The Los Angeles group asked them to travel to San Francisco to compete in an international barbershop quartet competition beginning July 3. Getting permission to make the trip wasn't a problem, but the members couldn't afford airplane tickets, said Kovalenko, 27. The Society for the Preservation and Encouragement of Barber Shop Quartet Singing in America Inc. raised about $20,000 to bring the quartet to America, O'Brien said. ``They are going back (to Russia) to form other barbershop choral and quartet groups,'' O'Brien said. ``We're hoping that in a year or so there will be freer visitation rights in Russia.''

DOC.HEAD: Organization Aims Effort at Tropical Diseases
DOC.TEXT: An international health organization Friday began a 10-year program to help developing companies control tropical diseases such as intestinal worms and malaria. International Medical Services for Health, based in Leesburg, Va., is raising money from companies, individuals and foundations to help Third World countries solve their health problems. ``We know we can affect the lives of 500 million people by the year 2000,'' said Linda Pfeiffer, president of the nonprofit international health organization.'' More than 3 billion people _ half the world's population _ are afflicted by intestinal worms, malaria and schistosomiasis, she said. ``We can't do it for the whole world by the year 2000 ... but for this large part of the population we can contain it,'' she said in an interview. Officials of the organization were holding a two-day conference in Washington with representatives of nonprofit groups from 25 countries and public health experts to work on the project, called the Millennium Program. The conference was sponsored by an educational grant from SmithKline Beecham Pharmaceuticals, one of about 25 drug companies that contribute to the organization. The most widespread health problem in the tropical areas of Asia, Africa and South America is intestinal worms, Pfeiffer said. Most of the approximately 3 billion people afflicted with worms are children, and about 1 million children a year die, she said. An estimated 100 million to 300 million new cases of malaria occur each year; about 1 percent of them are fatal. Schistosomiasis, caused by an intestinal parasite, afflicts about 600 million people. The disease is less widespread than worms but is more serious, she said. The organization has distributed about $50 million in medical services since it was formed in 1986, she said. It also provides technical, planning and training assistance to nonprofit groups in developing countries.

DOC.HEAD: Argentine Fans React With Anger, Sadness to World Cup Defeat
With AM-World Cup, Newspage
DOC.TEXT: Burdened by four-digit annual inflation and a debilitating recession, Argentines encountered another setback Friday when their defending world champion soccer team was upset by Cameroon in the World Cup. ``How sad the result,'' said a bank clerk who identified herself only as Alejandra. Her normally crowded bank had emptied when the opening game of the tournament began in Milan, Italy. Buenos Aires' afternoon traffic slowed to a trickle, and many of Argentina's 32 million inhabitants gathered in front of TV sets in homes and offices to watch the game. Many fans blamed Argentine coach Carlos Bilardo, the team in general and individual players for the 1-0 defeat, one of the biggest upsets ever in world championship soccer. Cameroon was considered a 500-1 pick to win the tournament. Argentina, which won the World Cup in 1978 and the last tournament in 1986, has been expected to do well. ``Bad, very bad,'' said Obdulio Fernandez, a locker room attendant at the Ferro Carril Oeste soccer club. ``We need some new soccer players, that's all.'' In Milan, Bilardo said the loss ``was the worst thing that has happened to me'' since he took charge of the national team in 1983. President Carlos Menem, who watched the game at Milan's Meazza stadium, said Cameroon ``deserved the victory.'' Star player Diego Maradona, who did not get in a single shot against Cameroon, said he believes Argentina can still win soccer's top prize. ``We can't afford to lose again,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Killings Expose Strains in Republican Movement
DOC.TEXT: The staunchest public defender of the Irish Republican Army said Friday the IRA killing of a reserve police officer and his wife this week was wrong. ``You don't expect me to say that it was a good operation when it patently was not,'' said Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, the IRA's political wing. Last week, Adams criticized the mistaken killing of two Australian tourists in the Dutch town of Roermond on May 27 as ``inexcusable and unjustifiable.'' However, Adams also told reporters in London earlier this week that he regards the IRA as ``freedom fighters.'' On Friday he said the killing of soldiers is justified. The IRA says it aims to end British rule in Northern Ireland and unite the mostly Protestant province with the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic republic of Ireland. Within two weeks, it has killed six people: attorneys Stephen Melrose and Nicholas Spanos in Roermond; British army Pvt. William Robert Davies, 19, on June 1 in Lichfield; British army Maj. Michael John Dillon-Lee, 34, in Dortmund, West Germany; and retired reserve officer James Sefton, 65, and Ellen Sefton, 66, in Belfast. The Seftons were killed Wednesday by a bomb planted in their car. ``What happened to those two old people was totally wrong,'' Adams said on Thursday. He reiterated that Friday, saying it was ``wrong _ that is my position.'' Meeting with journalists Friday, Adams said it was not IRA policy to attack retired police officers. Other recent IRA ``mistakes'' included the killing of Heidi Hazell, 26-year-old German wife of a British soldier in September, the slaying of the 6-month-old daughter of a British soldier in Germany the following month, and the death of 16-year-old Terry Love, killed by debris from an IRA bomb while watching a parade in Londonderry in January. Some Sinn Fein activists have blamed such operations for the decline in the party's vote in national elections from a high of 13.4 percent in 1983 to 11.4 percent in 1987. Adams was in London this week to promote his latest book, ``Cage Eleven,'' about his experiences in prison. Questions, however, inevitably focused on the killings in Roermond, Lichfield and Dortmund. ``I have been very critical of the IRA. I have made my criticisms known in a principled way where it matters, in republican circles as well as the mass media,'' Adams said. ``There can be no doubt where Sinn Fein stands on actions which lead to the deaths of civilians or injuries to civilians.'' But he did not criticize the killing of soldiers. ``I don't want to see anyone killed, much less a 19-year-old soldier, an Australian citizen or an Irish citizens, but there is a conflict,'' he said. ``There is a war going on. People join armies to fight.''

DOC.HEAD: Vice Railway Minister, Eight Others Ousted from Chinese Party
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party has expelled a former vice minister of railways and eight other officials in his ministry for accepting bribes, the official media reported Friday. It is the second major corruption case in the Railways Ministry in nine months. Last October, the director of the ministry's transportation department and three aides were accused of taking bribes to allocate rail cars for transporting goods. Chinese leaders ordered a nationwide offensive against official corruption last summer after crushing a pro-democracy movement that won popular support by calling for cleaner government. In the latest case, Luo Yunguang, who had been vice minister of the Railways Ministry since 1986, was ousted from his job in March for accepting a gold ring, a refrigerator and $465 in bribes, official reports said. He was also accused of embezzling $200. Reports on the case have not said what he did for the bribes. The party's Central Commission for Discipline Inspection on Thursday circulated a notice expelling Luo and eight other ministry officials involved in the case, the official Xinhua News Agency and the nationally televised evening news said. Official reports in March said Luo had not been legally charged yet and prosecutors were investigating the case.

DOC.HEAD: Utah Fusion Experiments Unaffected By Texas A&M Reports
DOC.TEXT: New findings have thrown cold water on ``cold fusion'' experiments at several laboratories, but researchers at the National Cold Fusion Institute here remain undeterred. Researchers at two Texas A&M University labs and at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico have conceded that the palladium rods used in their cold fusion experiments were contaminated with tritium. Tritium is a byproduct of fusion, the bonding together of atomic nuclei to create energy. The researchers now believe that what they took to be evidence of fusion was actually contamination. Ronald Parker, director of the Plasma Fusion Center at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said skeptical scientists long have speculated that contamination might be responsible for the evidence of tritium in such experiments. ``The thing that does astonish me is that something this wasn't detected earlier,'' he said. ``Tritium is the thing that would still pique the interest of many scientists. Now that there seems to be a logical explanation, maybe it is the last nail.'' But a spokesman for the Utah institute said Friday that it used palladium rods from a different source than the other labs, and they are believed to have been uncontaminated. ``My impression is that people would be well-advised to analyze thoroughly the palladium they've used in their experiments,'' Institute Director Fritz Will said. Nuclear fusion is usually accomplished at extremely high temperatures, and is a costly process. Cold fusion would be highly attractive because it would be a cheap and virtually inexhaustible energy source. The cold fusion experiments were first reported by Utah electrochemist B. Stanley Pons and British colleague Martin Fleischmann. They involved a palladium electrode wrapped in platinum wire, then immersed in deuterium oxide, also called heavy water. In a March 29, 1989, announcement that sparked a furor, Pons and Fleischmann said that when they applied electricity to the room-temperature device, more energy was released in the form of heat than they put into it. The pair have said the cells also produced tritium, a product of fusion, although they have not published any scientific reports explaining their findings, nor have they or other researchers pinpointed the reason for the excess heat. Will, who joined the state-funded institute in February, said he could not speak for Pons and Fleischmann, who conduct separate experiments in their chemistry department laboratories in addition to those at the institute. Telephone messages to Pons went unanswered. But Will said that most, if not all, of the palladium rods used at the institute were purchased from Johnson Mathey, a British scientific supplier, and that specifications called for them to be 99.99 percent pure. The Wall Street Journal reported Thursday that Kevin Wolf, a physicist at Texas A&M University's Cyclotron Laboratory, had conceded that the palladium rods used in his experiments might have been contaminated. Wolf said the rods were purchased from Hoover & Strong, a metals processor in Richmond, Va. An official there said the company refines and processes palladium primarily for the jewelry trade, and thus isn't as concerned about purity as scientists might be. Wolf was not immediately available for comment. Palladium from the same company was used in cold fusion experiments at a chemistry lab at Texas A&M and at Los Alamos.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Sees Creation of All-European Security Alliance
With AM-NATO
LaserPhotos MOS9,10,23
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Friday he envisages a new relationship between the NATO and Warsaw Pact alliances and the establishment of an all-European security body. But after more than four hours of talks with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, Gorbachev said he remained opposed to a united Germany as a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. ``We believe there is a chance for the formation of a new type of relationship between the two alliances as they go through a transforming process while overcoming military confrontation ... in Europe,'' Gorbachev said. At a news conference with Mrs. Thatcher, Gorbachev added that if the 16-nation NATO alliance agreed at a summit in London next month to adopt a political role, ``an all-European system of security'' could follow. During the hour-long news conference, it was clear that Mrs. Thatcher did not change Gorbachev's mind about the military future of Germany, a key dispute unsolved at last week's superpower summit in Washington. Gorbachev also suggested the Soviets want a matching response from NATO to the decision by the seven-nation Warsaw Pact at a summit here on Thursday to become a purely political and ``consultative'' organization by November. The Warsaw Pact is, however, regarded as a dying military alliance incapable of mounting any joint offensive operation because of the fall of communist governments in six of the member states. ``I think that what happened yesterday testifies about deep changes in the essence of the (Warsaw Pact) organization,'' said Gorbachev. ``If the processes go in such a direction at the NATO meeting in July ... (this) will open the possibility for some agreement in favor of an all-European system of security,'' he said. Mrs. Thatcher disagreed, saying, ``For the time being we should continue to work through the existing organizations.'' But she also said that ``No country is more entitled to assurance, and reassurance, about the future of Germany than the Soviet Union.'' The prospect of a united Germany has revived memories in the Soviet Union of the devastating German invasion during World War II that left millions dead. At the news conference, Gorbachev said the NATO and Warsaw Pact military alliances cannot ignore the political cooperation that has developed between East and Western Europe in recent years. ``One can have a policy that will resemble an elephant in a china store: one move to the left smashes half of the store. A move to the right smashes the other half,'' he said. ``If this is the policy we choose, I don't envy us.'' He said he was ``sure'' a solution would be found to the German issue. In the talks, Mrs. Thatcher and Gorbachev discussed, among other things, a nine-point U.S. plan aimed at overcoming Soviet concerns about Germany in NATO. It includes proposals for keeping Soivet troops in what is now East Germany during a transitional period. Mrs. Thatcher, who is on a four-day visit to the Soviet Union, was to leave Moscow on Saturday to tour a British exhibition in the Ukrainian capital, Kiev. On Sunday she goes to Armenia's second city, Leninakan, hit by an earthquake 18 months ago.

DOC.HEAD: Warm and Humid Air Covers Most of Nation
DOC.TEXT: Hot, humid air covered most of the nation Friday, as severe thunderstorms hit the central Plains, middle Mississippi Valley and much of the East. Temperatures reached the 80s and the 90s across much of the nation and climbed in the 100s in the desert Southwest and near the Rio Grande in Texas. Cooler temperatures, 60s and 70s, stretched over much of the northern tier, from the Pacific Northwest to New England. Golfball-size hail fell in Omaha, Neb., and thunderstorms over Western Kansas dropped dime-size hail in Goodland. Golfball-sized hail and four inches of rain fell in Excelsior Springs in northwest Missouri. In southwest Kansas, 1.70 inches of rain fell in Kearney. A warm front stretched from the Chesapeake Bay to southern Michigan, producing showers over much of the region. A strong thunderstorm produced dime-size hail in southern central Virginia. Showers and thunderstorms were reported in Ohio and Pennsylvania. In central Indiana, 3.75 inches of rain deluged Sheridan in just over a two-hour period, and 2.80 inches of rain fell in about two and a half hours at Alexandria. Gunnison, Colo. and Butte, Mont., tied for the nation's low temperature Friday at 33 degrees. On Saturday, rain is expected in the Northeast and much of the West while sunny skies are predicted for the central part of the nation. Temperatures are expected to again reach the 100s in the Southwest.

DOC.HEAD: Students Occupy Spanish Embassy in East Berlin
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of a Spanish terrorist group on Friday seized the Spanish Embassy in East Germany, forcing the ambassador and his staff from their offices, officials and news reports said. However, the 12 East German leftists surrendered to police about two hours later, the government news agency ADN said. The Spanish Foreign Ministry said Ambassador Alfonso Alvarez de Toledo and his staff were forced out of the East Berlin embassy during the takeover. No injuries were reported. Embassy attache Luis Fernandez said the youths were East Germans who declared solidarity with a Spanish leftist terrorist group known as GRAPO. The group is seeking to have its jailed members housed in the same prison. The organization has claimed responsibility for 30 killings since it was founded in 1975.
