Eighty-one of the members are in prison, and the government has sent members to many different prisons. Most of the 81 inmates have staged hunger strikes to protest the prisoner dispersal policy, and 40 are still on strike. One GRAPO member died of a heart attack May 26 after 177 days without food.

DOC.HEAD: KLM To Ground Pregnant Stewardesses Because Of Radiation Fears
DOC.TEXT: The national airline KLM will begin grounding pregnant stewardesses this fall because of a U.S. report saying crews may be exposed to harmful levels of radiation, a company spokesman said Friday. The study by the U.S. Transportation Department, released in February, estimates the lifetime cancer risk due to cosmic radiation for airline crew members who fly 960 hours annually would be from five to 61 deaths for every 100,000 individuals in 20 years of flying. It also notes some risk to frequent fliers and to the fetuses of pregnant women during the first trimester of pregnancy. ``We were planning on making some changes anyway, but the reports of possible dangers related to higher radiation levels made us act faster,'' KLM spokesman Hugo Baas said. Scientists and U.S. officials caution that the risk data was not based on any study of actual cancer cases but on mathematical models projecting the effects of low-level radiation from the sun and stars. Folkert Draaisma, a radio-biology expert at the National Scientific Research center in Rijswijk, said radiation is most dangerous between the 8th and 15th weeks of pregnancy, when fetal brains are formed. ``I estimate that a stewardess who flies during her entire pregnancy will reach the unacceptable level,'' which he indicated was 40 percent above the normal dose of cosmic radiation that everyone routinely receives. According to the new airline regulation, once a stewardess reports her pregnancy, she must be given the option of an alternative job on the ground or an extended paid pregnancy leave, union leader Joop Kostermans said. Kosterman heads the Dutch Association of Cabin Personnel, which represents 98 percent of KLM's 4,100 flight attendants.

DOC.HEAD: Russia: Its Laws Should Have Priority Over Central Government's
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to ADD that Russian Federation is largest, most populous of the 15 Soviet republics, minor editing. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Gorbachev strongly...'
DOC.TEXT: In a move reminiscent of the Baltic republics' first steps toward secession, lawmakers of the vast Russian Federation approved a draft proclamation that would give their laws priority over national legislation. The Russian Congress, led by radical reformer Boris N. Yeltsin, approved the article in a draft ``Declaration of Sovereignty'' by a 544-271 vote, the Tass news agency reported. The final version of the document must still be voted on. Most laws on the books in the 15 Soviet republics mirror national laws, but sovereignty allows the republics to push ahead with legislation that might contradict Kremlin wishes. The Russian Federation is the largest and most populous of the Soviet republics. The Russian Federation, with its capital in Moscow, comprises two-thirds of the country's territory and contains more than half its population. The vote appeared to set the stage for a confrontation between Yeltsin and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who has warned that the Kremlin cannot carry out its reforms if the Russian heartland is not firmly behind it. Gorbachev strongly opposed Yeltsin's election last month as president of the Russian Federation, saying his plans could lead to the breakup of the country. But he expressed no concern about Friday's measure. ``The Russian Congress has not passed anything that would contradict the Soviet Constitution,'' he told a news conference after he met with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, who was visiting Moscow. ``And I'm sure _ if you ask what percent, 100 percent sure _ that neither the Congress of People's Deputies of Russia nor the future Supreme Soviet will pass laws that would damage the development of the federation or complicate its reformation,'' he said. ``The Russian people will not stand for being pushed to pit themselves against other people, for breaking up the union,'' he added. The Baltic republics of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia began their drive for independence by proclaiming the priority of their laws over national laws. The Kremlin rejected their declarations of sovereignty, and it has imposed a partial economic blockade against Lithuania. Gorbachev indicated Friday he would seek a reconciliation with Yeltsin even if he continues his strong push for Russian sovereignty. ``What would disturb me more than anything at this stage is a split in the democratic forces,'' he said, implying that he viewed Yeltsin as an ally in the reform movement. Yeltsin, who has become Gorbachev's political nemesis over the last two years, has said he hopes to cooperate with Gorbachev despite their personal and political differences, but that his first priority is defending Russia's interests. He met recently with Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis and promised to set up strong ties with the breakaway republic as soon as Russia gained sovereignty. The pledge implied he would be willing to circumvent the Kremlin's blockade against Lithuania, which was imposed to pressure the republic into suspending its March 11 declaration of indpendence. The Russian Congress, which convened for the first time in late May, discussed the idea of sovereignty for hours, and virtually all deputies supported it as a means of gaining more independence from centrally dictated decisions. However, there were widely varying opinions on how far sovereignty should go. The measure passed Friday instructed the editorial commission working out Russia's declaration of sovereignty to base its work on the idea that Russian laws supercede national ones. ``The legal sense of this is that Russian laws have a certain priority over Soviet laws,'' said Sergei Gribanov of the Congress' press center. ``But I wouldn't say this should be taken as a secessionist declaration.'' A final draft of the declaration likely will not be ready before Wednesday, he said. Press center officials said they believed the draft would require a two-thirds majority in the 1,060-member Russian Congress. The brief Tass report from the Congress said the declaration proclaims ``the priority of the Constitution of the Russian Federation and laws of the Russian Federation on the entire territory'' of the republic. It would suspend any laws of the Soviet Union that contradict the republic's laws.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Agent: Security Breach `Unprecedented'
DOC.TEXT: A former U.S. Army sergeant with a brilliant ``criminal mind'' has admitted selling secret NATO plans for the nuclear defense of Europe that were passed to the Soviet Union, an FBI agent testified Friday. ``It's one of the most serious breaches ever _ it's unprecedented what went over to the other side,'' said Joe Navarro, who led the FBI's investigation. ``The ability to defend ourselves is neutralized because they have all our plans.'' Roderick James Ramsay, 28, made his initial court appearance Friday on the charge of conspiracy to gather or deliver defense information to aid a foreign government. U.S. Magistrate Elizabeth Jenkins ordered him held until a bond hearing Tuesday. Ramsay's attorney, Mark Pizzo, did not enter any plea on his client's behalf. Ramsay faces a maximum penalty of life imprisonment if convicted of espionage conspiracy. Ramsay was arrested Thursday night on a downtown street following a two-year investigation. The FBI said Ramsay worked in West Germany from 1983 to 1985 directly under Clyde Lee Conrad, 43, a retired U.S. Army sergeant convicted of treason by a West German court and given a life sentence earlier this week. When the FBI began collecting information on Conrad in mid-1988, agents conducted the first of some 40 interviews with the cooperative Ramsay, authorities said. ``Ramsay has acknowledged that he was in fact recruited by Conrad in mid-to-late 1983 and participated in espionage activity with him,'' Navarro testified. Ramsay had a high IQ, speaks fluent Japanese, Spanish and German, and has the ability to recall minute details, facts and figures from hundreds of volumes of documents, Navarro testified. Those included sensitive documents on the use of tactical nuclear weapons by U.S. forces and NATO allies, and plans for the defense of Central Europe, the Justice Department said. Ramsay also leaked technical manuals on military communications technology and material about the coordination of NATO forces. ``He had the unique privilege of being posted where a lot of highly sensitive information came through his hands,'' Navarro said. He mentioned other examples such as the sites of nuclear storage areas and contingency plans in the event of a nuclear attack by the Soviet bloc or a Third World nation. The material was passed to Hungarian and Czechoslovakian agents and eventually fell into the hands of the Soviet KGB, according to FBI and Justice Department officials. ``It involves an extensive amount of information provided to the Soviet intelligence service through Eastern European surrogates,'' said Justice spokesman Doug Tillett in Washington. Navarro testified that Ramsay began by photographing documents and later discovered he could record more information with a video recorder. In December 1985, the agent said, Ramsay spent a week recording some 45 hours of documents he had either stolen or copied. Although Ramsay told the FBI he received only $20,000 for his efforts, Navarro estimated the East bloc agents paid between $2.2 million and $5 million for the information from the ring. Authorities believe some of the money is stashed in foreign bank accounts, said law enforcement sources speaking on condition of anonymity. Investigators are trying to trace the money. Conrad controlled the money and Ramsay wanted very much to obtain it, especially since recent financial problems forced him to live at his mother's home in Tampa or sleep in his car, Navarro said. FBI agents would not discuss why they investigated Ramsay and kept him under surveillance for two years before making an arrest, but Navarro said agents hoped his cooperation would lead to other suspects. Ramsay's last known contact with Conrad came in January 1986 in Boston, when his former boss gave him a small cow bell and told him that anyone displaying a similar bell was involved in the spy ring, the agent testified. While the FBI has no evidence that Ramsay participated in espionage since 1986, his vast knowlege of NATO secrets made him a ``highly marketable commodity'' to hostile governments, Navarro said. During the investigation, agents learned Ramsay had stashed top secret documents at his mother's house and later destroyed them, Navarro said. The agent added that Ramsay still claims to have a tape with highly sensitive defense information. Agents searched the home and Ramsay's car following his arrest, but have not revealed what was found. The FBI agent described the mustachioed, bespectacled suspect as having a ``criminal mind'' and no remorse for his actions. Before joining the Army, Ramsay is believed to have participated in a 1981 bank robbery in Vermont and then fled to Hawaii, Navarro said. He added that Ramsay said he tried ``every drug under the sun'' and in fact was forced out of the Army in 1985 after traces of hashish showed up in a urine test. Ramsay was a man who had no fear of going to jail, telling FBI agents as recently as a month ago he would be able to read, get a law degree and obtain a criminal education, Navarro said. ```Look out when I get out,''' Navarro quoted Ramsay as saying, ```because I'm going to be an educated criminal.'''

DOC.HEAD: Miriam Makeba to Return Home After 30 Years
With AM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: South African singer Miriam Makeba, whose music was banned on government-run radio and television for 12 of her 30 years in exile, is to return home Sunday for a brief visit. Ms. Makeba, who has frequently spoken out against racial discrimination in South Africa, is best known for songs that rely heavily on traditional African rhythms. She spoke out against apartheid at the United Nations in 1976 and as a result, South Africa's government-run radio and television refused to broadcast her songs until last year. In 1987 she performed with singer Paul Simon on his ``Graceland'' tour. Ms. Makeba, 58, left South Africa in 1960 after touring abroad. She has lived in the United States, Guinea, Belgium and is now a resident of France. A spokesman for the South African Musicians' Alliance confirmed the visit by Ms. Makeba, and said she would not be performing. Ms. Makeba plans to see family and friends and visit the grave of her mother who died when she was in exile. Ms. Makeba has been married five times, including a marriage to political activist Stokely Carmichael.

DOC.HEAD: Principal Drops Charges Against Two Who Threw Paper Planes During Graduation
DOC.TEXT: A principal has asked for dismissal of criminal charges against students who threw paper airplanes during a graduation ceremony. ``This thing is settled and we want it to end. It has hurt the community and the school,'' Live Oak High School principal Owen Norgress said Thursday. Everyone involved in the May 25 graduation flight has apologized and none will be prosecuted, he said. Jared S. Vicknair and David D. Wallace, both graduating seniors, had to post $500 property bond each last week after Norgress filed a criminal mischief complaint against them. Vicknair's attorney, Eric Pittman Jr., said more than 20 other seniors also threw paper airplanes at the faculty. The sheriff's office had said earlier that at least three other seniors were involved and would be arrested when they returned from senior trips. ``I will ask the sheriff's department to drop all charges against the persons involved,'' said Norgress.

DOC.HEAD: Wildman Back Leading Tours as Private Citizen
DOC.TEXT: ``Wildman'' Steve Brill helped Wisconsin nature lovers munch their way through Central Park on Friday, warning the group they were breaking the law with each leaf picked. ``Three whistles is an SOS or ranger alert,'' he said at the outset of the tour, his first in the park since he quit his Parks Department job last month in a dispute with the new commissioner. Parks spokesman Skip Garrett said the department would not take any action against Brill unless he engaged in ``wanton destruction of the flora.'' Since 1981, Brill has led an estimated 15,000 people on walking-dining tours of city parks, encouraging people to sample the edible flora growing wild. Parks officials had him arrested in 1986, but reached an agreement for him to continue the tours as a city employee. But new Commissioner Betsy Gotbaum complained Brill didn't want to punch a time clock or report to an office, and that he was encouraging people to take things out of the park. She also said it could be unhealthy to eat things picked from the parks, given the number of dogs who relieve themselves there. Brill quit on May 29 rather than accept the new rules, he said. The group from the Riveredge Nature Center in Newburg, Wis., had arranged their tour with Brill last year and decided to stick with the plan despite his changed status. ``I think it's absurd, but then I've only heard his side of the story,'' said Pat Sherman-Cisler of Milwaukee, one of about 50 tourists.

DOC.HEAD: Floods Force Apparently Rabid Skunks Into Light of Day
DOC.TEXT: High water has flushed disoriented and probably rabid skunks into populated areas, and animal control officers are worried pets could be infected. Julie Glover, director of Bossier Animal Control, said skunks are nocturnal, but five were seen during the day in Bossier Parish in Northwest Louisiana between May 15 and June 1. The area has been beset by heavy rains. ``It wouldn't be impossible to have a large rabies epidemic,'' Glover said. The disease could easily spread to the many unvaccinated pets and wild cats in Bossier, she said Thursday. In nearby Shreveport, Regional Laboratory Manager Sam Marsala said there are probably rabid skunks, but no one has notified the authorities of sightings.

DOC.HEAD: Patton Letter Sold for $17,600
DOC.TEXT: A letter from Gen. George S. Patton Jr. describing how he motivated a fearful platoon in combat has been sold for $17,600. Patton sent the signed letter in 1944 to Gen. Charles Summerall, a former Army chief of staff who was one of his teachers at West Point. In it, Patton described how he ordered a retreating platoon to attack. ``The interesting thing was that the simple statement on my part that they would attack removed the nervous tension,'' he wrote. ``It is really amazing what the determination on the part of one man can do to many thousands.'' The letter was sold Thursday by Herman Darvick Autograph Auctions to an anonymous private New Jersey collector. The letter was one of seven Patton letters sold at the auction for a total of $50,325. One unsold item was a handwritten 1967 letter in which Ronald Reagan admonished his daughter Patti, then 14, for using ``deception'' to hide her smoking. Bidding reached $19,000 but the seller demanded a $20,000 minimum. Also Thursday, an 1847 letter from Charlotte Bronte to the publisher of her novel ``Jane Eyre'' sold at Christie's auction house in Manhattan for $52,800. It was signed with the Victorian author's pen name, Currer Bell.

DOC.HEAD: Baltic States Want to be Included in European Conference
With AM-Soviet-Russia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The foreign ministers of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia said Friday they made a joint request to attend a 35-nation meeting on human rights. The three Baltic states of the Soviet Union applied for separate observer status in a letter to Executive Secretary Ulrik Haxthausen of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, Lennart Meri of Estonia said. Meri told reporters they received no reply. He was joined by Janis Jurkins of Latvia and Algirdas Saudargas of Lithuania. At the opening of the conference meeting Tuesday, a separate Lithuanian request for observer status was rejected. The Danish foreign minister, Uffe Ellemann-Jensen, said admission of Lithuania was impossible because the Soviet Union would object. Lithuania on March 11 declared its independence from the Soviet Union, but Moscow has refused to recognize the declaration and imposed an economic blockade on the republic. The two other Baltic states are also seeking independence from Moscow, which took over the three republics in 1940 under terms of a Nazi-Soviet pact. Albania, the last hard-line Communist state in Eastern Europe, was allowed to attend the conference meeting in Copenhagen as an observer. Albania is the only European country that has not signed the 1975 Helsinki agreements on security and human rights that resulted in the 35-nation group.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Collaborator Slain in Occupied West Bank
With AM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The body of a Palestinian man who allegedly admitted to collaborating with Israel's Shin Bet internal security service was found Friday in a field in the occupied West Bank, Arab reports said. The victim, Ismat Yousef Al-Salem, 27, had been taken from his home two weeks earlier by masked Palestinians, the reports said. He had been stabbed repeatedly. The body of Al-Salem was found outside the village of Kufr Zibad near the West Bank's largest city, Nablus. Arab reports said after his abduction Al-Salem announced through a loudspeaker from the village mosque that he had worked with the Shin Bet since 1982. They said a leaflet distributed in the village accused him of collaboration. The army confirmed the death and said police were investigating. Al-Salem's death raised to at least 219 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs since the Palestinian revolt against Israeli occupation began in December 1987. Most were accused of collaboration with Israel. A total of 716 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers and civilians, and 45 Israelis have died in the violence. Also Friday, the army demolished the top two floors of a house owned by Mohammed Hassan Baker, 55, in Gaza City. Arab reports said Baker's son, Mazen, 27, is wanted by Israel on charges he was a member of a Palestinian enforcement group that killed suspected collaborators. The two floors contained five rooms that were home to 21 people.

DOC.HEAD: Railroad Strike Ends In Maryland And Five Other States
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge issued a temporary restraining order Friday forcing striking railroad workers in Maryland and five other states to dismantle their pickets and go back to work. ``We are in the process of notifying our people to remove their picket signs. I know they will,'' said George Laitila, a regional representative for the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, which organized the strike over the indefinite layoff of 11 crane operators in Cumberland. Laitila said thousands of union workers honored picket lines at six locations in Baltimore, Cumberland, Jessup and Brunswick in Maryland; Grafton and Fairmont, W.Va.; Pittsburgh and Philadelphia, Pa.; Wilmington, Del.; Garrett and Washington, Ind.; and Cincinnati and Willard, Ohio. U.S. District Judge John R. Hargrove issued the 10-day restraining order to end the strike, which forced 7,400 riders on two Maryland commuter lines to find other ways to their jobs in Washington, D.C. ``In effect, he called the strike off,'' said Lloyd D. Lewis, a CSX spokesman in Jacksonville, Fla. ``The determination was that this was a minor dispute that did not allow the union to strike.'' Laitila disagreed. ``We're not going to defy a federal judge,'' he said. ``The next step will be a hearing in federal court where we will have an opportunity to present our case to a federal judge.'' The IBEW contended that CSX violated an agreement with the electrical workers when it announced a furlough last week of 45 employees at a train yard in Cumberland. The indefinite layoff included 11 crane operators. ``The company took illegal action that affected 11 people directly,'' Laitila said. ``I called out 375 electrical workers I represent. In support of their fellow unionists, the other railroad labor unions honored our picket lines to an incredible degree.'' CSX spokesman said it was impossible to know how many people honored the union's picket lines.

DOC.HEAD: Gibbs Found Innocent in Second Murder Trial
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of pushing his wife and her friend off a cliff was acquitted of murder Friday, a year after another jury deadlocked in the same case. James Gibbs had insisted that Helen Gibbs and Susan White Haire fell to their deaths accidentally while he was taking their picture at a scenic overlook on the Blue Ridge Parkway. He said the two women were sitting on a stone ledge, and one grabbed the other's arm as she fell. He was charged with two counts of first-degree murder for the deaths on Oct. 17, 1988. ``He might have been guilty, but the state couldn't prove it,'' said jury forman Norman Arrowood, adding that the jury split 11-1 during morning deliberations. The jury took about three hours to return its verdict. A mistrial was declared last June when another jury deadlocked at 10-2 votes for conviction. Gibbs, 38, left the courtroom a few minutes after the verdict and was mobbed by reporters. Family members of Mrs. Gibbs cried and left quickly. ``Well, my feet hurt, I've been walking on them,'' Gibbs said in reference to pacing in his cell. During four weeks of testimony, prosecutors contended that Gibbs had a history of physically abusing his wife and that he was angered by her plans to leave him and get a divorce. Defense Attorney Charles Burgin told the McDowell County jury Thursday the state failed to prove several key elements in the case, including a motive. Gibbs had been in jail for close to two years since his 1988 arrest.

Los Alamos National Laboratory is trying to determine how one of its employees was exposed to radioactive tritium, a lab spokesman said Friday. The employee, whose name was withheld, worked in an area where experiments are conducted on materials that may be used in nuclear weapons, said lab spokesman John Webster. Tritium is a man-made radioactive isotope of hydrogen. The exposure dose cannot be definitely determined until the time of exposure is known, but the dose hypothetically could be as much as 3.2 rem, the lab said. A rem is the unit of measurement used to describe the biological effect of radiation exposure. Natural background radiation exposes a person to 0.1-0.3 rems a year; a routine chest X-ray, 0.6 rems. The maxium exposure allowed for federal workers is 5 rem a year. The employee's exposure was detected this week during a routine urinalysis, Webster said.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Says TV Marti Being Seen Despite Jamming
DOC.TEXT: An independent survey has concluded that the U.S.-government sponsored television station sending test broadcast which broadcasts to Cuba is reaching ``at least occasionally'' about 28 per cent of the households in western Cuba, officials said Friday. Tony Navarro, who directs the TV Marti operation, said the survey repudiates Cuban claims that extensive jamming has been virtually 100 per cent successful in keeping the station's news and entertainment shows from reaching Cuban households. TV Marti has been testing since March 27. Sometime this summer, President Bush is expected to make a determination as to whether the broadcasts should become permanent. The survey was taken of 543 Cubans who have arrived in the United States since testing began. Navarro said in an interview that the results clearly indicate that TV Marti is a worthwhile project that should be continued despite the jamming effort. The sampling, which was performed by a New York firm, was limited to Cubans who live in the ``primary target area'' of TV Marti _ the city of Havana and three western provinces. ``Twenty-eight per cent of the households in the primary target area appear to be able to receive TV Marti at least occasionally,'' Navarro said. He said the word ``occasionally'' means anywhere from five minutes to three hours at least twice a week. He said the credibility of the testimony of the witnesses was reinforced by the fact that 57 per cent were able to recall and identify specific programs. President Fidel Castro has called TV Marti a ``gross instrument of subversion'' and made arrangements to block the signal from the first day that programming began. He also has said the operation violates international law. In addition to jamming TV Marti, Cuban authorities also have begun blocking the signal in the Havana area of Radio Marti, a Voice of America station that began broadcasting five years ago. TV Marti has limited testing to the pre-dawn hours in order not to interfere with regular programming by Cuban stations. Its supporters maintain that TV Marti helps break the monopoly over news that the Cuban government has had for 31 years and also provides the Cuban people with more varied entertainment.

DOC.HEAD: Agent's Suit Challenges Anti-Homosexual Policy
DOC.TEXT: A veteran FBI agent sued the agency Friday, contending it irrationally bans homosexuals from employment, and plans to fire him because he disclosed in 1988 that he is a homosexual. The agent is identified as John Doe in the U.S. District Court suit _ not because he is embarrassed by his openly declared sexual orientation, but because he has done sensitive counterintelligence work for the FBI and wants to resume if he wins the suit, his lawyer said. ``The FBI has a policy and practice of denying security clearances and employment to gay persons only because of their sexual orientation, association with other gay people, and speculation about their sexual conduct,'' the suit said. It said the policy was based on sexual orientation, not conduct, and that no such policy covered heterosexual conduct such as extra-marital affairs. The policy is irrational as applied to Doe, who has an excellent work record, has received several special commendations, and isn't susceptible to blackmail, the suit said. Doe is based in San Diego. In Washington, FBI spokesman Carlos Fernandez denied that such a policy exists. ``Our concern is with sexual conduct, not preference,'' he said. ``You may have even heterosexual conduct with which we may be concerned if it affects the job.'' Stressing that he was not discussing any specific case, Fernandez said the FBI's policy is that ``homosexual conduct is considered a significant factor'' in employee hiring and retention ``on a case-by-case basis.'' He declined to say whether homosexual conduct is a bar to FBI employment or how it is evaluated. But Doe's lawyer, Richard Gayer, said the FBI's absolute ban on homosexual employees was declared publicly in response to a 1979 lawsuit that challenged the policy. Gayer said the FBI policy has been upheld in two other appellate circuits. ``The issue in this case is whether they can simply ignore 20 years of good service,'' Gayer said. Doe ``does not care who knows he is gay'' but never told the FBI until an investigation that started in December 1988, the suit said.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Seizes Japanese Ship In Fishing Incidents
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese trawler was seized by the U.S. Coast Guard and escorted to this northern California port on Friday after the Coast Guard alleged the ship under-reported its fish catch. The 400-foot ship Mayajima Maru was boarded 11 miles offshore, said Coast Guard spokesperson Elizabeth Neeley. The trawler had under-reported its catch and failed to log fish thrown back, she said. The case is to be investigated by the National Fisheries Bureau and the Coast Guard. The Coast Guard alleged the ship's operators failed to report incidental catches of salmon and dolphin pulled in along with the rockfish and sablefish they were supposed to be seeking.

DOC.HEAD: State Says Nunn Not Home Free After All _ Yet
DOC.TEXT: Just when it seemed Sam Nunn would go unopposed in his bid for a fourth term in the U.S. Senate, state election officials said Friday they have reinstated a woman as a Republican candidate for the job. Mrs. Hubert Etchison Sr., who refuses to give her first name, has informed the state she wants to rescind a May 31 letter in which she withdrew from the July 17 GOP primary, said Bill Crane, a spokesman for the secretary of state's office. Republican and election officials said they were studying the legal questions involved, but she is back on the ballot for now. Mrs. Etchison was the only candidate to qualify this spring to run against Nunn, the veteran Democrat who chairs the Senate Armed Services Committee. She used a check to pay her qualifying fee of $2,952 to the Republican Party in April, but the check bounced. Bill Thorne, the party's executive director, said GOP officials then gave her a May 25 deadline to pay the qualifying fee in cash. She was given an extension to May 31 on the condition that she pre-sign a letter of withdrawal and authorize party officials to submit it to the state if she failed to meet the final deadline. Thorne delivered the letter to the secretary of state's office last week. Crane said Mrs. Etchison called the secretary of state's office this week to rescind her withdrawal, saying Republican Party officials weren't supposed to act on her letter so quickly. She also delivered a cashier's check for the amount of the qualifying fee to GOP officials. Jeff Lanier, director of the elections division in the secretary of state's office, said Mrs. Etchison is back on the ballot for now. But he added that there is a question of whether a person can be listed on the ballot if he or she didn't pay the qualifying fee on time, and he has asked for advice from the state law department.

DOC.HEAD: Former Costa Rican President Figueres Dead at 83
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to CORRECT day of death from Thursday to Friday, ADDS funeral arrangements. Picks up 6th graf, `The charismatic ...' and SUBS superseded last graf with number of grandchildren. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Former President Jose Figueres, who guided Costa Rica through a revolution to democracy and then abolished the country's army, died Friday. He was 83. He was widely credited with starting this Central American nation of 2.8 million people on the road to 42 years of peace and relative prosperity in a region not known for stability or economic success. Figueres died at his home outside San Jose, presidential spokeswoman Ana Lorena Vargas said. The medical report said he died of natural causes, a family spokesman said. He had been in poor health in recent years. His body will remain at his home Friday night and lie in state at the National Museum beginning Saturday morning, a statement from the family said. Funeral services were scheduled for Tuesday at the National Cathedral with burial at his ranch in San Marcos de Tarrazu, 50 miles from San Jose. President Rafael Angel Calderon Guardia called a three-day mourning period. He described Figueres as ``one of the most valient men our country had who contributed enormously to the development of democracy in Costa Rica. He is one of the protagonists of our history and one of those who contributed most to peace.'' The charismatic and combative Figueres, known affectionately as Don Pepe, took to the hills in 1948 to lead a brief but bloody revolt against the late President Rafael Angel Calderon, father of the present chief of state. The elder Calderon was a strongman who allied himself with the Communists and was trying to return to power by canceling the presidential election of Otilio Ulate. During an 18-month interim presidency, Figueres abolished the army in 1949 and restored honest elections. The new constitution written by his government also increased social services. The Communist Party was banned, but has since been legalized. Figueres later was elected to two terms, serving from 1953-58 and 1970-74. A civil and rural guard continues to be Costa Rica's only defense in a region wracked by wars. The country invested in education instead, and has a literacy level of about 90 percent, one of the highest in the hemisphere. Born Sept. 25, 1906, soon after his parents arrived in Costa Rica from Spain, he attended the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and studied hydroelectric engineering. He established a ranch in Costa Rica where he carried out innovative agricultural and forestry projects. Even as president, the 5-foot-3-inch Figueres traveled without bodyguards, although he often carried a pistol. A fierce anti-Communist, he came to sympathize with the left. He visited Cuba numerous times, allowed establishment of a Soviet Embassy over widespread objections, and backed the leftist Sandinista revolution in neighboring Nicaragua that overthrew dictator Anastasio Somoza in 1979. He boasted of having worked closely with the CIA in his earlier days, but railed against U.S. policy when the United States supported Nicaragua's Contra guerrillas. ``Times change and only the rivers don't return,'' he once retorted to critics of contradictions in his politics. He went against public opinion and granted fugitive American financier Robert Vesco refuge here in 1972. Vesco was expelled in 1978. During the 1971 hijacking of a Costa Rican airliner, Figueres took matters into his own hands. Figueres grabbed a submachine gun and took off for San Jose airport after being told that the three Nicaraguans demanding to go to Cuba were refusing to cooperate in efforts to free the passengers. ``I'll end all this,'' he said as he moved toward the plane. Shots came from the plane, and police fired machine guns. The incident concluded with two hijackers wounded and the passengers leaving the plane unharmed. In his later years before his health failed, he traveled the world on behalf of Costa Rica and to many was the personification of his country. Costa Rica is one of the few countries in the region with a substantial middle class. Much of this is due to Costa Rica's possessing little mineral wealth. It was not settled by Spaniards seeking gold or silver but by European farmers who tended to work their own land. However, much of the country's prosperity was achieved on credit, and Costa Rica spends a high percentage of its export earnings paying off the debt. This has led to unpopular austerity measures in recent years. Figueres married Henrietta Boggs of Alabama in 1942. They had two children, Muni and Jose Marti, before the marriage ended in divorce in 1952. He later married Karen Olsen, a naturalized American citizen of Danish birth. They had three children, Jose Maria, Mariano and Cristiana. His wife now is a member of the National Assembly, the country's congress. He also is survived by 17 grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Extends U.N. Observer Force in Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council on Friday extended the mandate of the U.N. Observer Group in Central America for 19 days to complete the lagging demobilization of Nicaragua's Contra guerrillas. Disbanding of more than 13,000 rebel fighters and support personnel was to have been completed by June 10, but only about half have been disarmed. The observer group has 995 military personnel in six border zones, but it ran into trouble when some Contra leaders insisted on parallel dismantling of some forces of the former Sandinista army under the new U.S.-backed government. The council's unanimous decision Friday forestalled a confrontation between the United States, which has backed the Contras, and Cuba, which supported the former Sandinista government and blames Washington for tension in the region. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar told the council it appears impossible to complete the process of demobilization by Sunday, June 10, but rapid progress has been made in the past week in some areas.

DOC.HEAD: Store Owner Arrested on Obscenity Charge
LaserPhoto MH2
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with group's record company offering to help stores that sell the album; CORRECT that lyrics refer to sted advocate violence. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `The Miama-based....' ADDS one graf at saying early evening performances won't contain offensive material.
DOC.TEXT: Sheriff's deputies burst into a record shop Friday moments after an undercover detective bought 2 Live Crew recordings to make the first arrest since a federal judge declared the rap group's album obscene. E-C Records owner Charles Freeman had defiantly ordered a shipment of 25 copies of ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' and was doing a brisk business when an undercover officer bought the double-album and a cassette for $8.49 each. Before the detective reached the door, six deputies rushed in, handcuffing Freeman and arresting him on misdemeanor charges of distributing obscene material. If convicted, he could be sentenced to a year in jail and fined $1,000. ``America is free, free for everybody,'' Freeman said before authorities took him to the Broward County Jail, where he was booked and posted $100 bond. ``And as long as this is America and I'm not living in Cuba, I feel my rights are violated.'' The arrest came two days after U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez found that the sexually explicit recording was without social value, appealed only to prurient interests and violated community standards in Dade, Broward and Palm Beach counties. Lyrics of many of the songs on the album contain references to violence against women and abusive sex, though they're tempered with humor. ``The inevitable has finally occurred,'' said Robyn E. Blumner, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union in Florida. ``Someone in Broward is facing jail time because he sold a record album to an adult. That action put south Florida about on a par with Eastern Europe _ a year ago.'' She said the ACLU will offer legal representation to Freeman. At a news conference later in Miami, Luther Campbell, owner and president of 2 Live Crew's record label, said the company will help pay the legal fees of retailers arrested for selling the album. ``Somebody has to stand up and the retailers, I think, should stand up,'' Campbell said. ``We can give them some of the contacts we used in our case and we can help them financially.'' Campbell did not give specifics. The Miami-based rap group sued after Sheriff Nick Navarro sent his deputies in March to warn retailers they faced arrest for selling the album. The sheriff acted after a county judge said the material was ``probably obscene.'' Gonzalez said the sheriff's office engaged in prior restraint of free speech by threatening owners before the recording was ruled obscene. The judge listened to 2 Live Crew's recording, which offers a frank, detailed discussion of sexual positions and practices. He also heard witnesses and legal anti-censorship arguments May 14-15 before issuing his opinion. Michael Greene, president of the National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences, issued a statement in Los Angeles denouncing the court's ruling as politically motivated. ``It pungently underlines the oppressive right-wing political agenda that is attempting to legislate morality in all the arts, including music. It's another attempt to smother freedom in this country, freedom for the recording artist.'' In the three hours before his arrest, Freeman said, he sold all but six copies of the recording. He said a line had formed outside the shop in anticipation of the shipment's arrival. ``I'll go to jail, and I'll come back and sell it again,'' he said. ``I opened up a record store three years ago expecting to sell records and this was the furthest thing from my mind.'' Authorities confiscated the remaining recordings. Friends and customers packed into E-C Records to complain after he was taken to jail for booking on the misdemeanor charge. Assistant manager Edward G. Robinson said Freeman felt strongly about the issue. ``If we can buy them, Mr. Freeman will sell them,'' Robinson said, adding that he won't. ``Personally, I don't care for the inside of a jail cell.'' ``Why they'd pick this one guy?'' asked Gary White, 27, in the shop with his 19-month-old son. ``Once they take the rights away from one guy, it's going to spread. It's not right when a person can't express himself.'' The judge's obscenity ruling has no legal effect outside south Florida, but civil libertarians see a practical effect spreading nationally. Supplies of the disputed record dried up in the Miami area as the obscenity case was argued, but the decision was expected to boost sales elsewhere. The decision had no effect on the group's plans for shows Friday night at Club Nu in Miami Beach and Saturday night at Club Futura in nearby Hollywood. The group planned to perform its sexually explicit material both nights at a late show for adults, after an early, cleaned-up show for all ages, Campbell said.

DOC.HEAD: Roh Predicts Korean Reunification Within 10 Years
DOC.TEXT: President Roh Tae-woo, returning from talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, predicted Friday that the Korean peninsula will be reunified within 10 years. The 45-year-long division of the Korean peninsula between pro-Western South Korea and Communist North Korea was a key subject in Roh's talks with the Soviet leader in San Francisco and later discussions with President Bush in Washington. Roh said his Monday meeting with Gorbachev, the first ever between the leaders of the two nations without diplomatic relations, turned ``a new page of history to herald an end to the Cold War on the Korean peninsula.'' He said unification with North Korea would be realized ``before the present century is out.'' ``I have returned home with high hopes the next generation of Koreans will live in a peaceful and unified land, free of the danger of war,'' Roh said in his arrival statement. ``President Gorbachev and I confirmed that rapprochement had already begun ... and agreed that full diplomatic relations ought to be achieved before long,'' he said. Roh urged North Korean leader Kim Il Sung to abandon isolationism and accept repeated invitations to a summit. Roh has been pursuing a policy of establishing ties with Eastern European and Communist countries to bring pressure on North Korea to ease its hard-line policies. Opposition leader Kim Dae-jung on Friday praised Roh's diplomatic success but warned the president will face ``civil resistance'' if he does not match it with domestic reforms. Korea was divided in 1945 at the end of World War II, and the two Koreas fought a three-year war beginning in 1950. The border between the two nations is one of the most heavily fortified in the world. It is guarded by more than 1 million soldiers.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarians Demand Closure of Romanian Chlorine Factory
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto XBUC1
DOC.TEXT: More than 6,000 Bulgarians rallied Friday at the Friendship Bridge spanning the Danube River at the border with Romania to demand the closure of a Romanian chlorine factory. Chanting ``Close the Factory!'' ``We Want Clean Air!'' and ``Assassins!'' the flag-waving demonstrators, most from the Bulgarian border city of Russe, accused the Romanian government of refusing to deal seriously with chemical pollution that drifts across the Danube. Romanian officials have said the 15-year-old factory in Giurgiu, 37 miles south of Bucharest, will not be closed, but will be equipped with anti-pollution devices in the near future. While more than 6,000 Bulgarians turned out, only 30 Romanians showed up for the protest. The two sides joined hands in the middle of the bridge. Carrying a banner saying ``Purity everywhere and in everything,'' 58-year-old Maria Koleva from Russe, which has a population of 200,000, complained about the sooty, black, thick air that local residents breathe. ``Our throats are always sore, and so are our eyes. ... We have serious lung problems in Russe,'' Koleva said. ``I sometimes think of not sending my child out in the street.'' The Bulgarian news agency, BTA, said Romanian and Bulgarian experts will meet in Bucharest on Saturday to discuss the need for urgent action to stop chlorine emissions from the plant. ``People should be given food and salaries _ you cannot just leave them unemployed closing down factories,'' Petre Marcuta, the Romanian Environment Minister said in a recent interview. The earthquake and strong aftershock that rocked Romania and Bulgaria last week sparked renewed fears on both sides of the border of what could happen if the chlorine factory were damaged. Bulgarian experts quoted by BTA reported a 137 percent increase in chlorine emissions from the factory since the earthquake. The protest, organized by the Bulgarian environmental group Ecoglasnost and the Romanian Ecological Movement, came two days before Bulgaria's first free elections since 1932. The issue of chemical emissions at the plant was first raised in 1986 when the concentration of chlorine released by the factory started to rise. After a 1987 demonstration, then Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu stopped the production of chlorine and hydrochloric acid, but three 80-ton reservoirs of chlorine are still in use for the production of other chemicals at the factory. Ceausescu was deposed and executed in Romania's December revolution.

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Plant Explodes, Several Injured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with evacuation order lifted, victim Alexander Jacky released from hospital; DELETE extraneous reference to South Texas in lead. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `Dr. Paul...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XAH3
DOC.TEXT: Explosions rocked a chemical packaging plant Friday, sending up bright orange flames and clouds of black smoke visible from downtown Houston 12 miles away. Two employees were hurt. Firefighters said the blaze at the Solvents & Chemicals Inc. plant in an industrial area south of Houston could burn for days. Authorities called for an evacuation of the surrounding area as the fire raged, but few people left and the order was lifted in about six hours. The most seriously injured person was Eloy Salazar, a 26-year-old employee who told his doctor that a spark from a forklift touched off the explosion at about 11 a.m. ``They were apparently depressurizing some 55-gallon drums and there was a spark, I believe from a fork lift, and that set off the fire,'' said Dr. Jeff Britton of Houston Hermann Hospital. Salazar worker suffered second- and third-degree burns on his chest, face and back. Another employee, Alexander Jacky, 49, was being treated at Southeast Memorial Hospital in Pearland for minor burns to his forearm and released. Six firefighters and emergency workers were treated for heat exhaustion or smoke inhalation at Southeast, officials said. Dr. Paul Pepe, Houston Emergency Medical Service director, said the fire apparently occurred outside the main building when a vapor cloud that escaped from a container ignited. The two men were injured as they tried to flee the fire. Forty other employees were evacuated safely, according to the company. ``All of our people are out,'' spokesman Jordi Baizan said. Baizan said the company packages paint and lacquer thinners, windshield washing products and charcoal starters. He said most of its products are nontoxic. Richard Hawkins, division manager for the City of Houston Emergency Medical Service, said multiple types of solvents, including paint thinner, were burning at the plant. Emergency officials were keeping a close eye on the remaining storage tanks. ``There are several storage tanks nearby the fire and that's our biggest concern right now,'' Hawkins said. Howard Manning, director of operations for the Chemical Transportation Emergency Center of the Chemical Manufacturers Association in Washington, said there was no way of knowing how long it will take to bring the situation under control. ``Some of these things go on for days,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys For Banks Say Government Has No Proof Of Drug Claims
DOC.TEXT: The federal government has no proof that millions of dollars seized from financial institutions in South Florida is linked to a drug cartel and should give the money back to account holders, attorneys argued Friday. In a nationwide money laundering crackdown in April and May, the government seized 658 accounts worth over $400 million. It subsequently released all but 102 accounts, including 88 in South Florida. U.S. District Judge Lenore Nesbitt heard two hours of arguments Friday, but gave no indication when she would rule on a defense motion to free the accounts seized in Operation Polar Cap. The judge said she would rule later. Prosecutors contended there was probable cause to believe the money came from drug smuggling. Scores of lawyers representing the 88 claimants crowded Nesbitt's courtroom, but let their positions be represented by a half dozen attorneys. Attorney Mark Schnapp charged that while the government claimed the seized accounts were tied to the Colombia's Medellin drug cartel, they had presented no proof of this when they froze the accounts and the complaint was based on ``stale information.'' Attorney Fred Schwartz said he represented a U.S. citizen named Mark Levy who lives in Barranquilla, Colombia. ``Mr. Levy is a U.S. citizen with two children who pays his taxes in the U.S. and in Colombia and sends his children to school in the United States,'' said Schwartz, who said the seizure made it impossible for his client to pay his children's bills. In defense of the government's case, assistant U.S. Attorney Blanton Allen told the court Friday that in January 1990, after the overthrow of Manuel Noriega in Panama, a bank there pleaded guilty to charges involving money laundering. Transfers of funds from Medellin cartel sources resulted, Allen said, coming to accounts in Miami banks. The accounts were traced and the government has the ``day and dates and chapter and verse,'' Allen said. ``These people are not charged and will never appear in court in criminal matters,'' Allen said. ``They may not be involved, but their money is.'' Schwartz and other attorneys have said in the past that their clients bought dollars in Latin America on the black market _ a huge pot of money swelled by the cocaine trade _ without knowing the cash was drug-tainted. Account holders have denied laundering was involved, insisting the money was ``flight capital'' removed from unstable South American governments.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Party Leaders, in TV Debate, Call for Coalition Gov't
DOC.TEXT: The leaders of Bulgaria's three major parties all called for a coalition government after Sunday's elections to tackle the nation's serious economic and political problems. But Zhelyu Zhelev, chairman of the opposition Union of Democratic Forces, said Friday night that the UDF was not prepared to enter into a coalition with the former Communists, now the governing Socialist Party. Joining Zhelev in a television debate on political and economic topics were Socialist Party chief Alexander Lilov and Viktor Valkov, who leads the mainstream Agrarian Party. The three parties are expected to take most of the popular vote on Sunday when a total of 38 parties compete in Bulgaria's first free multiparty elections since 1932. Zhelev declared, ``We are ready to take part in a coalition with the ASP,'' the Alternative Socialist Party that broke from the former Communist Party after the last party congress early this year. ``In a coalition with the Socialist Party we cannot take part; not only because of political bias, but because it is still burdened (from the past) and cannot carry out the changes Bulgaria needs,'' Zhelev insisted. He said such a coalition may be possible at some future stage, but ``it is not enough (for a Communist Party) to wake up and be a Socialist Party.'' He was referring to last April's name change. All three men refrained from personal attacks or strong criticism, avoiding serious dispute two days prior to the voting. The debate was in sharp contrast with campaign violence and harsh accusations that may be settled in court long after the elections. The only real argument came when Lilov rejected a ``shock therapy'' for the national economy. The slogan, used early in the campaign by UDF officials, was dropped later, but Likov described it as unfeasible and dangerous. Zhelev said it was discarded to defuse Socialist claims it would cause chaos. ``We are for a quick, well-thought-out, radical road to a market economy,'' the UDF chairman said. ``When a Bulgarian goes to a shop and finds no sugar, this is a shock, or when he hears about an $11 billion foreign debt and has seen none of the money ... that is a shock _ and there is no therapy,'' offered by the Socialists, he declared. ``Let us not frighten people with shock therapy, neither you nor we are interested in this.'' Likov pressed his argument, saying such a course of action had caused 3,700 percent annual inflation in Argentina. Valkov called for integrating ``the party of the non-affiliated people. They have a lot of good, dignified people in their ranks.'' Lilov said his party was ready to form a broad coalition on the basis of national consensus, and ``we hold out the hand to all political parties.'' Zhelev complained about remnants of totalitarianism, including the ``one- party government.'' He and Lilov also disagreed on the need for private ownership, with Lilov saying, ``Private ownership by itself will not take us out of the crisis.'' The three politicians agreed they would respect the voters' decision Sunday. Bulgaria's longtime, hard-line Communist Party chief, Todor Zhivkov, was ousted last November.

DOC.HEAD: East German Ex-Spy Chief Says KGB May Be New Boss for Some
DOC.TEXT: Markus Wolf, East Germany's celebrated former spy chief, was quoted Friday as saying some former agents may now be working for the Soviet KGB. However, Wolf said he thought any such defections were individual cases, rather than the result of wholesale recruitment, according to an interview in the Sueddeutsche Zeitung newspaper of Munich. Wolf called for a meeting of officials from both Germanys to try to resolve the problem of inner-German espionage. He predicted the longer it takes to resolve how a united Germany deals with former Communist spies, the greater the danger even more East German agents will defect to other spy networks. Wolf, 67, recently returned to East Berlin from Moscow, where he said he went to finish work on a book. West German counter-espionage officials alleged he was meeting with the KGB to turn over East Germany's spy network in West Germany. Wolf retired in 1987 as head of foreign intelligence in Communist East Germany's Security Ministry, where he gained a reputation as one of the most skilled intelligence chiefs in the East bloc. West Germany has an arrest warrant out for him for his espionage activities, but Wolf is protected as long as the two Germansy remain separate countries. West German officials have not yet decided how they will handle East German spies after unification. The Munich Abendzeitung newspaper on Friday quoted Guenther Beckstein, a senior official in the Bavarian Interior Ministry, as saying East Germany should hand Wolf over to West Germany for prosecution. Beckstein likened Wolf's case to that of suspected terrorist Susanne Albrecht, who was captured by East German authorities in East Berlin on Wednesday and is expected to be turned over to West Germany next week. In Bonn, spokesman Roland Bachmeier of the West German Interior Ministry said a meeting of the two German interior ministers in April provided the information that led to Albrecht's capture. West German authorities had sought Ms. Albrecht, a suspected member of the leftist Red Army faction, for 13 years. The Red Army faction has been blamed for a wave of terror in West Germany since the early 1970s.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu Resists U.S. Pressure On Trade Reform
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 5th `Kaifu said' to UPDATE with report U.S. criticizing Japan for tardiness; pickup 6th pvs `Japan agreed...'
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu stood up to heavy U.S. pressure Friday and refused one of Washington's key demands to make Japan's economy more accessible to American businesses. Kaifu's tough stand suggests his government can assert itself, despite Washington's threats to retaliate if Japan fails to slash its $49 billion trade surplus with the United States. Kaifu's decision comes even as some observers are detecting a change in Japan's legendary resistance to imports. On Thursday, Japan accepted U.S. technology as the standard for a new generation of cellular phones. But Kaifu said Japan would not give in to a U.S. demand that it set an annual timetable for increasing spending on public works. The demand was raised in the Structural Impediments Initiative talks, which are aimed at eliminating structural trade barriers. Kaifu said this had settled the issue. ``I don't quite understand why they are raising the issue again,'' he told reporters. The prime minister spoke on the same day Kyodo news service quoted an unidentified senior U.S. official as saying Japan was dragging its feet in preparing a final trade report outlining more reforms. Japan agreed in April to boost public spending, which would expand the number of projects that U.S. firms could bid on. The United States demanded a definite annual spending target, something Japan refused to provide. Instead, it said it would specify a total figure for the next 10 years overall. Japan also agreed in April to deregulate its complex distribution system, including a relaxation on the establishment of large retail stores, to increase enforcement of antitrust laws with tougher penalties for bid-rigging, and to work to lower land prices. Cited by Washington as an unfair trade partner in satellites, supercomputers and forest products, Japan last month agreed to expand opportunities for U.S. businesses in those industries. After the agreement, President Bush dropped Japan from the list of unfair trade partners under the 1988 Omnibus Trade Act. Countries on the list can face tariffs of up to 100 percent on certain goods. But some congressmen in Washington still want Japan on the list. U.S. and Japanese negotiators will meet in Tokyo on June 25-26 to hammer out the final report on the Structural Impediments Initiative. But the Japanese government already has begun to implement some of the reforms. Last month, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry told local governments it had shortened the application period for opening large retail stores. This will benefit U.S. retailers. On June 6, Japan's Fair Trade Commission issued new guidelines that would prohibit manufacturers from pressuring discount shops that sell goods below manufacturer-recommended prices. But the most potent symbol of Japan's recent willingness to open its markets may be its adoption Thursday of digital cellular-phone technology by Motorola Inc. of Schaumburg, Ill. Motorola's CODEC speech coder system _ the technology to digitalize voice sounds and send them to a receiving unit _ outperformed six Japanese and one Swedish company to be chosen as the national standard, Japanese officials said. ``That has been unthinkable during the past 40 years, but it happened,'' said Richard C. Koo, senior economist with the Nomura Research Institute, a think tank connected with Nomura Securities. ``I was stunned.'' Japan's cellular phone market is estimated to be worth about $2 billion over the next five years, enough to put a dent in the $49 billion trade imbalance. The imbalance has been shrinking yearly from a high of $56.3 billion in 1987. It has been declining more dramatically this year, with a surplus in March of $3.6 billion, down 14.3 percent from a year earlier, according to the U.S. Department of Commerce. A major reason for the decline since 1987 has been the yen's strength compared to the dollar, which makes Japanese products more expensive overseas and imports cheaper. But some economists say a more fundamental reason for the decline is that Japan is finally becoming a consumption-oriented society after years of sacrifice to build the economy.

DOC.HEAD: Panama Lifts Bank Restrictions
DOC.TEXT: The government announced Friday it will release $1.26 million in saving certificates that have been frozen since U.S. economic sanctions were placed on the country. Vice President Guillermo Ford, head of National Banking Commission, announced the ``total freeing up of saving certificates and normalization of the banking system'' July 10. During the past two years holders of the savings certificates, similar to bank certificates of deposit, have been prohibited from withdrawing their money. The restriction was imposed in 1988 after the U.S. sanctions forced the closure of banks for two months. The sanctions, designed to pressure Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to step down from power, ended after Noriega's overthrow in December in a U.S. military invasion. Noriega is in prison in Miami, awaiting trial on federal drug trafficking charges. Under the bank freeze, depositors were only allowed to withdraw 10 percent of the money in their savings accounts, and checking accounts were also frozen. Last year, restrictions on checking accounts were lifted. In April, restrictions on an estimated $270 million in savings accounts was also lifted. In December, the banking commission decided to maintain restrictions on savings certificates until July, Ford said in a news conference. The banking commission said banks had a total of $16 billion in deposits in February.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela: Sanctions Should Remain Til South Africa Ends Apartheid
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela on Friday said the West should maintain economic sanctions on South Africa until the white government ends apartheid and the country is no longer considered ``the skunk of the world.'' The African National Congress leader said the South African economy then would require massive international aid ``if we are to move forward at a pace that recognized the urgency of the needs of our people.'' Mandela, 71, on the second leg of a six-week, trans-Atlantic trip, canceled a morning meeting with Red Cross officials due to fatigue, a Red Cross spokeswoman said. But he spoke later to the International Labor Organization, the World Council of Churches and Foreign Minister Rene Felber. Mandela received a loud ovation from more than 2,000 delegates to the U.N. labor organization. He told the 150-nation assembly he was encouraged by Thursday's lifting of the state of emergency in most of South Africa as well as by the release of more political prisoners. ``These steps constitute part of the process of implementing what was agreed (with President F.W. De Klerk) a month ago,'' he said. ``Of course, more will have to be done to ensure that the agreement is implemented in full.'' He said he was convinced that de Klerk and his colleagues ``are men and women of integrity,'' but ``until what was agreed has been done, we cannot afford to lower our guard'' and relax economic sanctions. Mandela, freed in February after 27 years in prison, concluded his speech by speaking of ``the glorious vision of a South Africa free of racism, free of racial antagonisms among our people, no longer a threat to peace, no longer the skunk of the world.'' The U.N. agency, which sets international standards for labor conditions, expelled South Africa 25 years ago for its racial policies. Under apartheid, the nation's 28 million blacks are deprived of a say in the government, while the 5 million whites control the economy and maintain separate services. At the Geneva headquarters of the World Council of Churches, hundreds of supports gave Mandela the clenched-fist ANC salute. He thanked the meeting for the support given him and fellow anti-apartheid fighters by the council, which has provided financial assistance to the ANC for more than a decade. Speaking with a firm voice and without a text, he said ``religions, Christian and non-Christian, have been the only source of hope for many years'' for him. During talks with the foreign minister, Mandela urged Switzerland to add to Western pressure on South Africa and impose its own sanctions against the country, a government spokesman said. Neutral Switzerland has never joined in the sanctions but has repeatedly condemned racial segregation. Spokesman Michel Pache said that during the 90-minute meeting in Bern, the capital, Felber said Switzerland was ready to promote economic contacts with the ANC. Mandela will stay in Switzerland this weekend before continuing to West Germany, Italy, Canada, the United States, Ireland, Britain and several African countries. He is scheduled to meet with Swiss anti-apartheid groups and U.N. refugee officials Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Guatemala Sets Nov. 11 for First Round of Elections
DOC.TEXT: Guatemala on Friday announced national elections for Nov. 11, opening the way for a crowded field of presidential contenders that is expected to include former military ruler Jose Efrain Rios Montt. The winner will succeed civilian President Vinicio Cerezo, whose five-year term expires Jan. 14. The president of the Supreme Electoral Tribunal, Arturo Herbruger, announced the election and said a runoff would be held Jan. 6 if no presidential candidate wins a majority. Voters will also pick a vice president, 116 national deputies, mayors, municipal councils and members to a new Central American Parliament. The regional legislature, proposed by Cerezo to discuss regional matters, has been ratified by El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua. Costa Rica has yet to do so. Guatemala's 19 registered political parties can start nominating candidates Saturday. Those actively seeking the presidency include Rios Montt, a former army brigidier general who took over in a coup in 1982 and was ousted 17 months later. Most public opinion polls show Rios Montt leading a presidential poll or trailing Jorge Carpio Nicolle of the National Center Union, who lost to Cerezo. Other expected contenders are Alfonso Cabrera Hidalgo of Cerezo's Christian Democrat Party, Alvaro Azru of the Advanced National Party, Manuel Ayau Cordon of the conservative National Liberation Movement and Rene Leon Shlotter of the Democratic Socialist Party and the Popular Alliance-5.

DOC.HEAD: Traces of Arsenic Found in Former Hostage Reed's System
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs, RECASTING lead to reflect that hospital didn't characterize arsenic level as high; UPDATE with comment from hostage's wife. Pick up 16th graf pvs, `The attorney...
DOC.TEXT: Arsenic was found in freed hostage Frank Reed's system shortly after his return to the United States, hospital officials announced Friday. Reed, 57, has been undergoing treatment at the Malcolm Grow Medical Center at Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland since soon after his release from 44 months in captivity in Lebanon April 30. In a statement, the hospital said screening for heavy metals such as arsenic, lead and mercury was normal procedure for returning hostages or prisoners. ``These tests were performed on Mr. Reed's arrival. The initial test for arsenic was positive. Subsequent tests confirmed this exposure to arsenic and its elimination to a non-toxic level,'' the hospital said. Hospital officials were unavailable to say how much arsenic was found, how it affected his health or how it might have gotten in Reed's system. Reed's arsenic levels were abnormally high, Reed's attorney, Bob Woolf, said in a telephone interview from Miami. ``This was beyond what was normal, believe me,'' Woolf said. ``It was enough to be concerned about.'' Woolf refused to comment on the possible source of the arsenic. He said some of the toxin had been eliminated from Reed's body since he began medical treatment, but that traces remained. ``It's not completely out of his system, but now it's at a controlled non-toxic level,'' Woolf said. Reed's wife, Fahima, said she believed her husband had been poisoned by his captors. ``What else could it be? The arsenic couldn't get in his body just like that,'' she said. ``I'm outraged that they would have done something like this,'' she added. ``I'm just happy that he's OK, that nothing's been damaged.'' Dr. Alan Woolf, director of the Massachusetts Poison Center, said trace amounts of arsenic could get into a person's system from water and food, especially seafood. ``You or I might have traces of arsenic in our blood after a heavy seafood dinner,'' the doctor said. ``It's used as a wood preservative and as a pesticide.'' Peggy Say, sister of hostage Terry Anderson, said she was appalled by the news, and worried it could mean other hostages could also be affected. ``If the arsenic poisoning is deliberate, it is the worst kind of barbarism,'' Ms. Say said by telephone from her home in Cadiz, Ky. ``If it is not deliberate, they are apparently living in conditions in which their surroundings are putting this arsenic into their systems. Either way, it is an extremely serious problem.'' Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was taken hostage March 16, 1985. Reed has said he last saw Anderson between a year and 18 months ago. The attorney said Reed was surprised by the finding. ``It was a little shocking and frightening for him,'' Woolf said. ``This was serious and totally unexpected.'' The attorney said it was still unclear how the poison would affect Reed's health. The Malden, Mass., native was gaunt and weak after his release, and during a Memorial Day visit to his hometown he said he suffered from severe anemia. ``We still don't know what all the ramifications are,'' Woolf said. ``But he seems to be coming along fine. He's gaining weight and I'm hopeful he'll be released in a few weeks.'' Reed was the director of the private Lebanese International School in Beirut when he was seized by Islamic extremists in 1986. After his release he told of being beaten when he tried to escape and of being chained and blindfolded for months at a time. Arsenic, a silvery-white poisonous chemical element, is used to make insecticides, glass, medicines and semiconductors. Exposure to high levels of the substance can produce a burning pain in the esophagus and stomach, vomiting, diarrhea and depression. Prolonged exposure can lead to a rapid, feeble pulse and circulatory collapse.

DOC.HEAD: NSF to Research Superfast Data Network
DOC.TEXT: The National Science Foundation said Friday it would back a major research effort aimed at developing long-distance data exchange networks that can work 20 to 700 times faster than today's best. The foundation and the Defense Department's research agency, the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, will spend $15 million over the next three years to develop five experimental mini-networks that can transfer data at 1 billion bits, a gigabit, per second. Collaborators, including government agencies, universities, computer companies and communications firms, are expected to contribute several times as much money, the foundation said. Such a speed would enable 70 fat novels of 300,000 words each to be transmitted every second. Today's fiber optic cables can carry data that fast from point to point; it is the switches and data-handling routines for a network that must be developed, and these are only now beginning to emerge from the laboratory. ``This is what telephone companies will be bringing to the table,'' said Charles Brownstein, acting assistant director for computer and information sciences at the foundation. ``We don't even know yet that such a network can be developed, and it may take until the next century to build one,'' said Alan Levitt, a spokesman for the foundation. One of the experiments, if all goes well, will enable neurosurgeons at the University of North Carolina to simulate an operation using CAT-scan images of a patient's brain, called up from a distant computer, before they operate on the actual patient. ``The surgeons will be able to say, `Let's see what happens when we peel back this layer of tissue,' or, `Put that one back and let's peel back this layer,''' said Brownstein. ``This requires a tremendous data file.'' Today's best networks, Brownstein said, operate at 1.5 million bits per second to 45 million bits per second, or 188,000 to 5.6 million characters per second. A facsimile machine's best speed is 1,200 characters per second.

DOC.HEAD: 10 To Be Charged with Prostitution; Authorities Say Case Closed
DOC.TEXT: Ten alleged participants in a male prostitution ring will plead guilty next week to reduced charges, authorities said Friday. Seven men from Indianapolis and one each from Chicago, Detroit and St. Louis will be charged, Indianapolis police said. Investigators already have contacted the men and each is willing to plead guilty to one count of prostitution in return for prosecutors not pursuing additional charges, police spokesman Andrew Stoner said. The prostitution charge is a Class A misdemeanor with a maximum penalty of one year in jail and a $5,000 fine. The men are expected to surrender beginning next week in Marion County Municipal Court, Stoner said. If any of the 10 do not reach a plea agreement by June 29, warrants would be issued beginning July 2. Extradition would be pursued on the out-of-state cases, he said. ``All 10 of these people will be charged, regardless of whether they come forward,'' Stoner said. ``We would consider this, generally speaking, to be the conclusion of the matter.'' Stan Berg, publisher of the midwestern gay newspaper The New Works News, accused Marion County Prosecutor Stephen Goldsmith of exploiting anti-gay biases for political gain. If alleged prostitutes were being prosecuted, their patrons also should be charged, Berg said. But authorities are unwilling to expend the manpower or money to pursue more than 500 people, he added. The prostitution ring, which investigators have said involved 396 patrons from 39 states, Guam, Canada and South Korea, operated primarily in Ohio, Indiana and Michigan. Police said the names of 116 prostitutes surfaced in the investigation but most cannot be charged for a variety of reasons, including expiration of the two-year statute of limitations and a lack of information.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Envoy Says New Israeli Gov't `Blessing in Disguise'
With AM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Arab League's U.N. envoy Friday said Israel's new hard-line government was a ``blessing in disguise'' and said the right-wing adiministration might force the United States to get tougher with its ally. Clovis Maksoud, permanent observer of the 22-nation Arab League, said the government, which will consist of acting Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc and smaller ultranationalist and religious parties, could force Congress to reexamine its relationship with Israel. Shamir's government, which still needs parliamentary approval, has vowed to expand Jewish settlement in the occupied territories, and has indicated it is prepared to use harsher measures to quell the 30-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israel's rule of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The United States has called Jewish settlements an obstacle to peace and has tried to encourage Israel to open peace talks with a Palestinian delegation. ``I hope formation of this new Cabinet will jolt the U.S. administration and the U.S. Congress to come back to their historical sense of fairness in the Middle East,'' Maksoud said after a strategy meeting with Arab representatives. ``This can be a blessing in disguise if it awakens the U.S. administration from permissiveness to allow Israel to proceed with the defiance of the international community,'' he added. Maksoud also criticized the United States saying it has shielded Israel from international censure by using its veto in the U.N. Security Council. On Thursday, the United States blocked an Arab-sponsored Security Council resolution calling for a U.N. team to visit the occupied territories and investigate allegations of Israeli abuses of Palestinian human rights. Arab states plan to reintroduce the measure.

DOC.HEAD: Alfredo Poveda, Former Ecuadoran Military Ruler, Dead at 64
DOC.TEXT: Retired Adm. Alfredo Poveda, who led a military junta that ruled Ecuador from 1976 until turning over power to a civilian government in 1979, died of a heart attack in Miami, his family said Friday. He was 64. Poveda had traveled to Miami for medical treatment, his family said. He died Thursday, and his family said the body was flown to the port of Guayaquil, where a funeral with military honors was scheduled for Saturday. The government issued no comment on the death of Poveda, who Ecuadoran politicians have called the most benign of the military dictators who dominated Latin America in the 1970s and early 1980s. He was born in Ambato, a mountain city 75 miles south of Quito, and studied in the United States, Argentina and Brazil during his rise in the navy. In 1976, the admiral replaced Gen. Guillermo Rodriguez Lara, who four years earlier had overthrown five-term President Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra after the civilian canceled elections and declared himself dictator. Although Poveda reached power through the military hierarchy, he set up a system to return the government to civilian power. The constitutional process he helped develop, which allows for no presidential re-election and a one-house legislature, survives today. He named a group of judges and lawyers to develop a new alternative to the 1945 constitution. Voters, given the choice between the two documents in a 1978 plebiscite, chose the new constitution.
