Poveda in 1979 turned over power to the winner of general elections, Jaime Roldos Aguilera. He then retired from the military.

DOC.HEAD: Investigation Underway Into Death of Bottlenosed Dolphin
DOC.TEXT: A gutted bottlenosed dolphin found with a cinder block tied to his tail could have been killed inadvertently by a fisherman who then tried to conceal his mistake, officials said Friday. The 8-foot-long male dolphin was found Monday on a Delaware Bay beach in North Cape May, at the southern tip of New Jersey, said Sheila Dean, co-director of the Marine Mammal Stranding Center in Brigantine. ``It's possible someone was trying to cover up that they had caught a dolphin in a net,'' Ms. Dean said, adding that area residents say there are several gillnetters in the area. Depending on the circumstances, killing a dolphin can be a violation of the U.S. Marine Mammal Protection Act, which is punishable by fines and a jail term.

DOC.HEAD: Maoist Guerrillas Kill Eight, Set off Bomb in Peru
DOC.TEXT: Maoist guerrillas shot to death eight people and set off a car bomb during a rash of pre-election attacks in the Andes, police said Friday. The Shining Path guerrillas assassinated seven people Thursday in different neighborhoods of Ayacucho, 230 miles southeast of Lima, police said. In addition, they shot to death a university student in Huancayo, 120 miles east of Lima. In Huaraz, 175 miles north of Lima, rebels blew up 22 pounds of dynamite in a car parked near a military barracks late Thursday. A passer-by was injured, but the 12 soldiers inside the barracks were unhurt. The attacks came as all three Andean cities face weekend ``armed strikes'' called by the insurgents to prevent voters from taking part in Sunday's presidential runoff. The Shining Path often enforces ``armed strikes'' through violence. In Sunday's elections, novelist Mario Vargas Llosa faces agricultural engineer Alberto Fujimori. According to polls, the two are running neck-and-neck. More than 18,500 people have been killed in political violence since the Shining Path began its armed insurgency 10 years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Reports Progress on Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; edits to trim and remove duplications
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday night ``we're making progress'' in easing Soviet fears about a united Germany in NATO. Bush said he and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl agreed that Moscow has ``understandable interests'' in the military future of Europe. Bush and Kohl met for more than two hours over dinner at the White House to discuss Germany unification and Soviet objections to a new Germany belonging to the U.S.-led NATO alliance. The meeting, their third in three weeks, came on the heels of Bush's summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who expressed strong concerns about NATO membership for a united Germany. Bush said that Western leaders, at a NATO summit in London early next month, would explore ways to allay Soviet fears. Kohl said, ``We Germans, as a matter of course ... also are going to bear in mind Soviet security. It's going to be important that NATO and the Warsaw Pact meet in a good atmosphere.'' Gorbachev, in opposing NATO membership for a united Germany, has proposed that the new country be a member of both the Warsaw Pact as well as NATO, or be a member of neither. He also has suggested limits on the size of the German army, an idea opposed both by Kohl and Bush. ``Any singling out and neutralization always means isolation,'' Kohl said. ``Out of the isolation of Germany which we had in the '20s, a lot of bad things came about. We want a unified Germany as part of NATO.'' Bush expressed confidence that Gorbachev's fears would be laid to rest. ``I think we're making progress but I can't make a prediction as to how successful, totally successful, we're going to be,'' Bush said. Bush and Kohl emphasized that there is no difference between them in insisting that a new Germany be a full military and political member of the U.S.-led NATO alliance. ``I never expected that this important question could be solved overnight,'' Kohl said. He voiced hopes that the so-called two-plus-four talks involving the four allied victors of World War II and the two Germanies complete their work by fall. The participants are the United States, Soviet Union, Britain, France, West Germany and East Germany. Bush, returning from an overnight political trip to the Midwest, met Kohl before heading off the Camp David for the weekend. Kohl, who gave the commencement address at Harvard University on Thursday, headed home. Bush said that he and Kohl agreed that the Soviets _ who lost 27 million people in World War II triggered by German aggression _ ``have understandable interests in all of this, but we did not try to fashion some compromise'' solution. Asked why he felt so confident about winning over the Soviets, Bush said, ``I just had the feeling'' from talks with Gorbachev that the Soviet leader was moving toward the West's position. ``They also paid some lip service, gave some credibility, to the idea that a country could choose what alliance it was going to be in,'' Bush said. ``The facts are on our side,'' the president said. ``A united Germany in NATO will not be threatening to the Soviet Union. A U.S. presence (in Europe) will not be threatening to the Soviet Union. So, we've just got to keep on making our case.'' In fact, Poland and Czechoslovakia, still nominally allies of the Soviet Union and East Germany in the Warsaw Pact, have said they prefer a united Germany in NATO to one outside the alliance. Bush told political fundraising audiences in Omaha and Des Moines that the German issues will not be resolved easily or quickly. ``We must see that German reunification adheres to the wishes of the German people, while respecting the views of other nations,'' Bush told a luncheon for Republican senatorial candidate Hal Daub. ``Serious differences still remain,'' he said. Earlier, at a fundraising speech in Des Moines, Iowa, Bush said that agreements struck at the summit, ``we hope, represent the beginning of the end of the Cold War.'' Gorbachev has said repeatedly that the Cold War is already over. Asked by reporters aboard Air Force One on the way to Omaha from Des Moines whether he and Gorbachev had different views on this subject, Bush said: ``I don't know. We've got a difference of semantics, don't we. ``We've got to wait and see how we can resolve all these problems out here. There are plenty of them around.'' However, he added in his remarks on the presidential aircraft, ``I felt the summit moved in the right direction.'' Bush said that Secretary of State James A. Baker III, returning to Washington for the meeting with Kohl, was bringing with him ``a certain degree of optimism'' from his talks in Europe on the German issue with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. But, Bush added, ``We'll have to wait and see.'' Soviet officials have also suggested that a 35-nation European council, made up of East and West bloc states, take over the roles of the two post-World War II alliances. The United States has rejected that idea. As he wrapped up two days of political campaigning in Wisconsin, Illinois, Iowa and Nebraska, Bush continued to emphasize the importance to the farm belt of trade and grain agreements made at last week's superpower summit. On other matters, Bush told reporters aboard Air Force One: _That he hopes the Senate will ustain his veto of a $2 billion transportation authorization bill, which includes funds for Amtrak, and not follow the example of the House, which voted on Thursday to override the veto. However, Bush conceded, ``I think it's going to be very close.'' _That he views as unfortunate the shoving by a Secret Service agent of Condoleezza Rice, Bush's senior adviser on Soviet affairs and the highest ranking black woman at the White House. She was shoved while accompanying Gorbachev in San Francisco. Bush said it was important to see that such an episode does not happen again while adding that ``I have great respect for the Secret Service and how they do their job.''

DOC.HEAD: Volunteers Tag Horseshoe Crabs
DOC.TEXT: A full moon and high tides brought horseshoe crabs to the shores of the Delaware Bay on Friday for their yearly mating game. The females dug into beaches along the bay, laying millions of green, shotgun pellet-sized eggs. Many of them had males hooked onto their tails and each would drag the male over the eggs so he could fertilize the batch. Horseshoe crabs, with long, spiked tails, are known to completely cover beaches, laying shell-to-shell while shore birds and seagulls hover around eating the eggs. On Friday, there was also a human factor in the scenario. Volunteers hit the beaches in Delaware and New Jersey, counting and tagging the menacing-looking creatures. The plans called for tagging 2,000 horseshoe crabs in Delaware alone. The work is part of research being conducted in both states to learn about their migration patterns and lifespans. Delaware Bay has the largest numbers of horseshoe crabs on the East Coast, according to Tim Jacobsen, an assistant research professor at Rutgers University. They are found as far north as New Hampshire and as far south as Florida, Jacobsen said. In Delaware Bay, no one knows how large the population is, how long the horseshoe crabs live or whether their numbers are declining. ``We want to see if the population is stable. Is it going up? Is it going down?'' said Marian Johnson Pohlman, outdoor recreation planner for Bombay Hook National Wildlife Refuge near Smyrna. Pohlman was in charge of counting at Port Mahon, just east of Little Creek. She said people use horseshoe crabs for bait and officials need to know if too many are being taken. It takes a horseshoe crab 11 years to mature and be able to lay eggs, Pohlman said.

DOC.HEAD: Kill Van Kull Cleanup Could Take Two Months, Tar Balls Hit Beaches
DOC.TEXT: It may take two months to clean 260,000 gallons of heavy heating oil that leaked from a grounded British tanker into a commercial waterway, the Coast Guard said Friday. The Coast Guard said it had received reports of grapefruit-size tar balls as far as 15 miles away, coming ashore along Sandy Hook and Breezy Point, the points that flank the mouth of New York Harbor. About 9,000 gallons of the industrial fuel has been recovered so far, said Coast Guard Capt. Robert North, adding that usually just 15 percent to 20 percent of a spill is recaptured. North is overseeing the cleanup that began when the BT Nautilus ran aground early Thursday morning while docking in Bayonne. The remainder of the oil will either dissipate or sink in the Kill Van Kull, a shipping channel between and Staten Island, N.Y. and an industrial stretch of New Jersey shoreline, officials said. The Coast Guard, and the New York and New Jersey attorney's general offices were all investigating the spill. Civil and criminal charges were considered, said Judith Yaskin, New Jersey Commissioner for the Environment. The accident, one of several significant oil spills in the New York Harbor this year, boosted the amount spilled in the area to more than 1 million gallons, or four times the 1989 total, the Coast Guard said. That is less than one-tenth the size of the catastrophic Exxon Valdez spill in Alaska's pristine Prince William Sound. Coast Guard Rear Adm. Gene Henn said a board of inquiry will begin hearings Monday ``because we do not know if it is bad luck or a common thread that binds these incidents.'' The board is to make recommendations within ``weeks, not months,'' he said. The tanker's first mate, Englishman Geoffrey Frederick Gregory, 52, faces state charges of operating a vessel while under the influence of either alcohol or drugs. He pleaded innocent at his arraignment Thursday, was released on bail, and is to appear in Bayonne Municipal Court on June 12. He is also charged with negligent discharge of a pollutant without a permit. The case is to be presented to a state grand jury in Trenton next week, said Christopher Florentz, a spokesman for Attorney General Robert J. Del Tufo, adding that the investigation is continuing. Capt. James Sanial, in charge of the Coast Guard probe, said until the grounding there was no communication between Gregory, on duty at the front of the boat, and the captain and pilot in the ship's bridge. The tanker's captain, Albert Ainscough, and docking pilot, Jim Naughton, were interviewed after the accident and said they noticed nothing amiss until the grounding. Sanial said Naughton had no previous record of accidents. ``Ultimately, the master (captain) is always responsible for the ship. In actual practice, the pilot takes over (during docking),'' said Sanial. More than 200 workers, including about 50 guardsmen, were cleaning the water and shores Friday, said North. The operation involved 47 vessels, including five boats equipped to skim oil from the surface, and a special Coast Guard oil spill response team from Mobile, Ala. The tanker owner, Nautilus Motor Tanker of Gibraltar, has assumed responsibility for the cleanup, the Coast Guard said. The tanker is operated by Bulk Tanker Management of London and registered in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEAD: Ransom Raised; Waiting Begins for Hostage's Family
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf pvs with 4 grafs to CORRECT that entire $60,000 wired to South America sted $5,000, UPDATE with father's description of negotiations and comment from U.S. diplomat in Quito. Pick up 10th graf pvs, `The money...
DOC.TEXT: Roy and Marge Heimdal marched into a Peoria bank Friday, clutching coffee cans stuffed with money as they concluded a fund-raising campaign to ransom their son held in South America. In less than four days, the Heimdals raised $60,000 demanded as ransom by Maoist guerrillas who ambushed 27-year-old Scott Heimdal in a jungle in Ecuador on April 28. Mrs. Heimdal, 47, said the kidnappers, reportedly members of a Colombian group known as the Popular Liberation Army, have threatened to ``show us where his body is.'' The attack left one man dead and another seriously injured. ``A shiver went down my spine when they told me we had $60,000,'' Roy Heimdal said Friday, about 80 hours after the financially strapped family went on TV to seek public help in raising money. ``I'm stunned,'' said Heimdal, who sells cabinets. ``If there had been any other way to handle this, we would have. But a public appeal was the only avenue we had.'' Even as the Heimdals fought their way through a herd of reporters into the bank, strangers approached with dollar bills for their overflowing coffee cans and words of encouragement. ``For the first few weeks, we felt so helpless,'' Mrs. Heimdal said. ``At least these past few days we've felt like we were helping Scott. We were doing something and that felt good.'' The $60,000 was wired to a bank in Ecuador where it will be taken by an intermediary into the jungle along the Ecuador-Colombia border this weekend to meet the kidnappers. ``The funds will be handled by a professional negotiators who have been handling this situation for us. It'll be their responsibility to get some of the funds to the kidnappers,'' though probably not all of the money at first ``and make a deal to get him out of there,'' Heimdal said late Friday. He said he didn't expect any further major developments until sometime next week. In Quito, a U.S. Embassy official who spoke on condition of anonymity said U.S. diplomats weren't involved in negotiations with the guerrillas. `The negotiations are between the police and the terrorists,'' the official said. The money was to be accompanied by a videotaped plea from his mother. ``I pleaded for my son's life,'' she said. ``I begged. I said, `Please give me my son back. He's my only son.' I've never begged before. I don't know if I did it right.'' But the family's work is far from over. There are passports to get and the family must find a way to get from Miami to Quito. Midway Airlines has provided free airline tickets to Miami. The family hopes it will all be capped next week by a community-wide welcome home celebration for Heimdal. Heimdal and four others were traveling by motorboat on the Bermeja River, about six miles from the border, when they were ambushed by armed guerrillas. The guerrillas killed the pilot, injured another and kidnapped Heimdal. Heimdal has worked the past two years at a dredging operation for Iminco Co., a gold-mining company near Quito, Ecuador.

DOC.HEAD: Abbott Apologizes to Slay Victim's Wife
DOC.TEXT: Prison author Jack Henry Abbott, acting as his own lawyer in a wrongful death suit, Friday introduced himself with an apology to the crying widow of the young actor he stabbed to death nine years ago. ``I almost don't know what to say, except to say I'm very sorry for the death of Richard Adan,'' Abbott told Ricci Adan, 32. Then, in their first exchange of words ever, Abbott asked Mrs. Adan, ``Are you under the impression I murdered your husband?'' Mrs. Adan looked at Abbott in apparent disbelief and said, ``I know you killed my husband. I know you took a knife and thrust it into his chest. I know he died. He's dead. He's not here.'' Abbott, convicted of first-degree manslaughter in Adan's death, maintains the slaying was not murder because he thought Adan was going to harm him. Mrs. Adan said she refused to attend the trial in her husband's death. ``You were not in my courtroom?'' Abbott seemed amazed. ``No, I didn't want to see all that,'' the widow said. ``I didn't want to see you. I didn't want to hear you. You killed my husband. How could you do that?'' ``Does anything matter to you other than Richard Adan died at my hands?'' ``Yes,'' she replied. ``Something has to balance out. There has to be some restitution, some kind of payback for what you did to my husband.'' Before Abbott began his disjointed cross-examination, Mrs. Adan testified that her husband had won a role on a Public Broadcasting System television series, a development she called ``a big break.'' ``We were having dreams about our future together as a husband and wife,'' Mrs. Adan said. ``Everything was so bright. He promised me children. He said we wouldn't have to go hand-to-mouth anymore. We wouldn't have to struggle so much.'' Abbott, 46, convicted in 1982 of first-degree manslaughter in Adan's death, is serving a 15-year-to-life sentence. Mrs. Adan has sued Abbott for $10 million for her husband's wrongful death and pain and suffering. Abbott gained fame from writing ``In the Belly of the Beast,'' a best-seller composed of letters he sent from prison to author Norman Mailer from 1978 through 1981. During that period, Abbott was in prison first for bank robbery and then for fatally stabbing another inmate. Mailer later supported Abbott's parole, largely because of his writing talent. Mrs. Adan's lawyer estimates that Abbott has a little more than $100,000 in an escrow account held by the sheriff in Manhattan in case of a civil judgement in Mrs. Adan's favor. Abbott had been free six weeks when he killed Adan around 5 a.m. July 18, 1981, in front of the Bini-Bon restaurant at Second Avenue and Fifth Street. Adan was a waiter at the restaurant, partly owned by his father-in-law. Earlier Friday, eyewitness Wayne Larsen reiterated that Abbott stabbed Adan after sneaking up behind him, reaching around from behind and plunging a knife into the victim's chest. On cross examination, Larsen got Abbott's standard question _ ``Did you read my book?'' Larsen said he began it but ``what I read was so revolting I had not appetite for the rest. You were describing what it felt like to plunge a knife into a man's chest.'' Larsen also said he will never forget what he saw, but tries not think about it. ``It's the lowest that I've seen a human being sink to. That's you I'm talking about,'' he told Abbott.

DOC.HEAD: Paintings Recovered Two Years After City's Largest Art Theft
DOC.TEXT: Some of the $6 million worth of paintings stolen in what police called the city's largest art theft have been recovered, the gallery director said Friday. Nicholas Hall, director of Colnaghi USA Ltd. on Manhattan's wealthy Upper East Side, confirmed that some of the 19 Old Masters paintings and eight drawings swiped have been found. A police department spokesman, Officer Fred Weiner, couldn't immediately confirm the recovery. Hall said no one had been arrested yet in the theft. He would not say which works were recovered and refused to provide further details, citing an ongoing police investigation. The most valuable pieces stolen were two 15-by-7 inch wood panels by the 15th century Italian Renaissance master, Fra Angelico. The panels, depicting saints, were worth a combined $4 million. Works by Lodovico Carracci, Pacino Da Bonaguida, Paolo Catamara, Gasper Duguet and Jean-Baptiste-Simeon Chardin were also stolen. In 1988, thieves broke in through a skylight in the brownstone where the gallery was located and shinnied down a rope.

DOC.HEAD: Actress Barbara Baxley Dead at 63
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Baxley, an actress whose career encompassed roles as diverse as Shakespeare in the park and TV's ``Hawaii Five-O,'' has died of an apparent heart attack. She was 63. Baxley was found dead Thursday in her Upper West Side apartment. Her Broadway debut was in 1948 when she played a confused bride in the revival of Noel Coward's ``Private Lives.'' She received a Tony nomination in 1960 when she played a different type of bride in Tennessee Williams' play, ``Period of Adjustment.'' Other Broadway credits include ``Whodunnit'' in 1983, ``The Three Sisters'' in 1964 and ``She Loves Me'' in 1963. Her performance as Sally Field's mother in the 1979 film, ``Norma Rae,'' won Baxley critical praise as did her 1981 performance in the Wendy Wasserstein play, ``Isn't It Romantic?'' Her film credits included ``Nashville'' in 1975, ``Countdown'' in 1968, ``No Way to Treat a Lady'' in 1968 and ``All Fall Down'' in 1960. She appeared in numerous television programs, including ``Murder, She Wrote,'' Hawaii Five-O,'' ``Playhouse 90,'' and ``Studio One.'' She played Isabel in ``Measure for Measure,'' a New York Shakespeare Festival production in Central Park in 1966 and Portia in ``The Merchant of Venice'' in the American Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, Conn., in 1967. A native of Stockton, Calif., Baxley won a scholarship to the Neighborhood Playhouse in New York after graduating from college in California. In New York, she studied with Sanford Meisner. She also was a charter member of the Actors Studio, where she studied with Elia Kazan. She had no immediate family.

DOC.HEAD: Man Allegedly Kills Wife and Boyfriend, Wounds Daughter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RESTORES first name in 2nd graf. James City County cq in 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: A man opened fire into a car in the parking lot of a psychiatric hospital Thursday, killing his ex-wife and her boyfriend and wounding his daughter, authorities alleged. Police sought Lloyd Christian, 56, who they accused of firing an undetermined number of shots from a .38-caliber pistol into the car at the Eastern State Hospital at 3:45 p.m., police said. Authorities obtained warrants charging Christian, of Toano, with two counts of capital murder, said James City County police Capt. Ken Middlebrook. He remained at large Thursday night. Middlebrook said Christian killed his ex-wife, Maxine Bartlett, of Toano, and Van Overby, 54, of York County, who apparently was Ms. Bartlett's boyfriend. He said Christian wounded his and Ms. Bartlett's 12-year-old daughter, Kizzy Christian. Ms. Bartlett's age was not available. Middlebrook alleged that Christian fired several rounds into the car, striking both Ms. Bartlett and Overby in the head and chest and Miss Christian in the hand. The girl was treated for a flesh wound to the right hand and released to relatives, said Dr. James Hess at the Williamsburg Community Hospital. Jennifer Fidura, deputy commissioner for the state Department of Health and Mental Retardation, said Ms. Bartlett had been dropping Overby off for his housekeeping job at the Eastern State Hospital. No patients were involved.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Gives Los Angeles County 20 days to Plan Redistricting
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge gave the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors a 20-day deadline Thursday to submit a plan for remapping districts to provide Hispanics with representation and erase ballot box discrimination. U.S. District Judge David Kenyon, whose ruling Monday in a voting rights suit could affect November elections, declared, ``I do believe time is important here.'' He warned that if the supervisors fail to meet his deadline, he will ``do whatever is necessary'' to devise a redistricting plan. Kenyon suggested that the supervisors hold more than their regular meetings to draft a proposal to be presented to him on June 27. ``I want to make it clear,'' said Kenyon, ``this is a deadline. After that the court will feel free to do whatever is necessary to come up with a plan.'' Supervisor Mike Antonovich, who attended the federal court hearing, told reporters he thought 20 days was insufficient time in which to hold public hearings on the issue. Antonovich is one of the board's conservative majority which voted to appeal Kenyon's decision mandating new districts. Attorney Marc Rosenbaum of the American Civil Liberties Union, which joined the U.S. Justice Department lawsuit on the matter, said hearings could be held immediately. On Monday, the day before a statewide election, Kenyon issued a long awaited ruling in the voting rights lawsuit. He found that board members conspired to ``protect their incumbencies and that of their allies'' when they redrew the county's five voting districts in 1981. The lawsuit, filed in August 1988, charged the supervisors deliberately spread the county's Hispanic population across several districts when they changed voting boundaries following the 1980 federal census. Hispanics make up an estimated 35 percent of the county's 8.7 million people. But no Hispanic has been elected to the board since 1875. Liberal supervisors have called for a settlement which would increase the number of districts and supervisors to offer more representation.

The National Rifle Association opens its annual convention today with some of its supporters puzzled why a group known for its clout is suffering legislative defeats and a sharp loss in membership. ``I think there's a great deal of frustration among the membership based on a very tough year,'' said James J. Baker, lobbyist for the 2.8 million-member gun lobby based in Washington, D.C. Once renowned for its political influence throughout the nation, the NRA has recently suffered legislative defeats in New Jersey, Maryland and Florida. An estimated 20,000 members will attend the convention in California, which last year passed legislation banning more than 50 types of military-style assault rifles.

Congress and the Pentagon are ending months of haggling with an informal agreement to save tens of thousands of military jobs by shifting money from major weapons programs, including land-based missiles. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and House Speaker Thomas S. Foley late Thursday decided to give the Pentagon the authority to transfer about $1.5 billion from weapons programs to payroll accounts. The money will allow the Defense Department to avoid dismissing thousands of men and women by October. The funds also will make up for a financial shortfall in the health insurance plan for military dependents, the Civilian Health and Medical Program of the Uniformed Services. Among the reductions are $8 million from the MX rail-garrison missile program, $10 million from the Midgetman missile, $20 million from the Trident missile submarine and $20 million from the Seawolf attack submarine.

A former Army sergeant responsible for safeguarding sensitive documents was arrested on charges he conspired to sell information on the nuclear defense of Europe to Hungary and Czechoslovakia, the FBI said. ``This represents a hemorrhage of extremely sensitive information which caused grave danger to the United States and its NATO allies,'' FBI agent Allen McCreight said. ``We think it has major implications.'' Roderick James Ramsay, 28, was arrested without incident Thursday night and was being held at an undisclosed location. He was scheduled to appear today before a federal magistrate. Ramsay worked in West Germany from 1983 to 1985 directly under Clyde Lee Conrad, 43, a retired U.S. Army sergeant convicted of treason by a West German court and given a life sentence earlier this week, the FBI said. It said Ramsay's arrest stemmed from the investigation of Conrad.

Czechoslovakia holds its first free elections in 44 years today following a campaign marred by a bitter last-minute dispute between the two leading non-Communist parties. Some 11.2 million people aged 18 and over are entitled to vote when polls open at 2 p.m. (8 a.m. EDT) for the first round of voting. Balloting resumes Saturday. The voters will choose 300 deputies to a new federal parliament charged with choosing a new president _ almost certain to be President Vaclav Havel _ and then revising Czechoslovakia's constitution to remove the last vestiges of 41 years of one-party Communist rule. The elections will also decide the composition of Czech and Slovak republican parliaments, which have responsibility for key areas of public life such as education and health care.

America's mightiest unmanned space rocket, a Titan 4, blasted off today with a secret military payload. It was the second launch of a Titan 4. The giant rocket boosted a missile-warning satellite into orbit in June 1989. The rocket was launched at 1:22 a.m. EDT from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station, lighting up the sky as it thundered toward orbit. The Air Force refused to discuss or even acknowledge the flight until about 20 minutes later, when a statement was issued. The payload was not disclosed.

In a union dubbed ``Cuomolot,'' two rising stars from prominent political families will wed this weekend. Kerry Kennedy, a daughter of the late Sen. Robert F. Kennedy, and Andrew Cuomo, oldest son of New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, will be the bride and groom Saturday in a major social event for the political world. ``Everybody in the world knows the Kennedy family,'' said William Cunningham, a veteran Cuomo political adviser. ``And the Cuomos _ in New York state, in the political world _ are at the top of the heap.'' But Cunningham cautioned against blowing the wedding's importance out of proportion. ``This isn't the Middle Ages where the Duke of Normandy and the Duke of Avignon get together and decide on a marriage,'' he said. ``This is not a dynastic accomplishment, this is two people who decided to get married.''

DOC.HEAD: For Former Sandinista First Lady, Loss Also Means Liberation
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: For Rosario Murillo, former President Daniel Ortega's companion of many years, the outcome of February's elections meant liberation as well as loss. ``There's no doubt I'm happier now,'' she said in an interview. ``I had a series of responsibilities that didn't let me do art.'' Murillo, a poet and singer, headed cultural institutions during nearly 11 years of Sandinista rule. She has not left political life, but moved out of her office into the street to revive stagnant party spirit and bolster wavering militants. ``It could be that we bureaucratized ourselves too much in power; that's the natural tendency,'' Murillo said after leading protesters at the Supreme Court in a medley of sometimes nostalgic revolutionary songs. ``Artists didn't perform in the street'' while the Sandinistas governed ``because the rules made it too hard,'' she said. ``You had to talk to 50 bureaucrats to get permission to do one performance.'' She said Sandinista singers, artists and writers will have a chance to put political content back into their work. Even Sandinista artists had been ``just wanted for entertainment,'' she told the interviewer. Murillo has found a new vocation in leading protests of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's government. They are small compared to past Sandinista crowds. Only 1,200 people, most of them employees of the government telephone company, appeared at the Supreme Court on May 22 to demand that it overturn a new civil service law. In the past month, Murillo has spoken almost daily to workers, students and artists. On May 25, she protested a government plan to reopen a public street that passes through a Sandinista compound where she and Ortega live. The Sandinistas, experts in symbolic battle, said the government's desire to tear down the brick wall blocking the street symbolized efforts to destroy everything the Sandinistas had built, including free health care, public education and land reform. ``It's also an attack on the security of the party,'' said Aldo Cajina, a Sandinista party worker who rushed to the compound to support Murillo. The government has backed off, at least temporarily. Sandinista lyrics sometimes have an ironic ring since Mrs. Chamorro's victory. They say ``We will win,'' ``The people, united, will never be defeated,'' ``It's not enough to pray; there's lot's to be done to achieve peace.'' Demobilization of U.S.-supported Contra guerrillas is going slowly, Murillo says, and claims the Chamarro government is threatening ``to re-establish the power of the rich over the poor.'' The InterContinental Hotel is ``full of fat businessmen from Miami'' who lived in exile while the Sandinistas ruled, she said. ``This government is starting to look like Somoza's,'' she declared, using what has become a standard Sandinista phrase likening Mrs. Chamorro's government to that of President Anastasio Somoza, whom the Sandinistas overthrew in July 1979. Murillo _ hair cut in a short punk style, dressed in tight yellow pants and a Hawaiian-style flowered shirt _ said she worried about the new government's cultural conservatism. ``We're returning to a troglodyte epoch,'' she said, using another party expression for the attempt by some Chamorro officials to forbid miniskirts in government offices. Like most party militants, Murillo puts the best face on the Sandinista election loss. The people will realize their error, she said, and return the prty to power in six years, if not sooner. In the meantime, the demonstrations she leads contribute to the party's effort to renew its identity and hold wavering militants to the faith. ``It's a great opportunity that Nicaragua has,'' she said. ``It's unique. There's more passion now; here the revolution is being reborn.'' Not all of her concerts are so overtly political as the singing outside the Supreme Court, she said, but the demonstration needed ``a very concrete message.'' ``They didn't come out to hear Chopin,'' she observed. She has not forgotten the grim dawn of Feb. 26, when she was part of one of the most riveting tableaus in Nicaraguan history. Her arms crossed, face raw with tears, she stood behind Ortega as he conceded that the voters had rejected Sandinismo. Murillo said she was happier not having to hold herself in check, to think about her relationship with Ortega every time she wanted to participate in something. ``People always saw me as someone's shadow,'' she said. ``I had to be careful because I didn't know how it would affect his image. It was an impossible self-censorship.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Friday June 15

DOC.HEAD: Young President Brings Active Style to Office
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf `Critics say' with two grafs to include exploding narcotics incident; picks up 12th `Collor governs'
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: One Sunday morning, President Fernando Collor de Mello climbed into an F-5B fighter beside a Brazilian air force pilot for an hour of aerial acrobatics. He pulled out a camera during the flight and took his own picture. Next day, the photo was on front pages across the country. It was a stunt typical of Collor, whose vigorous, media-conscious style has charmed many Brazilians and irritated others since his inauguration in March. At 40, he is Brazil's youngest president. He is the first since 1960 to be chosen by popular vote. Collor arrived like a whirlwind in Brasilia, a placid inland capital run for a generation by generals and bureaucrats. Brazilians have watched him soar through the air in an ultralight, race along back roads on a black motorcycle, zip over water on a jet-ski and glide beneath it in a submarine. He has bicycled, kayaked, jogged, swum and worked at karate, soccer and volleyball. A note from President Bush to a former ambassador, published in Rio newspapers, referred to the Brazilian leader as ``Indiana Collor.'' When the president recently announced plans to go skydiving, his mother thought it was too much. ``Everyone, please, write him letters; ask him to stop,'' Leda Collor de Mello said in an interview on government radio. ``I'm as worried as you are.'' Her son changed his mind and ruled out skydiving. Last week, a gasoline-soaked pile of illicit cocaine and marijuana exploded in flames when he dropped a torch on it. He covered his face and retreated, suffering a singed right ear, hair and forearm. Critics say the ``media events'' reflect a shallow populism aimed at the poor millions who are Collor's chief supporters. ``Collor governs by creating spectacular events,'' Rep. Jose Genoino, of the leftist Workers Party, said in an interview. ``He presents the image of a strong president in contrast to a weak society.'' Jair Meneguelli, president of the 12 million-member Central Workers Union, which supported leftist candidate Luis Inacio Lula da Silva in the December election, described the presidential outings as ``a stupid recourse to call attention to himself.'' Collor, a black belt in karate, wrote in an article for Veja, Brazil's largest newsweekly: ``I've always had a passion for sports. Today I'm in a position where I have to set an example.'' A similar style has been evident throughout his political career. When campaigning for local office in his poor home state of Alagoas in northeastern Brazil, where political assassination is not uncommon, Collor would beat his chest at rallies and defy the hired ``pistoleiros'' of his adversaries to shoot him. At the presidential inauguration in March, he dismissed his driver and made the 5-minute trip from the presidential palace to Congress on foot. He strode down the Esplandade of Ministries with Cabinet members struggling to keep pace. Every Friday, he crosses the street in front of the presidential palace to mingle with well-wishers, much to the discontent of his secret service guards. In the crowd, Collor signs autographs, shakes hands and receives kisses and slaps on the back. To make sure stores were obeying a price freeze he imposed, the president dropped in at a Brasilia supermarket and pushed a shopping cart through the aisles. At the produce section, he stopped and snapped at the startled manager: ``These potatoes are rotten. Remove them at once!'' He wrote a check for the $28 worth of food he bought, and gave the bag to a boy who was begging outside the store. All agree Collor is a master of television. His good looks, elegant suits and measured baritone are perfectly suited to it. ``TV is the great instrument of communication in Brazil, where 20 percent of the people are illiterate and only 10 percent have completed the eighth grade,'' political scientist Helio Jaguaribe said in an interview. Collor froze $115 billion in bank and money market deposits, changed the currency from cruzados to cruzeiros and invited the press along when, to encourage savings, he opened an account with the equivalent of $100. ``It's all a show,'' Genoino said. ``It comes from his authoritarian concept of government _ a charismatic leader with everything centered on himself.'' Allegations of authoritarianism increased after Collor introduced his economic plan by decree March 16 and told legislators not to ``tamper'' with it. ``He is a little emperor,'' sa1nd Meneguelli, the labor leader. ``He tried to sit on Congress, and then was forced to back off to avert an explosion.'' Some see Collor's style as a throwback to the classic Latin American caudillo, or populist leader. ``Latin America unfortunately swings between caudillos and dictatorships,'' Genoino said. ``Multiparty politics still doesn't exist. It's part of our backwardness.'' Others feel Collor has accurately read a public desire for an active, decisive president. ``He is exercising his authority, but is not authoritarian,'' Jaguaribe said. ``There's a difference. Brazilians like that, because the previous government showed very little authority.'' Jose Sarney, Collor's predecessor, was widely seen as weak and incompetent. His unpopular administration blamed for annual inflation of 4,000 percent. ``A comparison seems inevitable,'' said Claudio Humberto Rosa e Silva, press spokesman for Collor. ``We have a young, handsome, athletic, courageous and competent president. ... He replaced one who was ugly, short, old (and) cowardly.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Tuesday June 12

DOC.HEAD: We Are Family, Hopes the `Today' Show
DOC.TEXT: During last week's NBC affiliates convention, Deborah Norville faced station officials and said of the ``Today'' cast: ``This is a family. I'm sorry the print press doesn't see it that way.'' NBC hopes a more important audience _ viewers _ will see it that way today as it re-launches ``Today'' with Joe Garagiola, Faith Daniels and Katie Couric joining Norville, Bryant Gumbel, Willard Scott and Gene Shalit on the troubled show. The network's We Are Family plan puts a lot of hope on the addition of the gregarious Garagiola, 64, a popular ``Today'' co-host from 1969 to 1973. He'll join Gumbel and Norville as co-host on Tuesdays through Thursdays. (The print press keeps calling them co-hosts. Wrong, NBC recently has been emphasizing. Gumbel is the show's anchor. Norville and Garagiola are co-anchors. Oh, the print press has said.) Daniels, late of CBS, will be the news anchor, while Couric, who has a lively wit, will be the show's national correspondent based in Washington, where one can find far more harrumph than humor. Only time will tell, as they say on TV, whether the newcomers and NBC's image-rebuilding effort makes Nielsen families welcome the show back to their bosoms, or at least to the people-meters in 4,000 homes. As all but the dead know, co-host Jane Pauley left the show in December after 13 years. She was privately angered by ``Today'' changes that began last summer, but steadfastly has refused to blame Norville, her successor. Since Pauley's exit, the previously top-rated ``Today'' has been riding the crest of a slump. It has trailed ABC's ``Good Morning America'' for 22 weeks, its year-to-date ratings are 17 percent below those of 1989, and they're down 17 percent in what some consider a key demographic group _ women aged 18 to 49. That means uh-oh time. The ratings drop translates into millions of dollars in lost advertising revenue for both NBC and its 209 affiliates. However, notes Betsy Frank, a senior vice president at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in New York, the drop didn't start when Norville became ``Today'' co-host in January, just five months after she became its news anchor. The show's ratings were ``trending down even before the `cataclysmic' Norville-Pauley change,'' she says. That's why NBC officials began tinkering with ``Today'' in the first place _ to get the ratings back up. Alas, they foaled only a public relations nightmare and failure. In Round Two of tinkering, the hiring of old pro Garagiola came as a surprise, particularly to those expecting NBC to commit thirtysomething video voodoo to win back those younger, demographically desirable female viewers. But the bald, affable former major league catcher probably will do that, says Tom Capra, a ``Today'' rookie. He became the show's executive producer in January. ``I think he's kind of an Everyman,'' Capra says. ``Everyone likes Joe _ younger women, old men, everybody. He's just kind of a universal figure.'' Capra tends to scoff at those who write of the women 18-to-49 age group as if that group were to morning ratings what oxygen is to life its ownself. He'd like to have that audience watching ``Today,'' he says, but it ``is not gigantic in the morning on any show.'' And, he says, ``Our show, as are all the other morning shows, is sold on the basis of households as well as demographics.'' ``We also think that our core `Today' audience is still loyal to us,'' Capra says, ``and just isn't watching us as often as they used to. So we believe that the addition of Joe will cause them to come home.'' Frank says NBC, in seeking the top ``Today'' ratings of yesteryear, is hoping to ``recapture some of that warmth and family appeal'' the show once had. ``Garagiola seems to be a pretty good choice,'' she says. ``But my question is ... whether people, for whatever reason, have not gotten into the `Good Morning America' habit. And whether the addition of Joe is enough to bring `Today' back.''

Elsewhere in television ... REASON NO. 392 TO CONTINUE LIVING: ``CBS This Morning'' has signed author Alexandra Penney, editor in chief of Self magazine, to do a weekly Tuesday segment about men, starting June 19. Penney's books include a best seller, ``How to Keep Your Man Monogamous.''

DOC.HEAD: War Zone Hangs from Rest of Country by Rusty Thread
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: War and rain have made a rusty steel cable 50 feet above a swollen river the umbilical cord between half of Morazan province and the rest of El Salvador. Isolation that has come with every rainy season since 1983, when guerrillas blew up the bridge, makes a hard life harder for the 50,000 people north of the Torola River. They are virtually cut off from May to October, when the river is too deep for even trucks to ford. The people of this town nestled among mist-shrouded hills pray for the war to end. Salt, cooking oil, sugar _ almost everything except the corn, beans and coffee they grow _ must be hauled along the cable in a precarious iron gondola. The gondola also is the only transport for a mother and sick child who must reach the provincial capital, San Francisco Gotera. The region, along with the northern half of Chalatenango province to the west, is the zone hit hardest by a 10-year-old civil war that has brutalized this small Central American country. Rebels destroyed the bridge to hamper the movement of army troops. Soldiers have entered the area by helicopter since. Perquin is a guerrilla bastion 75 miles northeast of San Salvador. Most of the 600 residents seem to support the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, whose fighters can be found on street corners, talking with townsfolk. On the last Sunday in May, about 400 rebels mustered in the main square to hear a speech from the top guerrilla field commander. With scores of villagers looking on, several dozen fighters received shoulder patches distinguishing them for valor during and since the big rebel offensive in November. The people of this town nestled among mist-shrouded hills pray for the war to end. Strict limits are imposed on the amount of food each family may take north from the provincial capital each month. Medicine, boots, adult clothing and flashlight batteries _ there is no electricity north of the Torola _ are considered war materiel and are confiscated at roadblocks. Some kinds of fertilizer are banned because they can be used to make explosives. ``I've grown tired of arguing with them,'' said Juan Jose Rodriguez, a farmer riding in the back of a truck from Perquin to the river. ``They refuse to accept the obvious truth that we who are not guerrillas also need shoes and clothing and batteries.'' Because they have suffered in greater measure, the people of Perquin want peace perhaps even more than the rest of their 5 million countrymen. ``We can't take anymore,'' said Modesto Diaz, a 61-year-old farmer. ``Peace would be the best thing, but it is not a simple matter of laying down the guns. There have to be changes and accords first.'' Diaz said the army killed his brother and a nephew in 1983. ``Someone incorrectly reported them as guerrillas, so the soldiers came and killed them,'' he said. ``They didn't bother to investigate.'' Trinidad Ramos has spent all his 75 years in and around Perquin, cultivating corn and beans. His callused feet and gnarled, almost nailless toes were shod in thick-soled sandals and he sat on a porch, observing life through horn-rimmed glasses mended at one hinge with green string. ``If it hadn't been for the idiocy of the war, this town would have prospered,'' he said. ``God willing, it will end soon.'' Government and rebel representatives met for five days in May in Caracas, Venezuela, to set an agenda for concluding the war. The U.N.-sponsored talks are the most promising in six years, but great differences must be resolved. Townspeople in the square nodded as Commander Jorge Melendez declared: ``Our society is captive to the military. Our democracy is captive to militarism.'' The rebels demand ``demilitarization,'' beginning with a purge of human rights abusers from army ranks and a steady reduction of troop strength. They say the goal should be abolition of the armed forces in ``the midterm'' _ perhaps within five years _ leaving a civilian-run police force to keep order. President Alfredo Cristiani'a rightist government has acknowledged that, when the war is over, El Salvador will not need such a large army. Government spokesmen decline specific comment, citing the agreement of the two sides on strict confidentiality. Officials have said in private, however, that the 56,000-member security forces could be reduced by about 60 percent after a peace agreement took effect.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Friday AMs, June 15

DOC.SECOND: AM-Women in Politics, Adv11, 1st Ld-Writethru, b0324,1029
DOC.NOTE: $adv 11
For Release Mon AMs Jun 11
DOC.HEAD: Women Set Sights on Governor's Mansions in Texas, California
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 11, 13 pvs to UPDATE with another woman running for governor in Wyoming.
DOC.TEXT: The 1990 elections may not greatly increase the number of women in governor's mansions and Congress, but female candidates hope to smash a symbolic barrier by winning the top jobs in Texas and California. Democratic governor nominees Ann Richards in Texas and Dianne Feinstein in California are the bright spots in a year that, at best, may bring incremental progress in electing more women to top-level offices. Three women already are governors of smaller states, but claiming control in major states like Texas and California would ``break a big thick glass ceiling,'' said Sharon Rodine, president of the bipartisan National Women's Political Caucus. While numerical gains at the top are likely to be slim, more women than ever are running for state legislatures, statewide offices and Congress, according to the caucus. These candidates are receiving tens of thousands of dollars from a growing number of groups promoting women's candidacies. But all eyes and a good deal of money are on California and Texas, where the new governors will have a strong hand in the redistricting expected to add up to 10 new seats to their congressional delegations next year. ``California and Texas are key in terms of presidential politics and reapportionment,'' said Jane Danowitz, executive director of the bipartisan Women's Campaign Fund. ``These are not local posts. We are talking about chief executive officers for two of the largest entities in the country.'' The practical, powerbroker aspects of Feinstein and Richards victories would be matched by their symbolic import, many women say. ``Until we crack the stereotypical barrier of women as executives of major states, we will not have a woman in the White House,'' said Wendy Sherman, executive director of the Democratic EMILY's List, which supports women candidates. Feinstein faces Sen. Pete Wilson in November and Richards is up against oilman-rancher Clayton Williams. Both women survived bruising primaries and are considered viable contenders. ``Those women have been through tough, ugly primaries and shown they've got what it takes to hold those offices,'' Rodine said. ``Both of them are hungry for the job.'' Two women governors are retiring this year _ Democrats Madeleine Kunin of Vermont and Rose Mofford of Arizona. There are 11 others running for governor, including Republican Kay Orr who is up for re-election in Nebraska. In addition to Feinstein and Richards, Democrat Barbara Roberts in Oregon is considered a strong contender for an open seat. Republican Arliss Sturgulewski of Alaska will be in the same category if she wins her Aug. 28 primary. Republican Barbara Hafer of Pennsylvania won her primary but has an uphill fight against popular Democratic Gov. Bob Casey. The other governor candidates, all facing primaries, are Republican Marlene Woodson-Howard of Florida, Democrat Joan Finney of Kansas, Democrat Evelyn Murphy of Massachusetts and Republicans Mary Mead and Nyla Murphy, who will face off in Wyoming's GOP primary. Seven women are running for the Senate, which now counts two women among its 100 members. Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., is up for re-election, and Sen. Barbara Mukulski, D-Md., comes up for re-election in 1992. The one Democratic woman making a Senate bid this year, Josie Heath of Colorado, is expected to win her party nomination but faces a formidable opponent in GOP Rep. Hank Brown. Three GOP women are quitting the House to run for Senate: Reps. Claudine Schneider of Rhode Island, Lynn Martin of Illinois and Pat Saiki of Hawaii. Saiki is given the best shot at winning; her Democratic competitor is Daniel Akaka, who recently was elevated from the House to the Senate upon the death of Democratic Sen. Spark Matsunaga. Schneider and Martin are putting a scare into two entrenched Democrats, Claiborne Pell and Paul Simon. Longshot Senate candidates are M. Jane Brady, a Republican challenging Sen. Joe Biden, D-Del., and Republican Christine Todd Whitman, taking on Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J. There are 28 women in the 435-member House, including three certain departures by those running for the Senate. There also is speculation that Rep. Lindy Boggs, D-La., whose daughter is very ill, may retire this year. In addition, a few incumbent women in the House could be vulnerable, among them Democrats Jill Long of Indiana and Jolene Unsoeld of Washington. On the plus side of the ledger, California Democrat Maxine Waters is a shoo-in to win the seat being vacated by retiring Democratic Rep. Augustus Hawkins. There are a number of strong candidates among the more than 50 women running for Congress, and analysts are predicting a net gain of up to four seats. The most encouraging sign to Rodine is the crowd of women running for statewide and state legislative offices that traditionally are jumping-off points for governor and congressional races. For example, four women besides Feinstein won nominations last week for statewide office in California. Many women are looking to 1992 as a watershed year that could break the pattern of incremental gains at the federal level. Redistricting will open up new opportunities for women in states gaining House seats, and a large crop of incumbents is expected to retire because it will be the last year legislators can take their campaign war chests with them. The caucus, the campaign fund, EMILY's List and the National Federation of Republican Women all are offering money, time and expertise to make sure prospective female candidates are prepared for 1992 with sophisticated fund-raising and media techniques. Sherman said EMILY's List will help women in six to 10 states where new seats and retirements appear likely. ``We're going to take some risks in some places that won't pan out,'' she said. ``But we need to take those risks because this is the opportunity of the decade. It won't come again for another 10 years.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday AMs, June 10

DOC.TEXT: ConAgra Inc. has agreed to buy Beatrice Co. for $1.34 billion in cash and stock, the two food companies said. The investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. bought Beatrice in a $6.1 billion leveraged buyout in 1986, when the company was a huge food and consumer products conglomerate. Since then, Beatrice has sold off most of its businesses but still retains a number of brands including Hunt's, Wesson, Manwich, Peter Pan, Swiss Miss and La Choy. The deal announced Thursday completes KKR's divestiture.

Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca will stay on as head of the No. 3 automaker after his contract expires in 1991, the company said. Iacocca's decision, announced Thursday, follows last week's announcement that company Vice President Gerald Greenwald had quit to lead a three-union bid to buy United Airlines for $4.54 billion. Greenwald had been Iacocca's hand-picked successor. A year ago, he had told Greenwald that the chairmanship ``was yours to lose.''

Sales in May were sluggish for many of the nation's big retailers, who blamed unseasonable weather for discouraging shoppers. Retail industry analysts said abnormally cool temperatures and heavy rainfall, particularly in the Midwest and East, restrained customers in buying summer clothing and other seasonal merchandise, such as air conditioners, lawn mowers or outdoor furniture. Analysts expected business to accelerate later in the year, when the bulk of retailers' sales and profits occur.

American businesses plan to boost plant and equipment investment by 5.5 percent in 1990, the slowest rate in three years. Economists said Thursday's Commerce Department report reflected a sluggish economy and weak product demand. The spending plans would represent the slowest rate of increase since a 4.2 percent gain in 1987.

Americans took out only $584 million more in consumer credit than they paid off in April, a sharp slowdown attributed to less demand for new motor vehicles. The Federal Reserve said Thursday consumer credit increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.0 percent, down from a 4.0 percent growth rate the previous month. Spending on services generally continues to be brisk, but expenditures for big-ticket goods that are bought with loans have flagged.

Manuel H. Johnson, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, unexpectedly announced he will resign after 3{ years of helping to set monetary policy. His departure this summer, announced Thursday, will create a key opening at an agency often criticized by the Bush administration for keeping interest rates too high.

USX Corp. said its shareholders have rejected a proposal by takeover strategist Carl Icahn to spin off the company's steel division. Preliminary results of the vote taken one month ago show 57 percent of shareholders rejected the proposal, while 43 percent voted for it, the company said Thursday. Icahn, USX's largest shareholder with a 13.3 percent stake, had proposed spinning off at least 80 percent of the company's steel division in the form of a dividend to shareholders, saying the move would boost USX's share value.

A federal bankruptcy judge has authorized Greyhound Lines Inc. to pay salaries and operating expenses, after union attorneys made sure the strike-bound bus company's executives would not receive ``golden parachute'' bonuses. At a hearing in U.S. Bankruptcy Court Thursday, Judge Richard S. Schmidt also began the process of setting up a committee of unsecured creditors for proceedings involving the Dallas-based company, the nation's largest bus transportation company. Greyhound filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection Monday. It has been hurt financially since a walkout three months ago by its 6,300 bus drivers.

A Senate committee has approved a bill giving local governments some control over cable television prices, in a move that would restore cable industry regulations lifted in 1984. But the bill approved by the Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee grants significant concessions to the cable industry, including no regulation of such pay cable channels as ESPN, CNN and MTV.

Stock prices gave ground in a sluggish session Thursday, posting their third straight loss since the market reached a record high at the start of the week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 13.35 points on Wednesday, dropped 14.32 to 2,897.33. The dollar was mostly higher against other major currencies, while gold prices fell. Bond prices were mostly higher. Energy and precious metal futures prices fell, grain and soybean futures were higher, and livestock and pork futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Good News for Consumers: Sluggish May Sales Could Bring More Markdowns
With PM-Retail Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Weak retail sales growth last month may have left stores with so much extra inventory that they will have to slash prices to clear out summer merchandise. ``It will be good for the consumer,'' said retail analyst Monroe Greenstein of Bear, Stearns & Co. Many of the nation's big general merchandisers, discounters, specialty and department stores posted disappointingly modest May sales gains on Thursday. Retail executives said unseasonable weather discouraged shoppers. Abnormally cool temperatures and heavy rainfall, particularly in the Midwest and East, kept customers from buying summer clothing and other seasonal merchandise such as air conditioners, lawn mowers or outdoor furniture, several analysts said. But Greenstein disputed the importance of the weather. ``The poor weather may have played a role but I do not think it was the dominant factor,'' Greenstein said. Sales of apparel, which have been the mainstay for retailers for more than a year, lost momentum. The slowing trend began in late April, Greenstein said. ``It is the first sign of a slowdown for the industry,'' he said, adding that it indicates consumers have become more cautious about spending. He said markdown activity is starting earlier than usual this season and price cuts may end up being deeper than retailers originally planned. Retailers typically start lowering price tags in mid-June in an effort to empty their stores in preparation for shipments of back-to-school and fall merchandise. Several retailing executives acknowledged their May sales fell short of projections. But K mart Corp. Chairman and Chief Executive Joseph E. Antonini said the discounter's results were decent considering how much business was lost to bad weather. The Troy, Mich.-based nationwide chain posted a 10.4 percent May sales increase at all of its stores. Excluding stores opened within the past year, however, K mart's sales were up a weaker 0.9 percent from a year earlier. Analysts consider results from stores open at least a year, called same- or comparable-store sales, to be the best barometer of a retailer's performance. Sears, Roebuck and Co. also posted a meager 0.9 percent gain in its same-store sales. The Chicago-based giant said total sales for the four weeks ended June 3 also edged up 0.9 percent from last year. Wal-Mart Stores Inc. outperformed its competitors, as usual. Analysts say Wal-Mart could overtake its bigger rivals in terms of national sales volume as soon as this year. K mart currently is ranked second after Sears. Wal-Mart, headquartered in Bentonville, Ark., said its May sales jumped 24 percent from the year earlier level. And when measured on a comparable-store basis, sales still managed a double-digit gain, rising 11 percent. Some retailers had mixed news: good sales growth in an individual division or two but poor results in another. Such was the case for Dayton Hudson Corp., a Minneapolis-based retailer that operates the Target discount chain, Mervyn's and department stores. Chairman Kenneth A. Macke said business at Target and Mervyn's held up well while the company's department stores had a decline in same-store sales. ``We would be happy to have a good warm spell to increase sales of swim suits and other warm weather items,'' Macke said. Dayton Hudson posted a 7.9 percent increase in the four weeks ended June 2 from a year before. Sales at stores open at least a year rose 4.2 percent. The retailers' results differ from the monthly retail sales report issued by the Commerce Department. The government's report is more comprehensive and includes sales at auto dealerships and other retail establishments. The government focuses on month-to-month changes while the retailers measure their performance against the previous year's pace. Other retailers reporting Thursday included: _Woolworth Corp. said total domestic sales in the four weeks to June 2 rose 6.1 percent from last year and same-store sales grew 3 percent. Among department store operators: _May Department Stores Co. reported a 9 percent sales increase for the four weeks. Same-store sales for the St. Louis-based retailer rose 4 percent. _J.C. Penney Co. Inc. of Dallas posted a 2.3 percent increase overall and a 1 percent rise in same-store sales. Among specialty apparel retailers: _The Limited Inc. said total four-week sales rose 16 percent; comparable-store sales increased 6 percent for the Columbus, Ohio-based chain.
