DOC.HEAD: Iacocca's Sticking Around
DOC.TEXT: Lee Iacocca will stay in the driver's seat at Chrysler Corp. after his contract expires next year, but the question of his eventual successor will continue to loom large over the nation's No. 3 automaker. The line to the chairman's office was disrupted last week when Iacocca's heir apparent, Gerald Greenwald, resigned as vice chairman. The succession issue has heated up at a time when Chrysler's sales and earnings are under the most pressure since the company came back from the brink of bankruptcy a decade ago. ``Right now, there's a battle raging and I'm not going to leave my troops in the field,'' Iacocca said in a statement released Thursday after a Chrysler board meeting in New York. ``We have mutually agreed that my employment will be extended past December of 1991.'' Just how long the 65-year-old Iacocca will continue as chairman and chief executive officer and how much he will be paid isn't known, Chrysler spokesman A.C. Liebler said. ``Iacocca is probably the single most important element ot Chrysler Corporation,'' said Alan Helfman, general manager of River Oaks Chrysler-Plymouth in Houston. ``He sells the sizzle and people like the showmanship.'' That will be a tough act to follow, Helfman said. ``One of my prime responsibilities is to put an orderly succession plan in place,'' Iacocca said. ``We're going to do that according to our own timetable and it won't be driven by a big X on the calendar.'' Greenwald was told by Iacocca about a year ago that Chrysler's chairmanship was ``yours to lose.'' Greenwald chose to lose it, opting instead to head a three-union effort to buy the parent of United Airlines for $4.54 billion. Analyst Mary Anne Sudol of Fitch Investors Service Inc. said Iacocca probably would stay at the helm for no more than two extra years as a stopgap. ``I tend to think it (the extension) is to give the board time and the contenders the opportunity to establish their own track records,'' she said. Less than 24 hours after Greenwald's resignation, Chrysler said Robert S. Miller, the company's chief financial officer, would take over Greenwald's title and most of his duties. Chrysler Motors President Robert Lutz got the rest of the duties, but no new title. The changes prompted speculation that Iacocca might stay on after his contract expires Dec. 8, 1991. Neither Miller, 48, nor Lutz, 58, appeared ready to become chairman in 18 months. Greenwald was the highest ranking of three executives who announced their resignations in May. Michael Hammes resigned as vice president for international operations to head up hand tool operations at Black & Decker and Treasurer Frederick Zuckerman said he will quit sometime this summer. Chrysler has been thinning its executive ranks since last October, when it started a $1.5 billion cost-cutting program that will reduce the white-collar work force by more than 2,500 people. The company reported an 80 percent drop in first-quarter earnings to $71 million. Analysts don't expect an upturn until at least the fourth quarter. Earnings have been pressured by a dive in the company's car and truck sales. Through the first five months of this year, sales were running nearly 13 percent below last year's pace. Iacocca signed a four-year contract with the automaker in 1987. He joined Chrysler in 1979 after being fired as president of Ford Motor Co. by the late Henry Ford II. Iacocca's most lucrative year as chairman was in 1986 when he received $20.5 million in compensation. His average annual compensation since 1985 was $11.5 million. He received $4 million for last year. The company's 1990 proxy statement says Iacocca will receive 191,250 shares of Chrysler stock this coming Nov. 2 and another 63,750 shares after Dec. 8, 1991. At $16 a share, Chrysler's common stock price at midday Thursday, the stock would have a combined value of $4.1 million.

DOC.HEAD: Government Boosted Spending To Fight Dollar Rise In Feb.-April Period
DOC.TEXT: The government spent $1.58 billion trying to hold down the dollar's rise against the Japanese yen from February through April, the Federal Reserve reported. Still, the dollar increased 10 percent against the yen during the period, the Fed said in its quarterly report to Congress. The rise began to subside only when currency traders started to believe Japanese interest rates did not need to climb further and when Japan's stock and bond markets became more settled, the Fed said. The government used $200 million to buy West German marks to bring its total currency market intervention for the period to $1.78 billion. The dollar declined less than 0.5 percent against the mark in the three months. In the previous three months, the government spent $750 million intervening in currency markets, all of it to buy yen. Although purchases more than doubled in the latest quarter, it was ``far, far lower'' than pervious periods last year, said Sam Y. Cross, a Fed executive vice president who released the report at a press conference. The government spent a record $11.92 billion in the foreign exchange market during the three months ended July 31 and $5.871 billion in August-October period. The government purchased both yen and West German marks during those periods. In the latest period, the dollar saw its steepest climb against the yen from late February through early April. The climb subsided as the market awaited the April 7 meeting of finanical officials from governments of the world's seven leading industrial nations, the Fed said. Also, in April, market participants came to view the Bank of Japan's 1 percent increase in the discount rate as being sufficient to stop the yen's slide, and Japan's stock and bond markets began to recoup some of their losses, according to the report. The yen's weakness against the dollar helped trigger a slide of more than 25 percent on the Tokyo stock market early this year. The dollar was at its low of the period on Feb. 19 at 143.6 yen. But the dollar began to rally after election victories for Japan's Liberal Democratic Party and predictions of higher interest rates elsewhere in the world. The government sold $650 million to buy yen between Feb. 23 and March 2. Also, the dollar strengthened against the mark amid fears of inflation resulting from the pending currency union between East and West Germany. The dollar reached 1.7237 marks on March 1. Between March 5 and March 27, the Treasury sold $830 million to buy yen and $200 million was sold for marks. The purchases were made by the U.S. Treasury as the Fed temporarily put its intervention program on hold. The Fed and Treasury normally split the funds used for intervention. The temporary halt came after some Fed officials said they were concerned that high amounts of purchases like those in 1989 could cause doubts about the Fed's commitment to curbing inflation, according to the report. The government's currency intervention exacerbate inflation by increase the supply of dollars.

DOC.HEAD: Beatrice Co. History: a Long and Tangled Tale
DOC.TEXT: The story of Beatrice Co. resembles the rise and fall of an empire: The conglomerate was built up slowly, bit by bit, then dismantled in much the same manner. And the spoils of war made great fortunes along the way. The last piece of the company disappeared Thursday as ConAgra Inc. bought Beatrice's remaining food operations for $1.34 billion. It was the endgame of a decade of corporate Pac-man. The sale also marked the last chapter in the $6.1 billion leveraged buyout of Beatrice engineered by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. and businessman Donald Kelly, who went on to serve as Beatrice's chairman. After acquiring the conglomerate in 1985, Kelly and Kohlberg Kravis began systematically stripping away its assets _ at a handsome profit for themselves and other investors. Back in the early 1980s, Beatrice was a food and consumer products company with several big brands in its portfolio, including La Choy oriental foods, Samsonite luggage, Tropicana orange juice and STP auto products. Led by then-chairman James L. Dutt, the company had grown big through acquisitions. But the nature of its businesses _ high-profile consumer brands that generated lots of cash _ left it vulnerable to a breakup. In 1984, Beatrice set its sights on Esmark Inc., the acquisition that proved its undoing. Esmark had started out in business as Swift & Co., the meatpacker. But Esmark was also acquisition-minded, and in 1983 it had paid $973 million for Norton Simon Inc., another conglomerate. The purchase of Norton Simon gave Esmark such well-known brands as Hunt-Wesson foods, Max Factor cosmetics, Playtex underwear, Swift and Eckrich meats and the Avis car rental company. In May 1984, 10 months after buying Norton Simon, Kohlberg Kravis and Kelly _ then chairman of Esmark _ offered to take the company private for $2.4 billion. Dutt topped the bid and Beatrice won the firm for $2.7 billion. To pay for Esmark, Beatrice began to pare assets, saying it would sell Avis; Danskin clothing; International Jensen electronics equipment; and its cookie, food service equipment, agri-products and leather businesses. But Beatrice proved unable to handle the financial and corporate burdens of the acquisition. It led to management turmoil and a drop in profits, and eventually to the ouster of Dutt in August 1985. Two months later Kohlberg Kravis reappeared, again with the support of Kelly, who had quit Esmark after its buyout. They swallowed Beatrice for $6.1 billion. The breakup of Beatrice then began in earnest. In the late 1980s under Kelly's leadership, Beatrice sold off some $7 billion in assets. Several were then turned around and sold once again. Among them: _Avis was sold to its senior management and the investor group Wesray Capital Corp. for $1.6 billion in 1986. A year later, Wesray sold the car rental firm to its employees for $1.75 billion. _The company's Coca-Cola bottling businesses were sold to the Coca-Cola Co. for $1 billion in 1986. The businesses were combined with Coke's other bottling operations under a separate company, Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., and 51 percent of the firm was spun off to the public. _The Playtex consumer products and apparel businesses went private in 1986 in a management-led LBO for $1.25 billion. Playtex later sold its family products division to Johnson & Johnson Co. for $726 million. _Beatrice's international operations was bought by TLC Group LP for $985 million in 1987 and renamed TLC Beatrice International Inc. The following year, TLC sold the company's Latin American operations for more than $100 million. _Tropicana Products Inc. went for $1.2 billion to Seagram Co. Ltd. in 1988. Kelly also spun off Beatrice's specialty food and non-food businesses such as Samsonite luggage, Culligan water treatment systems and Stiffel lamps in a $1.92 billion public stock and debt offering. The new company, E-II Holdings Inc., was intended to be a vehicle for more acquisitions by the company. E-II lived up to expectations, launching an attack on American Brands Inc. in December 1987. But American Brands turned the tables on E-II, and acquired the aggressor for $2.7 billion two months later. With these and other divestitures, there remained Beatrice's core food business _ brands including Hunt's, Wesson, Manwich, Peter Pan, Snack Pak, Swiss Miss, La Choy, Swift Premium, Butterball, Eckrich and Reddi-Wip. The food business went on the block in 1987, but when talks with an unidentified prospective buyer broke down, the company took itself off the market in early 1988. Now, two years later, ConAgra is buying the company. The more than four years of divestitures proved very profitable for investors. Kohlberg Kravis estimated Thursday that equity investors who put up $420 million to buy Beatrice had reaped a total of about $2.2 billion, a return of more than 50 percent a year on their investment.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Chief Going on the Road Again
DOC.TEXT: Securities and Exchange Commisson Chairman Richard C. Breeden is taking his message of international cooperation among stock market regulators on the road again _ to Luxembourg, Germany and Hungary. The head of the federal agency that regulates stocks, bonds and other securities said Thursday he'll travel to Europe later this month to sign an international cooperation agreement in Luxembourg and help reopen the long dormant Budapest Stock Exchange. He also said an advisory committee on East European markets, ``representing some of the best and the brightest'' on Wall Street, will hold its first meeting in Washington next week to discuss ways of helping the infant free market economies of former Iron Curtain countries. Since taking office last October, Breeden has traveled to Japan, France and the Netherlands to hammer out cooperation agreements with foreign securities regulators. High-level officials from the Soviet Union, Hungary and Poland have visited SEC headquarters in Washington _ some delegations more than once. ``Together the countries of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union represent a potential market of 400 million people,'' Breeden said in a speech to the New York Financial Writers Association. ``Helping these countries create free economic markets is the right thing to do,'' he added. In addition to helping the Budapest Stock Market celebrate its reopening June 21 after 42 years in limbo under Communist rule, Breeden said he expected to sign an assistance agreement with Hungarian government on securities matters. He said the SEC also was working on new agreements with Mexico, Australia, Israel and several other countries. In other matters, Breeden defended proposed legislation to give the SEC control of stock index futures. He rebutted congressional criticism that the bill unveiled by the Bush administration earlier this week is riddled with loopholes that would hinder, rather than assist, investor protection. Breeden also said he believed there was still time in the dwindling congressional session to get the controversial legislation enacted. Critics have said the proposal to take regulation of stock index futures away from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and give it to the SEC would ``open the flood gates'' to deregulated trading because of vague legislative language. The CFTC and the SEC have battled publicly over which agency should oversee financial products that have elements of both a security and a futures contract. Such hybrid products include stock index futures, which allow investors to speculate on movements in the stock market without having to buy the stocks themselves. The administration's plan for ending the turf battle would ``unify regulation under the SEC of the `one market' of stocks, stock options and stock index futures,'' according to the Treasury Department. But Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, which oversees the CFTC, said Wednesday the proposal was ``riddled with loopholes and legal inconsistencies'' that could result in ``massive deregulation.'' ``I'm not aware of any loopholes,'' Breeden told reporters before his speech. Breeden, who has often complained about the split in regulatory authority over new financial products, maintained that the proposed legislation would decrease instability and protect investors from stock market gyrations. Some Washington officials have suggested there may not be enough time to get such a controversial piece of legislation approved before Congress adjourns for the year on Oct. 5. ``I don't think time is necessarily a problem,'' said Breeden, adding that the issue already has been thoroughly explored and debated in numerous committee hearings.

DOC.HEAD: Deal Makes ConAgra One of Largest Food Companies
DOC.TEXT: ConAgra Inc.'s $1.34 billion purchase of Beatrice Co. closed out one of the key leveraged buyouts of the 1980s at a big profit and established ConAgra as a leading U.S. food company for the '90s. ``This will put ConAgra at roughly $20 billion (in annual sales),'' said Stephen Carnes, an analyst with Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood, in Minneapolis. ``It consolidates the food industry even further,'' said John McMillin, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities in New York. ConAgra would rank as one of the world's biggest food companies along with Nestle of Switzerland, the Anglo-Dutch giant Unilever and New York-based Philip Morris, McMillin said. ConAgra will acquire Beatrice for cash and stock valued at $1.34 billion. The deal announced Thursday will unite some of the country's best-known food brands on a single corporate shelf. ConAgra generated more than $15 billion in sales in the year ended May 27 by processing grain, selling farm products such as fertilizer and animal feed, and marketing prepared foods. Its food brands includes Healthy Choice, Banquet, Armour Classics, Morton, Chun King and Kid's Cuisine frozen foods; Armour processed meats and Country Pride chicken products. Beatrice had $4.3 billion in sales in its most recent year with brands such as Hunt's, Wesson, Orville Redenbacher's, Manwich, Peter Pan, Snack Pak, Swiss Miss, La Choy, Swift Premium, Butterball, Eckrich and Reddi-Wip. ``We believe ConAgra and Beatrice together will be the best food company in the United States,'' Chairman Charles M. Harper said at a news conference at ConAgra's Omaha headquarters. ``One of ConAgra's most important long-term objectives has been to establish a strong sales and distribution system to the shelf-stable section of the grocery store,'' he said, referring to food products that don't require refrigeration. ``Beatrice will fulfill that objective.'' The deal, which is subject to approval by federal regulators, was announced after the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange, where ConAgra's stock rose 75 cents to $32 a share. The sale completes Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co.'s divestiture of Beatrice, a classic asset-stripping exercise that pocketed huge profits for the New York buyout firm and its other investors. KKR purchased Beatrice _ then a major foods and consumer products conglomerate _ in a $6.1 billion leveraged buyout in 1986. In subsequent years Beatrice sold off Avis rent-a-car, a Coca-Cola bottler, Tropicana Products Inc. and other prominent brands. The food businesses sold to ConAgra were all that remained. Investors who put $420 million of equity into KKR's Beatrice buyout reaped a total of about $2.2 billion from the selloff of its businesses, representing a compound annual rate of return of more than 50 percent, the buyout firm said. Under terms of the sale, ConAgra will buy Beatrice for $11.50 a share from KKR partnerships and management investors. The purchase price consists of approximately $626 million in cash, $355 million in ConAgra common stock and $355 million in two series of ConAgra preferred stock. Harper said the acquisition would have no immediate effect on employment at Beatrice or ConAgra. There also are no plans to move executives from Beatrice's Chicago office or to phase out the Beatrice name, he said. ``Our whole company is trying to manage them (Beatrice) as independent operating companies,'' Harper said. Consumers will see no immediated changes, he said, but added, ``I think there will probably be more new products introduced over time that fit consumers' needs and improve their quality of life.'' Beatrice reported earnings of $12 million on sales of $4.26 billion in the year ended Feb. 28. ConAgra is expected to report earnings for its fiscal year ended May 27 later this month.

DOC.HEAD: GM, Soviet Automaker Sign Joint Agreement
DOC.TEXT: A $1 billion deal with the Soviet Union's largest automaker may pave General Motors Corp.'s way to more lucrative contracts in that country, Vice President William Hoglund said. ``As President Gorbachev said last week and as we have felt for a very long time, if you ever want to play in that market ... you have to start someplace,'' Hoglund said at a news conference at GM headquarters. He was referring to the Soviet leader's comment to bankers, industrialists and manufacturers five days earlier in Minneapolis: ``Those who don't want to risk their dollars will remain observers for years to come.'' Under the five-year agreement signed Thursday at Volga Auto Works in Togliatti, 700 miles east of Moscow, GM will supply Volga with engine emission-control systems. The first components would be shipped in 1992 for Volga's Lada cars. The contract marks the first automotive deal between a U.S. and Soviet company since the Great Depression. Ford Motor Co. last year pulled out of joint venture talks with Soviet companies. Chrysler Corp. has no dealings in the Soviet Union. ``It does provide a very good foundation from which start, to learn how to do business there, learn how to find hotel rooms and make telephone calls,'' Hoglund said. World automakers have been looking actively for business in Eastern Europe as a result of recent political and economic changes. GM already has announced vehicle manufacturing deals in Hungary and East Germany. The technology GM will supply Volga will enable the company to meet current or expected worldwide emission standards and export Ladas to pollution-conscious Europe and other markets, Hoglund said. GM systems would make Lada engines cleaner-running and more fuel efficient, Hoglund said, ``and provide massive improvements to driveability.'' GM will supply 100,000 to 150,000 engine-control systems a year to Volga. not a vast number compared with its capability of making more than 5 million systems a year for the U.S. market, he said. GM is to be paid in dollars, assuming Volga can export enough cars to raise the hard currency. ``This as a proportion of our total engine-management system business is a reasonably small risk,'' he said. Components GM will supply include engine-control computer modules, fuel injection systems, ignition parts, wiring and catalytic converters. The first batches will be made by GM in the United States and Europe. The components make up the bulk of the $1 billion deal, Hoglund said. GM also will do engineering work at its European Technical Center in Bascharage, Luxembourg, on how the systems are to be adapted to 1.5 liter and 1.7 liter Lada engines, he said. The company also will train Soviets in the use of the systems, he said. GM and Volga said they also will discuss forming a joint venture to manufacture catalytic converters in the Soviet Union. That could give GM a valuable source of the costly platinum and platinum-based elements used in the converters, materials found chiefly in the Soviet Union and South Africa, Hoglund said. Last February, GM's Allison Gas Turbine Division said it had signed a deal to supply up to 100 helicopter engines to the Soviet Union beginning in 1992. That agreement could be worth $50 million to $100 million during the 1990s, officials have said.

DOC.HEAD: Creditors Reject Drexel Reorganization Proposal
DOC.TEXT: Creditors have spurned Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc.'s bankruptcy reorganization proposal and are pursuing their own plan that would oust the management of the collapsed Wall Street firm. The committee representing Drexel's creditors decided Thursday to reject Drexel's plan for emerging from Chapter 11 protection. The previous day, Drexel proposed to pay creditors 100 cents on the dollar, in part by giving them a share of the company's holdings of junk bonds and other illiquid investments, valued by the firm at about $2 billion. Drexel has asked for a 120-day extension of a deadline set for Wednesday giving it the exclusive right to file a reorganization plan. But the creditors said they would asked U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Howard C. Buschman III for permission to file their own plan. The company filed for bankruptcy protection in February and its brokerage subsidiary, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., followed suit last week. Drexel plans to emerge from bankruptcy court as an operating entity, although it is unclear what shape the firm would take. Creditors said they were dissatisfied with Drexel's proposal that would keep management in control as the company liquidates assets. They also said a plan to repay creditors of most subsidiaries with cash and creditors of the parent company with notes backed by Drexel's assets was unacceptable. Drexel management was ``a problem of consequence but certainly the plan they proposed wasn't in any manner sufficient,'' said Sylvan Schefler, a former Drexel managing director who is representing former employees on the committee. The creditors' proposal would ``substantively consolidate'' the parent company and its major subsidiaries and provide for 100 percent recovery to creditors within three years. It also would create a new board of directors and new management for Drexel. The creditors said debt instruments and common and preferred stock would be created under their plan that could be traded publicly. Under Drexel's proposal, the firm would create a separate business entity out of its investments. Creditors would receive promissory notes valued at the amount of their individual claims and backed by Drexel's assets. The notes would be paid off as Drexel's assets are liquidated. Drexel's attorneys said the firm would manage the portfolio. The creditors panel said its plan also would ask the bankruptcy court to estimate the amount of Drexel's liability in more than 400 lawsuits, which seek damages for the firm's trading activity. A separate litigation trust would be formed to handle potential claims against recipients of some $260 million in bonuses Drexel paid out in the months before it filed for bankruptcy protection, the committee said. Drexel rose to power in the 1980s by dominating the high-yield bond business but failed to recover from a government securities fraud investigation. The firm last year pleaded guilty to six felonies and agreed to pay $650 million to settle insider trading and other allegations.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Gains, Nikkei Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar gained slightly against the Japanese yen today, while stock prices fell moderately. The dollar closed the week at 152.65 yen, up 0.10 yen from Thursday's close. Yuichi Tsuchiko, a dealer with Fuji Bank, said the dollar moved little throughout the day, adding that the market is awaiting a series of economic data to be released next week by both Japan and the United States. On the stock market, the the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues shed 199.21 points, or 0.60 percent, closing the week at 32,993.29 points. The Nikkei index gained 239 points on Thursday. A total of 700 million shares were changed hands on the first section, up from Thursday's 650 million shares. Yozo Asai, an equity analyst with Yamaichi Securities Co., said the key index headed lower over active trading of spot issues in exchange for futures contracts.

DOC.HEAD: Research on Citrus Disease Yields Unexpected Benefit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Scientists studying a disease affecting citrus fruit inadvertently discovered two antibiotics that might be used to treat staph infection among humans, the Agriculture Department says. Staph bacteria became resistant to earlier antibiotics and are beginning to resist the current method of treatment. ``In lab tests, the new potent antibiotics stopped the growth of staph bacteria,'' said Robert A. Baker, a chemist with USDA's Agricultural Research Service. He and retired colleague James Tatum discovered the compounds after fermenting the soil-borne fungus Fusarium solani in vats. ``We weren't really looking for the antibiotics,'' said Baker. ``We were trying to establish a relationship between the soil fungus and a citrus disease.'' He said the antibiotics can be easily isolated from fermentation broths. About 20 percent to 40 percent of all adults intermittently carry staph bacteria on their skin, in their nose or on their clothes, said Dr. Mary Young of Georgetown University Medical Center's division of infectious diseases here. If a carrier gets an abrasion or cut, the bacteria can attack not only the surface skin cells, but also enter the body and cause even more serious problems, she said. ``The staph organism quickly becomes resistant to antibiotics by producing an enzyme that renders the antibiotic ineffective,'' Young said. Baker said he thinks his discovery can be effective against staph, but such testing would have to be done by pharmaceutical companies.

Farmers who were hard hit by continuing severe weather and flooding need not lose their price support benefits, the Agriculture Department says. The department announced Thursday that producers who were prevented from planting a program crop because of weather conditions will be allowed to withdraw from their contracts with the government without the assessment of liquidated damages. They also will be able to receive prevented-planting credit from the program crop, John Stevenson, acting executive vice president of the department's Commodity Credit Corp. The action follows a letter to Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter from eight senators whose states experienced serious flooding this spring. ``In Missouri alone, only about 50 percent of our corn crop has been planted and we are more than two weeks behind normal planting cotton,'' said Sen. Christopher Bond, R-Mo., who spearheaded the senators' efforts. Other states that suffered severely from planting delays are Tennessee, Florida, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Louisiana, Texas and Mississippi. ``Giving our farmers the flexibility to plant as weather permits without jeopardizing their future income form the government programs will help them through yet another difficult time,'' said Bond.

Three new varieties of sweet potatoes with built-in defenses against insects have been developed by Agriculture Department scientists. Most sweet potatoes have skins that naturally provide some resistance to insects and nematodes, but few have the level of resistance of these new varieties, said scientists at the Charleston, S.C., vegetable lab of USDA's Agricultural Research Service. The new sweet potato varieties are called Regal, Southern Delite and Excel. ``Resistance in Excel amounts to 80 percent control of soil insects, 75 percent of the sweet potato flea beetle and 92 percent of the white grub,'' said plant geneticist Alfred Jones. ``That's control you just cannot achieve with the presently recommended chemical treatments.'' Jones said Excel, the newest of the varieties has unsually strong resistance to seven common soil insect pests in field tests: the southern potato wireworm, tobacco wireworm, banded cucumber beetle, spotted cucumber beetle, elongated flea beetle, pale-striped flea beetle and sweet potato flea beetle. On test plots, the new varieties produced more marketable potatoes without insecticide than did Jewel when it was sprayed regularly with insecticide, USDA said.

DOC.HEAD: ``Swampland Into a Dreamland'' Theme Park Opens, With Glitches
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Universal Studios Florida wants its new $630 million theme park to prove it can compete worldwide with entertainment giant Walt Disney World. But first there are some bugs to be worked out. Glitches on a glitzy opening day Thursday at the combination film production center and tourist park closed several of the heavily publicized rides, including ``Kongfrontation,'' featuring King Kong. And long lines formed throughout what Sidney Sheinberg, president of Universal parent MCA Inc., calls his ``swampland into a dreamland'' _ the 444-acre rival to Walt Disney Co.'s dominance among the 13 million annual visitors to central Florida. ``I have never been so mad in my entire life,'' said visitor Denise McDonald of Toronto. ``I'm so ticked off.'' Because of the difficulties, all patrons today were to receive a free pass with no expiration date. But Sheinberg was optimistic. Universal Studios ``is the prototype of the studio and visitor attraction we hope to build in Europe and the Orient and some day in other locations around the globe,'' he told opening-day guests. MCA's Recreation Services Division will be ``a major segment of our future, second to none of our other businesses,'' Sheinberg said. The $3.38-billion entertainment conglomerate has relied on its filmed entertainment and music operations for up to three-fourths of its annual revenue. Up to now, Recreation Services primarily has been involved with MCA's Universal Studio Tour in California and concession operations for Yosemite National Park, industry observers say. Walt Disney Co. operates three Orlando-area theme parks, including the year-old Disney-MGM Studios. Universal Studios Florida is a joint venture of MCA and the Rank Organization PLC of London. Rank's chairman, Sir Patrick Meaney, said France and England are enthusiastic about proposals to build a new theme park in their countries. Sheinberg said he hoped to announce a European site within two or three months. MCA also has indicated interest in building a studio park in Japan with Nippon Steel. But operational problems plagued the much-heralded opening of the Florida park. The six-story tall ``Kongfrontation'' sound stage was closed because the 6-ton steel-and-fur monster could go through its computer-activated terror routines only in stages. A program that melds all the segments into one smooth performance was inoperative, a company spokesman said. A re-creation of a San Francisco earthquake for passengers aboard a subway train operated only partially. Actor Charlton Heston became the main attraction at that site. He was joined by celebrities Michael J. Fox, Bill Cosby, Linda Blair, Jimmy Stewart, Ernest Borgnine, Sissy Spacek and dozens of other stars flown in from Hollywood and New York by chartered plane and train. Robert Wagner, master of ceremonies for the inaugural ceremonies, directed the sealing of a 25-year time capsule of Universal Studios memorabilia. Director Steven Spielberg cut a ribbon before visitors poured in. Universal Studios Florida has a capacity of about 40,000, but officials have said attendance would be held below 20,000, if necessary, for the first few weeks until a shakedown is completed. Universal hopes to attract about 5 million visitors in its first year. Jay Stein, president of Recreation Services, told reporters that ``somewhere between 3 or 4 million people would put us in the black.''

DOC.HEAD: Government, Business To Cooperate on Network
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Private businesses, universities and government agencies are teaming up to develop an advanced computer network that would transmit data 700 times faster than currently possible, The New York Times reported today. The project is expected to be announced later today by the National Science Foundation, based in Washington, D.C. The high-speed computer network would enable the transmission of 1 billion bits of computer data per second via fiber-optic cables currently used for telephone service. Government laboratories at Los Alamos, N.M., and Livermore, Calif., will participate in what would be the first comprehensive effort in the United States to advance the technologically critical area of computer networks, the newspaper said. Dozens of corporations, including IBM, AT&T, MCI, and the regional Bell companies, and such universities as the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the University of Pennsylvania, the California Institute of Technology and the University of California at Berkeley, will participate, it said. The network might be used to link computers and televisions to allow users to manipulate images on screen and transmit them to other users within seconds. Another use would be three-dimensional medical imaging that would allow doctors thousands of miles away to simultaneously analyze lifelike images. Weather forecasting would improve because supercomputers throughout the country would be linked, and business trips could be eliminated in favor of multimedia teleconferencing. Several technological challenges confront the project, such as the need to develop a new class of computers to keep up with the new ``data highways.'' The network will be set in motion with a $15 million grant from the National Science Foundation and the Pentagon, and more than $100 million from the computer and communications companies, The Times reported. Other recent cooperative technological projects have failed because of lack of money or enthusiasm among government and industry. They include U.S. Memories, a joint government-industry project that would have strengthened U.S. semiconductor businesses. In Japan, the government and large corporations have already begun work on developing data highways.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Moving to Reimposing Restraints on Cable Operators
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate is moving toward reimposing price restraints on cable television six years after it decided to lift controls on a younger, less powerful cable TV industry. Faced with rising constituent complaints about prices and service, the Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee on Thursday approved a bill that would allow local governments to control some cable TV prices. ``This is a major victory for the American public,'' Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., said following the 18-1 vote. ``Millions of subscribers are fed up with high prices and `who cares' service. The message is that help is on the way.'' ``We oppose the bill, but we recognize, too, that it is a significant improvement over the original staff draft,'' said John Wolfe, spokesman for the National Cable Television Association. The association was concerned over last-minute changes on how cable must deal with competitive distributors such as satellites and ``wireless cable'' trying to acquire cable programming. James Mooney, president of the association, said his group also was concerned about provisions ordering the Federal Communications Commission to consider limits on the number of cable systems one company may own and the number of channels that may be occupied by a programmer in which the cable operator has an interest. Mooney said that while his group would work to effect a ``reasonable bill'' in Congress, ``We cannot accept legislation that hampers the ability of our industry to continue to grow, and to serve our subscribers.'' Thursday's vote marked the first time lawmakers have moved to restore some of the regulation of the cable industry that Congress lifted in the 1984 Cable Act. The 1984 law ended local rate regulation effective in 1987, and since then cable prices have risen dramatically. Prospects for the bill's passage in the full Senate were unclear. Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher wrote Danforth and committee Chairman Sen. Ernest F. Hollings, D-S.C., that the administration opposed the bill because it emphasized regulation at the expense of trying to improve competition in the cable industry. The cable industry also vowed to fight any attempt to amend the legislation to allow telephone companies into the cable business. Sen. Conrad Burns, R-Mont., agreed to withdraw an amendment Thursday that would have allowed non-Bell telephone companies to own cable TV programming after he was assured the committee would vote on a separate bill before the cable measure goes to the Senate floor. Several cable re-regulation proposals also are pending in the House and may be voted on by the House Energy and Commerce telecommunications subcommittee by the end of the month. The Senate bill, among other things, would: _Allow local governments to regulate prices for a ``basic tier'' of channels including local over-the-air broadcast channels. Ad-supported pay cable channels such as ESPN, CNN and MTV would not be subject to local rate regulation. However, if local authorities or a subscriber complains about rate increases for such ad-supported cable channels, the FCC could establish ``reasonable rates'' if it finds them to be excessive. _Require cable operators not to discriminate against cable programmers such as movie channels with which they have no affiliation. Some cable companies are owned by giant conglomerates that also own movie channels. _Require that all cable programmers make their programming available to owners of home satellite dishes.

DOC.HEAD: First Female Chief Quits Bar Association
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The first woman to serve as executive director of the American Bar Association is resigning amid mixed reviews, ending a sometimes stormy three-year tenure. Jill Wine-Banks, a 47-year-old former Watergate prosecutor, submitted her resignation Thursday to L. Stanley Chauvin Jr., president of the 360,000-member bar. She was hired in August 1987 for the post, which now pays $225,000 a year. ``Although my tenure at the American Bar Association has been an exciting and challenging time, I am now eager and ready to move on to explore several other exciting opportunities awaiting me,'' Wine-Banks wrote. Chauvin credited Wine-Banks with streamlining the bar association's bureaucracy, reforming its budget process and putting into effect the first long-range plan the association ever had. ``And she broadened the association's appeal to women, minorites, younger people,'' Chauvin said. Others welcomed her departure. ``Frankly, the mainstream of the ABA's membership will applaud this change,'' said former ABA president Eugene Thomas. ``The leadership sets the tone and we want someone who sets a different one.'' Wine-Banks drew unwanted attention last year when news stories suggested that she had used her political clout to seek disciplinary charges against a veterinarian for mistreating her Dalmatian, who died after eating a tampon. She said she had the right to complain about Mell Wostoupal, who eventually was suspended for 45 days from practice. At the time, Thomas wrote a letter to bar association leaders calling for Wine-Banks' resignation, saying she ``does not understand the use of power and lacks a sense of decorum and propriety in professional matters.'' At a closed-door meeting last year, the board of governors decided not to fire her. Wine-Banks also was criticized for wasting the association's money when she traveled to and from work in a limousine equipped with a television. Chauvin said she opted for renting the limo because it was cheaper than the cost of a car, which the association had agreed to buy her. She called the charges that she misused her power ``total baloney.'' ``The people I admire and respect felt very positively about my performance and that's what matters to me,'' Wine-Banks said. George Bushnell Jr., head of the bar's House of Delegates, said Wine-Banks was criticized because of ``culture shock.'' ``The ABA has, until the last five years, been an organization of staid and conservative male lawyers,'' Bushnell said. ``Jill was neither staid nor conservative nor male. She caused a lot of discomfort simply because she represented radical change.''

DOC.HEAD: USX Shareholders Reject Icahn's Spinoff Proposal
DOC.TEXT: Takeover strategist Carl C. Icahn said he would continue his battle to increase the value of USX Corp. stock despite shareholders' rejection of his plan to spin off the company's steel division. ``We have a number of options that we're exploring,'' Icahn said Thursday. ``We have no definite plans, but we are going to continue to be very involved as far as what is happening.'' USX said Thursday preliminary results of the vote count show about 57.1 percent of shareholders _ representing about 99.9 million shares _ rejected the proposal, while 42.9 percent _ representing about 75 million shares _ voted for it. Icahn, USX's largest shareholder with a 13.3 percent stake, holds about 33.9 million of the shares cast for the proposal, the company said. USX Chairman Charles A. Corry said the vote meant shareholders have ``decisively supported our policy of well considered and prudent corporate change. ``Management is dedicated to improving the corporation's operations and financial position,'' he said. ``Corporate restructuring will continue as opportunities arise and when it is in the best interest of all of our shareholders.'' Greg Drahuschak, a steel analyst with Butcher & Singer in Pittsburgh, said Icahn's failure to gain the support of even a simple majority signaled sound rejection of his plan. ``The management has been in the driver's seat ever since Icahn stepped in the door and they knew it,'' Drahuschak said. ``Down the line, some of Icahn's ideas are going to happen, but in management's time.'' Icahn explained the loss by saying a few institutional investors sided with USX management even though they agreed with his spinoff plan. Icahn said the institutions told him they received indications from management they would undertake a ``meaningful restructuring'' soon. Shareholders voted on the non-binding proposal at the company's annual meeting in Findlay, Ohio, on May 7, exactly one month before the results were announced. Icahn proposed spinning off at least 80 percent of the company's steel division in the form of a dividend to shareholders, contending the move would boost USX's stock. Icahn contends the relatively weak steel business is depressing USX's stock price and is a potential drag on the company if the economy slows. He wants the company to shift its focus to its energy businesses, including Marathon Oil Co. Icahn said that while campaigning for his proposal, he was ``disappointed by what appeared to be a `whispering campaign' that I might be a seller of the stock, which I believe was another factor in the tally.'' Icahn said he had no intention of selling his stock.

DOC.HEAD: EC Environment Ministers Fix 1997 for Total CFC Elimination
DOC.TEXT: European Community environment ministers Friday agreed to fix 1997 as the deadline for eliminating the manufacture and use within the community of a gas that destroys the earth's protective ozone layer. They also said they would negotiate with other countries to enforce a total international ban on chlorofluorocarbons between by 2000. Although the decision does not yet have the force of law in the 12-nation EC, a spokesman for the EC's executive commission said a law would be adopted by the end of this year. The law would mean that EC industries that use chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs, as a cooling agent or as an aerosol component would have to use alternative technologies. The ministers also decided to try at a meeting on the Montreal Protocol in London later this month to forge an international agreement to end worldwide use of CFCs by the year 2000. The Montreal Protocol, signed by 40 nations in 1987, agrees to cut the use of CFCs in half by 1998. Large developing nations like India, China, Mexico and Brazil have not signed the Protocol, arguing that it would cost them too much money to introduce new technologies. They said they would need $230 million in an international fund in order to develop alternative technologies. Diplomatic sources said the Commission would likely suggest the creation of such a fund at the London meeting. Sources also said the Netherlands, Italy, West Germany and France strongly backed the idea of raising money for the fund by taxing both manufacturers and users of CFCs.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's First Linear Train Railway Route Chosen
DOC.TEXT: A 26.7-mile route near Tokyo has been picked as the site for a $2.3 billion test track for a superfast, magnetically levitated linear train, the Transportation Ministry said Friday. The first-phase of construction on the 343-mph system will start later this year for completion by late 1994. Following a three-year test period, the railway will go into business by the end of 1997, officials said. The test track, linking Sakaigawamura and Akiyamamura in Yamanashi Prefecture northwest of Tokyo, could become part of a Tokyo-Nagoya or a Tokyo-Osaka ``Maglev'' railway, officials added. Nagoya is 169 miles west of Tokyo, while Osaka is 255 miles west of Tokyo. Japan began searching in 1962 for ways to apply superconductive materials, which carry electricity without any resistance, to building a commercial version of a high-speed train that floats above its tracks. In 1988, researchers at the Railway Technical Research Institute set a record of 321 mph _ then a world record _ on a 4-mile test track near Miyazaki City. So far about $302 million has been spent on developing the system, the government said. The train is guided by a magnetic field instead of by rigid rails. The train's powerful superconducting magnets suspend it 4 inches above hundreds of oppositely charged metal coils set in the base of its U-shaped guideway. They also keep the train centered in the guideway and propel it forward, through attraction to electromagnets along the guideway's walls. In the United States, a bill introduced in Congress in April would spend $350 million over three years to develop a magnetic levitation system that would whisk passengers between major U.S. cities in streamlined capsules. The 300-mph U.S. system is aimed at competing with the high-speed transportation systems under development in Japan and Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Embittered Businessmen Say They Are Shut Out of Japan
DOC.TEXT: Embittered U.S. business leaders told Congress Japanese companies copy their designs then, with the help of the Japanese government, push the U.S. firm out of the market. ``We are in a trade war with Japan ... that the Japanese are equipped to win through MITI, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry,'' Edgar Otto, head of Therma Systems Inc. of Plainfield, New Jersey, told the Congressional Task Force on Technology Transfer Thursday. Otto said his company's insulated ``thermal trays'' for serving food hot to hospital patients revolutionized an antiquated serving system in Japan. After five years of success, his Japanese distributor, with the excuse that the U.S. trays were declining in quality, abrubtly switched to an affiliated Japanese supplier it had quietly commissioned to copy his design, Otto said. Nancy H. Chasen of Rockville, Maryland, said after initial success her high technology firm, Fusions Corp., ``collided directly with a massive structural barrier in the form of the Japanese patent system.'' Long waiting periods for patent approval coupled with the practice of quickly making applications public invites behavior that in the United States would be regarded as fraud or piracy, she said. ``Yet the Japanese patent fraud statute has never been enforced and predatory companies feel free to target promising technologies and to file for patents derived from the products of others,'' she added. Ms. Chasen said U.S. negotiators in the year-old Structural Impediment talks with Japan should insist on ``meaningful intellectual property rights provisions,'' persuading the Japanese ``to upgrade their system to the standard of those in the U.S. and Europe.'' Ken W. Cole, vice president of Allied Signal Inc. of Morristown, N.J., said his aerospace and engineering firm filed an unfair practices complaint last March with the U.S. Trade Representative. He said MITI organized and helped fund a 34-corporation group that told Allied to license its property rights for power transformers at a low price ``or else to stay out of Japan.'' He said Allied was told no one would buy from them if they didn't cut the license price. Cole described it as ``a classic case'' of the Japanese government targeting an advanced technology for development by its own industries.

The stock market was little changed today, marking time after the shallow decline of the past three sessions. Gainers held a slight edge on losers in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 457 up, 448 down and 529 unchanged. That posed some questions about how much lower interest rates might go in the immediate future after their sharp drop since late April. Rates were narrowly mixed in the credit markets this morning. Among actively traded blue chips, Boeing lost { to 83]; International Business Machines ] to 120\; Exxon [ to 47{, and Philip Morris [ to 44}. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell .30 to 197.91. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .26 at 363.31. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 14.32 to 2,897.33, stretching its loss over the last three sessions to 37.86 points. DOC.BYLINE: Are Casino Bonds a Crap Shoot or a Good Bet? ^By TOM BUERKLE
DOC.TEXT: For bondholders of Donald Trump's three Atlantic City casinos, the gambling doesn't stop at the tables. News that bankers were in negotiations with the eponymous developer and might seek to force him to sell assets sent prices of the casino bonds plunging early last week. Junk bonds backed by the Taj Mahal, the new billion-dollar resort that some analysts consider the shakiest leg of the Trump empire, lost 10 percent of their face value in one day alone. Although they ended the week well off their lows, the 14 percent bonds still traded at less than 60 percent of face value. At that price, the bonds would yield more than 27 percent to maturity in 1998, assuming the Taj can generate the income to make its payments. The low price reflects investor worries that Trump's casinos could turn out to be another Resorts International Inc. That gaming company, which Trump sold to Merv Griffin in exchange for the Taj, defaulted on its bonds last year. Resorts is seeking court approval of a plan it hopes will take it out of Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Given the experiences of Trump and Resorts, investors may think twice about buying bonds _ usually considered among the safest of investments _ if they are issued by a company dependent on gambling. Some analysts and fund managers see nothing wrong with gaming per se, but they offer plenty of caveats. ``The casino industry as a whole is a relatively stable industry,'' says Robert Nelson, vice president at the rating agency Standard & Poor's Corp. The key to judging investments in the field, Nelson says, is to find casino operators whose properties are well-built, well-managed and located in prime areas. It also helps to be diversified geographically so a slowdown in one market, such as Atlantic City, doesn't threaten the business, he adds. S&P has looked at the field, and it gives only one casino company an investment-grade rating: Circus Circus Enterprises Inc. That company has casinos in the major Nevada markets and later this month plans to open the world's largest hotel, the 4,000-room, castle-shaped Excalibur, in Las Vegas. B. Daniel Evans, president of Fitch Investors Services Inc., says casinos can be real cash cows if operators attract a steady stream of high rollers. ``It's run like an insurance business, except it's on a cash basis like a McDonald's,'' he says. The house odds for a casino are like an insurer's actuarial tables, Evans says. A lucky gambler or card-counter may make a killing, but over time the odds are in the house's favor and the take can be predicted with some precision. Trump's problem, Evans says, is volume. The Taj Mahal represented a big increase in capacity for an Atlantic City market that has shown little growth in recent years. ``If the Taj goes well, it has to go at the expense of other entities,'' including the Trump Plaza and Trump Castle casinos, Evans says. (Indeed, holders of the Plaza and Castle bonds last week sued Trump claiming he short-changed the casinos by steering high rollers to the Taj Mahal.) Ralph Stellmacher, manager of Oppenheimer's High Yield Fund, says he is not too concerned about the fund's holdings of Trump Plaza and Castle bonds because they are secured by mortgages on the properties. ``Unless the bottom falls out from underneath Mr. Trump, they represent good value here,'' he said. The fund also has bought some of Resorts bonds recently, expecting to profit from the company's reorganization, he said. The plan calls for investors to exchange $927 million in Resorts bonds for a 78 percent stake in the company and $430 million in new bonds. It would leave Resorts ``well-capitalized,'' Stellmacher said. Evans said the decline of Trump's bonds show the market's skittishness. The risky economics behind the Taj have been known for months, he said. Only the publicity about Trump's reported problems and supposed fall from the ranks of billionaires has changed, he says. ``To own these bonds, you've got to be patient and be able to take a long-term view,'' Evans says. ``Certainly at these prices, it increases your gambler's odds.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for June 11

DOC.HEAD: Portugal Unveils Plan to Cut Deficit
DOC.TEXT: The government unveiled plans Friday to slash the country's deficit and lower inflation in an effort to prevent Portugal from falling behind as Europe approaches economic and monetary union in 1992. Finance Minister Miguel Beleza said in a statement that an economic adjustment plan would cut current public sector spending and possibly raise some tax rates on purchases. Economists have warned the large public sector deficit has overheated the economy, boosting inflation and damaging Portugal's chances of meeting EC deadlines for monetary integration. According to government forecasts, the 1990 deficit will total about $4.1 billion. Inflation registered 12.9 percent on an annualized basis in April, about double the EC average. Beleza said the program aims to halve the public sector deficit in five years, to 3.5 percent of the gross domestic product, and trim inflation to below 5 percent. Beleza said Portugal must fully participate in the EC's plans for economic and monetary union in order to influence the future shape of the 12-nation trade block. He restated Portugal's commitment to place the escudo in the exchange rate mechanism of the EC's European Monetary System but insisted it wold have to be handled cautiously. The exchange rate mechanism fixes nine EC currencies at a set rate against the European Currency Unit and permits them to fluctuate within fixed limits on either side of that rate. A statement Wednesday by Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva's that Portugal would join the exchange rate mechanism soon prompted a burst of speculative buying of escudos on world markets. Portugal, Greece and Britain are the only EC nations outside the mechanism. The remaining EC countries are Belgium, Denmark, West Germany, France, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, Spain and the Netherlands.

DOC.HEAD: Japan To Use Motorola System as Standard For Digital Cellular Phone
DOC.TEXT: The government has chosen voice-coder technology manufactured by Motorola Inc. as Japan's national standard for new-generation digital cellular phones, officials said Friday. Motorola, which has long fought to increase its foothold in the Japanese market, was selected from among eight Japanese and foreign companies. The decision, the first to allow Motorola technology to be used nationwide, could pave the way for other foreign electronics companies in the Japanese market, said an official at the mobile phone division of the Post and Telecommunications Ministry. The ministry official said the action showed the Japanese market is now open to foreign competitors. ``The result also proved the excellence of the U.S. technology,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Anybody, regardless of whether Japanese or foreign, can sell their products here only if the quality is high. It's up to how much effort each company will make,'' he said. The decision follows an unprecedented agreement in April to attack the underlying economic reasons for the persistent U.S. trade deficit with Japan. Under a trade agreement called the Structural Impediments Initiative, Japan promised to reform the closed-door policies long employed to bar foreign competition. The cellular phone issue had been a major dispute between Japan and the United States, although it was excluded from the list of high-priority trade issues under the 1988 Trade Act. Motorola's CODEC speech coder system _ the technology to digitalize voice sounds and send them to a receiving unit _ proved best among those offered, said Kiyohiro Omatsuzawa, a spokesman for a government-backed Research and Development Center for Radios System. Most existing cellular phone systems are based on analog technology, but digital systems, which allow vastly more callers to use the service at once, are believed to be the wave of the future. Omatsuzawa said major manufacturers will produce trial equipment based on Motorola's design before starting mass production. Such digital cellular phones will be marketed by the end of 1991, replacing the current telephone with analog system, he said. He said other competitors were Sweden's Ericsson and Japan's Toshiba Corp., NTT, NEC Corp., Matsushita Communication Industrial Co., Mitsubishi Electric Co. and Fujitsu. Ministry commissions are studying details of the standards for the new transmission system. Last month, Japan Mobile Communications, also known as IDO, signed a contract with Motorola to supply cellular equipment but only for the corridor between Tokyo and Japan's central city of Nagoya. For the last two years, Motorola has also supplied cellular phone system equipment to DDI, a Japanese company, while selling cellular phones to both DDI and Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp. In June, a bilateral agreement opened the way for the introduction of Motorola's cellular phone technology in the greater Tokyo area, which had been limited to NTT technology.

DOC.HEAD: McDonald's To Post Nutritional Information
DOC.TEXT: McDonald's Corp. said today it will post complete nutritional information _ including fat and sodium levels _ on all of its products at its restaurants by the end of July. ``The more (customers) know about McDonald's food, ... the easier it will be for them to see how McDonald's fits into their balanced diet,'' said Terri Capatosto, spokeswoman for the Oak Brook-based fast-food giant. McDonald's drew fire from anti-cholesterol crusader Phil Sokolof this spring when the Omaha, Neb., industrialist took out full-page ads in newspapers across the country pleading with McDonald's to cut the fat in its hamburgers. Sokolof's ad, under the headline ``The Poisoning of America,'' was attacked by McDonald's as misleading and malicious. Ms. Capatosto said today's announcement had nothing to do with Sokolof's campaign. ``We've been providing complete nutrition information since 1973,'' she said. ``We've provided nutrition information in booklet form since 1986. ``What we're trying to do now is make it as easy as possible for customers to get information before they make a purchase at McDonald's.'' The company will post nutritional information on the ``customer side'' of its more than 8,200 restaurants, she said. Posters will include nutrient values as well as complete ingredient listings, she said. Sokolof was not immediately available for comment.

DOC.TEXT: Texas Instruments Inc. blamed defense department cuts today when announcing a plan to reduce its workforce by about 1,000 employees over the next year. The cuts will come at the company's Defense Systems & Electronics Group, which employs about 22,000 people primarily in the United States, Texas Instruments said. ``As we told stockholders at out annual meeting in April, we expect defense markets to decline for at least the first half of the 1990s as the U.S. Department of Defense adjusts to the changing world political environment,'' said William B. Mitchell, TI executive vice president and DSEG president. The employees affected may be able to bid for other jobs in the company, the company said. All will be given job placement assistance. Texas Instruments develops, manufactures and markets semiconductors, defense electronics systems, software, computer systems and consumer electronics products. The company said it did not expect the workforce reduction to have much effect on its second-quarter financial results. ``Our strategy is to size our defense business to the declining market and then, as the market stabilizes, drive for increased market share,'' Mitchell said. ``TI has a strong technology base and a good mix of programs, which will help the company remain a strong competitor in the defense market of the 1990s.'' The company reported 1989 earnings of $6.5 billion, up from $6.4 billion in the previous year. First quarter revenues were $1.5 billion, down about 4 percent from the same quarter the previous year. DSEG is headquartered in Dallas with plants at Lewisville, McKinney, Abilene, Austin and Sherman in Texas. The group also has plants in Ridgecrest, Calif., and Colorado Springs, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: First Interstate Sells Consumer Lending Business to Transamerica Finance
DOC.TEXT: First Interstate Bancorp said Friday it has agreed to sell a San Diego-based consumer lending operation, Nova Financial Services, to a Transamerica Corp. subsidiary for about $108 million in cash. First Interstate announced in March it intended to sell Nova as part of its strategy to focus on consumer banking and middle-market lending in its 14-state territory. It said the sale of Nova would yield a pretax gain of more than $90 million. Nova makes loans through 71 offices in California, Colorado and Hawaii. It had nearly $430 million in loans outstanding as of March 31. The sale, expected to close in July, is part of a trend toward specialization in financial services. Many banks, for example, have sold their credit card debt processing operations to huge companies specializing in that business. Transamerica Finance Group, the nation's third largest independent finance company based on capital funds, is involved in consumer lending, commercial lending and leasing.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu Says No to U.S. Pressure A Day After Major Trade Breakthrough
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said Friday he would not give in to a key U.S. trade demand that Japan specify targets for boosting its public works spending, a hoped-for wedge in opening the market here to more foreign business. Kaifu's tough stand, coming a day after a stunning trade breakthrough in which Japan accepted U.S. technology as a cellular-phone standard, suggests the government intends to assert itself despite heavy pressure for economic reform. Japan agreed in April to increase public spending as part of an unprecedented pact to reduce its $49 billion trade surplus with the United States by attacking trade barriers. But the prime minister has come under harsh criticism in Parliament for bowing to U.S. demands. Kaifu said Friday that Japan would refuse to specify the ratio of public works spending to its gross national product in a final report on the April agreement, called the Structural Impediments Initiative. ``It was settled in the interim report (in April),'' Kaifu told reporters. ``I don't quite understand why they are raising the issue again.'' Japan did agree then to boost public spending, which would expand the number of projects that U.S. firms could bid on. But the United States had sought a definite annual spending target. Japan, rejecting what it called interference in internal affairs, said it would specify a total figure for the next 10 years and decide yearly spending flexibly to avoid overheating the economy. Kaifu's firm stand was a striking contrast to Thursday's announcement. The government, in what may be the most potent symbol of Japan's recent willingness to open its markets, said it was adopting digital cellular-phone technology made by Motorola, Inc., as a national standard. ``That has been unthinkable during the past 40 years, but it happened,'' said Richard C. Koo, senior economist with the Nomura Research Institute, a think tank connected with Nomura Securities. ``I was stunned.'' Motorola's CODEC speech coder system _ the technology to digitalize voice sounds and send them to a receiving unit _ outperformed six Japanese and one Swedish company to be chosen as the national standard, Japanese officials said. Koo said the significance of the decision is that it came without the overt pressure and acrimonious debate that marked previous trade talks. ``The Japanese side moved before it became an issue,'' he said. ``It really is a first for Japan. ... And it couldn't have been made without decisions at the highest level.'' The Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications chose Motorola over Japanese giants Toshiba Corp., Nippon Telephone and Telegraph, NEC Corp., Matsushita Communication Industrial Co., Mitsubishi Electric Co. and Fujitsu as well as Sweden's Ericsson. A ministry official said the action showed the Japanese market now is open to foreign competitors. ``The result also proved the excellence of the U.S. technology,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Anybody, regardless of whether Japanese or foreign, can sell their products here only if the quality is high. It's up to how much effort each company will make,'' he said. Motorola, which lost its once-signature television business to Japanese competitors and eventually sold its TV division to Matsushita in 1974, long has fought to increase its foothold in the Japanese market with other technologies. The Schaumburg, Ill.-based company first tried to enter Japan's cellular phone market in the mid-1980s and met stiff resistance. In 1987, the United States and Japan agreed that Japan would operate under two cellular standards: NTT's in the busy Tokyo-Nagoya strip and Motorola's in the rest of the country. Phones using one standard did not operate in the other's territory. Last year, under the threat of U.S. trade sanctions on 50 Japanese products, Japan agreed to open its cellular phone market and allow Motorola to compete in the Tokyo area. Japan's cellular phone market is estimated to be worth about $2 billion over the next five years.

DOC.HEAD: Groundbreaking Trade Talks With Japan Already Yielding Results
With AM-Japan-US, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Japan's desire to avoid U.S. trade retaliation and its growing realization that many Japanese consumers want the benefits of an open market have already forced some restructuring of business practices, economists say. While U.S. and Japanese negotiators meet in Tokyo on June 25-26 to hammer out the final report on the groundbreaking Structural Impediments Initiative, the government even now is implementing some of pact's reforms: _Last month, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry told local governments it has shortened the application period for opening large retail stores to 18 months. Under previous law, the application could take up to 10 years, effectively shutting most U.S. retailers out of the market. _On June 6, Japan's Fair Trade Commission issued new anti-monopoly enforcement guidelines that would prohibit manufacturers from pressuring discount shops that sell goods below manufacturer-recommended prices. As part of the SII agreements in April, Japan agreed to deregulate its complex distribution system, including a relaxation on the establishment of large retail stores, to increase enforcement of antitrust laws with tougher penalties for bid-rigging, and to work to lower land prices. The agreements came during a flurry of Japanese concessions aimed at keeping the United States from putting Japan on a retaliatory ``hit list'' of countries with the most offensive trade barriers. ``There is a sea change going on, slowly but surely,'' said Richard C. Koo, senior economist with the Nomura Research Institute. ``It's in the interest of the United States not to press too hard to the point that it invites negative reaction.''

DOC.HEAD: Newsweek Selects New Ad Agency
DOC.TEXT: Newsweek magazine has selected John Emmerling Inc. to develop a major new advertising campaign, the nation's second biggest weekly newsmagazine said Friday. The magazine, which is owned by Washington Post Co., plans to spend more than $1.5 million this year on advertising aimed mainly at those who buy or place ads, officials said. Publisher Peter Eldredge said Emmerling was selected because its president, John Emmerling, is ``one of the best in the business at creating impactful campaigns for magazines.'' The agency created ``The rewards of money'' campaign that Money magazine has used since 1984 and the new ``Power People'' ads for Reader's Digest. It also is the agency for the Magazine Publishers of America, a trade association. Industry executives said officials at Money, which is owned by Time Warner Inc., asked Emmerling to resign as their agency after taking the Newsweek job, and the agency was expected to do so. Time Warner's flagship magazine is Time, Newsweek's foremost rival. A call was placed to Money magazine for comment but the magazine's spokesman was said to be unavailable until next week. Emmerling replaces the Bergman Group as Newsweek's ad agency. Bergman had worked for Newsweek for about 21 months, said Newsweek spokeswoman Mary Manz. Its most recent ads used the line ``We're not afraid to say it.'' Newsweek ranks second among the major newsweeklies with average circulation of 3.18 million in the six months ended Dec. 31, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations. Time had an average circulation of 4.34 million over that period and U.S. News & World Report was third at 2.21 million.

DOC.HEAD: States Asked To Lower Wine Barriers Against Each Other
DOC.TEXT: A national task force on the wine industry says it is time the 50 states stopped treating each other like foreign countries and buried the restless corpse of Prohibition. The 33-state task force is asking the National Conference on State Legislatures to standardize licensing, unify state-federal and interstate regulations, and consider reciprocal shipping agreements between states. ``Complying with (the) staggering array of state and federal regulation tests the stamina of every American wine producer,'' task force chairman Dominic L. Cortese said Friday. The task force's recommendations, released this week after a year of hearings, attempt to deal with barriers created with Prohibition Repeal in 1933, when the states were permitted to retain elements of that 14-year experiment as they saw fit. The task force, noting that 43 states make wine from the grapes produced by 8,000 grape growers, said the wine industry ``is one of the most heavily regulated industries in the United States.'' ``As a grower of grapes, the wine producer is subject to all agricultural regulation. As a producer of wine he or she is subject to alcohol regulation at both the federal and state level,'' the task force report said. ``Each state has its own comprehensive set of regulations. Each state has its own bewildering laws regarding wine, and no two states have the same laws. The federal government has its own comprehensive set of regulations. As a result, wine is one of the few products where interstate sales are spoken of in terms of `import' and `export.''' The trade barriers between the states, said the task force, ``are bad for business and employment. They steal the competitive edge and ultimately are bad for the state and national economies.'' Above all, said the lawmakers, a joint committee should be formed ``with the liquor administrators to review the uniformity of laws among the states and make recommendations regarding policies that could be adopted by all the states.'' Since the 21st amendment told the states they could make their own licensed beverage laws, the federal government would not be involved in much of what the wine task force hopes to accomplish, said Cortese, who also chairman of the state Assembly Select Committee on California Wine Production and Economy. The recommendations are the product of four hearings in Tulsa, Okla.; Santa Fe, New Mex.; Sacramento, Calif., and Boise, Idaho. The general membership of the NCSL, made up of state lawmakers, will vote on them in August in Nashville, Tenn. The U.S. wine industry accounts for 250,000 jobs and $12 billion in retail sales annually, according to the California Wine Institute.
