DOC.HEAD: Medtronic Agrees To Buy Bio-Medicus
DOC.TEXT: Cardiac pacemaker giant Medtronic Inc. said Friday it had agreed to buy Bio-Medicus Inc. for $190 million in a bid to diversify its line of cardiovascular medical devices. The two biotechnology companies settled on a stock swap worth $25 a share to Bio-Medicus shareholders, but the value and stock exchange ratio could change based on fluctuations in Medtronic's stock price. Bio-Medicus' board of directors accepted the bid in a meeting Thursday night, hours after Medtronic sweetened its bid. Medtronic's initial offer would have given Bio-Medicus shareholders a value of about $21.63 a share. The agreement is subject to approval by Bio-Medicus' shareholders and Medtronic's board of directors, reaching a definitive agreement, qualification for pooling of interests accounting treatment and regulatory approvals. In addition, Medtronic could kill the deal if its own stock price falls below $72.50 a share, the companies said. Medtronic fell $3.12{ a share to $76.50 in trading Friday on the New York Stock Exchange. Bio-Medicus rose 50 cents a share to $23.62{ in over-the-counter trading. Eden Prairie-based Bio-Medicus is the world leader in the $30 million market for disposable blood pumps used during open-heart surgery. Fridley-based Medtronic is the largest maker of cardiac pacemakers, but also makes blood oxygenators, other cardivascular products, drug pumps and other products. Medtronic this week reported revenue of $837 million for the year ending April 30. Bio-Medicus generated $31 million in sales in the year ending in March. Bernard McDonagh, an analyst with Piper Jaffray & Hopwood in Minneapolis, said Medtronic's sweetened offer was a reflection of its success selling blood oxygenators, devices used in conjuction with pumps during surgery. Oxygenator sales were up 40 percent in the quarter just ended, McDonagh said. David Duclos, a medical analyst for Minneapolis-based Wessels, Arnold & Henderson, said he thought the acquistion of Bio-Medicus would be good for Medtronic, which has recently been expanding in related medical fields. The exchange ratio tentatively is set at 3.1 shares of Bio-Medicus common stock for each share of Medtronic stock. Above a Medtronic stock price of $92, the ratio will adjust to provide $29.68 in value to Bio-Medicus shareholders. Between $72.50 and $77.50 the ratio will adjust to provide $25 in value to Bio-Medicus shareholders. Below $72.50 the ratio will adjust to provide $25 in value to Bio-Medicus shareholders, but Medtronic can elect to kill the deal instead of adjusting the ratio below $72.50. The final exchange ratio will be based on the 10 trading days prior to the effective date, which will be in approximately 75 to 120 days, the companies said. Medtronic already owns 5.5 percent of Bio-Medicus' 8 million shares.

DOC.HEAD: Poland Has New Airline Connections with the United States
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Poland signed an agreement creating a new airline route to Miami and a new connection to Los Angeles, the official PAP agency reported Friday. A Polish-U.S. agreement on air transport was signed for an indefinite period of time during talks in Warsaw from June 6-8, the agency said. The agreement allows the Polish national carrier LOT to start up regular flights to Miami, making it the third city served by the airline after New York and Chicago, PAP said. LOT also has the right to a connection with Los Angeles as part of cooperation with U.S. air carriers, the agency reported. The United States has the largest population of people of Polish descent outside Poland, and many Polish families have relatives on the other side of the Atlantic.

DOC.HEAD: President Promises to Press for Agriculture in Trade Talks
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told pork producers Friday that his administration continues to push for including all agricultural products in a new international trade accord, despite stiff resistance from Europe. Leaders of the swine industry, meantime, announced an alliance with colleagues in Canada and Mexico to attack barriers to sales of their products overseas and ``provide ammunition'' to U.S. negotiators at the Uruguay Round of talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Farm trade already is big business. The U.S. Department of Agriculture estimates total U.S. agricultural exports will reach approximately $40 billion in the fiscal year that ends in September. Expanding export markets for pork, particularly in Japan, has helped fuel a surge in hog prices, which reached record heights last week in the United States. Pork products accounted for a record $325 million in U.S. farm exports in 1989. But Mike Wehler of Plain, Wis., president of the National Pork Producers Council, said he told Bush that despite a growing export market, ``we are a 6 percent to 7 percent net importer of pork.'' European markets have been tough to crack because of restrictive standards and subsidized competition, pork producers complain. Bush said his administration is working to remove those barriers. ``We're determined to press in the Uruguay Round for all agriculture products to be included,'' Bush told pork producers as a pool of reporters was ushered out of the room at the start of the meeting. ``It's hard to get this, and particularly to get the Europeans to do what they should be doing in giving up markets,'' Bush said, according to the pool report. ``I want you to know at the outset we're not backing off ...'' After the meeting, John Hardin of Danville, Ind., president-elect of the pork council, praised what he said was the president's ``firm commitment to protect agricultural interests in the Uruguay Round of GATT.'' Bush met for just under a half hour with 14 representatives of the pork group following an appearance at a fund-raising breakfast for Gov. Terry Branstad. Wehler said the council, which represents 300,000 pork producers, believes its members are the most efficient producers in the world. But he said U.S. pork is locked out of many markets by unfair competition. ``We seek a level playing field,'' he told reporters at a post-meeting briefing. ``We were pleased that he (Bush) was supportive of those types of comments.'' Wehler said the participation in a North American Alliance for Pork with Canada and Mexico would help Secretary of Agriculture Clayton Yeutter and Trade Representative Carla Hills in their talks aimed at countering subsidies of competing foreign farm products. And even though U.S. and Canadian hog producers have battled in the past on subsidies on Canadian pork products shipped to the United States, Wehler told reporters ``some things we can agree upon.'' He said Bush ``encouraged us to keep the pressure on in the export arena so that the producers of this country have the opportunity to expand their market.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Greenwald's UAL Compensation at Least $9 Million
DOC.TEXT: Former Chrysler Corp. executive Gerald Greenwald will receive at least $9 million to spearhead the proposed employee buyout of UAL Corp., even if the deal falls through, a newspaper reported Friday. Greenwald, who had been in line to succeed Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca before his decision to leave for UAL last week, received a $5 million bonus for signing on with the buyout group, The Wall Street Journal said. He will receive an additional $4 million fee, even if the $4.54 billion buyout does not succeed, the newspaper reported citing unidentified sources. Greenwald was out of the vice chairman's office at Chrysler until Monday and not available for comment, his secretary said. UAL, parent company of United Airlines, referred all calls to the United Employees Acquisition Corp., an entity formed by the airline's unions to handle the buyout. Steven Matthews, a spokesman in New York for the employees' group, said, ``We would have no comment at all on that.'' The newspaper said that the five-year deal negotiated by Greenwald included a $1.2 million annual salary, which began the day the contract was signed. If the buyout is successful, the 54-year-old Greenwald, who would become chairman and chief executive officer of UAL and United Airlines, will receive an additional $1.2 million ``success fee'' in the first year of his contract, the newspaper said. Unidentified union officials cited by the newspaper said current Chairman Stephen M. Wolf received a $6.7 million bonus to take the job three years ago. The employees, led by the Air Line Pilots Association, the Machinists union and the Association of Flight Attendants, have agreed to substantial wage concessions as part of the buyout. They are seeking to acquire backing for the deal before a financing deadline of Aug. 9 set by UAL's board. Matthews said Greenwald is heading talks with potential financial backers for the buyout, in addition to negotiating with United's non-union employees. ``We're working on a fairly tight schedule,'' Matthews said. The group also has retained the executive search firm of Spencer Stuart Associates to recommend outside directors for the 15-member board.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Finish Mixed; Selloff in Gasoline Called a Correction
DOC.TEXT: Wholesale gasoline prices tumbled Friday while home heating oil and crude finished moderately higher. Trading volume was light to moderate. Energy analysts said futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange bobbed up early in the session on rumors of a possible OPEC meeting to address the recent slump in oil prices. But the buying subsided when there was no confirmation that the oil cartel would meet. Crude and heating oil managed to end the day with minor gains due to short covering, which is buying to compensate for previous sales. The contract for July delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, closed at $16.78 a 42-gallon barrel, adding 11 cents. The contract lost 25 cents Thursday. Later months also gains. The July contract for home heating oil rose 0.31 cent to 47.21 cents a gallon after losing 0.41 cent on Thursday. Subsequent months settled unchanged to moderately higher. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for July delivery dropped 1.02 cents to 56.59 cents a gallon, expanding Thursday's loss of 0.75 cent. Most of the selling was confined to the July and August contracts; later months ended modestly higher. John H. O'Connell, senior energy analyst at Refco Inc., said the decline in gasoline came in reaction to bearish industry statistics released earlier this week showing a buildup in oil stocks. He said gasoline prices had not responded to the earlier news as fully as other energy futures so Friday's selling represented a correction to previous market activity. A news report that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries might convene a special session initially encouraged buying. But the report, which O'Connell said was based on comments by a South American OPEC official, came to be viewed with skepticism by energy traders. In natural gas trading, prices ended mixed. The July contract closed marginally higher at $1.575 per 1,000 cubic feet compared to $1.573 on Thursday. Later contracts settled slightly lower to slightly higher.

DOC.HEAD: Gold, Dollar Higher
DOC.TEXT: Gold prices finished a sluggish week Friday on an upbeat note and the dollar finished the day stronger against major currencies. Gold, which has been increasingly shunned by investors may have hit bottom on Thursday when the price in London reached a four-year low at $351.50 in morning trading, one analyst said. ``I think if the market was going to break $350 it would have happened this week,'' Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst at PaineWebber Inc. said. ``It was the perfect climate for the market to collapse and it didn't,'' he said referring to reports Thursday of Middle East selling. Many traders fear Saudi Arabia has been selling large amounts of gold lately, leading to at least two sharp drops in recent weeks. Bullion for current delivery rose $1.10 to $355.70 a troy ounce on the New York Commodity Exchange. Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $355.00 a troy ounce, up $1.40 from late Thursday. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $354.50 a troy ounce from $354.15 late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $354 from $353 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 39 cents an ounce to 356.06 per ounce. Silver bullion was quoted in London at $5.02 an ounce, up from $5.01 bid late Thursday. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, silver for current delivery slipped 0.6 cent to close at $5.007 a troy ounce. The dollar was stronger as investors anticipated next week's economic reports. Many apparently felt the Consumer Price Index and Producer Price Index could show stronger inflation, which could lead to higher interest rates, said Robert Hatcher, corporate trader at Barclay's Bank PLC in New York. The dollar began its trading day in Tokyo, rising 0.10 yen to a closing 152.65 Japanese yen. Later, in London, it also was quoted higher at 153.48 yen, and in New York, it rose to 153.49 yen from 152.55 late Thursday. In London, the dollar rose against the British pound, which was quoted at $1.6843, compared with $1.6880 late Thursday. In New York the pound also dropped against the dollar, falling to $1.6840 from $1.6895 on Thursday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late rates, included: 1.6975 West German marks, up from 1.6930; 1.4495 Swiss francs, up from 1.4445; 5.7145 French francs, up from 5.7035; 1,248.00 Italian lire, up from 1,244.75 and 1.1743 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16975. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's levels, included: 1.6973 West German marks, up from 1.6913; 1.4480 Swiss francs, up from 1.4385; 5.7155 French francs, up from 5.6993; 1.9088 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9028; 1,248.50 Italian lire, up from 1,244.25; and 1.1743 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1678.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Instruments, General Dynamics Announce Layoffs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for AM-TI Layoffs item on AM-Business News Digest.
DOC.TEXT: Texas Instruments Inc. and General Dynamics Corp., a pair of major defense contractors, plan to lay off almost 2,000 people in Texas because of anticipated military budget cutbacks. Texas Instruments said Friday it will trim its Defense Systems & Electronics Group by about 1,000 employees in the next year. The announcement came one day after General Dynamics announced planned cuts of 500 to 800 people over the next few months at its Fort Worth division. Both companies said their decisions were influenced by the shrinking U.S. defense dollar. Improved relations between the United States and the Soviet Union have resulted in a series of arms reductions, and lawmakers are showing an increasing reluctance to keep purchasing new military hardware. ``It's unfortunate that our industry and employees must bear the brunt of these changes; it is the price we in this industry will pay for enhanced world peace and stability,'' said Charles A. Anderson, a division vice president and general manager for General Dynamics. William B. Mitchell, DSEG president for Texas Instruments, said his company doesn't expect things to get better soon. ``As we told stockholders at our annual meeting in April, we expect defense markets to decline for at least the first half of the 1990s as the U.S. Department of Defense adjusts to the changing world political environment,'' Mitchell said. TI employs about 22,000 people at its DSEG Texas plants in Abilene, Austin, Lewisville, McKinney and Sherman, and at facilities in Ridgecrest, Calif., and Colorado Springs, Colo. The TI cuts are the third in two years. Last year, 230 people were laid off, then 240 more were cut earlier this year. Others also took advantage of an early retirement program aimed at decreasing staff numbers, but TI spokeswoman Terri West said the number of DSEG employees involved was not available. Some of the TI employees may be given job elsewhere in the Dallas-based company that manufactures and markets semiconductors, defense electronics systems, software, computer systems and consumer electronics products. ``We'll do several things to try to lessen the impact,'' Ms. West said. ``That includes severance pay, extended insurance protection and outplacement assistance.'' Anderson said General Dynamics employees losing their jobs will be notified in the coming weeks. The cutback in Fort Worth will include both salaried and hourly employees, he said. Anderson had told division employees in April to expect a ``gradual reduction'' in employment this year as production of the F-16, the U.S. Air Force's front-line fighter and a top international arms export, slows down. The division general manager also said he expected that the division's work force would be no larger than 25,000 by the mid-1990s, meaning that about 7,000 jobs would be cut. So far this year, about 500 employees have been cut as work schedules on the F-16 and the next generation Advanced Tactical Fighter for the U.S. Air Force and the A-12 attack plane changed. More cutbacks are coming, Anderson said.

DOC.HEAD: McDonald's Says It Will Post Nutritional Information
DOC.TEXT: McDonald's Corp. said Friday it would post complete nutritional information _ including fat and sodium levels _ on all of its products at its restaurants this summer. Terri Capatosto, a spokeswoman for the nation's biggest fast-food restaurant chain, said the move was intended as a convenience for McDonald's customers, not as a response to a recent ad campaign attacking the nutritional value of the company's food. ``We've been providing complete nutrition information since 1973,'' she said. ``We've provided nutrition information in booklet form since 1986. ``What we're trying to do now is make it as easy as possible for customers to get information before they make a purchase at McDonald's.'' But Omaha industrialist Phil Sokolof, who has used advertising and the news media to pressure a number of food companies to reduce or remove saturated fats from their products, criticized the move was ``window dressing.'' Sokolof _ who blames a bad diet for a heart attack he suffered years ago _ took out full-page ads in newspapers across the country on April 4, calling on McDonald's to cut the amount of saturated fat on its menu. McDonald's said Sokolof's ad _ which was headlined ``The Poisoning of America'' _ was malicious and contained inaccurate and misleading information. The company will post nutritional information posters on the ``customer side'' of its more than 8,200 restaurants, Capatosto said. The posters will include nutrient values and complete ingredient listings, she said. She said McDonald's wants to ensure that its customers receive the information ``ahead of time so that they can make more informed choices.'' But Sokolof complained that what needed to be done was reduce the saturated fat content of McDonald's food. ``McDonald's affects the lives of millions of people a day,'' he said. ``One simple step _ eliminating beef tallow from their french fries _ could reduce the incidence of heart attacks in our country.'' In recent years, McDonalds has developed a menu that includes salads, 2 percent milk and bran muffins. It has said it is experimenting with using pure vegetable oil _ rather than the current beef shortening-vegetable oil mixture _ for frying its french fries and hash browns.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market closed out its first losing week since April with a broad decline Friday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 34.95 to 2,862.38, finishing the week with a net loss of 38.59 points. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 458 up, 1,010 down and 523 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 142.60 million shares, against 160.42 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 176.30 million shares. Over the five preceding weeks the Dow Jones industrials had rolled up an advance of 255.92 points. Analysts said the enthusiasm built up in the market's advance to record highs as recently as Monday began to cool down as prices pulled back a bit in the last few days. The upbeat mood was tempered by indications from the Federal Reserve that it wasn't ready to adopt a more stimulative credit policy on the basis of a few months of sluggish economic growth. That posed some questions about how much lower interest rates might go in the immediate future after their sharp drop since late April. Rates edged upward in the credit markets Friday, putting yields on long-term Treasury bonds in the 8.44 percent-8.47 percent range. Financial stocks were mostly lower as enthusiasm about the interest-rate outlook waned. In the money-center bank group, Bankamerica dropped { to 32; Citicorp [ to 24; Manufacturers Hanover ~ to 36|; J.P. Morgan | to 37}, and Chemical Banking [ to 28]. Mortgage issues also slipped. Federal Home Loan Mortgage fell 1[ to 78{ and Federal National Mortgage { to 42[. Among actively traded blue chips, Eastman Kodak lost } to 41}; International Business Machines 1~ to 118}; Coca-Cola { to 44\; General Electric } to 68{, and Philip Morris | to 44\. Conagra climbed 1\ to 33\ following word of the company's agreement to acquire Beatrice Co. and its large stable of well-known food brands from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. The Gap Inc. fell 2] to 56[ on top of a 4]-point drop Thursday after analysts expressed disappointment with retail apparel sales figures for May. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $30.03 billion, or 1.50 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 2.16 to 196.05. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 5.30 to 417.43, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 4.44 at 358.71. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market slumped 3.22 to 460.87. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 361.17, down 2.40.

DOC.HEAD: Cocoa Futures Prices Plunge
DOC.TEXT: Cocoa futures prices were sharply lower Friday on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange amid widespread stop-loss selling. On other markets, grain and soybeans were lower; livestock and pork futures mixed; precious metals were mixed and energy futures were higher. The cocoa futures market opened moderately lower, following the London market's lead, but regained some ground before plunging due to commission house selling. Judith Ganes, an analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York, said a number of factors contributed to the market's selloff. She said the market rose recently because of concerns about the political climate in the Ivory Coast, a major producer of cocoa. She said the unstable conditions in that country have eased, largely removing market concerns. Also weighing on cocoa futures was the settlement of the Brazilian dock workers strike. Ms. Ganes noted that although the strike had not prompted a rally in the market, the settlement allowed the shipment of cocoa and gave those wanting to sell a reason to do so. Cocoa settled $65 to $76 lower with the contract for delivery in July at $1,235 a ton. Grain and soybean futures were lower in heavy trading the Chicago Board of Trade. Weather remains the key force driving the market, as forecasts call for dry conditions for the corn and soybean crop producing areas into next week with a return of wet conditions late in the week, said Steve Freed, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. Corn prices were pushed lower by profit-taking, with the market ignoring planting delays and the possibility of yield losses from late planting of fields. Soybean futures were pushed lower by pre-weekend liquidation and professional selling. Soybeans also came under pressure from a concern that additional acres will be planted in areas of the Midwest where corn planting has been delayed. Soybeans can be planted in the southern Midwest into the first week of July because they mature faster than corn. Wheat fell as traders shrugged off reports of disease ravaging soft red winter wheat crops in the lower Midwest. Wheat was 4 cents lower to } cent higher July at $3.30} a bushel; corn was 3 cents lower to a \ cent higher with July at $2.84} a bushel; oats were 1 cent lower to 1 cent higher with July at $1.48\ a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 5 cents lower with July at $6 a bushel. Energy futures were mostly higher in trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Crude oil prices climbed on rumors that OPEC ministers will hold an emergency meeting to discuss violations of production quotas, said Jerry Samuels, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in New York. Short covering in advance of the weekend also contributed to the modest gains in crude oil. Short covering occurs when traders buy contracts so that they can fulfill earlier promises to sell. Gasoline futures were also higher, with trading shrugging off concerns over the huge stocks of gasoline reported earlier in the week, analysts said. West Texas Intermediate crude oil was 11 cents to 18 cents higher with July at $16.78 a barrel; heating oil was .10 cent to .31 cent higher with July at 47.21 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.02 cents lower to .35 cent higher with July at 56.59 cents a gallon. Precious metals futures were mixed on New York's Commodity Exchange. Gold was $1.10 to $1.40 higher with June at $355.70 a troy ounce; silver was .60 cent to .70 cent lower with June at $5.007 a troy ounce. Livestock futures were higher and pork mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .02 cent to .52 cent higher with June at 75.60 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .40 cent higher with August at 85.35 cents a pound; hogs were .67 cent lower to .15 cent higher with June at 64.15 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .35 cent to .83 cent higher with July at 67.75 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Cypress Semiconductor Signs Unique Pact With Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: Cypress Semiconductor Corp. said Friday it plans to make computer chips and other electronic devices for the Soviet Union in a unique licensing agreement that will give the company Soviet chip-making technologies. Cypress signed a letter of intent with the International Center for Informatics and Electronics of Moscow, which has officials touring the Silicon Valley as part of a 10-day ``Silicon Summit.'' T.J. Rodgers, president and chief executive officer of Cypress, said the deal, which is still being developed, will be a good technological marriage. The Soviets will provide semiconductor designs that Cypress would modify for production in its manufacturing plants for sale to U.S. customers. The Soviet chips involved are used for high-definition television and sound and audio processing. Cypress does not currently make any products covered under the agreement and views this as an opportunity to expand. Rodgers estimated it would be at least a year before Cypress produces a sample chip from a Soviet design, but that Soviet-designed chips could generate as much as $60 million per year in sales for Cypress two or three years from now. Cypress revenues from all sources were $199.3 million last year. The Soviets' main interest in the deal is not to gain access to U.S. products, but to work with American companies to commercialize and manufacture technology products that the Soviets are designing. The chips in the proposed Cypress deal are being designed by the Soviet International Center for Informatics and Electronics, a coalition of about 40 Soviet science and engineering organizations set up to remove advanced-technology development from government control. The Soviets have made advances in a semiconductor technology known as submicron lithography, which can be used to produce extremely dense silicon chips that could handle large volumes of data quickly. The Soviets also developed advanced compounds to coat magnetic disks in disk drives to make them faster, more reliable and longer-lasting than U.S.-designed disk drives. But while the Soviets have developed these new technologies in the laboratories, members of the delegation said they lack the manufacturing capability to bring them to market as commercial products. ``Our activity in research and development and microelectroncs have produced new technologies and new technology equipment,'' said Kamil Valiev, director of the Soviet Institute of Physics and Technology. ``We have proposed to come to U.S. companies and have them make commercial products from our technology. And we hope this summit is the first step along the way.'' Rodgers and key Cypress personnel will travel to Zelenograd, considered the Silicon Valley of the Soviet Union, in July to discuss the specific technologies and products under consideration. Under the terms of the agreement, Cypress would acquire the advanced semiconductor fabrication technologies developed by the Soviets and a license to manufacture some semiconductor products designed by the Soviets. In return, Cypress would pay royalties to the Soviet Union, which are still being negotiated. Cypress plans to deposit $100,000 in an escrow account from which the Soviets can start to withdraw royalties, Rodgers said. The Soviets signed the letter of intent after touring the Cypress plant in San Jose Thursday in high style. The visitors arrived in stretch limousines and were welcomed by a brass band, cheering employees and American and Soviet flags flapping in the wind. ``As soon as we stepped into the plant and put on our (protective white) suits, I realized we had opened doors here and that we would sign an agreement today,'' Nicolai Kleschev, general director of the Soviet's International Informatics Center, said through an interpreter. The products that are being considered for manufacture under the deal include chips for high definition television, digital signal processing, telecommunications and audio and video products. Cypress, a chip design, development and manufacture company, currently doesn't make any of those products. ``This is a tremendous opportunity for Cypress,'' Rodgers said. ``Our philosophy is to grow through the addition of new products and product lines. This agreement fits our needs perfectly. It also meets the Soviets' needs. They require high quality process technology, international marketing capabilities and support, as well as negotiable currency _ all things we can provide.'' Cypress makes programmable logic devices, memory programs and other computer products.

DOC.HEAD: Poland Gets $250 Million Loan for Natural Gas
DOC.TEXT: The World Bank on Thursday announced a $250 million loan to help Poland develop natural gas. The non-communist government in Poland has received $781 million in loans from the bank, the biggest source of aid to Third World and east European countries. The loan for natural gas is repayable in 15 years. For the first five years Poland must pay only interest, at a varying rate now 7.75 percent annually. The loan will be supplemented by another $60 million from the European Development Bank, part of the 12-nation European Community.

DOC.HEAD: Production Goes Up This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 236,497 cars and light trucks this week, up from last week's 198,964, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is higher than the same week a year ago, in which 228,458 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 143,904 cars this week, compared with 121,509 a week ago and 140,501 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 92,593, compared with last week's 77,455 and last year's 87,957. Canadian automakers were to build 26,640 cars this week, down from 26,998 a week ago and up from last year's 18,922. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 20,477, compared with 20,100 a week ago and 18,266 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: John Hancock Agrees To Pay Forbes Insurance Claim
DOC.TEXT: Insurance policies designed to protect Malcolm Forbes' estate from the taxman may have proved to be the bon vivant businessman's last capitalist tool. Insurance companies that originally balked at paying millions of dollars in claims to the estate have paid up, a Forbes official said Friday. The late publisher of the business magazine dubbed ``capitalist tool'' reportedly took out millions of dollars in life insurance with different companies in the years preceding his death in February at age 70. Forbes died of an apparent heart attack at Timberfield, his Far Hills, N.J., mansion. But John Hancock Mutual Insurance Company last month withheld payment on a multimillion-dollar policy pending an investigation into the claim. Hancock officials had said only that an investigation was being conducted, but published reports indicated medical information provided by Forbes was being examined. But Hancock spokesman Richard Bevilacqua said the company had completed its ``routine'' investigation and paid the claim. Forbes spokesman Don Garson said all pending insurance claims have been paid to the Forbes estate. Neither spokesman would discuss the amounts of money involved, but Garson said that the previously reported figure of $46 million in total insurance claims was too low. ``Forbes is an exceptionally valuable property. That ($46 million) seems like a drop in the bucket,'' he said. Garson said Forbes often commented that the only way to pass on an estate worth any money when he died was to have large amounts of life insurance. Estimates of Forbes' estate range from $400 million to $1 billion. The estate would be taxed in the 55 percent brackets, according to tax specialists. But much of Forbes' estate, such as the magazine and his art collection, could not go on the auction block to pay the government. Forbes' apparent solution was to take out insurance polices, some within the last two years, to pay the necessary cash. Garson said no discrepancies were discovered in the medical information Forbes provided to Hancock. ``I can assure you all investigations have been completed. There were no irregularities ... and the claims have all been paid,'' he said. Bevilacqua would not discuss the details of the agreement between Hancock and the Forbes estate, which he said was concluded Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Down Slightly
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices dipped in light trading Friday as many traders stayed on the sidelines awaiting several government reports scheduled to be released next week. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond fell 5-32 point, or about $1.56 per $1,000 face amount, while its yield, which rises when prices fall, rose to 8.44 percent from late Thursday's 8.42 percent. Analysts said bond traders were just marking time as they waited for the figures that will provide clues on the direction of the economy and perhaps give some insight into the Federal Reserve's credit policy. The Labor Department will issue wholesale and consumer price figures for May, while the Commerce Department will announce retail sales figures for May and trade deficit reports for the first quarter and for April. If the figures indicate a slowing of the economy and inflation, bond traders will be looking for some sign from the Fed that it will relax credit, allowing interest rates to decline and bond prices to rise. Some analysts say favorable figures could reignite the price surge of June 1, when the Labor Department announced employment figures that signaled a weakening of the economy. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments were unchanged to 1-16 point lower, intermediate maturities were 1-32 point to 1-16 point lower and long-term issues ranged from [ point to 5-32 point lower, according to Telerate Inc., the financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 0.94 to 1,159.67. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds was unchanged at 91}. The average yield to maturity remained at 7.5 percent. Yields on three-month Treasury bills were unchanged at 7.95 percent as the discount held steady at 7.70 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 8.03 percent as the discount advanced 4 basis points to 7.63 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 8.06 percent as the discount picked up 1 basis point to reach 7.51 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 3-16 percent, down from 8\ percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Calls Back First Hard-Core Pilot Strikers
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines has for the first time recalled pilots who stayed off the job until the end of the Air Line Pilots Assocation strike, the company said Friday. They will be among 90 pilots called back to handle increased summer schedules and a planned expansion of Atlanta routes, said airline spokeswoman Karen Ceremsak. Most of the 90 had volunteered to work before the end of the ALPA strike in November, but the group also included some pilots who refused to sign up until the eight-month job action officially ended. Ms. Ceremsak said the recalls were unrelated to ongoing negotiations with ALPA in Washington and were instead based on the airline's needs. Eastern ALPA spokesman E.J. Breen said the union had mixed emotions about the action. ``It's terrific _ but we're disappointed that in seeking labor peace, the management has screwed it up,'' Breen said. The union thought it had an agreement that pilots would be called back by seniority, but instead Eastern went outside the seniority lists, he said. ``They have only done it because they need us, and they've done it in a confrontational way,'' Breen said. But he acknowledged there have been other positive signs. On Friday, Eastern withdrew several New York court suits challenging ALPA's right to represent the pilots. Ms. Ceremsak said another reason Eastern needs pilots is that many currently flying to South America will need to be retrained when those routes are turned over to American Airlines this summer. No pilots will be laid off due to that change, she said. The returning pilots will not begin flying immediately. They must be retrained under both airline and Federal Aviation Administration rules and will have to pass physical exams. Before the recall, Eastern had 1,775 pilots flying about 800 flights a day, she said. The pilots aren't the first hard-core strikers to return. Ms. Ceremsak said that among 440 flight attendants recalled since Thanksgiving are employees who remained on strike until their union agreed to return to work. The recalls do not affect the Machinists union, whose members struck March 4, 1989, amid a contract impasse and rising hostilities with Frank Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern's parent Texas Air Corp. The other two unions walked out in sympathy. Control of the airline was taken away from Lorenzo in April when a bankruptcy court judge appointed current trustee Martin Shugrue because creditors had lost confidence in the old management. Shugrue and the Machinists union have established a dialogue, but there have been no details on their talks.

DOC.HEAD: Knoxville Newspapers Dissolve Joint Operating Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Knoxville's morning and afternoon newspapers, locked in a legal battle since January, agreed Friday to dissolve their joint operating agreement by the end of December 1991. Owners of The Knoxville News-Sentinel and The Knoxville Journal announced they had reached an agreement in principle to end their 4-year-old JOA. ``The parties expect to sign a definitive agreement by June 21, 1990, following notice to the Department of Justice,'' their statement said. After the JOA ends, ``The Journal intends to publish separately and in competition with The News-Sentinel,'' the statement said. The News-Sentinel is owned by The E.W. Scripps Co. of Cincinnati. The morning paper has a daily circulation of 101,000 and a Sunday circulation of 169,000. The Journal is owned by Persis Corp. of Honolulu, Hawaii. The afternoon paper publishes Monday through Saturday with a circulation of 40,000. Under the JOA, The News-Sentinel provides sales, production and distribution for The Journal. Editorial departments of the two newspapers are separate. The statement did not say where The Journal will publish after 1991. As part of the termination arrangement, The News-Sentinel will pay Persis $40 million in two $20 million installments. The money will be in lieu of payments The Journal would have received from Dec. 31, 1991, through the scheduled end of the JOA on Dec. 31, 2005. The termination arrangement also will end litigation brought by The News-Sentinel in Knox County Chancery Court against Persis in January. The lawsuit alleged Persis violated the JOA terms when the Hawaii company purchased The (Maryville) Daily Times in neighboring Blount County in December. Journal editor and publisher Gerald Garcia also was made the president and publisher of The Daily Times. The Daily Times publishes in the afternoon with a circulation of 21,000. However, The News-Sentinel, which recently began a zoned edition in Maryville, considered The Daily Times a direct competitor. The lawsuit contended that with Garcia in the dual roles, The Daily Times would have access to The News-Sentinel's confidential business information and trade secrets. ``We are pleased with the agreement,'' said Thurston Twigg-Smith, president and chief executive of Persis. ``Once we concluded that it was unlikely that the JOA would be extended beyond 2005, we wanted to begin separate publication at a time when The Journal was a strong and vital part of the Knoxville community,'' he said. The News-Sentinel's agreement to pay Persis $40 million will result in a charge to E.W. Scripp's second-quarter 1990 net income of about $23 million, or 30 cents a share. ``This one-time payment is less than the expected amount The News-Sentinel would have paid in distributions to The Journal had joint operations continued through 2005,'' Scripps president and chief executive Lawrence A. Leser said. ``We look forward to hardy economic competition in addition to the fierce editorial competition that has existed between the two newspapers for many years,'' Leser said. Until the termination in 1991, The News-Sentinel will continue to act as agent on certain business matters for The Journal under a special interim agreement that provides for The Journal's ``reasonable prospects for ongoing economic viability.''

Ames Department Stores Inc., trying to jettison unprofitable operations, announced plans to close 221 stores and lay off about 17,500 employees as it struggles to emerge from bankruptcy protection. The closings, which represent nearly a third of Ames' 679 stores nationwide, must be approved by the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in New York, where the nation's fourth largest retailer filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankrutpcy laws on April 25. If the court approves, the company said Friday it plans to close the stores in August or September after conducting inventory liquidation sales.

Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said he would not give in to a key U.S. trade demand that Japan specify targets for boosting its public works spending, a hoped-for wedge in opening the market here to more foreign business. Kaifu's tough stand Friday, coming a day after a trade breakthrough in which Japan accepted U.S. technology as a cellular-phone standard, suggests the government intends to assert itself despite heavy pressure for economic reform. Japan agreed in April to increase public spending as part of an unprecedented pact to reduce its $49 billion trade surplus with the United States by attacking trade barriers. The prime minister has come under harsh criticism in Parliament for bowing to U.S. demands.

McDonald's Corp. said it would post complete nutritional information _ including fat and sodium levels _ on all of its products at its restaurants this summer. Terri Capatosto, a spokeswoman for the nation's biggest fast-food restaurant chain, said Friday the move was intended as a convenience for McDonald's customers, not as a response to a recent ad campaign attacking the nutritional value of the company's food.

Eastern Airlines has for the first time recalled pilots who stayed off the job until the end of the Air Line Pilots Assocation strike, the company said. They will be among 90 pilots called back to handle increased summer schedules and a planned expansion of Atlanta routes, airline spokeswoman Karen Ceremsak said Friday.

Texas Instruments Inc. and General Dynamics Corp., a pair of major defense contractors, plan to lay off almost 2,000 people in Texas because of anticipated military budget cutbacks. Texas Instruments said Friday it will trim its Defense Systems & Electronics Group by about 1,000 employees in the next year. The announcement came one day after General Dynamics announced planned cuts of 500 to 800 people over the next few months at its Fort Worth division.

Cardiac pacemaker giant Medtronic Inc. agreed to buy Bio-Medicus Inc. for $190 million in a bid to diversify its line of cardiovascular medical devices. The two biotechnology companies settled Friday on a stock swap worth $25 a share to Bio-Medicus shareholders, but the value and stock exchange ratio could change based on fluctuations in Medtronic's stock price.

A Texas businessman stung in a federal crackdown on child labor law violations cautioned Congress against letting ``governmental paternalism'' ruin worthwhile work opportunities for youngsters. Donald Farrell said Friday that jobs like those he provides give youngsters, especially those from unstable homes, a chance to earn money, experience and self-respect. His Dallas business is under investigation for allegedly letting nearly 300 children illegally sell newspaper subscriptions at night.

President Bush told pork producers that his administration continues to push for including all agricultural products in a new international trade accord, despite stiff resistance from Europe. Also Friday, leaders of the swine industry announced an alliance with colleagues in Canada and Mexico to attack barriers to sales of their products overseas and ``provide ammunition'' to U.S. negotiators at the Uruguay Round of talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

Cypress Semiconductor Corp. said it plans to make computer chips and other electronic devices for the Soviet Union in a unique licensing agreement that will give the company Soviet chip-making technologies. Cypress said Friday it signed a letter of intent with the International Center for Informatics and Electronics of Moscow, which has officials touring the Silicon Valley as part of a 10-day ``Silicon Summit.''

The stock market closed out its first losing week since April with a broad decline Friday. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 34.95 to 2,862.38, finishing the week with a net loss of 38.59 points. Gold prices finished a sluggish week higher and the dollar was stronger against major currencies. Bond prices dipped in light trading. Cocoa futures prices were sharply lower; grain and soybeans were lower; livestock and pork futures mixed; precious metals were mixed and energy futures were higher.
